description:
Manna is my new go-to Korean restaurant in the city! Highly recommend for serious Korean food fans. 

1. High quality ban chan - fish cakes are bomb.

2. Very efficient service.

3 Their soon du bu (tofu soup) is on point. This is my favorite Korean dish and always order it at every Korean restaurant I go to. After trying Manna's soon du bu, I'm happy to say it is definitely one of the best in the Bay Area (the other one I recommend is tofu house in Palo Alto). The flavors are very authentic, and it's just the right amount of salt and spice (some places over do the salt). Get medium spice and with beef.

4 Other things to get include seafood pancake, spicy wings, and dol sot bibimbap. 

There is usually a wait on weekends, so would recommend going during the week. Your party must be present to be seated.
author: Lizzie F.

description:
Bibimbap!! I went to Manna a few times before I visited South Korea years ago and had bibimbap their. Maybe it was the places we went, but Manna won hands down. Unlike other places in SF, Manna seems to put the right blend of veggies, a delicious crispy bottom and tasty chicken ( yes I get chicken in mine). We also love their tofu soup, which I have them make with water and chicken since I don't eat beef or pork. Their banchan also has a good mix of flavors and I find myself eating most of them and asking for more. 

The service is usually pretty great too, with yummy hot tea to get you started. There is almost always a line and you have to ask for water, but other than that, 5 stars!
author: Kat M.

description:
Returned with my mom for Friday lunch. They weren't busy yet so we were seated quickly yay! 

GOOD:

Service is quick and pleasant.

Food is delicious. I took one pic only-of the delicious crispy sweet and spicy wings. The kalbi beef short ribs were tasty, sweet and tender. The spicy tofu soup with pork was also delicious. Banchan are only 4 or 5 varieties but the Napa kimchi and the fish cake are very good.

BAD:

Pricey for the small serving sizes. We got three lunch specials and the total was $40 before tip. Still I'd return because the food is tasty and service is quick.
author: Trish W.

description:
While having dinner at Perilla last Friday night, Wifey saw this place from across the street and curiosity got the best of her.

So the next day, she managed to twist my arm to have lunch here suddenly ended up driving here by chance. I mean she wasn't driving, but we ended up in the Inner Sunset two days in a row. 

There were a few people ahead of us as we were quoted 15 - 20 minutes wait time....which was approximately just about right. The menu is right underneath a glass cover on the table, a brilliant way to prevent sticky icky menus. The server immediately gave us two glasses of water as we got seated down.

Wifey decided to order the Beef Bulgogi while I chose the Stone Pot Bibimbop and a side of Sweet & Spicy KFC to share. While the glass of water was a nice touch and appreciated, we also requested hot tea for both of us. Their Banchan came after and it was a nice selection of the usual suspects. Nothing to scram about, but it was good.

We received the KFC first and it wasn't as advertised. It definitely was sweet, but not spicy. In fact, the sauce was uber sweet and overpowered the entire thing. It was almost like eating candied chicken wings...which is not my thing. 

Then my Bimbimbop came and dismayed to see the yolk of the egg was overcooked. I mean, what's the purpose of having an egg on top if I can't mix the entire thing with the yolk oozing to blend together? The hot stone pot created a nice crust on the rice though, but it was missing that punch that only an egg yolk could provide. 

Wifey's Beef Bulgogi was pretty OK, but it was also more on the sweet side. Thank god for the kimchi to break the monotony of sweet on sweet and ordered another side of it. 

Overall, nothing wowed us and nothing stood out. It was just run-of-the-mill Korean food, with good and friendly service.
author: John G.

description:
I first tried Manna about 5 years ago with a group of friends. For some odd reason, we decided not to do family style, so naturally, I ended up with an entire plate of Korean chicken wings to myself. I typically would never do this...but I really had a hankering for wings that night. Needless to say, I polished off the ENTIRE plate of sweet and spicy chicken wings and had no regrets. 

Manna has been in constant rotation ever since. I come here about twice a year and always come early since they don't take reservations. The place isn't that big...maybe around 30 people max can fit and there's usually a wait by the time 6pm rolls around. Reasonable prices, a no frills atmosphere, and a well rounded menu that isn't overwhelming. The dishes are tasty and authentic, but still welcoming for those who are unfamiliar with Korean food. 

Besides the chicken wings, the kal bi, bbq spicy pork, kimchi fried rice, and seafood pancake are my go-to orders. The dol-sot bibimbap is also one of the best I've had because they get that stone pot so darn hot! It actually crisps the rice up, which is a rare occurrence. Overall, Manna is a solid spot that won't disappoint!
author: Deanna Y.

description:
This is my favorite place to get korean food in SF! 

I usually order their bbq spicy pork and their sweet and spicy chicken - both very appetizing! The bbq pork is very flavorful and pairs well with rice (which is free + can ask for refills).The sweet and spicy chicken is also well marinated, but tastes more sweet than spicy. 

The only downside is that this place is pretty small, so there's usually a long wait time...but I think it's worth the wait! I'll keep coming back here!
author: Aileen J.

description:
I like this little local Korean restaurant.  Came here with family for dinner. We still like the food. Tried 2  appetizers, fried dumplings which was great and the chicken wings.  The wings have a sweet bbq tart flavor.  Not my favorite flavor of wings but is OK. I asked for mild soft tofu chicken soup but it still came with a bit of heat.  I like this dish a lot. Hubby always order the bibimbap, his fav.  
If you come early you can get a seat. A later time for dinner will mean waiting outside. They do a lot of takeout too. Our dishes came to $80 before tip. Not exactly inexpensive.
author: Ry T.

description: For the line hype it was food...everything tasted pretty healthy which is another way of saying not very flavorful. Nothing was really memorable. One thing I did remember and not because it was good was the broccoli small plate that was just steamed broccoli which was reminiscent of something that you'd  have to force your kids to eat. I had the Dol-Sot Bibimbap which was beef, veggies, rice and topped with an egg. It was okay. Again it was just this general sense of 'yes, that tastes like carrot' and 'yes that bite was definitely rice'. I felt like I was eating to just not be hungry here but at least it was healthy. The tables can be a bit small so coming with a bigger party might be difficult.
author: Emily L.

description:
Super solid Korean fare just steps away from Golden Gate Park! The restaurant itself is pretty small but works in their favor since the size and structure of the place felt like eating homemade food out of someone's kitchen. Tables are very close together, so be prepared to get cozy with your neighbors.

The cashier/service counter where the waiters pick up food from the kitchen faces the floor so it is easy to hail anyone if you need help (or need refills on banchan... my favorite and much too often problem). 

Get the dolsot bibimbap, which comes in a sizzling hot stone pot. You can get pork/chicken/seafood/tofu as the meat options and with a beautiful sunnyside fried egg on top. The rice cooks nicely and becomes wonderfully crunchy as you mix everything together and shovel it into your mouth. Their seafood pancake is also pretty amazing -- it takes up the entire large plate, not too battery, and generous with fresh shrimp, scallops, and squid!
author: Lily C.

description:
It's been a long time since I've been here. I was craving Korean, and Manna did not fix my cravings. 

What I liked:
-Lots of veggies in my seafood bibimbap
-Food came out quickly

What could be improved:
-There was a long strand of hair in my boyfriend's bibimbap. . . 
-Small servings of banchan
-Water was only refilled when the check came
author: Erica M.

description: While visiting Golden Gate Park, my friends and I got hungry so we yelped a place to eat. This spontaneous place was not disappointing at all! We were seated right away before the lunch rush, so no wait for us. They menu is a basic korean menu, but I feel like the entrees are super flavorful. I think the best item we ordered was the kimchi fried rice. It was spicy yet also tangy at the same time, highly recommend. The portions were also pretty large. My friends and I eat A LOT but we had leftovers to bring back to our hotel. Probably the only downside was that because there were so many people that the service was really lacking, but good service really makes a meal perfect.
author: Jessa L.

description:
My go-to Korean BBQ! Its just a quick walk around the neighborhood. This place is small and gets pretty busy so there's usually a wait. But i usually do to-go orders and it's still great because the all the side dishes are still included in every entree! The price reasonable specially for lunch.

I usually get the kimchi jaeyuk bokum which comes with pork and all the sides. Super filling and the sauce is sooo good. Their kimchi fried rice is also bomb and comes with the side dishes too. Also, can't go wrong with the spare ribs Galbi although not too much spare ribs when I ordered lunch to-go but still got me pretty full.

Definitely a must try in the neighborhood.
author: Carmina D.

description:
This review is for their kimchi fried rice to go. Tiny Korean mom and pop type restaurant, seemed to always be packed. The kimchi fried rice was good and flavorful but man it was so oily!! The whole to go bag and soiled in all red oil, a complete disaster. 

Next time I'll try eating in the restaurant.
author: Debbie D.

description:
Affordable tiny Korean spot.

What I've tried:
*Bibimbap- rice is usually a little mushy 
*Tofu soup - yum!
*Kimchi fried rice

Overall thoughts:
*Small restaurant mostly for groups of 2-4 but customers leave fairly quickly 

*Usually very busy so service is average- we were given tea when asked for water and a dirty cup 

*Food is more of 3.5 star food and not bad for the price
author: Sarah W.

description:
PROS
- Friendly, Quick Service
- Food was out within ten minutes
- Lunch Menu available (discounted Tue-Fri from 11am-3pm excl holidays)

CONS
- Small Restaurant, No Private Parking
- No Seating for those waiting to be seated
- Canned Soda

Located at the corner of 10th Avenue and Irving Street, is the cozy little Korean restaurant, Manna.

Upon entering, you'll find a sign in sheet to write your name and party size.  We came in on a Saturday afternoon, about 2:30pm, and were lucky enough to be seated right away.  Shortly after we got seated, the following parties had to wait outside as there is no seating indoors for those who are waiting, and the restaurant itself is snug and small.

There are approximately 12 tables for two, which can be pushed together for groups as well as seat an extra person on the side if walkway permits.  The tabletop is glass with a menu underneath the glass so you can start contemplating what to order right when you are seated.  Orders were taken promptly and food was brought out within a timely manner.

Ordered:
- 33. Fried Dumpling - Fried Beef & Vegetable Dumpling
- 1. Kal Bi - Juicy Tender BBQ Beef Short Ribs (comes with rice)
- 9. Dol-Sot Bibimbab - Beef & Assorted Vegetables with Fried Egg over Rice in Sizzling Hot Stone Bowl
- two canned Cokes

First off, the food came out within ten minutes and was piping hot.. which I have no complaints about!  However, I was slightly disappointed when I got my fried dumplings because I was expecting to find noodles in them but Manna didn't have that kind of Mandoo.  The Kal Bi was well seasoned and well portioned, it also came out with a bowl of rice.  And the Dol-Sot Bibimbab was good, according to my fiance.

We also received banchan in six little dishes and tea-water? prior to our meals.  Our banchan were quickly replenished upon request.

Overall, the food was delicious and service was great.  Given that it was Korean marinated meat, our burps were quite unpleasant for several hours after.. hehe.  But yes, I would return to Manna if I am ever in the area and craving Korean food, or unable to find another new restaurant to eat at and review!!

--/ One for ME, YELP for YOU.
@sandyexplores
author: Sandy S.

description:
I got off my flight to SF, and the first thing I wanted was tofu soup. I found Manna and wanted to try it out. Upon entering, I noticed there was a waiting list for a table, as it was a little busy. I put my name down and waited for about 20-30 minutes. Once I got my table, I got too excited.

I ordered my beef tofu soup with medium-level spice, and while waiting, I ate the traditional korean small appetizers. I thought all of them were well seasoned, thus helping myself to a second serving of fish cake. I usually don't like kimchi, but theirs was good.

Soon, my soup arrived alongside the rice. The rice was super quality, with the correct cook on it. The soup was out of this world, as the tofu was especially soft, and the broth was flavorful. The little bits of beef and vegetables were complementing, but the the tofu and broth were the true stars of that soup.

Wait staff was attentive. They even laughed at one of my jokes! The food was quality and delicious, and the prices were reasonable. 

tldr: traditional korean fare that hits the spot!
author: Lydia M. And Connie C.

description:
One of our favorite Korean restaurants in the city. 

#6 - Soy Sauce Chicken Wings - LOVE THESE. Had them for the first time recently and they came out piping hot, in a delicious sweet soy sauce glaze, with a perfectly crispy outside (which stayed this way even after it had been sitting in the sauce for a while). Definitely getting this every time I come here now. 

#9 - Dol-Sot Bibimbap - There are many other Korean dishes I would prefer over bibimbap, so I don't order this often and don't know how it compares to other places. But my parents like this here, as do many other Yelpers apparently.

#13 - Seafood Soft Tofu Soup - We were asked how spicy we wanted this and were given the options of no spice, mild, medium, and spicy. When asked anywhere else, I usually order a medium, but we decided to get the mild this time. HOLY CRAP it's spicy for mild! Bearable, and still delicious, but the mild here is spicier than the "medium" level at other places, such as Dae Jang Geum Tofu House. 

#27 - Seafood Korean Pancake - I usually order this item with caution at Korean restaurants, because there is the tendency to put in too much batter, making the pancake too thick and starchy. Not the case here. This is the best seafood pancake I've ever had. Light and crispy with a generous portion of seafood, yum. My dad loves the sauce that comes with this too. 

The small dishes here don't have much variety, but taste is definitely on point (broccoli, fish cake, shredded potato, kimchi, bean sprouts). Service is decent and water is refilled often. Parking is kind of difficult in this area because there are so many good options for food. We usually look for at least 15-20 minutes, but I'd say it's totally worth it. The restaurant is small, so we almost always have to wait - half an hour this time (Thursday at 7pm). Drop someone off to put your name down before looking for parking! Even thinking about this place is making me want to make a trip right now...
author: Nicole M.

description:
I bookmarked this place a while back as something to do in case we get really bored.  Seemed like a small sort of authentic Korean place which is different for us.  As an aside, wtf is up with all the "asian" places in the Sunset being so busy every night.  My theory is that they have good street cred due to actual dudes from country in question making stuff in the back.  Which is a good argument, it's authentic.  But in the 80s/90s when I lived here before nobody gave a f.  Also it was much foggier, I swear.

Manna is a small place with a limited menu. I like that.  They don't try to do everything, focus on a few good dishes.  Then they served us water in warm glasses and the water tasted funny.  Finally when our waitress rounded the corner towards us I complained. But it turns out this was on purpose due to it being some sort of tea.  My bad.

I ordered a soup of some kind.  I took a picture but it's been awhile so i don't remember what.  But is was super hot to the point that it was boiling.  That's good soup in my book.

We also got about five or six little plates of Korean side dishes like Kim Chee and other stuff.  That's standard for everyone here like bread at an Italian restaurant.  Was good.

One of the things that most impressed me was the owner, near closing, getting a bunch of the same stuff as us and settling down for a nice meal at the end of the night.  Also, he was a real congenial guy.
author: Asper K.

description:
My go-to for Korean food in SF. 

I always get their beef tofu soup or their yukgaejang, and both are very flavorful and doesn't just have that "spicy flavor." Love how extra bonchon and rice is free and service is super friendly. 

Just remember it's closed on Mondays so don't make the trek out to find out they're closed on Mondays like I did before!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars. 

Is it the best? No, but it's conveniently located and does the job. 

Arrived on a Thursday at 7pm and we're seated immediately. 

We ordered the spicy pork which wasn't spicy, chicken wings that will never be as good as San Tung's, galbitang that has only 3 pieces of meat and not great broth, and finally Dolsot bimbimbap that was prob the best meal. 

Banchan had five bowls of sides that honestly seem alot smaller than other places. 

Service is pretty lackluster but that's the type of joint it is. 

All in all, not the best but not the worst. It's ok for the city.
author: Mandi W.

description:
My bf and I were visiting SF for a few days and of course, we had to go try the infamous san tung. Unfortunately we went on a Wednesday, and they were closed so we just decided to explore around the area and came across this place. We stood outside for awhile looking at the pictures in the window and also looked up some yelp reviews and decided to give it a shot.

We ordered a dol-sot (hot stone) bibimbap, soft tofu soup and soy sauced chicken wings. The bibimbap was very flavorful and yummy. I like that they let you add the gochujang (red sauce) by yourself so you can adjust the spiciness to your liking. The tofu was also really good. It was unlike all the other soondubus I'd tried before which was surprising. My bf and I both agreed it tasted very authentic and not like it came out of a package like what we're used to. However, the star of the day had to be the chicken wings SOOO GOOD, definitely one of the best, if not the best I've ever had. The skin was super crispy and the inside moist and flavorful. The ban chan was also really good, I loved every single one!!

Overall, I'm super glad we stumbled across this place. When we told our friends back home they almost laughed cus no one goes to SF to eat Korean food (BUT THEY SHOULD). I would definitely recommend this place to my friends. The service was also really great, the girls working were super friendly and cute.
author: Emily K.

description:
5 stars based on their lunch deals. 

Manna is pretty small, so it'll be hard to fit a big group in. We came around 1130, and there was no wait. Service was great! Our waters were refilled quickly, both hot and iced. However, wish we got more side dishes since the three of us went through them so quickly. It filled up by noon, so get there before the lunch crowd!

I ordered the Seafood BiBimBap.. so delicious! It was only $10.99, which is an incredible price especially for San Francisco. And I was stuffed!
author: Michelle N.

description:
I'm definitely coming back!

Pros:
-High quality deliciousness, authentic food
-Reasonable prices
-Friendly waitstaff

Cons:
-They're delicious and the neighborhood knows it, so waits might be a bit long. Small shop so difficult for large groups
-They're super busy so sometimes it's hard to get their attention. (We were missing spoons the whole time, so there's room for improvement, but that doesn't hinder me coming back!)


Dol sot bi bim bap 4.5*
Fresh ingredients, great mix of flavors, and nice hot bowl.  Everything was good separately, but mixed together unlocked its potential--and the crispy rice at the bottom was just perfect.  Their high quality rice really elevated the dish.

The gochujang (red chili paste) was bomb! Some places have it too salty or it can muddy the flavors, but this was so delicious I added it to another non spicy dish and it just amped up the flavor.  So good, I wanted to take the bottle with me!

Royal Court Dok Bok Ki 4.5*
I really like the general rice cake dish (spicy) so was excited to try this.  

The owner actually came over to warn me about this in case I didn't know what kind of rice cake it was, saying some people find it bland.  This has been the case at some other places (spicy version), or the sauce gets one-note fast, but not at Manna.  So good--perfectly chewy rice cakes and really flavorful sauce.  This version didn't have a spicy sauce, but I added the gochujang and it was awesome.  My partner usually doesn't like fish cake and he even liked it in this dish.  Would def order again.

Banchan 4*
-Kim chi: really good. I usually don't like kim chi, but I liked Manna's
-Broccoli: fresh and green
-Bean sprouts: flavorful
-Fish cake: touch of spice and very flavorful
-Potato slices: delectable, almost crunchy, and nicely salted

I'm coming back and I'm going to be trying a bunch more items from the menu.  It's all going to be good!
author: Anna D.

description:
Really great lunch specials!

Came here with a colleague and was pleasantly surprised. Prices are reasonable and the portion and accompaniments are generous. We arrived just before the lunch rush and got a small table for two in the window nook. 

I ordered the BBQ ribs and my colleague got the veggie bibimbap in the stone pot. We also got a seafood pancake to start. I really like the ribs but they were a little fatty and hard to eat with chopsticks. The pancake was really good but the full-sized baby squid in there were a little off-putting :/ Otherwise it was really good but wish the seafood was chopped up more. 

I liked the accompaniments--especially the potato and broccoli. Didn't care too much for the tofu (fishy) or the kimchi/cabbage.

They served unlimited hot tea with the meal and service was kind and efficient. Great option for lunch!
author: Semuteh F.

description: SO GOOD. Hands down the best Korean food in SF city, and very reasonably priced. My friend and I ordered a yuk-gye-jang (spicy beef soup), seafood pancake, Jae-yuk-bokkum (spicy pork with kimchi + tofu), with a bottle of flavored soju. The total was around $65 with tip (!!!) which is very reasonable for the city. Will definitely come again!!
author: Somin L.

description:
6:30pm -  FriDate with my fiancé (wait was around 20 minutes) 

This is a particular small restaurant and can seat up to no more than 30 people at a time. We decided to do family style because I like variety. We ordered ddukbokki, Kimchi pancake, and kalbi. The kalbi was on point and it wasn't hard to pull to meat off the bone as well. Part of the Kimchi pancake was burnt. The ddukbokki came with about 15 pieces of rice cake and lots of fish cake. For $9.99 I expected more rice cake. Other than that it had a good texture.
author: Annie Y.

description: Been craving for Korean food and this is the place to go! It isn't too far from where I live and the food is delicious. First is the Kimchi Fried Rice. Nice flavors and fun seeing the egg yolk pour on the hot steaming rice. Next is the Spicy Rice Cake or Dukbokki. Nice amount of spice, but one teeny tiny complaint I have is that they should put more rice cake in the dish. Mostly vegetables and fish cake. Lastly is the Sweet and Spicy Chicken Wings  They were amazingly crunchy. Thick glaze on all of the wings. Definitely worth it! :D
author: Carrie L.

description: Good little spot for authentic Korean food. They always have a bit of a line outside, but the wait wasn't too long for a weekend (15 min). I had the spicy seafood pot. It was very spicy but there was a ton of seafood in it! I wasn't expecting crab, but it was delicious! Also came with mussels, clams, squid, and scallops.
author: Kristine C.

description:
quality of sf korean food will always be inferior; however, if i had to choose a korean joint to feast on, this is the only one. 

i recommend going with a large crowd and get the 8ppl set or any of their larger people set.
author: Annie C.

description:
Good service and food with iprice. Love the seafood pie and the soft tofu soup, tastes amazing! The beef was ok, too sweet...
Waited for 40 mins on Friday afternoon ...
author: Peizhi Z.

description:
This Korean restaurant place is very small, ideal for a party of two.   We had to wait about an hour as a table for 4 is scarce.  
I do not like to wait in the SF cold for a seat to eat anywhere.  Since everyone raved about this place, we decided to give it a try.  

The hostess was gracious to keep checking in with us and let us know that there would be a table for us momentarily.

Once we sat down, the complimentary plates of various kimchi got to the table quickly.  Food and drink to the table was quite fast.  

We ordered from the menu
 
##1- Kal Bi-  bbq beef short ribs were juicy and tasty.  It's amazing that there were plenty of meats on this iron plate for 4!   I must say this was definitely the second best plate of the night. --$16

##5- Sweet and spicy chicken wings.  Super yummy!   This is the number one plate of the night.  --$10

##9 --Dolsot Bibimbat-  rice in clay pot. --$11

##16- Jabchae--clear noodles with vegetables.  I had better at other Korean places.  The noodles were soaked in too much oil --$10

##27- Seafood Korean pancake-   It's good but the pancake was not crunchy as I used to have.  Also, my order was full of octopus --$10

Overall, this place is inexpensive and the waiters are very nice and friendly. I won't return if I have to wait for an hour to be seated.  However, I would love to return and get some chicken wings to go.
author: Ivory B.

description:
Come for the best soondubu out in the avenues. I know, I know. Many will say, no, you're wrong. My Tofu House in the Richmond is better. Maybe it is for a slightly better authenticity with their stone rice, but come on, the soups are almost the same. And My Tofu House prices are ridiculous with their lack thereof banchans. 

Anywho, back to Manna. Few years back, had a friend live down the street so I'd frequent this spot a lot more. Now that the friend doesn't live there, and I have to look for real parking UGHHH, it's shitty ppl. Like horrible beyond belief. Inner sunset has got to be one of the worst areas to find parking...at most hours of the day...esp for restaurants around this area. THEN, on top of that, the wait at Manna is sometimes crazier. If you're looking to skip the lines, come before 5:30 (any night) or after 8. It's a small, small spot. The bathroom is like an airplane bathroom!! As for the staff, they're nice ish. Sometimes hard to get their attn, but they are dealing w lots of takeout orders at the same time. 

But onto the food. Banchans are fairly tiny serving sizes here and there are a limited number in variety, but you've got the good ol basics here (more than the four you get in My Tofu House in Richmond...). I ALWAYS order the seafood soondubu here. There's never any variances. Not unless I'm also ordering the seafood pancake, which I haven't gotten in a while. If you're getting the Tofu stew, ask for an egg. They apparently don't hand them out like hot cakes here. Gotta ask!! Remember!! 

Overall, still a solid 4 experience. So 4 it is!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I came here at 9:30 after finding that 3 other restaurants were closed because of holidays. I was surprised and relieved that they were still willing to serve us. Despite how late it was, there was still a good amount of people there. The service was also quick and attentive, they got our food out pretty fast. 

I ordered japchae, it was hot and flavorful, but not too greasy. In my opinion, the portions were quite generous, they did not skimp on the meat! My friend ordered the soft tofu soup that came with rice, she said it was good.  

Definitely come here if you're craving Korean and in the area
author: Donald C.

description:
One of the best places to get authentic tasting korean food :) We ordered the glazed wings, japchae, ttebbokki, and dol sot bibimbap and not a single dish let us down. The glazed chicken wings were so sweet and savory, only bones were left afterwards. The japchae looked questionable but was actually flavored and moist in just the right way. The ttebbokki was also delicious but it could use more rice cake and less zucchini. The dol sot bibimbap was also very tasty and full of flavor. 
Service wise, everyone was very kind and attentive to when we needed something at the table. They explained certain ingredients to us and kept a positive attitude the entire time. 
In all, Manna left a great impression on us and we hope to visit again sometime.
author: Neha M.

description: Great restaurant! We came at a good time when they weren't busy, around 4:30 pm for an early dinner. The service was attentive, even when they become jam packed for dinner around 5 pm. Food came out in a timely manner, my friend and I both enjoyed our meals. I got the spicy seafood tofu soup with Japchae while my friend got the bibimbap. I asked the server for SUPER SPICY since she asked how hot I wanted my soup, I don't think she quite believed me since I'm white because although the soup was spicy, I could have taken so much more heat and spice with that soup. I LOVE my food spicy but overall food had great flavor, presentation was excellent, restaurant was clean, and i had a great night out with my friend!
author: Esca N.

description: My to go Korean food fix! & prob the best one in town!! Great appetizers, all the food I tried on the menu are on point. My all time favorite is definitely beef tofu soup mild. Their spicy pork and kimchi fried rice are also heavenly. Their to-go also comes with appetizers and rice, which is amazing and thoughtful! It's a small place so get ready to be in line waiting.
author: Sharie H.

description:
TLDR - Cheap and delicious Korean food

I almost forgot what it's like to have a tasty, filling lunch for $10. But that's my fault for not venturing out into the (Inner) Sunset more.

Manna is a pretty small Korean restaurant, so either come at an off hour or expect to wait. I wouldn't recommend coming with a large group. Good for 2 people, 4 people would be doable, but any more would be a squeeze. My friend and I stopped by during lunch hour on a Tuesday and luckily, there was one table for 2 open for us.

Service is quick here. Honestly a little too quick because we had sat down for maybe a minute and hadn't looked at the menu yet before the waitress came by asking if we were ready. It felt a little rushed but at least they were also attentive about refilling our tea and banchan when we asked.

Their menu has a large variety of Korean dishes: bibimbap, tofu soup and other soups, meat like bulgogi and kalbi, noodles, rice cakes and more. Lunch specials average around $10, while most dishes on their normal menu are still around $10-14. Not bad given the portion, quality and taste.

* BANCHAN (complimentary) - 4/5
Their banchan spread was somewhat limited compared to other Korean restaurants I've been to, but everything tasted good. The kimchi was kind of sweet rather than strong, fermented quality kimchi. There was also broccoli, bean sprouts, potato strips and fish cake, all of which were pretty normal.

* DAKDORITANG ($9.99) - 4.5/5
[chicken stew w/ mixed vegetable in spicy sauce]
Not a soup despite the "tang" and despite the "stew" in the description, which was a little disappointing because a spicy chicken stew sounded really good to me. The waitress did mention that it's not a stew but I ordered it anyway and thought it was delicious. So much sauce, so much flavor! It wasn't super spicy but had some heat to it. The chicken was cooked with zucchini and potatoes, and I ended up adding the broccoli and bean sprouts from the banchan for some more veggies and to soak up the sauce.
author: Jessie L.

description:
This is a great Korean restaurant! Pretty authentic food, especially since the restaurant is owned and operated by a Korean family. 

I've tried the dumping soup, tofu soup, and the chicken wings (soy sauce and sweet/spicy). 

Tofu soup was pretty standard for a non tofu soup specializing restaurant. But still pretty satisfying. 

Dumpling soup was great! It's been a while since I had it but I do remember loving it. 

Soy sauce wings were good. The sweet spicy ones were even better! I def recommend these wings. 

Cons:
-Not many tables, so you may need to put your name down and wait.
-Food takes a while to come out. They may be understaffed in their kitchen.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I'm sorry, but worst Korean food ever   Not even comparable to Korean food in LA where I grew up.  Tofu soup has no flavor and side dishes are bad too. Sigh.
author: Mariko Y.

description: Great service, good food, super chill environment. Nice people. I would definitely come back. The food was delicious.
author: Joni W.

description: Look at that picture of my food! Love this place. One of my favorite Korean spot in SF. WISH IT WAS CLOSER TO DOWNTOWN!
author: Kuan H.

description: The food was delicious!  Fresh and tasty and portions were large.  There was a wait to be seated as the restaurant is extremely small--the service was good and friendly.  Seems like a regular spot for locals.  Would definitely return when I'm back in the area.
author: Abbee N.

description:
Manna has had my back since day 1. 

It's been the only legitimate, delicious Korean restaurant on Irving for so long. The staff there is also so cheery and great with service. But what made me deliver e a 5 star Yelp review was because of their take-out. I ordered Manna through Postmates, going a little crazy with the ordering but I knew I would take leftovers to work. They stuffed every takeout order with side dishes and didn't skimp out on the main courses. Talk about AMAZING! So great to order from here and I will be ordering from this place again 100%.
author: Emily F.

description:
This place does seem to always be full, but I can see why. If you go during the right hours (like early lunch or something) you can get seated right away.

This is probably my go-to Korean place because I love their bi bim bap. They give a nice ratio of bulgogi, veggies and rice. And in the stone pot, the rice ends up so nice and krispy at the bottom.

Seafood pancake is also huuuuuge for an "appetizer". Like a great surprise if you were expecting small to be honest. It was nice and krispy. 

Banchan- the basic stuff, nothing to amazing but they're generous when it comes to refills.
author: Kimberly T.

description:
It's difficult to find a good Korean restaurant in SF. It's a fact. That's why I'm glad we have Manna!!! This is that one restaurant I recommend to others.

I'm Korean and I find this restaurant's food phenomenal. My parents also think it's delicious so there you go 

I got Kimchi Fried Rice to-go the day before my half marathon and I did really well on my race haha! Kind staff, good food, convenient location, good price (especially for SF)....  thumbs up!!
author: Lori K.

description:
My girl friends and I were looking for some Asian food for dinner before we headed to Nightlife at California Academy of Sciences. After a little Yelping, we found this cute little hole in the wall that's closeby. Even before the dinner rush, there were people waiting outside to dine at Manna. (The restaurant is pretty small!) 

- Seafood soft tofu soup ($10.99): not bad, but also nothing special. 
- Soju ($9.99): get the grapefruit flavor... no regrets!

Lunch specials may seem cheap, but their dinner prices are all about the same as restaurants in the South Bay. Food was just okay, but hey, I do like the mom and pops feels of this place!
author: Christine S.

description:
What a wonderful place to grab a meal.

On every visit that I have made here, the wait has been out the door. The restaurant is small but the space is well utilized. My go-to order is dol-sot bibimbap. The dish comes with generous servings and I often go home with a to-go box for my leftovers. There are 5 banchan dishes that are served. 

Lunch specials are Monday to Friday, 11am - 3pm.

Service is good. There is metered parking in front of the restaurant.
author: Katie C.

description:
Finally, after years of passing by this restaurant and seeing the restaurant consistently full, with a line outside, I decided to try it. To me SF doesn't have very much Korean food, or really good Korean food and I'm comparing against the Korean food I've had in NYC. 

On a Friday afternoon at around 12:30, there was still a 20 minute wait. The restaurant isn't very big and the staff is 3 people. 

Food: 
- Banchan: good selection of standard choices (broccoli, fish cakes, kimchee, bean sprouts)
- Dolsot Bibimbap: really great flavor, very colorful dish 
- Soft Tofu Soup (with pork): very flavorful broth, soft tofu
- Seafood pancake: really large (and affordable at $10.99!), chock full of seafood, perfectly fried

Service: Not perfect, but nice enough 
Atmosphere: Very casual
Pricing: Really decent, especially for the lunch specials

Definitely found my go to spot for Korean food in SF.
author: Amanda C.

description: Authentic family run Korean restaurant. Go try their Bibimbap, soft tofu soup, Jabchae, Kal bi short ribs, and spicy ramen with egg!
author: Annie L.

description:
place is very good. service is fast and servers are friendly, courteous and always attentive.

seafood pancake is my favorite. i may be small but I can finish it in one sitting to myself haha.
author: Kelsey D.

description:
Finally got to try this place! Usually, there is a long wait, but we came here on a Thursday around 6pm and were immediately seated. 

The menu is quite extensive and being the indecisive person I am, I went with my usual go-to at Korean restaurants - bibimbap in a stone bowl (#9 Dol-Sot Bibimbap). Compared to the regular bibimbap, I enjoyed the stone bowl more since it makes the rice at the bottom brown and crispy. The red sauce that accompanied the dish was delicious and the portion size was so large it lasted me two meals. 

I also appreciated that they served a bunch of side dishes (kimchi, fish cake, bean sprouts, broccoli, etc.) as well. Overall a good experience!
author: Kris C.

description: We had bbq there, pork belly is good. Their business is busy, service is just passable.
author: Jacky C.

description:
I've come here only a handful of times in the last 6+ years as the place is super small and you always have to wait. But,  let me tell you, it's always worth the wait and I've always had a great experience.

Located at the corner of 10th and Irving,  manna is a jewel of the inner sunset.  Family owned and operated,  everything is made from scratch and its a true taste of authentic Korean barbecue.  I'm not Korean,  but my Korean friends always agree and love the place. 

I  terms of what to order,  well everything is good. They have lunch specials on weekdays from 11am to 3 pm and its a great place to come for lunch with work friends. They bring hot tea as soon as you sit down and the staff are so kind and friendly. If you're in a group, the sweet and spicy chicken wings is great for sharing.   My favorite is the BBQ boneless chicken, get some kimchi to go on that and you'll thank me. I would also recommend the vegetable fried rice.
author: Arman J.

description:
Good food.  Nice service.  Authentic Hot Stone bowls.  Tasty!!
If you are looking for decor look elsewhere.  If good value and tasty num-num is what you seek in the Korean flavaz.  Go and eat here.  It will be satisfying.
author: Kashif M.

description:
This is cheap korean food that doesn't taste quite as cheap as its price. Friendly & efficient service. Eating here for lunch is usually only around $1 cheaper than the dinner menu. That means dinner is a really good deal and there are probably better options for lunch.

The spicy pork was not as spicy as other places in the area. The beef bulgogi was kind of dry. The banchan was decent and they refilled the ones we finished when asked. The person who ordered a noodle dish wasn't too happy, while the person who got the tofu soup didn't say much - not a great sign since I think they would be shy about insulting food at a place when being taken out by their boss.

This place looks like it is popular for a specific reason: Lower prices & above average efficiency in service for a korean place. Presumably their business model relies on getting people in and out quickly. Probably not worth waiting for a table but if I am in the area and see an open table I will give it another shot.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Great little local spot! Fast and friendly service and good spread of Korean food options. Only con is its a small spot so you have to wait if you come at a busy meal time as seating is limited. They do get food out pretty fast though so turnaround is relatively quick. 

We got the Kalbi (which includes the ban-chan little sides), BibimBap in the stone bowl, and the Japchae noodles. All delicious and well portioned!
author: Tiffany W.

description: This is a great, small Korean restaurant tucked about two blocks away from Golden Gate Park. We stopped by here after visiting the California Academy of Sciences. It was also almost 3pm on a Sunday, so a bit late in terms of lunch time and we avoided any waiting time. They have vegetarian dolsot bibimbap and beef bibimbap, which cost around $11 each. Stone pots are extremely hot, and for the safety of your tongue, don't eat too close to the sides.
author: Luci L.

description: Really good korean food , has nice customer service and pretty inexpensive. Would like to recommend the kimchi bokumbap and the mandu !!!!!
author: Kataline C.

description:
This is my favorite Korean place to go. Not only is the price very cheap relative to other places, the food is also really good. I really like their seafood tofu soup and their bibimbap is also quite tasty. They also give those mini dishes for free; my favorite is the fish cake!

The only downside about this place is how small the restaurant is. It's pretty cramp and you're close to your neighbors, but it's still well worth the visit. Try to avoid coming at 6:30 to 7:30 because there's a long wait for dinner. Nonetheless the service is good and the food is worth the wait.
author: Victor L.

description:
I've been to many Korean spots in SF and Manna remains my to-go! I HIGHLY suggest stopping by for LUNCH 11am-3pm ON WEEKDAYS for their "lunch menu" which is $2-$3 dollars cheaper than their dinner menu (SCORE!).

Though the restaurant itself is fairly small, you can easily snag a seat on weekdays OR just order to-go! One time I stopped by and it was SUPER packed so I ended up ordering to-go and grubbing in the car...savage I know..BUT the meal was JUST as tasty and they even packed some of the side dishes in the order too :O

The DUKBOKKI is to die for. Seriously...not too spicy and just a hint of sweetness! Whenever I have a mad craving for dukbokki or seafood pancakes...Manna comes to mind.. MMM MMM
author: Mary L.

description: I don't like reviewing Korean places in SF because I know for the standard it's usually decent to pretty good.  This is your very standard Korean restaurant.  I ordered the Soon Tofu and the flavor was just okay.  It was a tad bit too salty and so was the galbi tang.  The service however was good but if I'm ever craving soup I will take myself elsewhere.  I will come back and try the other stuff though.
author: Ted Y.

description:
This was one of the restaurant on my list, as recommended by some family friends. I hadn't had Korean food in a while either, so what better opportunity than now. I also usually get the hot tofu pot whenever I go, but thought I might as well try something different for once haha.

- Bibimbap dolsot: the hot stone pot is the best, especially when the rice gets nice and crispy hehe. It was a generous and tasty portion of all the yummy stuff mixed together.
- Side dishes: no potatoes sadly :( But the fish cakes were quite good.
- The hot sauce was interesting - we couldn't really figure out what it was. There were faint elements of sweet, savoury, sour, and a hint of spicy... maybe a bit of Hoisin sauce through in there, but can't say for certain. It was quite interesting nonetheless haha.

This was a pretty solid Korean meal, and I'd definitely come back to try their other dishes!
author: Joanna C.

description:
I love the dry fried wings here.  They're the best in the city, and yes, better than San Tung's in my opinion.  They're larger, juicier, and have a crunch to them that's hard to describe.  The sauce is less sticky too, and has a subtle garlic sesame flavor to it.  I'm addicted.

(Beware of the ramen and Daekboki.. been here with a couple people and we all got stomach aches.  It's probably the sauce.)
author: Andrew P.

description:
Had the soon tofu..bland. I put a lot of banchan in it to flavor it a bit.

You have to ask for the egg. If you're concerned about spicy level, consider it white people spice levels. The mild was barely spicy at all.

Banchan was ok, only a few different items. Maybe 4?

It's ok for a quick bite but I probably won't go here again.
author: L Z.

description:
As long as you dont mind waiting, try this place. 

Taste was pretty decent but why 5 star?


Because,
Quality of food was good, all very fresh. 
Friendly Service. 
All Food came out so quickly!
Lunch price was very reasonable! 11 am - 3 pm


I know parking sucks here.
Street Parking costs 2.50 or something for 1 hour if you get lucky enough to find one near restaurant. 
You also probably have to wait as well. 

But it is how it is in the city. Lol

This place deserves 5 star because under this circumstances, I still had a good time eating there. 


Yeah, I would go back again.
author: Bladen K.

description: I've been here a handful of times with friends and every time I just think the food here is just mediocre. There's just something missing in their food and I just don't know what it is. I've had their tofu soup multiple times and seafood pancake. I live nearby and when passing by, I usually see a line of people waiting outside. I like Korean food but I don't claim to be an expert. I just personally like other places more than this place and I think it's a little overrated.
author: Christina C.

description:
I've been to Manna at least a dozen times, and it's continued to be my go to Korean comfort food in SF. Coming from NY where we have amazing Korean food, I have really high standards for it and Manna sticks out as one of the better places in SF. Do be aware that there is frequently a wait given that the place is small, and I've waited up to 30 minutes during the busy times. 

Overall, the service is friendly, the banchan is relatively generous, and everything on the menu is solid. 

My favorite dishes below for those indecisive: 
- Seafood tofu soup (soondubu)
- Seafood pancake 
- Fried chicken
- Spicy pork
- Galbi
author: Claudia C.

description: Came here with a group of 4 early around 6pm on a Sunday. I definitely say come here with a party of 2 is the best. We were the first group waiting on the list, and it took a while to get a table. The venue has limited seating, and the service is on the slow side. That said, the food is good. I got the seafood bibimbap. There is plenty of seafood and it is a pretty good portion for a good price, which is hard to find on the east coast :).
author: Tiffany W.

description:
My friend and I stopped by here for lunch, famished after a busy morning of apartment hunting. We split an order of seafood pancakes, and they were okay. I think they would have been better without the seafood, personally. They didn't add much to the flavor, and made the pancake sort of fall apart.

I got a bibimbap bowl and it was kinda tasteless. Even with heaps of chili sauce, I could hardly taste the difference between the meat, veggies, and rice. Pretty disappointing overall, it was too expensive to be this uninteresting.
author: Shawn W.

description:
This Korean place in Sunset isn't bad. We came here around 6pm on Sunday and we had to wait for 15 minutes to get seated. Since the restaurant is pretty small, we noticed that there were about 15 people waiting outside when we were eating. If people are coming to this place, I'd definitely recommend coming here early, especially on the weekends. 

The food itself was 4/5. I ordered the beef bibimbap served on a hot-stone pot and it tasted fine. My friend ordered the tofu soup served with rice, and she didn't really like it. She said the taste was a bit too dry and the food portion was not large either.
author: Jack T.

description:
Unfortunately, good Korean food is really hard to come by in the city.  Manna, on the other hand, is one of the better spots compared to all the other restaurants.  The wait is always long and the restaurant is quite small.  The service is super efficient though as they try to get you in and out to turn and burn their tables.  

We ordered a number of dishes.  The menu is pretty basic...basic meaning a good combination of bbq, street food, and bibimbap.  I'd prefer my mom's home cooking but the food here was pretty good if you just want to go out and grab some Korean fare.  

The prices are also affordable as Korean food is typically quite expensive.  I'd say food will cost you between $10-$20/person.  Parking is always difficult but not impossible. 

4 stars to one of the better Korean restaurants in SF.
author: Jen W.

description:
I started coming here as soon as they opened years ago, and fell in love with this place!

They serve amazing Korean food and I always find something to eat. The servers are friendly and the owner is super nice! I definitely recommend the spicy pork and the galbi. Their jjol-myeon is something I usually get when I miss some home-style cooking. The seafood and kimchi pancakes are also a pretty good way to start off the meal!

The only con is that the wait is ridiculous around dinner time, so I usually order takeout or go in for an early dinner. :)

Food: 5/5
Staff: 5/5
Atmosphere: 4/5
Value: 5/5
Overall: 4.75/5
author: Evan K.

description:
This place gets busy! Even on weeknights. Not sure if they take reservations (maybe not, as we wrote our names on a wait list). So you may end up ... waiting. And once you're in, if you're sitting by the window your food will get ogled by the crowd of others who are still waiting outside. That's right - eat your hearts out. Ooh so delicious now. Suckers. Nomnomnom...

Great value for the money! Not very expensive, and the flavours are quite tasty!

If you're craving spicy beef soup, try the Yuk Gae Jang. It's my go-to dish, and a good way to judge a Korean restaurant as it's a somewhat traditional dish. They make it very well here! It's not super spicy though. If you're craving *super* spicy Korean food, this place isn't for you... nothing we tried here was very spicy, even dishes labelled spicy.

Even added the extra spicy sauce to our beef bi bim bap, and it wasn't very spicy.

Spiciness isn't everything... but just saying. This spot may not satisfy a spicy craving - even though it IS delicious!

Service was very good! They are running around like crazy trying to serve everyone - but manage it quite well!

I would definitely return here and try some more dishes - if I happen to catch it when it had a short wait.
author: Alex G.

description: Very delicious soft tofu soup extra spicy! Banchon is okay and the short ribs are well marinated but not as tender as I'd like them to be. Portion is good. Order takeout is the best way if you want to eat their food for the wait is something I can do without.
author: SJ L.

description:
Went around 2ish and got a seat immediately. The place is very small and it can get very loud.

My friend and I ordered a kimchi fried rice, rice cake, sweet & spicy chicken and a japchae.

Kimchi fried rice- I've never had it with cucumber or whatever the green stuff was so I was surprised by it. The flavor didn't make a huge impact on me because it honestly tasted like any other kimchi fried rice but with more oil in it. The oil made the rice a bit soggy but it was still alright, somehow. I don't think I'll order this dish again.

Rice cake- my friend and I ate a couple of the rice cakes and then stopped because it was a lil bit spicy lol but this dish was alright. The rice cake was very chewy and it was super flavorful!

Sour spicy chicken- oh lord! No wonder why this chicken is so popular in here! The combination of both sweet and spicy felt like I was tasting heaven. I really liked it.

Japchae- I got this to-go for my boyfriend. I forgot to ask him for feedback but he finished his japchae at the speed of light so I think it's self explanatory LOL

Overall, this place was alright. I had super high expectations on this place because all my friends liked/rec it but I was just a bit disappointed by the kimchi fried rice. Next time I'll order the bibimbap and I wanna try the soy sauce chicken! Customer service was super good. A man, I assumed it's the boss, was so funny. I like him
author: Kathy D.

description:
I usually recommend this restaurant. However I ordered their very delicious chicken wings, like I always do, but about half of my wings were completely dry with no sauce at all. 

I've never ran into this problem but after a long day of work and looking forward to eating these wings I'm extremely dissatisfied and disappointed.

Will be a while until i might decide to come back.
author: Irene R.

description: Authentic Korean cuisine, quick and affordable. Perfect casual lunch spot
author: Brandon Y.

description: Was planning on going to San Tung to try the chicken wings to sadly find out that they're on vacation! So we yelped other places with chicken wings and found Manna pretty close by. I read they're usually pretty busy inside and we were eating a tad early so thought it'd be a good opportunity to try it plus everywhere else seemed to not open until 5pm the earliest.  The pictures of banchan fish cake and KFC on the menu also sold us.  I didn't ask if the banchan was free refills but we had plans to eat Orenchi Beyond after so we were trying to keep it light.  Ordered the seafood pancake and KFC. I think the pancake needed the sesame sauce they give you and it was very proportionate with the ingredients and batter.  The KFC was good but I like this place in OC more since they also do all flats with lighter batter. Overall I'd definitely be interested in coming back to try more food.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
First off, this place is super crowded so you might have to wait in like for 20 minutes or so. It's also a really small restaurant so try to come during off hours.

The food here is pretty delicious and reasonably priced. This is pretty much my go to Korean restaurant in SF that I go to. Everything is pretty safe to order. I typically get a bibimbap or jabchae noodles. Both are consistently tasty and never disappoint. The small dishes that they provide have changed a lot over the years so these might not be up to date. I love their fishcakes. I can't really think of another restaurant that has better fishcakes. Their sprouts, broccoli, potatoes, and kimchee are fine too. I'm very disappointed that they took out the sweet black beans because they were my favorite after the fish cakes. They will be missed.
author: Edmund L.

description: If you want excellent Korean food in a fun easily accessible area, this is the place for you. (GET THE KIMCHI PANCAKE IT'S AMAZING) It's pretty small so I recommend going earlier in the evening to land a table as the wait can get kinda long. But the wait staff are very nice and fast. Great for vegetarians as well! There are fun chill bars in the surrounding area as well if you were looking to go to a bar after!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Decent neighborhood parking around this area. Come here around lunch times 11-3pm, the prices are so worth it (no lunch specials on weekends) Also, this place is a bit tiny, so make sure you come a little early and put your name on the list.

I think the selection here is great for indecisive people like me! We got the dwinjang chige, which is like a bean based soup w/ a little of red pepper sauce. It was surprisingly tasty -- we didn't know what to expect w/ the bean paste base. :O It was savory and tasty, but you might need to be accustomed to the bean-taste ;)

We also tried the dokboki, but we added ramen into it! It was super yummy, they make the dokboki sauce sweet and spicy here. It's definitely worth a try if you're craving just dokboki but want more carbs/for it to be more filling. 

I'm a regular at this place! And the owner always smiles at me with warm greetings :). Definitely come try this place out!
author: Melanie T.

description:
1st time @ Manna on a Friday night. A very small restaurant with about 24 seats. A clipboard and pen hung on the inside of the door for diners to jot down their name and party size. After ~30 mins of waiting for a party of 2, we get seated and ordered:

(1) Bulgogi beef - thinly cut pieces of beef sauteed w/ onions
(2) Seafood soft tofu soup (customarily it comes w/ a fresh egg, however, we had to ask)
(3) Two bowls of rice

Five kinds of side dishes were offered - broccoli, Kim chi, pickled sprouts, pickled daikon+carrot strings, & tofu.

The sides were so-so & were barely enough for two. It took the server about 15 minutes to replenish the sides. We enjoy eating the side dishes @ Korean restaurants, unfortunately, Manna failed on this note.
author: Duke T.

description: Simply delicious, well recommended to everyone.  Tasty, healthy and amazing varieties.
author: Kevin R.

description: The bimbimbap is quite good! It took a long time to be served; however, it was worth it. There was a lot of flavor to the bowl that I didn't have to pile on any sort of hot sauce. I highly recommend and would definitely go again!
author: Kalani R.

description:
Below average Korean restaurant. Doesn't even include an egg by default with their tofu soup. I got mild spiciness but it's extremely tasteless. If you've had that at BCD tofu house, you'd know what I am talking about. The short ribs here are below average, nothing on par with what you get in ktown LA. The meat was overcooked and hard to chew. Not very flavourful either. 

This is a small restaurant so expect long wait times (on a Tuesday night we waited 20 minutes).
author: Tom P.

description:
One thing that LA does much better than SF is Korean food. However, Manna keeps the gap a little closer.  Irving Street has a plethora of good restaurant options and so you may skip out on this place, but then you'd feel tremendous regret after reading my review. 

Manna does a great seafood pancake. Lots of pieces of actual seafood inside the pancake  instead of all batter and green onions. Although, I love green onions actually. Those things are amazing when grilled and eaten in pancake form. The one minus of the pancake is that sometimes, it gets a little oily so eat it fast and forget about how you've just downgraded your health status. Kalbi short ribs are a decent option too if you like being a carnivore. I would say it's your standard fare and similar to other Korean places in the city.  A for the effort here. To round out the meal, I tried their chicken "stew", which really wasn't a stew since it didn't come in a pot. Instead, it was served on a plate and that really confused me for a few minutes.  It actually was really tasty since the chicken was tender and the sauce was perfect balanced between sweet and spicy and salty. 

I can't review a Korean spot without mentioning the banchan. The selection isn't huge since they only give you like 5 things. However, it's done pretty well regardless of whether they make it in-house or not.  The one standout I would say is the jicama (I think?) that cleanses your palette for more eating! The tea also does the same, which the waitresses refilled pretty often. I noticed it's a popular lunch spot so get their early or you'll be waiting in line.
author: Quoc N.

description: Hands down my favorite Korean restaurant in the city!! Only downside is how long the wait is because of how many people love their food, haha! Other than that, I love their dishes compared to other Korean restaurants that I have tried. Not only that, I think they are well priced as well. My favorite dishes are the Hot Stone dishes and Kimchi Fried Rice.
author: Vivian N.

description: First time eating Kbbq and it did not disappoint! I definitely loved the brisket and kimchi together. It was so fun to cook our own meat and enjoy a nice time in a big table. The wait time was short and plenty of parking. I got the meat sweats!
author: Monica G.

description:
Look I honestly don't know much about Korean home cooking but if you want a spot thats reputable and certainly tastes authentic and awesome Manna is the place to be. The interior is your pretty standard asian mom and pop shop but just polished up a bit more. Oh and side note be prepared to camp out a bit for parking especially during those lunch and dinner hours.

Alright so for sure make sure to stop by Manna for their lunch specials, its truly a bang for your buck. So I ordered the bbq chicken tossed in a spicy sauce and boy it was just the embodiment of how simplicity can go so for. Like I don't even have much to say which is the true testament to the beauty of simplicity. If you're all bout efficiency in your life Manna is the place TO BE. Tea served bang. Side dishes bang, Chicken bang, rice bang. Thats it! That's all it is and all it needs to be!

So final verdict! Honestly I truly believe Manna is one of the best stops for a San Franciscan lunch. Like shit if the only con is parking then damn its SF worthy!
author: Adrian E.

description:
Restaurant was incredibly tiny; however, it was accommodating and the service was great. 

Our waitress returned to fill our waters regularly. 

I wasn't too fond of the bibimbop, but I really loved their wings. 

Another thing I thought was really strange: their weird rationing of napkins. 

We needed extra napkins because of the wings. When they dropped off our bill, the waitress took all of our napkins. 

Aside from that weird exchange, everything else was okay.
author: Carmen C.

description:
So far, the best Korean restaurant I have tried in SF!

This Korean family owned place is a tiny little restaurant with maybe 8-10 small tables. Often I have seen lines out the door for peak lunch or dinner times. I came around 1pm on a Sunday and miraculously beat the line and waited for about 10 minutes to be seated.
Though authentic, everyone speaks english and the menu is well translated. They serve the most classic Korean restaurant dishes and nothing more: fried chicken, dumpling soup, tofu soup, kimchi soup, Korean seafood pancakes, bibimbap, buckwheat noodles, etc etc.

Their side dishes are very minimal and simple, but good. My friend and I ordered:
Med. spicy beef tofu soup: nothing amazing about it and could have a bit more deep flavor but decent.
Sweet and spicy fried chicken: YUM. crispy, hot, and delicious.
Dumpling soup: also nothing super special, and I think it could have had more flavor in the soup, but still a warm and delicious bowl of goodness.

It ain't LA Koreatown, but it's definitely one of the best we got in SF. Stamp of approval from a Korean picky eater.
author: Grace P.

description: Came just in time before the dinner rush.  We had the seafood pancake with so much seafood,  saw tiny little clams and tender squid.  We had #34 spicy octopus,  the sauce wasn't spicy at all and it had just the right sweetness and spice.  The octopus was a bit chewy, but with so much tentacles.  We had the nonspicy rice cake, which was chewy and tasty.  I can't say enough how everything is so tasty  and I can eat a gallon of their kimchi. Lived drinking barley tea. Service is fast.
author: Helen L.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant in the sunset! Everything is delicious. They have regular side dishes, fish cake FTW! Their Kimchi is a bit on the crunchy side which I prefer. Also, the bibimbap is actually in a stone pot! My favorite entree is their seafood soondubu!
author: Theresa N.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night with a group of four. Though there was a bit of a wait as the place is quite small, the waiters were amiable and very efficient.

Food was absolutely delicious as well, with large portions and reasonable pricing. The banchan is unlimited too and one of the best of the Korean restaurants I've tried. I particularly liked the Soy-Sauced Chicken Wings and Beef Short Ribs (as a meat lover).

Good experience and would definitely come again if craving some good Korean food.
author: Tammy L.

description: I went with a group of 5 friends. The restaurant is well situated but can't manage many groups, it great for 4 people or less. The food was good. The bulgogi was okay but the short ribs were really good. Chicken wings spicy and sweet also very good. Retired the seafood bibimba -whatever it's called- and really enjoyed it. Good place to go to.
author: Morea P.

description:
I'm not from SF, but compared to San Jose, this place was pretty decent.

It's very small and the wait could be quite a while. You also might sit VERY close to the people to the left and right of you. The service is pretty good here. The waitresses were all very friendly and helped us out at a very good pace. 

We ordered:
Japchae noodles: I really liked these noodles here. They are clear, dry, sticky noodles. One of the most flavorful japchae I've had and pretty large portions too! 

Galbi tang: this galbi tang is pretty good. For those of you who don't know what this is... it's a clear beef broth based soup. It comes with a little bit of noodles, and beef on the bone. Also has green onion and an egg. Love that it comes with an egg!.. not all places put an egg in there. I thought it could have been a little hotter in temperature.. probably just my preference though (I like my galbi tang piping hot). 

Seafood pancake: very good here! It's not super dough-y. It had a nice crunch to it.
author: Joanne C.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday afternoon for a late lunch with a friend. The restaurant was about half filled so we got seated right away. We made it in time for the lunch specials still so I ordered the stone bibimbap, which was $10. 

The banchan side dishes were decent. It had your ordinary bean sprouts, kimchi, fish cakes etc. We had to get more of the fish cakes because who doesn't like fish cakes am I right? Don't argue with me just agree. 

Anyways, the bibimbap came in a generous portion and went beyond my expectations. The egg was perfect and it had a lot of the burnt rice at the bottom of the stone bowl, which is arguably the best part. Overall, the food was great and the service was good. I took off a star because one of the waitresses had a small attitude, but I didn't really let it affect my overall experience. Will definitely come back in the near future!
author: Golden H.

description:
I've been introduced to this place recently by my daughters. Both of their families frequent this place frequently.. I've also been here for both lunch and dinner. It's a nice, no nonsence, Korean place. 
The food is very tasty, large portions, good selections. The service is frienbdly and efficient. The prices are super reasonable. 
During busy lunch or dinner hours, you can expect to see a waiting line. But the turnover is fast, so waiting time usually is not bad. Highly recommend it for a quick, satisfying meal.
author: Gene L.

description: If you decide to come here, get the bulgogi with rice. That is my absolute go to here. They cook the bulgogi just right. Their bon chon dishes are also really good. Their jap chae is also really delicious if you're craving something with less meat.
author: Allyson L.

description:
My favorite to go place for my Korean food cravings 

I love their dukbokki . They make it just right and it is very delicious . I usually go for their kalbi , it's a must order every time . Even though most people complain about their spicy ramen coming from an instant bag noodle , it tastes good . I order it every time I come to eat . The only thing I don't like is how they already stir cook my egg into my ramen , but understandable since they don't serve the noodle in a stone bowl . 

The only downside is the store is too small . So come early to get seats without waiting .
author: Annie L.

description:
We had the vegetarian dol-sot bimimbap, dak bulgogi, and japchae. All three were good, and the bimimbap was my favorite. I also like that they give you hot tea to drink for free.  The environment is unassuming, and Manna is in a good location close to Golden Gate park. 

We went around 7:00 on a Wednesday night and waited for about 20 minutes to get in with two people. 

Quick service too. I would definitely visit again to get my Korean food fix.
author: Lauren A.

description: Solid Korean bbq - meat comes out of kitchen sizzling and hot. Great customer service. Only complaint is lines but we usually choose to go there before the lunch crowd hits.
author: Charlene L.

description: After hearing so much about Manna, I decided to finally try it out. I've passed by the place several times, but it never caught my eye. My friend and I came on a Monday afternoon and the place was pretty packed. We waited around 20 mins for our table. The waiters were super friendly and our food came out pretty quickly. I ordered the bibimbap served in a hot stone bowl, my friend ordered the veggie tofu soup, and the both of us shared the rice cake. Food was pretty good and I would definitely come here again!
author: Stella E.

description:
Tried out Manna first time. It was a great experience.  The place was packed but we only waited less than 10 mins to get in. Service was fast n attentive. Food was quick and really delicious. 
We ordered the Soft Tofu Soup with Bibimbap. 
Loved the soup n crispy rice on the bottom of the Bibimbap. 
Both came hot sizzling n ready to eat. Worth the price and the wait.
Must try spot. 
Two thumbs up.
author: Pure M.

description: Really good food. The place is bit small so often times you will have 20-30mins wait time but worth it. The sides given are really delicious too.
author: Shimul B.

description: The seafood stew, number 20 has a nice spicy kick and is sooo good.  When you order it you are warned it takes extra time to make (15-20 mins) but is worth it.  Note that this is real Seafood- there are like 5 small half crabs in it, shell and all, so you it isn't for the faint of heart.  But if you can navigate crab (or eat around it) it is worth it.  Stone pot fried rice is good, as is the seafood pancake which has shrimp and squid (go light on the dipping sauce which is very tangy).  Staff is nice, quick with service.  The seating area isn't big so you will likely need to write your name on the waiting list on door and listen carefully for your name to be called or they will move on.
author: Dan P.

description: Okaaaaaay! Best hot and spicy wings ever made on earth! Better than San tung trust me!!!!  I never used my bare hands to hold any oily food, but guess what? this dish made me do it. I didn't even realize I was holding it and my bf knew something was weirdly off lol. "Must be really good" and yup it sure was!! We also ordered kimchi fried rice and instant ramen spicy soup. Both were phenomenal. Legitimate Korean hole in a wall. I wish the place is bigger so we don't have to wait to get seated. You might have to wait awhile but it's worth it. Minus one star for service not being up to par, took them really long to get me water but I know they were just busy. They also sat a family next to us literally 5 inches away from our table. Too close and impolite.
author: Gwen M.

description: On a Sunday evening, we luckily didn't have to wait too long for a table for two. It came with a variety of banchans, which we refilled because we were so hungry waiting for our food. We ordered the Sweet and Spicy Chicken Wings ($10), Soft Tofu Soup ($10), and Spicy Pork ($12). Some of the dishes took longer than others to come out, but the food was yummy. For the tofu soup, make sure to ask for the raw egg or they won't give it to you. Everything was flavorful and was more than enough for the two of us. I was pretty glad to take the chicken wings home for leftovers because Korean fried chicken is the best! This place is delicious and totally worth the value, but there can be a bit of a wait on a busy day.
author: Cindy Z.

description: The food was very good, but the wait was way too long, had to knock a star off because there's nothing else to do nearby.
author: Shiya L.

description:
I enjoy this small Korean spot a lot. It's packed on a Sunday noon and the wind was ridiculous cold even we've got some sun. 

It was very straight forward, my friend and I shared a Stone Pot Bibimbap, an order of Fried Chicken and a Kimchi Pork Soup. It was too much for us -- blame no one -- we enjoyed every dish and I love the crispiness as the fried chicken go, just enough of the sauce to keep the sweet and spice on it. 

Also lovely yummy small dishes. Friendly and fast servers. 

2016017
author: Leslie C.

description:
One of the best, yet affordable Korean restaurants in SF.  One of my faves is the Vegetable Dol-sot Bibimbap. Awesome choice for vegetarians. After devouring most of the veg and rice, you're left with this delish crispy rice made from the stone pot. Tip: add a little bit of your tea to the pot to lift up the crispy rice. 

Another face is the Soft Tofu Soup (aka soondubu jjiggae). I got the veg only and medium spice. You get rice for free and man oh man this soup is so comforting on a cold day!

5 stars for the awesome customer service! Everyone is so nice here and works super hard.
author: Hyejin N.

description:
Been wanting to come here for some time and finally got an opportunity recently.  Arrived fairly early for lunch on a Saturday a few weeks ago and was pleased to get seated quickly.  It's a small very quaint restaurant and there's usually a wait during their busy times.

My son and I ordered the Kanpoongki (Sweet and Spicy Wings), which I really liked.  They weren't very hot, but I enjoyed the crispy texture and they were just sweet enough for my liking.  My son ordered the Bul Kogi, which was really tasty.  The meat was tender and the portion size was good.   I ordered the Dol-Sot Bibimbap, which I really enjoyed.  Nothing says Korean comfort food than a bowl of Bibimbap.  

Service was quick and friendly.  I'll have to come back to try a couple of other items on the menu.
author: Lon H.

description: My boyfriend's favorite kbbq joint. I love their selection of meats and salad. Despite being pretty popular, the wait at peak hours is still not bad. The parking situation here, however, is absolutely terrible. They don't allow you to park in neighboring plazas and walk over to the restaurant. You have to find a more out of the way spot on the street.
author: Maiyi H.

description:
Awesome spot. Food is pretty decent quality at a very reasonable price. I never understood why Korean restaurants can charge 30% more than their other Asian counterparts. Ever since moving to SF, I see an even higher mark up for places that aren't even great. Here, everything was around 10 bucks except for the obvious expensive things like gal bi.

Manna is a nice family own looking place. Super friendly. Food is good quality - good prices. Will definitely go back.
author: Edward K.

description:
I've been getting over a minor cold so I was craving soondubu (soft tofu soup). Chose this place because it was close and convenient. 

Rating Breakdown:

1.5/2 Stars for Taste --
I got the beef soondubu, which didn't blow me away but hit the spot. I ordered it spicy, because as my Korean friend says, if it ain't spicy, it ain't soondubu. The soup seemed to be more onion than tofu or beef. My friends also ordered soondubu (chicken and seafood) as well as the dolsot bibimbap. The bibimbap was good, nice crispy rice on the bottom, but then again, it's pretty hard to screw up bibimbap. 

The banchan wasn't anything to write home about. They had the basic dishes -- fish cake, kimchi, bean sprouts, broccoli, and shredded potato. My favorites were the shredded potato and the fish cake. 

0.5/1  Stars for Value -- 
OK, the price (and selection) of Korean food in SF is just ridiculous. It was $10.99 for most dishes (for dinner), which is decent. I know other places charge over $13 for soondubu, which is just heinous. My tofu did come with rice, but my one qualm is that it didn't come with raw egg. YO. The egg is an integral part of my soondubu experience! 

One of the more ridiculous prices I saw was kalbi for $16.99. Seriously? I'm better off making it at home. Anyways, I would recommend coming to check this place out at lunch time, where the portion sizes are the same but the prices are $2-3 cheaper.

1/1 Stars for Customer Service
Our waitress was awesome. After she took our orders, she repeated them back to us to make sure there were no mistakes. She kept our hot tea refilled (served in glass cups, what's up with that?), and didn't give us any attitude when we asked for more banchan. 

We were a party of 4, but one of our friends turned up 30 minutes late, while another showed up unexpectedly. The waitress took everything in stride, and even brought over an extra chair for our extra friend. If I had to have one complaint though, I would say that the food service is kind of slow, with dishes coming over 10 minutes apart. Lots of banchan eating while waiting for friends' dishes to arrive.

No bonus star because I probably wouldn't come back to Manna. If I'm craving Korean food again, I'll just hold out until I go back to the South Bay to get my fix.
author: Abby W.

description:
Have been wanting to try Manna since seeing the lines of people and the positive reviews on Yelp.  Small, clean, restaurant on a busy Inner Sunset street corner.  Popular area .. A movie crew was filming down the block making traffic and parking even more challenging on a Saturday.  Lunch is cheaper week days.

As for the food, we had Dol Sot Bi Bim Bop, Chapchae, and Spicy Pork.  The flavors were all on point and prices representative of the Inner Sunset area.
