The only gripe that I have is that the Beef in the Bi Bim Bop and the Pork in the Spicy Pork were all in small shreds and not in larger grilled pieces.  Why such small shreds?  Unless you're trying to turn over tables faster and smaller pieces of meat cook faster.  I like to chew , thus give me bigger pieces of meat which I am used to from other Korean restaurants.
author: Scott L.

description: I came here on a Wednesday night thinking it wouldn't be crowded, but I was wrong. They started prioritizing to go orders over people that were here. FYI . And I waited like 1 hour for my food.
author: Jacky S.

description:
Awesome place...regular...all are delicious. Had the following
Beef sundubu, jabchae, Kalbi, dolsot bibimbap, kampoongi
author: Richard C.

description: Good quality Korean food but restaurant is tiny so be ready to wait outside in the chilly inner sunset climate. Prices are really good for the area and interior is clean. The owner guy seemed kind of upset we left so much food leftover but we had ordered too much. I'd come back here again, the food was cheap and delicious which is why we waited 45 min for a dinner on Sunday.
author: RachEl L.

description: The food is really good but finding parking is such a hassle. Unless you are ubering or live walking distance, it's not worth spending money for parking and not have a seat because it's always full and extremely small. Besides that, worth trying!
author: Mai Bee H.

description:
Gotta say, this place is not as good as it was when it first opened.  I can't quite put my finger on it but I think they are just using lower quality ingredients.  The bugogi meat is thinner and has more onion/meat ration that before.  Other ingredients like the seafood just seem like they are lower quality that other Korean restaurants.  

Dishes like the scallion pancake and bi bim bop are still pretty tasty, but they could be more generous with the meat in the bi bim bop too.
author: M S.

description: This place satisfied my cravings for some Korean Food. Highly recommended and definitely coming back when we're in town.  The price is worth it and good portion. Had the Bibimbop, which tasted the same as what I'm looking for.  Their Ramen soup is good and satisfied my daughter.
author: Anna Liza C.

description:
Delicious tofu soon doobu! I'm one of those people who LOVE spicy food. I got the very spicy tofu soon doobu with vegetables instead of meat and it is completely delicious. Ive had plenty of soon doobu that lacked depth of flavor but this one was fantastic. I've been craving the spiciness since! My friends had the vegetable bibimbap with egg as well as the pork soon doobu with medium spiciness. They both enjoyed theirs thoroughly as well. 

I recommend this place for authentic Korean food and you will not be disappointed! Although if you enjoy quality service, this may not be your place. We asked our waitress for refills on side dishes and to split the check 3 ways and she didn't say a word. She also slammed down our side dishes once we received them.
author: Nina I.

description:
After passing by a lot because of the long line I usually see outside, I've eaten here twice now for lunch and gotten take-out once. It's best to come right as they open so you don't have to wait. The food is so filling and affordable! Especially if you come here during the week for lunch time and can order from their lunch menu which consists of about half of their regular menu, but a dollar or two cheaper. Hey, a penny saved is a penny earned, and it all adds up!

Eat-in or take-out, the quality is great! Their fried chicken is great. Kimchi fried rice and bibimbap is amazing. And I really love their savory-sweet deokbukki dish (the royal one). I haven't tried their spicy one because the people that I've eaten with can't really eat spicy, but if the royal one is delicious, I'm sure the spicy one will not disappoint either!

Although it's kind of a small restaurant, they manage to jam in a lot of tables. It might leave a lot to be desired in elbow room, but the amazing food and great service makes up for it!
author: Courtney S.

description: This was the first time.  :)   The restaurant was not so spacious or fancy but I was so glad to experience an original Korean tastes and very friendly service as well.  All staffs are very responsive, kind and nice.  I want to go there again pretty much soon !! :)
author: Chris H.

description: Wings and seafood pancake is good. Next time I'll try their kimchi pancake. Service is good. Small cozy place. Overall I enjoyed it.
author: Christy V.

description:
Food: the food is fast and tasteful! We ordered  tofu soup and dok bak ki, and both of them are wonderful! There is free rice (come with the soup) and appetizers (you can refill them!), and the whole meal is just enjoyable.

Service: might be a little bit slow, because the store is super packed and busy, however, the servers did their best to encounter us as kindly and friendly as possible

Environment: a little crowded, but not to the point where everyone is crashing all together. Overall the atmosphere is pretty relaxed and and the store is not super noisy.
author: Vicky G.

description:
I came here for dinner with a friend before Night Life at Academy of Sciences! We were seated prompty and the menu is already tucked under the glass on the table so you can order quickly.

It is a small restaurant so it could be a little squishy. They have a table right next to the refrigerator where they store beer and soju. I can't imagine how cold the guests are everytime they open it. 

Prices for food is fairly cheap. I ordered Dukbokgi(correct me if that is the wrong name). It is basically cylindar ruce rolls with fish cake in red spicy korean sauce. It's one of my favorite korean dushes especially since i love rice rolls. Korean rice rolls are extra chewy which i like. It came with a bowl of rice with no extra charge! Usually at other places, they charge extra for rice. 

Note: the bathroom is a little small. They sure know how to use every inch of their small restaurant wisely!
author: Allie Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean spots right in the Sunset District on Irving! The usual things I order is the bibimbap either the veggies or the seafood cause they are just great tasting. Also I order the seafood pancake, but the only thing is that it is oily and it makes me feel sick after and I think that it is well worth eating there to be honest haha. They have a good variety to order which is amazing to try!

One con thing is that they try to rush you.. I really disliked it because they were trying to pack our pancake when we were still eating and I think that you shouldn't push a table to leave when they aren't ready when..you see people waiting cause we were the ones that got there first.

Worth the try!
author: Brittany L.

description:
I'm not gonna waste your time, I'll jump straight to the food, because chances are that's what you're here for...

omg their Kimchi - the perfect balance of heat and funk, salt and crunch - I kinda just want to buy a giant bottle of their kimchi and bring it home with me.

Other notable standouts ... kimchi pancake, jabchae, dae ji bul kogi. The tofu soups smelled so good too. Definitely will be returning next time and getting that as well!

All meals come with tea, rice and an assortment of your typical Korean side dishes, including the famous kimchi, bean sprouts and broccoli.

Very cheap. Most items on the menu are less than $10. The portions are actually really huge (lunch portions are a little less). 
Very well decorated, great ambience, wait can be a while though.

You will find me returning, I'm a happy camper.
author: Xin W.

description: Came this restaurant last night and would have to say that I am very impressed. Fairly small and cozy restaurant. We got the jeuk bokkem (didn't have too too much meat in it as I would expect it too which was sad but flavor was great), pork tofu soup, and their kkangpponggi wings. All three dishes came out to about $37 and I was super surprised at how fair the price was. Service was awesome and food was great!
author: Monica L.

description:
Had dinner here on Father's day. It's a small restaurant with quite a long line of people queuing up to get a seat. 

Service:
- Being a very busy restaurant with only three people managing orders, cleaning & setting tables and doing billing, it can get difficult to get seen (we had a corner table). We had to put a lot of effort flagging someone down for our order, though it was frustrating to see the other tables who came in later having their orders taken in first. 
- One of our dishes came in really late. We thought that they had forgotten about the bulgogi my bf ordered as my mom and I were almost finished with our dishes by the time it came in. Again, had a hard time flagging someone down.


Food:
Japchae- It was sweet, had a bit of veggies and pieces of beef on it, but it was unfortunately very bland and oily. It looked very different from the other yelper pictures as the japchae we had did not come sitting in sauce.

Beef bulgogi- very dry and hard to eat. 

Galbi Tang- I loved how there were a lot of greens in this dish and a whole egg! The beef was tasteful though it wasn't very soft. The soup was just ok in my opinion. 

Pork bulgogi- I can't eat spicy food so I didn't get this. But it was apparently quite spicy and my mom liked it.
author: Francesca C.

description: One of my favorite Korean spots in San Francisco! Small and cozy place for a nice dinner for 2 to 5 people. Some of my favorites are the tofu seafood soup, Kalbi juicy bbq beef short ribs, and seafood bibimbop. Everything always tastes so fresh and the service is excellent!
author: Nadya G.

description: Love their soft tofu soup, their dol-sot bibimbap and their soy sauce chicken wings. Always satisfy my korean food cravings and their customer service is always on point, even though they are always super busy.
author: Becky Mae A.

description:
MANNA Mia, here I go again. 
My My, how can I resist you?

I came here with a friend for lunch and I left feeling like I visited my grandmother's house and just had the best, warm, and most loving meal ever. 

First off, lunch prices are cheap - well worth your money. I was shocked at how cheap the meals were, considering the portion size and how fresh the food tasted. 

I ordered the Soft Tofu Soup with Beef and it was delicious. You can't really go wrong with Soft Tofu Soup, but I felt like Manna's soup was full of flavor and hit the spot. The side dishes were just as good.

I love how simple the restaurant is. It offers solid and affordable Korean food with good service. Place is a bit cramped and small, but I was too busy enjoying my meal to be bothered by it. 

Thankfully, my friend and I didn't have to wait to be seated, but I'm not surprised why there's usually a wait for this place. 

I will for sure want to come back again!
author: Kristal D.

description:
TL;DR - Best korean food that I've had in SF.

Oh wow, I think I finally found some solid competition for han il kwan and its tucked away in this unassuming little joint. 

I love kbbq as much as the next person, but it doesn't quite hit the spot for the ultimate comfort food. (Probably because the guys prefer to gorge themselves on AYCE and I just can't hang haha)

Anywho. Why is Manna better than Han Il Kwan? The wait moves FAST. I think because HIK also serves HUGE parties and kbbq, the wait time is totally ludicrous.

We started off our night with soju bombs (I know, class right?) 
Next, we hit the galbi, seafood pancake, yukgaejang and the dolsot bibimbap.

This place definitely fills the empty void of LA's ktown for me.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Very good korean cuisine,  highly recommended. Prices are very reasonable,  feels like I am in Soul, south korean restaurant, very authentic and delicious.
author: Marina M.

description:
Manna is the place I go to for my Korean food craving. It's a small place on the corner of 9th and Irving that seats about 15 people. 

Because of the lack of tables, the wait for Manna is very long. For instance, a party of 2 on a Sunday night at 7:00pm is 1 hour. A part of 2 on a Tuesday night at 7:00pm is 1 hour or more. Because of this, I'd recommend anyone wanting to go to Manna to be prepared for a wait or to come in at more odd hours of the day. 

In terms of food, the quality is great and most dishes range from $10-15. They will serve you 5 side dishes consisting of broccoli, kimchi, bean sprouts, white radish, and fish cake. The food comes out steaming hot and very quickly. The most popular dishes here seem to be the bibimbap (in the stone pot) and the kimchi pancake, although I doubt you can go wrong with anything you pick here. I've also tried the seafood tofu soup and it is superb - They didn't crack an egg in it as many other Korean restaurants do. Maybe you have to ask for it?  

Service is professional and efficient. They refill your water frequently and without prompting. Barley tea is free. They do try to turn tables quickly and this is probably not the place to go if you want to take a leisurely lunch.

Overall, this is an awesome place for Korean food. Come here at the odd hours or early evening (definitely before 7pm) to avoid a long wait. Order the bibimbap in the hot stone pot. Prices are reasonable in the $10-14 range.
author: Nicole J.

description: We've only had a few deliveries from here until today and the place did not disappoint. Food is great (we knew that from their deliveries and their packaging) and service was friendly and prompt. Will definitely come back (or get delivery) for sure.
author: Karen H.

description: The kal bi was the best I've had since living for a month in ktown in LA.  Tons of things on the menu that I will be back for.  We came on a Thursday night and hardly waited at all.
author: Shannon S.

description:
HANDS DOWN THE BEST KOREAN FOOD IN SF!!!

I've been going here for years, needless to say there is no other better option elsewhere! 
This restaurant is a small little family owned business and it's definitely authentic as it can get!
The lines get pretty long over the weekends, but I would not suggest coming here with more than a party of five, since its a rather small restaurant. 

These are my favorite dishes at Manna! ( Not in order )

1. Soft Tofu Soup w/ beef ( Spicy ) #12 ; The soup is just the right amount of spiciness for someone who enjoys a kick for their taste buds! The soup comes out pipping hot in a small black pot, accompanied with a side of rice. Easily, the best tofu Soup I've ever had. Extra charge if you want to add an egg. 

2. Dol - Sot Bibimbp w/ Beef #9 ; A must have, especially for those who are super hungry. The portion is ridiculously huge! Comes in a hot pipping stone pot, accompanied with a bottle of korean spicy sauce to mix the rice and veggies together. 

3. Kanpoongki #5 ; These chicken wings are literally the perfect combination of sweet and salty! The are ridiculously delicious and layered with lots of sauce! Great sharable item with friends! Get the wings, you will not regret! 

4. Korean Seafood Pancake #27 ; The seafood pancake is pretty standard as far as flavor goes. It's a rather large portion, so great item to share or even as an appetizer. 

5. Kalbi #1 ; Great portion size, as far as flavor it was just the right amount of sweetness, however I  wish the onions were carmelized more for flavor. Overall, if you are a big fan of ribs, this might be for you!  

6. Dai Ji Bul Kogi #3 ; Really good Spicy Pork!! However, I wish it was more spicy, but if you want just a kick of spice, this would be a great option. 

Overall, this is one of those places that you will never get tired of going to because it's just that great. The side dishes that come with the meals are seriously good! Also the owner is super friendly! I will forever be a fan of Manna!!
author: Lydia L.

description: Dropped by Manna for a late lunch on a Sunday and was lucky enough to grab the last table for two before a line formed out the door! We ordered the kimchi panckae, vegetarian soft tofu stew, and the spicy rice cakes. It was a bit of a logistical nightmare once all the food got to the table, but everything was super delicious! The kimchi at this place wasn't as fermented as I usually like so the pancake didn't have that tangy/tart taste to it that I love. However, it was crispy on the outside without being oily which was much appreciated. The soft tofu stew was great, particularly since it was a really chilly day, and the spicy rice cakes were absolutely perfect. They had a good amount of spice without being overwhelming and were cooked well so that they were chewy, but still had a good bite to them. Overall, this is a solid Korean food place to go to in the city, particularly if you are looking for vegetarian options!
author: Lakshmi M.

description: Oh man, Bibimbap and hot tofu soup. So good! This is a little place without frills or finery. The menus are fixed under the glass of the table, and there are only a few tables with little room. However, people come here for one thing, great Korean food. The prices are very reasonable. After going to another korean place nearby and paying nearly $20 for bibimbap with meat I was very happy to see a hot stone bowl bibimbap for $13. Can't wait to come back here and try more of their menu. The table next to us ordered the chicken wings and I almost reached out to grab one they looked so good.
author: John W.

description: Love this place! Main downside is that it's quite small - I think they seat like 26 total - so during busy times there can be a wait. That's a big part of the reason why it took me so long to try this place out... However, the food is great! The lunch specials on weekdays are a great deal. I love their seafood pancake and stone pot bibimbap; they're both consistently great. Food generally comes out fast and piping hot, and the staff here are very friendly and do a good job of checking up on you every now and then.
author: Delia Z.

description:
Solid spot. Haven't been disappointed in anything I've ordered so far. I LOVE grabbing takeout from here to avoid waiting for a table in their small space. Each one of their menu items come with rice and sides when your order takeout.

Personal favorites: 
+ any of the Dol Sot Bibimbaps
+ any of the tofu soups
+ Gal Bi Tang (my go-to for hangovers)
+ any of the pancakes
+ pollack stew
author: jolie L.

description:
Unfortunately, it's one of the best Korean food in SF. But god forbid that you have a table that they want when there's a wait outside. They'll deliver all the delicious food to your table, only to come back five minutes later to take everything away to box without asking. 

Might be better off just ordering take out cause you're pretty much doing it anyway but have to tip for the illusion of table service.
author: Tina W.

description:
My super rad friend Riana took me here because we're basically food soul sisters and she highly recommended it. It certainly did not disappoint! 

The restaurant is fairly small so you may have to wait depending on what time you get there. I suggest standing by the door and inhaling all the delicious smells while staring people down, making them nervous so that they'll eat faster and make room for you. 

Everything we got was on point. The fried dumplings were possibly the best I've had. Everything was also boiling hot. My soft tofu soup (w/ chicken) was the right amount spiciness (medium) and full of flavor. We also got an appetizer of the sweet and spicy chicken wings because we were convinced that we needed that much food. We took most home because we were too full, but they were the perfect amount of crispiness and flavor.
author: Kelly G.

description: Love this place! I always love bringing new people here and every time I get back into the city I have to visit. I once dined in and ordered more to go lol. I think that says something
author: Mayna H.

description:
This place doesn't need another five star review since it's already so well liked.. But I just thought I would put in my two cents as well. This my FAVORITE korean restaurant. Hands down. The servers and owner are incredibly polite and friendly which I love. The food is amazing-- I've never had a dish here that I didn't like. Their banchan is really flavorful and I'm in love w/ the fish cake! 

Things I've tried: 
-Soft tofu soup (beef/seafood): Seafood is my personal favorite. I order it mild and its the perfect amount of spice for me. It's SOO flavorful and they don't skimp on the seafood either. Comes with mini clams, squid, etc. Perfect for a cold evening. 

-Japchae: Comes w/ beef. Super flavorful and not too salty like some other places. Would recommend.

-Kimchi Fried Rice: w/ beef and a fried egg. The best kimchi fried rice in SF without a doubt. Soooooo good I can't even describe it LOL. It does have generous amounts of kimchi though :-) 

-Chicken wings: comparable to san tung. Crispy. Covered in that semi sweet brown sugar(?) sauce. 
 
-Duk Bok Ki: Rice cakes w/ spicy sauce. Chewy. Spicy. BOMB... 

-Bibimbap: this one is pretty standard. LOL. Probably the only thing here that is standard.
author: Marny N.

description: Ugh best naengmyeon (cold noodle) I've had in awhile!! The broth is so tart and flavorful and the egg is well cooked. The noodles aren't stuck together and they cut them for you so it's easier to eat. Don't be intimidated by this if you've never had it before, it's so worth the jump out of your comfort zone!
author: Sam L.

description:
Great lunch specials! Everything priced around $10, and a ton of food for the price. 

Three of us shared seafood pancake, dolsot bibimbop, Kalbi, and soft tofu soup. Banchan and barley tea arrived right away (complimentary) and shortly after everything else. And wow, every single thing we got was yummy! My only complaint was that the squid in the seafood crepe was a little chewy, but the flavor was excellent. We had so much food we took leftovers home ( always good to have lunch for tomorrow, right?)

Service was friendly, quick and efficient (this is a busy place.)

This was a great choice for lunch!
author: El B.

description:
The roommate and I ordered delivery on Sunday, May 31st around 5:45pm. We decided to try DoorDash since the first order is $1 for delivery. (Prices below are what I paid through DoorDash.)

*Bibim naengmyeon: cold buckwheat noodle mixed with spicy sauce ($9.50)
I'm not a huge fan of cold noodles, but the roommate seemed to enjoy this.

*Kalbi: juicy tender bbq beef short ribs ($14.95)
Great price for kalbi. It was good. Had a nice smokiness and sear.

*Kanpoongki: sweet & spicy chicken wing ($10.50)
I was not a fan of this at all. The sauce made the wings super mushy.

*Nakji bokum: sauteed small octopus & vegetable with spicy sauce ($13.95)
Good, but there was too much sauce in the container. It ended up leaking all over everything.

*Seafood soft tofu soup: seafood soft tofu soup with rice and assortment of side dishes ($10.50)
Subtle spice. I wanted something soupy so this hit the spot.

*Soy sauced chicken wings ($9.50)
Way better than the kanpoongki. Was crunchy and had a nice savoriness to it.

The two wings, octopus and kalbi all came with bean sprouts, broccoli, fish cake and kimchee. I enjoyed the side dishes. We also got a takeout container of rice and side dishes that came with the soup. Plus we got 4 sides of rice! I liked that they didn't skimp on the banchan and rice.

Other than the kanpoongi, I really enjoyed the food here. Plus, the prices are great. I'm used to paying $20+ for kalbi. Even more for delivery. Great place for Korean food when you're too lazy to leave the house.

Note: I got a compliment from someone that works at Manna saying DoorDash marks up their prices by 20%. Not sure if this is true as I've never seen a current menu from Manna, but I did do some price comparisons on other restaurants and it looks like they do mark up prices. Regardless, my review is for their food, regardless of price. In fact, I thought their kalbi was still cheap!
author: Elena N.

description:
Generous portions, affordable prices, and authentic Korean food!

Came here on a Saturday around 5 pm for dinner with some friends. There was surprisingly tables available. I've passed by Manna many times before but never was able to get a spot to eat here because it was so crowded that I had gone somewhere else to eat. 

We ordered the Dol-Sot Bibimbap, Royal Court Duk Bok Ki (Cause these people I was with couldn't handle spicy food), and seafood Korean Pancake. The food was okay, I've been to many Korean restaurants and the food was pretty good and the prices were fairly cheap. The dol-sot bibimbap was my favorite! You can taste the flavors when it was mixed together. The food was authentic and the staff were friendly.The side dishes came maybe maybe 10 minutes after we ordered. Usually they come right when you are seated. 

Definitely will be back!
author: Jeanette Q.

description: Nice small place next to golden gate park. The vegetable bibimbap was really good. The wait can be a little long since there are not many tables inside but it is worth it if you have the time.
author: Alex C.

description: i've been coming here since high school and i still think this is one of the best korean restaurants there is in sf. the place is very small so there's always a wait. everything i've had here is good haha. the pricing for food is pretty decent and i doubt you will leave this place with a complaint haha. i always get the tofu soup and kimchi fried rice. i feel like their kimchi fried rice has changed over the years but i can't seem to put my tongue on what has changed. the same guy is still running the place though ahaha. always ask for water because they usually give you just tea at the beginning. overall i would still wait here to eat haha
author: diane d.

description: After extensive research for a korean spot in the san franini area, I came across this with one $ and a 4.0 rating. Me and my jigaes got there pretty early around 6pm. We got a table immediately, which we soon found out was extremely lucky. Within five minutes, there was almost a whole page filled up with names for a waiting list. We saw people hovering and waiting through the window outside. This made me quake, I just knew it was gonna be good. The place was so real, people yelling in korean, the waitresses hustling and bustling around, trying to get to everyone and tend to them before they flipped out. People were cramped together and it was sooo tight but who cares. We ordered the beef bibimbap, some bulgogi pork, dukbokki, and kimchi panqueque. They brought the banchan, my favorites being the broccoli and fresh as pucc kimchi. I was shaking waiting for my impending feast. The bip came out in no time, and we attacked. We squirted some sauce on and got to it. The bip...was but a dream. Everything about it...amore. Next up, the dukbokki. This was subpar, the rice cakes were hard, there was so much sauce, idk. Comin in hot fresh out the kitchen was the pork. The real star of the show here was the kimchi pancake. I repeat...the kimchi pancake***!!! This is such a pregame for my soon to be trip to korea, i just love it.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Solid Korean BBQ, great lunch specials, and decent service. 

The Line: not horrible for lunch. We came around noon on a Sunday and only waited 10 minutes for a group of 2. 

The Food: I found it delicious and relatively affordable, despite the Korean lady complaining to her SO how unauthentic the tofu stew is. We ordered the spicy BBQ chicken, bulgogi (BBQ beef), and jap chae (yam glass noodles) and got two bowls of rice/barley tea/pickled veggies (banchan) for as complimentary items. The spicy chicken wasn't that spicy but was delicious, the bulgogi was authentic enough (to my hangry Chinese girl taste buds), and the jap chae was amazing but IMO a bit low on the beef. The kimchi was really really good. 

The Service: they were pretty good about refilling our banchan but the waitress accidentally forced my guy friend to pay for my meal by taking the bill before I slapped my CC down. Awkward but understandable. Asian girl + Asian boy at Asian restaurant = must be dating! ;) 

Overall, it was a great meal. Thanks Manna!! I am becoming more and more obsessed with Korean food.
author: Diya L.

description: Great Korean BBQ at a great value. Good service, got a table immediately even though place is busy. Will be back for sure.
author: Ryan K.

description:
After going to the De Young Museum one evening recently, a friend and I were hankering for something to eat. I remembered Manna had been on my restaurant radar screen for a long while, and we decided to check it out. One of the staff said that we would only need to wait around 5 minutes for a table, and he was right on the money! We were seated promptly and given some hot tea.

We decided to order the beef and vegetable bimbimbap and the jap chae. The service was fairly quick as we expected. And they were kind enough to replenish our banchan when we devoured them. I think they even refilled our tea about 3 times. Thanks! :)

I would say that this is a solid Korean restaurant if you're in the hood. We definitely had plenty to eat to satiate ourselves, and I would likely come back to try their seafood pancake and bulgogi.
author: Evelyn K.

description: This place definitely not a good place for baby. If u have to bring your baby with stroller, I will say don't go to this place. They don't like to see the stroller and ask you put your stroller on the street where is outside the restaurant with impolite attitude ask you to do that. I don't understand why they can ask customer to put their stroller on the sidewalk. Also, we mention that we have baby, but they still let us sitting in front of the door(it was so windy). Because that my bay got sick after we got home. Not recommends this terrible place.
author: Ja W.

description:
Right around the corner from the California Academy of Science, and it's literally situated at the corner of Irving so you get a nice view of the neighborhood. 

After tasting a number of Korean restaurants around The City and other part of the Bay Area (ranging from Tofu house to Korean BBQ), I'd say their style is comparatively more homemade. I ordered a  (soybean based soup) and it was the perfect amount of flavor for me.

My boyfriend ordered Kimchi fried rice, which I took a few bites from. I loved the egg; it was perfectly between being sunny side up and medium done. One thing though, I personally thought they put too much sesame oil. It was so obvious every bite. Maybe it's to keep the stir fried rice moist?... I did like how moist (not dry) it was.
author: Lucy L.

description:
One of my favorite Korean places in the city- can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review! Prices are affordable and the quality of the food is great and it's always consistent. I typically get the stone pot bibimbap ($10.99) and always comes out sizzling with my rice crispy to perfection. I also love the beef tofu soup ($9.99).

Banchans typically include: (shredded) potatoes, kimchee, bean sprouts, fish cake, broccoli
author: Lauren K.

description:
Whenever I crave Korean food that's not Korean BBQ, I think of coming to Manna. It's a small place with only a couple of tables so expect to wait awhile during busy hours! I came here recently around 8:30 on a Friday but luckily didn't have to wait. Maybe because it was the day after Thanksgiving. 

Every dish I've tried from here is tasty. Soo far my favorite dishes are the seafood tofu soup & the kimchi fried rice. They give you a good portion for a reasonable price. Their complimentary appetizer dishes are great to eat with your meal & they're unlimited! 

One issue I have with this place is how clean they are. When I received an empty glass, there was something on the inside & outside that I had to wipe off. Double check your utensils & glasses before using them!
author: Yen V.

description:
beef soup was really good
octupous was chewy:)
author: Diane W.

description: My go-to place for soft tofu stew. The food here is amazing and the staff are kind too.
author: Annie C.

description:
Delicious, inexpensive and cozy place.
Manna is a hidden gem in the sunset district. Small place, very busy where you have to write your name on the list and wait outside.
The service is prompt and polite.
The menu has a lot of options and the prices are very good.
We ordered the bibimpap, fried rice, kimchi pancake, chicken wings ( spicy) and they all tasted delicious.
The ramen soup is delicious and spicy as well ( had it last time I was there)
The drinks menu is very limited with sake and beer but does the job.
The place gets crowded and the tables are small but the politeness of the waitresses, the owner and the delicious food overshadow that:)
Great job Manna!
author: Junior V.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night around 6:30 and there was no wait! The food here is pretty decent and the staff there is really attentive and friendly! We got:

Seafood spicy tofu soup - pretty decent and medium spicy was the perfect level for me! 
Seafood pancake - not too doughy, decent amount of seafood, good dipping sauce, and good portion for 3 - 4 people
Bulgogi - Really juicy and well marinated
Japchae - I think this was my favorite dish out of everything we ordered! Super flavorful and not super oily like other japchae I've had at other Korean restaurants
author: Winnie T.

description:
Went to Manna by chance as the bf and I were trying to go to San Tung but alas, they're closed on Wednesday! 

Our feelings of disappointment were quickly dashed as we stumbled upon Manna. 

We arrived around noon and sat at a table of our choice. The menus are conveniently displayed on the tables and complementary hot tea is brought out.

We went with the Soy Sauced Chicken Wings and the Kim Chi Fried Rice. Both great choices! The chicken is fairly tender, the breading is super crispy and the sauce is sweet and salty. The fried rice was delicious as well! It's more wet than I've had and kind of had a seafood flavor that I couldn't quite place. Affordable prices. The only thing I had issue with was the banchan dishes. I would have liked to have had more dishes, but there were only four: kimchi, fish cake, bean sprouts and broccoli. 

I wish I lived closer to try more dishes! I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Dorothy L.

description: This is probably about the best Korean you can get in SF. It is not saying too much, as good, legit Korean food is scarce in SF, but it is a great place where you can get mul or bibim naengmyun (cold noodles) on a hot day like yesterday - although they could've added a few meats into it, like a few pieces of beef. The dolsot bibimbap is good too with a heavy dose of all the ingredients from bean sprouts, spinach, carrots, beef, etc. I also got the bulgogi and galbi here before, and the portions are fairly large. It is nothing special or unique, but it is an affordable place where you can get some authentic flavors served by a hospitable Korean family.
author: Jin N.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Manna. 

the tl;dr version: I love Manna and recommend it to anyone who's craving Korean food in SF. 

It's a somewhat small corner restaurant in the Inner Sunset. Parking can be a b33zy but it's worth it. It's not an AYCE Korean BBQ but one where you order bimimbap and soft tofu soup - which is what we do. 

The service is great and the food is delicious. I recommend the beef tofu soup and the stone pit bimimbap. 

The price isn't bad either!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
There always seem to be a line here, and I don't really understand that.  Prices are definitely cheap, but the food isn't worthy of lining up for.

The Sweet and Spicy Chicken Wings were good, although you really need to soak each wing up in the sauce, otherwise there's not much taste.  Loved the BBQ Boneless Chicken, probably cause it was the best dish out of all the ones we ordered.  We also had the Cold Buckwheat Noodles in Soup, and I wish we hadn't ordered it.  Perhaps it's just me, but the noodles were slimy and I felt like I was going to choke with each mouthful.  

This is definitely not one of my favorite Korean restaurants.  Plenty of other places that have better Korean food.
author: Karen L.

description: This is my favorite place to get Korean food in SF. My only advice is that they start giving you an egg to drop into your tofu soup. Still at 5/5 for me but you have to ask for the egg currently. Also the kimchi pancake is delicious!
author: Cainen G.

description:
This might be one of the best Korean food I have ever had in San Francisco!

We arrived on a Saturday evening around 530pm and there was a 30 minute wait. The large clear windows made it irresistible to stare at the food of the consumers inside. Once we entered the building, the smell and smoke grazed my face and my mouth started to water.

First, the bon chon was quite limited. I felt that they were a little bland. But at least they set the table with their version of go-chu-jang on the table for me to customize the flavors to my liking. Our group decided to share a seafood pancake and the sweet and spicy chicken. The seafood pancake wasn't grilled long enough so it was a bit soggy and floppy. But there was more than enough seafood to have been sprinkled throughout the pancake and it was both chewy and flavorful. The chicken was extremely appetizing. The batter was at a perfect thickness but it was easy to bite into the meat without it being overbearing. The sweetness level was on point and the spice was mild to my desire. I can honestly say that this is the best fried chicken I have ever had from a Korean restaurant.

I then ordered a beef bibimbop for myself and it was delicious! The meat was very juicy and tender. The vegetables were light with a slight crunch and the runny egg on top was the perfect way to melt all the ingredients together. I ended up asking for more kimchi and bean sprouts to add in! The burnt rice from the hot pot gave the ending of the meal the perfect touch.

I felt like the price was fair and the food was extremely extremely gratifying! I will definitely come back to try everything else on their menu. Or... enjoy the same dishes for the second time!
author: Linda K.

description:
was very good
enjoyed the food good service nice Irving Street restaurant.
Recommned
author: Steven M.

description:
As much as I miss KBBQ in LA, I'm glad to have found some good Korean food in the city.  This place was recommended to me by different people, so I had to check it out to see if they were right.  

It is a small space and the parking situation sucks, but that's just something to expect.  We had a late dinner (later than expected because of the time to find parking), but there was no wait on a weeknight.  All the food was good.  I enjoyed the ban chan, bulgogi, seafood pancake, and dukbokki.  The price point is on point cause it doesn't break the bank and the service is very attentive and friendly.  All in all, it was a very enjoyable meal.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Skip the dolsot bibimbap. It's fairly basic and lacks a flavor punch. Plus the egg is cooked too much to really bring it all together when you break it and mix it up. Sadness.

Soft tofu soup is good, with a nice complexity to the spicy flavor. It lacks a variety of veggies and is pretty much just spicy broth with tofu and a side of rice. I suppose you can make up for that by going to town on the pre-meal bowls of veggies.

Speaking of which, the fish cake one is gooood. I almost stole one from another table after they left. But I didn't :(
author: Andrew R.

description:
Saturday dinner with full house yet good food and Great service!!!  

Food:
-Solid 5 options of pan chan. 
-killer sweet and spicy wings.  Crispy outside and juicy inside.  You get about 8-9 pieces
-bulgugi - this one was okay. We should have ordered the Kal bi ribs instead.  
-rice cake with fish cake (non spicy). - big hit with the kids as they are not spicy.  The sauce is on the sweet savory side. 
- seafood tofu soup. - shrimp, clams, squid w tofu. Mild was more like a medium spicy to me.  I appreciate the shrimps do not have shell. ;)

Service:  They refilled water, tea, Kimchee proactively.  Asked us how we are doing thru out the meal.  THAT is customer service! 

I can understand why the long line waiting outside. ;).
author: May Y.

description:
My friend and I arrived right when they opened on a Wednesday so parking at the meters outside was a breeze. It's a small restaurant, but we were the first customers so we were greeted and seated right away. 

Side dishes included broccoli, radish, fish cake, bean sprouts, and good kimchi. We ordered the beef bulgogi and kimchi fried rice from the lunch menu, which was basically $1 off regular price for each dish. The beef bulgogi tasted good, not too sweet like some other places. 

My main complaint is that after we finished the bulgogi, our fried rice still wasn't out; other tables already got their food while some phone to-go orders were being picked up. What if we had decided to not share the dishes family style? One person would have been eating the entire time while one hungrily watched. If it was going to be a wait for one dish, they could have let us know when we ordered. We were short on time so the waitress apologized and cancelled the fried rice for us.
author: Karen W.

description:
Delicious Korean place. It's a smaller area so I wouldn't recommend large parties. 
I got the seafood bibimbap and it was sizzling hot and perfect for a rainy day.
But coworkers have also raved about the chicken there as well.
One star deducted because they don't take more than one CC per table. I would recommend paying cash.
author: Vince D.

description:
My friends and I tried to go to San Tung next door but that was a no go so we went to Manna instead. The restaurant is not that big either but the wait wasn't too long.

The menu is pretty standard Korean fare. Mostly barbecue and pancake dishes. The small side dishes are there and they're pretty good. I couldn't stop eating the fish cakes! They were flavored so well.

The dolsot bibimbap wasn't bad. The rice was actually burnt properly so I got a lot of crunchy pieces. The meat was a little dry and not that flavorful though.

The kimchi pancake was good and definitely requires sharing.
author: Danielle C.

description: It is worth the wait!! Very amazing food and service! The staff is very friendly. We come here very often and we recommend this place to all of our guest when they come to visit us.
author: Silmarie N. M.

description:
Not for the claustrophobic, this tiny Korean dive restaurant barely fits 20-ish people shoulder to shoulder. Even so, since the food is pretty good here, there is usually a small wait during lunch and dinner hours. 

So far the must orders are:
1) Sweet n Spicy Chicken Wings - perfectly crispy n sticky with just the right amount of sweet and sour - they use big fat wings and always make them fresh. Don't burn yourself! :)

2) Dolsot Bibimbap - Really good flavor especially with the red sauce (Kochujang?). My favorite thing to do is to let the hot stone pot crisp up the rice on the edges and then scrape it off with the edge of the spoon. Mmm.. crunch.

3) Soft tofu soup - this isn't for everyone since you really have to like soft tofu and the korean flavoring of the soup. But for me, nothing beats this on a cold day.

I thought the banchan was pretty good. They don't give you quite as much as the other places in SF, but cmon - do we really need 12 banchan??

Also funny trivia - every time we come here we keep on getting seated at the same table..
author: Henry W.

description: Since my friends and I were in the area, we decided to check out this place especially since we were craving tofu soup.  The restaurant is really small and three of us had to squeeze on to a small table.  It was pretty cramped.  However, the service was okay.  They were very busy the night we went.  I ordered their tofu soup and I thought it was average.  I wasn't too impressed.
author: Mikayla M.

description:
The service for this restaurant is less to be desired. The food is authentic and great, but this review is written for its service specifically. My collection of data is collected over a period of two incidents after going to the restaurant 4 times. 

The first incident happened when we were waiting in line and the restaurant owner crossed our names off without checking to see if we were here or not. I went up to him after my table was given away to someone that was behind us, and instead of apologizing and giving us the table, he said just brushed us aside. We had been waiting here for 30 minutes, only to have our table given away.

The second indictment happened when my friend who had paid for it didn't have any cash at hand to give to the owners for tip. The owner again made a snide remark and request money to be give. 

The last incident is the last draw for me and I refuse to come back here again.
author: Linda C.

description:
This is my favorite Korean place in San Francisco! I came here with a friend for lunch the other day and found out they have lunch specials! The restaurant is rather small but cozy! The place probably have a max occupancy of 20-25 people. I'd recommend coming here with no more than a party of 2 (4 max) if you want to get settled quicker. The place was packed with people when we arrived and we had to wait about 15minutes or so. We were quickly served with water and barley tea. The tea was so good! I've had other barley tea at other Korean places but Manna definitely has the best. 

I went with the beef tofu soup and my friend had the dolsot bimbibap. Both tasted great, but I personally prefer my tofu soup more than the dolsot bimbibap! Their lunch menu consisted of many items and even included bulgogi, kalbi, etc. Their side dishes were also good! Love how they gave us fish for the side dish! Service was great!

My friend love this place so much that she started ordering take out from them. Oh, and they have take-out as well! There are take-out menus right by their register! Will definitely be back!
author: Shanna C.

description: Very tiny but efficiently run place.  The food was delicious and the service was very attentive.  Good value.  Always a line, so be sure to go early.
author: Susan L.

description: This is probably one of the best places in San Francisco that I like. The food the fantastic, fresh, healthy, and warm. It is a truly new experience.
author: Mina R.

description: Manna is a small Korean restaurant located in the Inner Sunset, and both the food and the service here are absolutely amazing. I came here for dinner on a Saturday night with a group of four, and we were seated after waiting for about 30 minutes (as I said, the place is fairly small, but the staff seem to turn things around quickly). The food here is classic Korean--we got to try the deliciously crispy, flavorful seafood pancake, the classic seafood tofu soup, dumpling soup (mandu guk), the seafood dolsot bibimbap, and the stir-fried rice cakes. Of course, there were plenty of banchan side dishes that we enjoyed as well, from the kimchi to broccoli, bean sprouts, fish cakes, and radish. Everything was fresh and tasty (the only dish I wasn't particularly crazy about was the rice cakes, which were a little bland), and the service in particular really stood out. Every time we needed something and called the waitress over, we got exactly what we asked for within minutes. And the value for the food here is unbelievable, especially as the restaurant is located right in the city. If you want some really good Korean food in the Sunset area, Manna is the place to come!
author: David K.

description: Went here to try something new. There was a long wait time, but we did come during peak dinner time. The wait was well worth it. My favorite so far is their spicy rice cakes and my husband loved their pork tofu soup. A smaller restaurant but very friendly staff and delicious food!
author: Sammie A.

description: Went here the second time two days ago and didn't disappointed me; however I felt like this time the wings were smaller than the first time I was here and they were a little over dressed this time. Service is pretty nice, the space is nice and cozy but because of the small space, I felt a little uncomfortable, you can literally see if the person at the next table is staring at you. I look forward to visit again to try more things I'm interested on the menu. I came for the wings and makes me don't want to order it again. But their stuff tasted pretty darn good so I don't mind trying items I want to try on the menu.
author: Siu W.

description: Seating here can be quite a pain (very cramped) and there are usually long waits during peak hours, which unfortunately is the only time I ever decide to come here) but for those who have the patience, this place is definitely worth the wait.  My friends and I have come multiple times and while they usually order something like the bimbimbap, tofu soup, seafood pancake (which is all very good), my favorite thing is their very reasonably priced, and very tasty Kal Bi.  It comes out on a hot sizzling plate and the meat is perfect every time.  It comes with a side of rice and I usually find myself wanting a little bit more than one order (sometimes I go for two) which I'm not sure if it's an indictment on my appetite and gluttony, or their portion size being a tad too small, but the food is good so that's all I care about.  The service is fast and pretty friendly as well so no complaints from me there.
author: Charles H.

description:
Manna is one of the better Korean restaurants around my place! I especially love their ban-chans (side dishes), and it's really the whole reason why I come here... Lollll! Their side dishes are always so fresh and I think they're seasoned lighter than some other ban-chans I've tasted. Also I think they're really good quality and not like the ones at the other Korean restaurants who kinda gives you some leftover tasting stuff. 

But even though I love their ban-Chans, I think their main dishes are just mediocre with the exception of their haemulpajeon (seafood pancake). Their seafood pancake is definitely a star, it's the only pancake I've had in sf that was packed with seafood and tastes like the ones I had while I was living in Seoul. The dipping sauce that came with the pancake was also really tasty and complimented the pancake really well. If there is one dish I think you should try here-- it's definitely the seafood pancake! 

   On another note-- their kimchi jiggae is not to my taste, tasted too fermented.
author: Janet K.

description: This place rules, but for God's sake do not come here the wait is already nuts. Get the bimibab or jabche, but please to go only, don't eat there.
author: Brad E.

description:
What a solid Korean joint!

I got the bibimbap and left feeling satisfied and happy at such a great price! $9.99 for the lunch special 11am-3pm

The banchan were good too. The fish cake is my favorite and it wasn't spicy at all. Plus they had daikon, bean sprouts, broccoli, and kimchee. Despite what other people said in older reviewa the servers were really nice when we asked for refills. Plus they were good with refilling the water/tea
author: Mimi T.

description:
It was a rainy day in San Francisco, so I decided to have some hearty Korean tofu soup. This location size is so tiny, as if you were sitting in someone's dining room. They give you complementary hot tea but you can always ask for water. They have lunch specials!

To start off, they gave us complementary ban chans which had veggies, fish cake, and kimchi. I ordered a seafood tofu soup in mild. It was boiling hot and I enjoyed my soup. They did not cheap out on the seafood in my soup, which made me satisfied. In addition, I ordered a Korean rice cake dish with fish cake and beef. I thought it was okay, could be a little spicer although I did ask for hot sauce on the side to give it a kick. Also, I had the spicy pork dish. The meat was soft and tender which I thought was good, but I was upset because it was NOT spicy at all! Should fix that, but it did come out on a hot skillet which kept the meat hot.

Customer service - Mostly Korean waitresses/servers. They were really nice and refilled our ban chans whenever we asked. 

Overall experience, this restaurant is a great place to get some hearty soup during a cold rainy day. But I can just not compare to tofu soup restaurants in Orange County. I would come here again, but just for the tofu soup.
author: Catherine T.

description: I've been here twice and both times have been pretty good experiences. The food isn't anything super amazing but it's definitely pretty good. The waitresses are extremely friendly and will attend to your needs very quickly. I could see this might become one of my go to spots for Korean food. The only downsides are, the prices for dinner are a little bit more expensive, and the lines can get pretty long at times.
author: Henry H.

description:
Manna is a 20-seat Korean restaurant that had a 25 minute wait for lunch on a weekday. My first thoughts were that either that the food was excellent, or the restaurant was too small. The truth was somewhere in between.
 
My family was fortunate enough to score a table for five. The food was inexpensive. I ordered the vegetable bibimbap for less than $10. Bibimbap reminds of Applebee's sizzling entrees in a way, except with well combined Asian flavors. That kind of crushes my soul, but I won't knock Applebees too much for their effective advertising.

There was a certain fresh-but-savory balance in Manna's bowl that is not so easy to find. It's hard to compare bibimbap to bibimbap, but each bite at Manna felt rewarding.

The service was kind too. We were cramped at the table, and once another table cleared up, the server moved us immediately. 
 
I would return if I were in SF and looking for Korean food. Parking is a nightmare and there will probably be a wait, but those are small prices to pay for consistent, affordable, Korean food.
author: Chris O.

description:
Great KBBQ for a reasonable price! 

THIS PLACE IS A LOT SMALLER THAN IT LOOKS!!! My friend and I came here on a Wednesday. We got here around 6:20pm and there was already a 30 minute wait. There is no space to wait inside so you have to stand outside. The wait time doesn't get shorter, because when we left around 8pm, there was actually more people lining up...Seems like a pretty popular place.

We ordered a spicy pork ($13) and a rice noodle ($9) for two of us. The spicy pork came with rice, and with the side dishes, it was a plenty of food. The spicy pork came grilling on a stone plate, and SMELLED DELICIOUS with grilling onion pieces. It is A BIT ON THE SWEET SIDE, but if you eat with rice, it taste just perfect. The rice noodle came in a big portion. Nothing was too special about it other than the traditional Korean sauce, which is also sweet. IF YOU LIKE SWEET DISHES then this would be the perfect place for you. 

Serving time was reasonable, but the service was eh. The place is pretty popular and the owner knows that too, since it is the one of the ONLY KBBQ in Inner sunset. When we finished they were trying pretty hard to get us to leave. The setting was VERY CRAMMED. If you are claustrophobic, go somewhere else.

Otherwise, food is good. A little bit on the expensive side.
author: Wendy F.

description:
We enjoy going to Manna every so often and think that the people, food, service are all great. We typically have dolsot bibimbap (Hot Stone Bowl) which is a kinda speciality of the house. Its yummy, fiery, steaming hot. You will love it and have that steam coming out of your ears soon. Wash it down with a cold beer. We also enjoy many other dishes including the kimchi pancake, japchae noodles, fried rice and soft tofu soup. Its all good and  if you are ever looking for a Korean place, not too expensive, Manna is the place for you. In short:

People: Awesome 
Service: Prompt
Food: Yummy
Price: $15 to $20 per person
Wait time: Sometimes you'll have to wait for 15/20 minutes, but its totally worth it.
Ambience: Crowded and Packed. Tiny place. But clean and well run.
author: Mark R.

description:
Great neighborhood find.
No other good korean in the area.
Good quality and value, unfortunately too long of a wait these days.
author: karen c.

description:
Perfect Korean place to get your Spicy Tofu Soup, Bibimbap, and Kal Bi BBQ Short Ribs on in the sunset on a chilly night.

Prices are super reasonable $10-15/Entree. 
Tiny by cozy spot for tables of 2-4. 
Flavors are on-point.

I'm a fan!
author: Ellen W.

description: What's better than having Korean when you're starving? Nothing. Korean food is where you can usually get the fullest for the cheapest in SF. Walked in around 2pm almost 3, and it was not super packed but it was pretty much filled. This place was tiny so it didn't seat more than 20 people at most. I ordered the Dol Sot Bibimbap and Soft Tofu Soup in Medium Spicy. The side dishes came first and it wasn't like a lot compared to other Korean restaurants like Tofu House. Manna's prices however, is cheaper. Food came in fairly quick and service was very attentive. Refilled our cups whenever it got low and asked us if everything was okay. The bibimbap was the best part with the goojuchang(spicy-light spicy red sauce). The soup didn't have anything extraordinary, it mainly tastes like the kimchi bowl noodles from Costco but without then noodles. Overall this place is amazing for Korean food, only downside is that it's way too small in here but so it isn't very convenient for groups to come here.
author: Lisa W.

description:
When I first heard about Manna, I was stoked to check them out.  Despite the diverse array of restaurants 9th Ave has to offer, the area's long been without a Korean restaurant (sorry, but Hahn's Habachi doesn't count).  Now that I've finally tried them though, I wish I had a good reason for not trying them sooner!

Really, the consistent line for a table is the only reason I've put off scratching Manna off my bookmarks.  With a menu full of so many tantalizing dishes, it's easy to see why people have been drawn to check them out.  However, after one look at the food as it came out, it was even easier to see why people keep coming back!

-- BANCHAN - Cold Potato Strips, Broccoli, Fishcakes, Sweet Beans, Bean Sprouts, and Kimchi
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?select=1qnYALIc6fxleqrD_qmkgw#3_WA0Uq_KkNej-3KIqjPxw)
Selection was a little light (we only had five beans), but the quality was great.  The fishcakes and kimchi were particularly notable; the fishcakes weren't overly dressed while the kimchi had just the right amount of spice and pungency.

-- FRIED DUMPLINGS with Beef and Vegetables...$7.99
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?select=1qnYALIc6fxleqrD_qmkgw#J64m2q8iocWFYjUxtfuoCA)
As much as I enjoy steamed mandoo, they just taste that much better fried!  The filling was delicious, there wasn't much filler, the skins were perfectly thin and crispy, and they weren't very oily.  Not much to complain about! 

-- DOLSOT BIBIMBAP...$10.99
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?select=1qnYALIc6fxleqrD_qmkgw#jyIbsa5w_rA8F6NDT2avUg)
Just like with the little dish of broccoli, the vegetables were so fresh!  There was so much natural flavor, I didn't even need to add much of the gochujang sauce.  Though it could have used a little more beef, that's also true for any bibimbap...

Although there's likely to be a crowd waiting outside during peak lunch and dinner times, don't get discouraged like how I did.  The wait may look long, but the line seems to move rather steadily.  For lunch on a Saturday, my friend and I only had to wait about 5-10 minutes for a table.

At this point, since I've only tried two things (simple ones at that), I can't quite say whether Manna is a five star joint or not.  However, after I try some of the soups, stews, meat plates, and noodle dishes, I wouldn't be surprised if this gets knocked up a notch.  I guess that means I should go back soon!
author: Mike L.

description:
Service was good cause the food came out pretty fast. Both the appetizers and the entrees came out at the same time. I thought the tea was yummy as well. 

My BF and I tried the soy sauce wings and they're like super amazing! After we finished it, we wanted to order more even though we were full off of one order! I could've just ordered that as an entree instead of getting the tofu soup. I got the soft tofu soup and it's just like every other restaurant so I wasn't much a big fan of it. We also got the regular hot style bibimbob, which was amazing as well (I especially like the crunchy rice part). 

I definitely would recommend getting the soy sauce wings if anyone is a first-timer. Also, it would be good to go early cause there's always a dinner rush and a lot of people wait outside. The place is kinda cramped and small, but that shouldn't be too much of a big deal.
author: Vanessa L.

description: This is my go-to korean restaurant partly because it's walking distance and partly because it's so freakin good!!! Every time I come here, I wait at least 15 minutes max but during the lunch deal it's much shorter. My favorite dish has to be the Jab Chae and the Kal Bi. The Jab Chae is always very savory and has great texture. The Kal Bi is cooked perfectly with enough flavor. Everything is usually very flavorful. I would also like to mention that the Kimchi Fried Rice is also very delicious. However, it is more on the sweeter side than spicy so this kind of threw me off because I love spicy food and expected the kimchi fried rice to be just that. This also goes for the kimchi appetizer, it is much sweeter than spicy. Those are the 3 main regular dishes I order and the main reasons I come to this restaurant regularly. I also love the workers here!! They are all very friendly.
author: Catherine C.

description:
After the horror at Stone Korean downtown, we came back to our favorite Korean in the city. The kalbi and dak bulgogi were great as usual.

We've been here many, many times. It's always great.
author: Rain ..

description:
Awesome little place on the corner! Great food and great prices. It's a small place and is a really cozy little spot best for small groups. There isn't really any table for more than four people so you most likely would have to split up into separate tables if you're bigger than a group of four.

They give you some side dishes such as broccoli, bean sprouts, fish cakes, kimchi, pickled vegetables. The side dishes weren't that great and normally fish cakes are my favorite but I found the fish cakes a little lacking in flavor.

However, the food was excellent. Prices were around $10-$11 a dish which is normally the cheapest you can find for Korean food in the city. We got the kimchi stew, seafood pancake, and pork bulgogi to share. Everything was delicious and we finished everything on our plate. Stew wasn't overly salty or oily. Pancake was crispy and thin. Nothing was burnt. You don't know how many times I've ordered spicy pork bulgogi and had them burn the meat on the side. They gave us two bowls of rice and were very attentive in making sure to refill our tea or bringing us bowls for the stew. The tea was really good too. Or maybe I was just super thirsty. 

I would definitely come again next time to try their other items. Their bibimbap seem to be popular as well.
author: Diana C.

description: Fast and delicious. We got the Dolsot Bibimbop and the Seafood Dolsot Bibimbop and the Fried Dumplings. It took me forever to eat my Bibimbop since the stone bowl kept it so friggin' hot for so friggin' long. I bit the inside of my cheek 3-4 times, burned my finger twice, and then figured out to scoop some on my plate to let it cool a bit so I could eat it. None of this is their fault, of course, just a learning for me for next time...get it in a cold bowl. I wasn't thrilled that the dumplings don't have a vegetarian or seafood option. Finally, there were very few banchan dishes to start...I believe 6. I'm sure that's why it's more affordable here. I wouldn't hesitate to return, though...the flavors were very good.
author: Laurie H.

description: Delicious food on little plates! The Kim-chee was so good and the bean sprouts were done the way my mom use to make!! The atmosphere is quaint and packed on a Friday night! Don't forget to write your name on the waiting list on the back of the front door!!
author: Dolores M.

description: OMG Manna is the best Korean restaurant ever!! This place is packed on almost every occasion, but so well worth the wait. Great authentic Korean food that became most of my friends' first introduction to kimchi fried rice. Seafood pancake, bbq chicken, japchae, spicy tofu soup, all awesome. Owner is nice and waiters/waitresses are all polite. Even if dining is not always the option, I would order to go.
author: Michelle C.

description: Came here for early dinner. Our wait was only 15min, not too bad.  Small place and good Korean food.  We were hoping to enjoy our time and have desserts too, but no dessert menu.  :(    Food is good, give it a try!
author: HQ S.

description: My sister and I are always here!!! I live in the South Bay peninsula and I always make the drive up to have Manna! Their seafood pancakes are to die for!!! The Best combination I've had! Everything tastes super fresh and homemade. The staff is always welcoming and happy to be there! LOVE this place!!! Even if the wait time can be long sometimes - it's worth it!!
author: Philina L.

description: Drool. The food is delicious and the owner is very nice. The restaurant is tiny so I tend to get take out or only go during off peak times. I always get the chap chay, bulgogi, and kalbi.
author: pei c.

description: On the money!  I spent about 3 years doing business in Korea & have become a promoter of the cuisine.  The place is 95% there. The missing bits are based on lack of ingredients which the resturant can not control.  My stone bowl bibinbop was as it should be & the jabchae was from Seoul if you didn't know better. I never had deep fried dumplings in Korea so maybe that was their surrendering to American tastes. Come here & try it. I'm coming back.
author: Leung T.

description:
I am a big fan of Korean food, and I've tried many. Manna is a good one. This place is usually crammed so go early or be prepared to wait. If anything order to go. Their chicken is yummy and so is their tofu soup. Why I give Manna five stars is because many places that order to go do not include side dishes, but a reason why I love Korean food is because of the many choices, that being side dishes. A majority of the time I order to go, so having them include my favorite side dishes for free along with my meal, I feel my money was stretched, unlike other places where side dishes, when ordered to go costs almost an extra $3.

I've tried many types of beef medium tofu soups and I know this place does not have MSG. It's real spices and real flavor. Usually for Korean food, go for spicier. After all, they are known for their love of red pepper, so it naturally would taste better for dishes to have the spice. They have good service and the man who owns the place is nice. Come and eat well!
author: Natalie T.

description:
Manna is one of my favorite Korean restaurants.

They switch up their sidedishes from time to time and are always very generous about refills. Their menu is straightforward and easy to read. Different prices for lunch and dinner. Lunch prices are about $2- $3 cheaper on most items.

The food is never disappointing. I usually order:
(Dinner menu prices)
- Kimchi fried rice ($8.99) - lots of kimchi with a perfect sunnyside eggs. Always a must order for me.
- Bul kogi ($13.99) - average portion size and just enough to satisfy. Meat us always juicy and tender. Ive never received it burnt before. I've gotten burnt meat dishes at several other Korean restaurants before.
- Seafood pancake ($9.99) - although it says appetizer don't be tricked! The pancake is huge. It makes me so happy. Always nicely crispy.
- Tofu Soup ($9.99) - with or without seafood still same price. Perfect on one of those cold sf days aka most days. Comes with a bowl or rice.

Another thing I really enjoyed was the environment. The older Korean man, whom I assume is the restaurant owner, seems to always be very smiley and friendly with his employees. Always a great sign and more than happy to support a business like that!
author: Sarah T.

description:
This is my go to Korean spot in the city. It's cheap during lunch time, and still at a good price for dinner.

The two things I always order when I come here are the kalbi short ribs and the seafood tofu soup. I also enjoy their chicken wings and japchae once in a while. I need to try their dol-sot bibimbap, cause I notice that a lot of people always order it.

The best part of the meal is the banchan (side dishes that are served with korean food). Sometimes I just wanna come here cause I crave for the side dishes.

The service is pretty good here. The servers are attentive. The owner is really friendly and always talks to me for a bit since I always come here.
author: Derek T.

description:
Manna has the best tofu soup ever!!! I come here regularly and the workers all know exactly what I want when I come. That is how good the tofu soup is.
I always get my chicken tofu soup SUPER SUPER spicy. It is REALLY good. The soup is very spicy and always hit the spot.
The price is one of the cheaper korean places I been to. I usually pay about 20-30 for a plate of gal-bi, but there is almost 12 during lunch.
I love Manna and will probably be coming here for the rest of my life. :)
author: Ariunaa B.

description:
I've got pretty high standards when it comes to Korean food (naturally coming from a Korean family), but there are certainly things that Manna does right :)

One of my favorite things would have to be the pajeons, aka those large pancake things. The seafood and vegetable pajeon is delicious. Crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Dipped in the sesame soy sauce provides a great kick of flavor and is definitely a dish I recommend shared amongst your party 

I had the soft tofu soup last I was here, and it was a tad of a disappointment, especially based on the high ratings this place gets. It's a bit average; the presentation makes it look authentic and delicious, but the flavor profile falls just a bit flat. 

The dolsot bibiimbap that some of my friends had got high praise marks, and the fried chicken wings also seemed like a huge hit amongst the group

Also, the place is pretty tough to find parking in so it might be worth making it over via public transportation
author: Jay P.

description: One of my favorite Korean spots in the city! Freshly made entrees with quick service. There can be a wait, especially on weekends! They are closed on Mondays. The pancake dish is my go to!
author: Kerry K.

description: Service was fast and got seated quickly even with a small restaurant. Got the Korean BBQ and the Bimbimbap which was very tasty. Would definitely head back again to try the rest of the menu.
author: Colin F.

description: Went to this place for mine and my boyfriend's first valentines together. It is a very small place so your neighbors are literally less than two feet away but the food was amazing!! We ordered so much and it was just a great dining experience. Since then, we've come back multiple times :)
author: Frances J.

description: This is a great little Korean restaurant. Its located on Irving and parking here can be hard. I recommend bussing or walking if you want to avoid the hassle of parking. We were seated quickly which was nice usually there is at least a 5-10 minute wait but if you go after the lunch rush you should be good. The service is fast and very nice. The banchan was really good it was beansprouts, broccoli, kimchi, fish cake, and potatoes. Everything tasted fresh. I ordered soft tofu soup and my friend ordered kimchi jjigae both were piping hot and delicious. One of the best things about Manna is that it is very affordable for Korean food which can be pricy. All around a great spot but there can be a wait and parking can be a challenge.
author: Charlie H.

description: I went here for the first time just a few weeks ago. We got there right after the lunch time rush and were able to be seated immediately. I tried the Bibimbap and an order of the wings. Both were quite good and had healthy size portions. Will be eating here again and recommend!
author: Andrew N.

description: Best KBBQ in SD hands down would recommend to anyone who wants to try kbbq or even for kbbq vets
author: Matt S.

description: I love their food-! This place is smaller side so it does get packed for busy hours. I can't wait to taste their food next time-!
author: Jang R.

description: This meal was delicious and pretty authentic. On the whole, everything was tasty and the service was pretty good. It was quite busy when I went at 3pm and the eating area is quite small with quite few seats. The waitresses were nice and friendly and the food arrived quickly.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
A few things: this is a REALLY tiny restaurant. Like, tables super close together, tiny. Like, I can see into the kitchen, tiny. Like, I can bring my check to the counter by taking 3 steps, tiny. But don't let that deter you. The food here is deeeelicious!

I've eaten at Manna on two separate occasions. Once on a failed date (didn't like the guy), and again with my now-boyfriend. Both times, the food was yummy! The four stars are only because it's kinda odd that tea is served in water glasses, and the seafood bibimbap was... Err, interesting, but other than that, delicious!!

I'd recommend the chicken wings and kolbi sizzling plate. :) This is a nice place to go for a chill little date. It's not too expensive, the food is good, the service is decent, and you can bounce out to Blackthorn across the street after for a drink. Would come again!
author: Sherilynn M.

description: We always come for dinner or lunch! 7/20/2017 was the first time they have a hair in BQ chicken ! We told the person one in charge and he said it's not my hair' I said it's not my! So he took of the bill. And said he is sorry! He was nice about it
author: Marie W.

description:
Went here for lunch on a Saturday afternoon. It was completely crowded, luckily my bf and I got seated in 10 minutes or so. 

Waitress that served us was quick & friendly. Refilled our teas, gave us water & napkins when we asked. And refilled our ban chan dishes.  

+ legit chopsticks
+ fast & efficient service 
+ love the ban chan 
+ love the tofu soup with beef
+ a great amount of portions 
+ accepts CC 

- hard to find parking 
- small place
- #5 chicken wings were like tonight Soju wings 
- Kim Chee fried rice was decent, but Toyose Kim Chee fried rice will always be my favorite


Not bad, not great. Deserves 3 stars.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
I was feeling sick and wanted some Korean Tofu soup so decided to stop by Manna and get their seafood tofu soup.

It was really the most mediocre tofu soup I've ever had... I had better at fastfood korean places in malls...

I asked for it spicy but it wasn't spicy at all... my friend didn't ask for his to be spicy but it was so I think they may have mixed up the spice level for our orders.

The banchan was decent though...
author: Lily L.

description:
Sigh. I broke my rule in not returning to the same restaurant twice (unless it's on my Re-re-repeat Restaurants list).

But it was worth it for the person I was dining with, especially since some cursed pathogen was crippling her immune system. Some people are worth making exceptions for :)

We were able to catch their lunch special, which runs Tuesday to Friday from 11 AM - 3 PM (except holidays). Since the last time I came, a price of one dish (the soondubu) has increased very slightly: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?select=crF8RdH6Uasoe6jF_SIhdg#crF8RdH6Uasoe6jF_SIhdg

All meals come with a bowl of rice and the highly anticipated set of 6 banchan: fish cakes (favvvvv), black soy beans, broccoli, shredded daikon, kimchi, and bean sprouts.

The carnivore in me has been crying for more attention as of late, so I decided on #2: BULGOGI, a hot plate of juicy, tender BBQ sliced beef rib eye for $8.99 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?select=crF8RdH6Uasoe6jF_SIhdg#aDsqN_jVHgIp02QerH-hRA). The beef is well-seasoned and well-portioned. Thumbs up.

My friend got #22: DAKDORITANG, a chicken stew with mixed vegetables in spicy sauce for $8.99 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?select=crF8RdH6Uasoe6jF_SIhdg#2wSVwcopwc3UVq_hZ2M1NQ). We both were expecting a stew, so imagine our surprise when a plate comes out. It's definitely got a hint of spicy (for those who are spicy-intolerant), and the chicken is kind of tough. I would pass on this.

Recs? The BULGOGI and the DOL-SOT BIBIMBAP.
author: Adele F.

description: Manna has very good food and excellent service. Gets very crowded most nights so expect a bit of a wait if you are not doing takeout. My go to is the bulgogi. And they'll typically make it with chicken if you ask nicely.
author: Jesse D.

description:
This place is DELICIOUS! The only downside is that it is a bit cramped and small so wait times can be long.  The tea that they serve pairs nicely with the food and works well with the spice.  I love having the food come out and seeing all of the spicy red sauces and oils that are about to get in my belly. This place is very affordable, the ban chan is tasty and the portions are quite large. I ordered everything medium spice and I definitely could have gotten spicier. 

Dishes Tried:

Bibimnaengmyeon:  Chewy buckwheat noodles, a sweet-nutty sauce that is also spicy, refreshing cucumber slices and pickled daikon (i think??) and a half a hard boiled egg

Soft Tofu Stew: Really tasty with the silken tofu and lots of pepper flakes, a lovely savory broth with slices of chicken served with rice  

Dukbokki: My favorite dish that I tried here.  I love the chewy rice cakes with the salty slices of fishcakes coated in a thick spicy and sweet sauce.  I believe there is zucchini and chopped kimchi in this as well.  I definitely recommend getting this one.
author: Perri B.

description:
Manna has great food and quick service but the establishment is tiny.

I come here a couple times a year and nothing really changes. Waits can reach up to 20-30 minutes due to its size but quality and service aren't affected.

Their bibimbap is great and their Korean pancakes are a must. Prices are average and I would recommend this place to any person that is a fan of classic Korean food.
author: Junming G.

description: Not much to say that hasn't already been said. The food is good plus I really like how they have a lunch menu. I came by for lunch over the weekend and ordered the seafood bibimbop. So good! I burned my fingers a couple times from the bowl though so be careful of that! It stays hot the entire time.
author: Dara S.

description:
Friday afternoon.
 I was walking down Irving in the Sunset contiplating what to eat when I noticed Manna. It was just across the way.
