I dated a Korean girl last night and boy did we have fun, so I figured "what the heck". I wanted to feel a bit of nostalgia. You can understand that, can't you? By the way...I also noticed a Vietnamese place close but decided against it. Yeah she's on my mind too. Sometimes.
Anyway I'll blog about it if you care. Check out my FB page. Thehumanexperience podcast/FB or better yet this
https://www.facebook.com/The-Human-Experience-Podcast-863975623729660/
For all the right reasons. 
Suzy,
The place is amazing.
Wey
author: Eric L.

description: The place had good seafood tofu soup and lunch special pricing is an incredible deal. The banchan variety is fine. We waited for 15 mins, since the place is fairly small and packed. I'll come back again but definitely expect a wait.
author: Alice S.

description:
Wow. Where do I start? 

The food is amazing. AMAZING. 

The wonderful family that owns and runs Manna is so sweet. They always remember me when I come in. It's probably because I can't eat a chicken wing with chopsticks to save my life, but they graciously hand me extra napkins without laughing. 

The service is great, especially considering how busy they get. Oh, and did I mention the food?!?! I could live off their wings and bibimbap for the rest of my life. 

My boyfriend and I had our second date here and now (two years later) our only real argument is whether to get the sweet and spicy wings, or the soy sauce wings. Tough choices! 

Come early to avoid the lunch and dinner rush, or be prepared to wait.
author: Kat W.

description: Great place for lunch. Portions and the prices are great! Ive tried the beef bibimbap, seafood pancake, tofu soup, kalbi, and kimchee fried rice. All delicious! The place is not very big so sometimes the wait can be kind of long during lunch. Parking is not that easy around here.
author: Vickiiieee V.

description:
Delicious bulgogi and vegetable pancake!
I often get food to go when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Martha N.

description: We had this for our office lunch. The beef was nice, tender, and sweet. I loved the fish cake. First time having Korean food and it was amazing.
author: Cynthia G.

description: The wait here is always so crazy long even when we try coming here "earlier" to beat the rush. I always love getting the dolsot bibimbap here as well as their tofu soup. Because I can't eat spicy food at ALL, most places I go to for tofu soup, the soup ends up just tasting extremely terribly bland because I can't order it spicy. Manna is one of the few wonderful places that actually has flavorful broth to begin with so it actually TASTES like something without having to rely on spice for flavor, which is a big big plus for me! For being in SF too, Manna is pretty reasonably priced and is a favorite for us to come back to all the time!
author: Stephany L.

description:
Their seafood pancake is so good! One of the best I've had. I love their side dishes as well, and I like how clean their seating area and tables are. 

Because the restaurant is at the corner of the street and is surrounded by big windows, the natural lighting during the day nicely complimented my dining experience. Friendly staff that kindly let my friend take some of their tea to-go in her cup.

Would definitely come back for more Korean food.
author: Sara T.

description: This place is pretty good. Had the seafood soondubu and it was flavorful and well priced. Definitely coming back again
author: Jackie C.

description:
I had the dolso bibimbap. It tasted delicious, came at a timely manner, average service, and seated right away. 

The only thing that disrupted me was that, there were people smoking outside, but none of the waiters attempted to close the enterance doors. Infact they kept it open.. unpleasant while eating much!
author: Aya H.

description: My favorite item at Korean restaurants is the seafood pancake, and my go-to entree is the soft tofu soup. Manna's seafood pancake was huge and did not disappoint! The pancake was crispy with big pieces of diverse seafood including squid and oysters spread evenly throughout. I specified medium spicy level for my soft tofu soup and it came out quite spicy, so next time I would get low spicy level. The boy got the dolsot bibimbap, and I liked it a bit better than the soft tofu soup. We felt the pressure to eat and consolidate our many little banchan plates in order to have enough room for all our main dishes (hello, first world problem!). Manna gives very big portions, and the boy and I had enough leftovers for a small dinner at the end of the day after a later lunch at the restaurant. Great casual Korean place.
author: Amy G.

description:
I love Korean food. There is something so comforting about settling down with a sizzling bowl of Dol-sot bibimbap on a cold winter night. It wasn't very cold in San Francisco that night, but I was still wanting a sizzling bowl. Since my daughter and I were going to the Penguins and Pajamas nearby at the California Academy of Science we decided we would grab dinner beforehand rather than eating in a museum cafe. 

There are 3 dishes I can never decide between on a Korean menu Dol-sot bibimbap, soft tofu soup, and a kimchee pancake. Since this was my one shot here, and the prices were reasonable, I ordered both the Dol-sot bibimbap and pancake. 

Manna offers 3 different versions of the bibimbap: traditional beef, seafood, and vegetable. I ordered the vegetable. The man dining at the table next to me ordered the soup and it took everything in me to not ask him if I could try a bite. 

They quickly brought out the food and the bibimbap was delicious. They gave me a squirt bottle of the gochujang, which I always prefer so I can put on as much as I want.

The pancake wasn't the best I've ever had, but I would have polished it off if it had been the only meal. 

The banchan sides were delicious, especially the kimchee which I can polish off pretty quickly.

My only complaint was once our food was delivered we did not receive any service so glasses went empty while trying to eat the spicy goodness. I have also been able to write this review and still have not received a check. Good thing we aren't in a rush.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I've been to Manna about 3-4 times and each time feels the same. Just ok.

Came here for dinner on a Sunday. 5pm, there were still 1-2 tables open so no wait. Service here was a little slow. When we were ready to order, we had to wait about 10 minutes before someone came to take our order. After ordering, we got our ban chan and our orders came shortly after.

All the dishes were good, not enough flavor in my opinion. I also found a hair in my Dok Boki... Not very pleased with this. Waitresses and I assume the owner, were very apologetic when they made a mistake so props to them.

I would only come here because of their prices. They are on the cheaper end compared to most Korean restaurants. But it's hard to find parking here so beware.
author: Benita M.

description: Employees are friendly and they offer great Korean food. Here will be my regularly Korean cuisine for lunch. Highly recommend it if you haven't try it
author: Jasper K.

description:
Still a big fan of this place!!! Came here with 3 of my girl friends and we decided to get 3 dishes and split them all. We ended up getting the beef tofu soup, seafood pancake, and japchae! The tofu soup was pretty standard. Good flavoring but not too spicy! The seafood pancake I think was my favorite dish of the night! I've never tried anything like this so I was surprised when there was actual oysters, octopus, and shrimp in it! I expected them to skimp on the portions because seafood is expensive, but they definitely didn't! It was also fried and crisped up to perfection and served with a type of soy sauce on the side. The japchae was really good as well, a little too sweet if you eat too much though. It's different than normal japchae because it's very saucy, but I liked how they gave a lot of meat and veggies in it too. 

Us 3 girls were pretty full from these 3 dishes (and the side dishes of course!!). Also, never be scared to ask for more side dishes because the waitresses here are very accommodating. They probably won't refill it unless you ask though, so be sure to ask! Same goes for water and tea refills.
author: Tara A.

description: The bulgogi was alright. Was not the sauciest most delicious mouthwatering goodness, but it was okay. The chop chae was good and my boyfriend rather enjoyed the sweet and spicy chicken wings. I wish the sides were more authentic, but were tasty nonetheless. It's a super cute business though and it's run by a family. Gotta love that!
author: Loren T.

description:
This place is great for Korean food in the city. I always bring my friends here when they want some good korean food that's more authentic and not soju bars. 

I always order the kimchi fried rice, soft tofu soup, and kalbi short ribs. Everything has great flavor and level of spicy is always just right for my taste. I also love their banchan (small side dishes) here because they have fish cake! I loveeeee fish cake :)

The only thing that stops me from coming here all the time is the parking. I try to stay away from the 9th and irving area because parking really sucks there especially when you're starving! Other than that.... service and food is great!!
author: Brittany L.

description: This place is very tiny. When I went here, it was raining so my friends and I stood inside and waited to get seated. It was difficult because it was so cramped and people kept coming in and out. The order and receiving process went smoothly. My only issue was that I asked for no cucumbers in my bibimbap, but I still got cucumbers. Other than that, the food and service was great. This place is overall a nice corner restaurant.
author: Ken Francis V.

description: Very tasty korean food especially the ramen bowl and the kimchi  pancake. The place is small yet no waiting. The servers are pleasant.
author: Neha G.

description: Soooooooooo good. Great service-- loved the fish cake in the banchan side dishes. Food was super authentic. I had a sampling of all my friends foods which ranged from different soups to galbi and everything was so good. One of the best korean places I've been. A line started to form around 7pm, and it's a small place, so get there early! Would come back in a heartbeat just wish it weren't so far from me.
author: Y W.

description:
Food (5/5): I got the mandu (dumpling) soup, and loved it!! The broth is light but peppery, and it came packed with huge dumplings, beef, and egg. Perfect comfort food. My bf got the hot stone beef bibimbap, which he really liked. Banchan was also super fresh! 

Service (5/5): Pretty cramped space, which makes it really easy to get a server's attention. Our waters/banchan were refilled frequently.

Value (5/5): At least 30% cheaper than what we've been eating near Japantown, with equal or larger portions. It's a little cheaper for lunch, but honestly their dinner prices are a dollar or two more. 

Our favorite Korean place in the city by far :)
author: Abby S.

description:
This is always my go-to spot to get my Korean fix. It took me a while to write their well-deserved review but here it is! 

The food here is cheap with reasonable portions. They offer complimentary banchan (is that what they're called?) and will refill it upon request! My favorite ones are the fishcakes and broccoli. They also offer pickled radish, potatoes, sweet black beans, bean sprouts, and Kimchi of course. They switch it up sometimes so they might not have all of the ones I just listed. Also, they give you refills on the rice too for when you order the meat or tofu soup!  So if one bowl of rice isn't enough, just ask for another bowl! 

I have tried almost everything on the menu and everything is just tasty. The following listed are a few of my favorites. The seafood pancake is big in size and is packed with seafood. The spicy chicken wings are so tasty. It is crunchy and is coated nicely with their spicy sauce. Mmmm gives me a little chicken wing fix when San tung down the street is busy. I always order the seafood dolsotbibimbap when I get there and I can never finish it! They give you your own bottle of sauce so you can add as much as you want to your liking. The egg is always cooked perfectly. When you mix all the ingredients together in the crackling stone pot, it blends together harmoniously. The occasional crunch from the burnt (not actually burnt) rice.... Errrrmyyygerd! SOOO GOOD. 

The service is great here. The owner always greets you with a smile when you come in. It is a small restaurant so if you come in a big group it may be hard to get seats. 2-4 people is a good amount. There is usually a long wait cause of its small size but it is definitely worth trying out. There's a lunch special menu that you can check out where some of the items are slightly cheaper.
author: Solana T.

description: This place really is as good as all the reviews say it is. I was kind of surprised when I found it rated #1 on Yelp, but I've eaten twice here and it's been notably good both times. Inexpensive, good service, very tasty. Yes, it's a small place, get there early or expect to wait.
author: Fred C.

description:
4.5 stars.

My go-to Korean place in Inner Sunset; close to home. I go a lot.

Authentic food, fast service, pretty efficient.

Show up before the evening crowd, and expect to wait. Also, don't come with over 4 people. There just isn't room. Best for 2 or 4 people.

If there's a line - which there always is on weekend evenings - sign your name on the clipboard on the front door, and wait outside in the cold.

You get boricha, which is a barley tea, as well as unlimited banchan, or side dishes. They usually give mung bean sprouts, kimchi, broccoli, and potato.

My favorite dishes are yukgaejang (spicy beef stew) or galbitang (savory beef stew, but more like a soup).

Generous with the portions; good value for the price.

Lunch combo is an especially awesome deal for $9.99.

When I ask for to-go boxes, the staff (even the owner) boxes the food for me, which is a really nice touch.

I'm spoiled with top-notch Korean food from LA / Seoul / Duluth, so I can't quite give 5 stars. If the inside and waiting experience was more polished (waiting area? online reservation system?), and if the beef was more tender (often kinda chewy), and they had more banchan (I wish they had a few others that I prefer), I could give 5 stars.
author: Erik R.

description:
Delicious ad comforting Korean food. 

This is a small restaurant so be prepared to wait a bit for a table (usually 20 minutes for small groups). IMHO, it's worth the wait. The food is authentic and affordable. The service is good as well.

TIP: don't wear your best clothes because it will absorb the aromas of the restaurant! Better yet, go to Manna on laundry day!
author: Nina M.

description:
A nice little neighborhood restaurant right on the corner street.  We ordered the following -
Seafood pancake was good with the Korean red sauce
Bulgogi was also good, can do with a little more flavor
Bibimbop is always good, especially with some of the scrapings of crunchy rice from the stone pot. 
Nice to have some ceiling fans because it was really hot that day. Lunch prices only applies to weekdays.
Overall a good experience.  Staff were friendly and attentive.  The Man behind the counter must be the the boss, always with a smile on his face.  Will go back to try other items.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Went on a weekday eve, so the wait was short. 

Food was delicious and the service for us non-Korean customers was very good. They explained each condiment and thanked us multiple times. 

Recommend the kimchi pancakes and bi bim bap.
author: J. M.

description:
(1) FOOD: Everything came out hot and fresh. Portions were great too. Seafood pancake came was a great portion and was not stingy on seafood side. Spicy beef tofu soup was hot and delicious. They cooked it just to the perfect spicy level we requested. Would recommend on any occasion, especially on cold breezy nights. Bulgogi bibimbap in clay pot was delicious as well. Clay pot came out hot and allowed for the rice to crispy up perfectly. Overall, left here full and satified. 

(2) SERVICE: Hostess was super attentive on trying to get us in as quickly as possible and updating us on the wait. Waitress was responsive and nice as well. Food came out reasonably fast. 

(3) ATMOSPHERE: Place seems to get pretty packed and loud during dinner hours, so be prepared to wait and eat in a relatively small and loud area. Gets pretty warm in there, but you're stuffing your face with spicy hot food anyways so it kind of adds to the experience. Not the best place for large parties, unless you are willing to wait or come in a bit later than dinner rush hour.
author: Christy C.

description:
After coming back from Korea on vacation, I've never been so thankful for a restaurant. Hits the spot and feels very authentic. The bibimbap is pretty cheap too, so great for late night take out (since it's always so incredibly crowded in that tiny place).

Also I enjoyed the spicy chicken wings, but not as good as what I had in Seoul.
author: Tony G.

description:
Context: I am Korean-American and I was born and raised in Korea. 

The side dishes at a Korean restaurant typically speaks volumes, and this place is exception to this general rule. Side dishes are fantastic, and so is the main food. I usually just get the dol-sat bibimbap because it is really great. I haven't tried too many different meals here, so I can't comment on the other dishes. 

My rating is actually 4.5 stars because of one major area for improvement: long wait times because they do not take reservations. Wait times can get ridiculously long sometimes, and for this reason, I choose to go elsewhere from time to time despite craving a meal here. If a party with a reservation is a no-show, then they can just let the next one in. I understand the marketing value of having people gather around a restaurant, but Manna is fairly well known and established by now. Please allow reservations!
author: John Y.

description:
I guess I haven't been too lucky here as I see all the good reviews about the food. I decided to get a order of soy sauce chicken wings since I didn't want anything too sweet. Price was normal for wings(~$10) and I liked that it came was veggies, kimchi and a side of rice.

Although the sides that accompanied the dish were good, the chicken was completely dripping in oil. By the time I got to the second wing, I definitley had a bottle of aspirin by my side just in case. The portion was good, but each bite included packets of oil hidden beat the meat and skin. Couldn't eat the rest.

I might try them again sometime, but I'll be going to San Tung for my wing cravings from now on.
author: Amir M.

description:
I tried ordering take out and it shouldn't be this difficult. I saw a fellow Yelper's picture that said they have lunch special and I saw what I wanted to get.

I called their number and talked to a female employee for about 2 minutes and she said (from my understanding) that I can't have what I wanted (deep fried cutlet with rice) with rice. I was confused because it said it came with rice. She proceeded to explain but I still didn't understand her which was hard.

To make matters worse, there was no online menu. I ended up giving up and saying I don't want to order.
author: Aj C.

description: Walked in with an empty stomach. Walked out with a satisfied tummy. Amazing service, delicious food.
author: Andy T.

description:
This place is pretty much as good as it gets. Their portions are huge, and the price is pretty affordable, at least compared to other Korean restaurants in the city. So far, nothing on the menu has failed me (or my friends), but I highly recommend the seafood pancake! It was huge, and they don't skimp on the seafood. 
I wish I could give 4.5 stars, but I'll have to settle for 4. Minus 1 because there could have been a bit more variety in banchan. I'm not sure if it's because we went later in the night, but the few times I've been, there have only been 4-5 different side dishes.
author: Natalie C.

description:
This is my go to restaurant whenever I crave Korean food! The service is good, food is amazing, and the prices are kind of unbeatable. Plus, the location is great because there are plenty of dessert options around the area afterwards. 
I always order a sizzling meat dish (usually BBQ chicken), the spicy soft tofu soup to put over my rice, the seafood pancake, and sometimes the japchae (clear potato noodles). They always serve hot tea and complimentary side dishes in the beginning. Feel free to ask for more side dishes if you run out, because they are pretty generous with that, from my experience. I will definitely keep coming back to satisfy my Korean food cravings!
author: Corinna T.

description: Ordered delivery via DoorDash and was very impressed with the food at Manna. Got the kalbi, kim chi pancake, seafood bibimbap, japchae, mul neungmyun. One of the better Korean places I've had in SF. I'm going to be ordering here a lot.
author: Quincy Y.

description:
I'm no Korean foodie, but Manna has the best japchae I've tried. A little on the salty side, but nothing a few glasses of water can't keep in check. The naenmyeong and dolsot bibimbap are also delicious, but I found the dubu jigae and banchan to be just so-so, and the kanpoongki, pretty bad. Go to San Tung instead if you're craving fried chicken. Then again, if I'm to be perfectly honest, I only come to Manna when I go to San Tung and it's closed (which it always is on Wednesdays!).

Service here is wonderfully attentive and it's a family-owned business. They work hard for their money and it feels good to be supporting them. After all, they are probably the best Korean restaurant in the Sunset.
author: Tiffany H.

description: This my probably my second favorite Korean place to eat lunch or dinner. My favorite is the #3 the spicy pork and the #12 the spicy beef tofu soup, Sometimes it can get crowded when it's lunch time but it's worth the wait!
author: Tommy L.

description: Definitely the best Korean food I've had in San Francisco. I recommend the Sweet and Spicy chicken wings! The dukbokki was very good tool. Small space though so expect a wait if you go during busy times. Most tables are suited for 2 people.
author: Brandon H.

description:
This has been my go to spot for Korean food for a couple years already. Recently my boyfriend & I have coming here at least once every 1-2 weeks. Usually when we come as a pair, the wait would be less than 30 mins.

Side dishes are the best! They were so generous about refilling our side dishes. You can never go wrong with the Kalbi w/rice and spicy beef tofu soup. Their Kimchi fried rice is quite unique because it has a sweet flavor to it, and they also fry it with squash, which i love! Price is good for the quality of food. Go during lunch time and its a few dollars cheaper!

I hate to say that we were unimpressed with the service. The boss and one of the female waitresses were super friendly and nice! Even when it's busy she would stop by our table and ask us if everything is okay. The other female waitress seems like she hates her job. This seems to happen all the time when we eat here. She's the waitress with the glasses, ponytail, and bangs. We would ask for something, and she seems like she purposely ignores us. One time, we asked for a rice refill and she decided to give it to us 10 minutes later. Today, we asked for refills for our side dishes and she angrily collected the dishes, came back with 2-3 piece filled in each dish, angrily throwing them down. It makes us really hesitant to ask for anything from her..

Regardless of the service, we will always come back for the food. We just wish that the waitress was more friendly and welcoming like everyone else in there.
author: Vivian C.

description: Poor service, the queue first to arrange the seats, the first service, the latter only arrange us, and later know that the boss is treated special, the waiter under the wrong menu, the boss did not solve the problem, and back again, the restaurant exhaust is not good, eat Body hair clothes are all smoky, is the worst time to eat in the United States!
author: Jia Li H.

description:
One of the best Korean spots in the city-it is by far my favorite. It is a small restaurant with limited seating and they don't take reservations. 

Here's what I recommend getting:
- seafood hamupajun/Korean pancake 
- kalbi (beef short ribs)
- soondoobu (soft tofu soup)- common Korean dish, it is a broth with kimchi, soft tofu and slices of beef or pork, quite tasty with rice
- bugolgi (marinated beef)

Any other dish will probably taste very good as the food is authentic and amazing! Your belly will definitely be happy with this choice.
author: Lillian C.

description:
Nothing fancy but this place will fulfill any korean food craving.
Don't be discouraged by the wait/line.  The restaurant is tiny with very little elbow room but the staff are efficient and food is served quickly so table turnover is fast. 

Standard banchan dishes.  Dolsot bibimbap and soft tofu jigae are delicious.  I love a hot bowl of Yukgaejang on a cold windy day.  It is hearty, has so much flavor, a bit spicy and will leave you completely full.  Portions are large and prices are fair.
author: Angel W.

description: The food is pretty good but there is ALWAYS a line as the space is small and it's the only Korean place in the general Inner Sunset area. I would say the operation is efficient and service is okay, not super friendly as it's obvious they just want to get you in and out to serve more patrons.
author: Ting N.

description: Manna is one of my favorite Korean restaurants here in San Francisco. All of the food menu items are pretty decently priced.... especially if you go during lunch time. I love their banchan variety too and they always refill them (just be sure to ask). So I love ddokbokgi (rice cakes), I either get the regular spicy one or the royal court one. ($10) The royal court one is served in this sweet and salty soy saucy/homemade sauce and comes with some beef and onions. Both are super delicious and they give a really great amount. They also have this really great spicy beef stew and it's around $13. It is totally delicious and the beef is super tender.... had to ask for another bowl of rice cuz I finished it so fast!
author: Sam L.

description:
I had dinner with a friend here on a weeknight and it was crowded. But, we only had to wait 10 mins for a table. 

She ordered the bulgogi and I had the soft tofu soup with chicken. We also shared the chicken wings. 

My friend liked her bulgogi. I got my soup mildly spicy and it was really good. It was so full of flavor. I devoured the whole thing! The chicken wings were nice and crispy. I liked that they weren't overly drenched in sauce. 

Overall, service could have been better. But, there was literally only 2 waitresses, so it was understandable. Besides that, I really enjoyed the food here.
author: Fallon P.

description:
Quite possibly the smallest Korean restaurant I've ever been to, but possibly the best Korean restaurant in SF.

I had their yookgaejang, and my friend had her galbitang, and we split the seafood pancake.
Their banchan was on point, and generous refill. Kimchee was legit.

I can now understand why people are waiting outside this restaurant... I used to think it was odd while I waited for line at SanTung. From now on, if San Tung line is too damn long, I am walking over to Manna and waiting in line for some bomb ass Korean food.

Thank you Manna for the delicious authentic Korean food.
author: S Y.

description:
We've eaten there a few times in the past.  Nothing too amazing, but the last time we went...
all 3 of us ended up getting a bit of tummy trouble...not sure if it was just the off day...but I don't think we'll be back...
author: Barb L.

description:
I've always seen the long lines in front of Manna and frequently tempted to try it.  However, it wasn't until my girlfriend and her sister picked it for a late Friday dinner spot till I got to try it.  The line was there and we were quoted between 20-30 minutes for a table.  However, a particularly squatty table stretched that out to nearly an hour.  Getting grumpy, I was finally relieved to be seated.

My girlfriend and I ordered a few dishes to share, evening ordering extra to compensate for the new hunger from waiting so long.  These included the seafood pancake, spicy chicken wings, and tofu soup.  The side dishes were just ok for me and we didn't clean out any of them on this trip.  I quite enjoyed the food overall, and my favorite was the pancake and wings.  I'd be interesting in trying their lunch special and BBQ dishes too, which looked awesome on other peoples' tables.  Next time!

Parking in the area is always a pain and the line doesn't help.  Park far and come early to avoid the meter maids and line, and it's a great place for a solid Korean meal.

Food: 8/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Kanpoongki (sweet & spicy chicken): 5/5.

Bulgogi: 3.5/5.

Bibimbob: 4/5.

Mandu Gook (dumpling soup): 4/5.

Seafood Korean Pancake: 3/5.

Service: 4/5.
author: Clarence H.

description:
I came back to Manna two days ago with a friend because the food was both cheap and delicious. How could I pass up another chance to go? The restaurant is small so I felt a little guilty for taking my time while catching up with my friend. But the lunch rush was over so there were other tables available. The servers were all friendly and came by often to refill our glass of tea.

I ended up ordering the spicy rice cakes with fish cake since my sister recommended it. Best decision ever. Sometimes I'm not sure whether or not I like rice cakes because it's very starchy. I feel that you can get tired of it pretty quickly. However, this dish here was not the case. The rice cakes were perfectly seasoned with the spicy sauce. There was also a good amount of fish cake, which created a balance for me. I loved that it wasn't all rice cakes and that there were different textures. My only complaint was that there were so much onions, both green and white ones. I would accidentally bite into one and it would leave an unappealing spiciness from semi cooked onions. However, other than that, the food were delicious and the sides were good and plentiful.
author: Andrea G.

description:
We came on a Friday night, and definitely knew the line was going to be long. You write your name on a pad that hangs off the door and there were almost 10 people ahead of us. But luckily, a lot of people get scared off by the length and usually walk off after putting themselves on the list, so we were seated within 15 minutes.

We definitely over ordered as I've been looking forward to Manna for a while. We ordered the dolsot bibimbap like every one recommended, the seafood pancake, fried chicken, and the bulgogi. 

To be honest, everything was amazing. I've had a fair share of bibimbap and am usually disappointed because it tends to be a bit bland, and my boyfriend has never been impressed by any bibimbap, but he enjoyed Manna's a lot. 

We ordered the seafood pancake, and unfortunately, my bf also hates squid so this dish was up to me. It was definitely much larger than I thought, not an appetizer and should be shared. Unfortunately, I had stuffed myself so full with the chicken (bone-in, tender, and the sauce wasn't overpowering) that we ended up having to pack the pancake, but I gladly ate it all the next day for lunch.

Because the place was so busy, and there were only two waitresses, the service was only a little slower, but I'd gladly come back for the food again. When we went, there was a sign saying they were off for holidays and weren't coming back until early August, so I can't wait to come back!
author: Julia Z.

description: If you want to avoid lines then go during off hours. We went there at 2:00pm and got seated within 10 mins. The restaurant was full but there was no line. There were two of us and we ordered three dishes: the Dol-Sot bibimbab, the sweet and spicy chicken and the octopus. They were all delicious except for the octopus which was very hard to chew. The service was fast. This was our first time at this place. We will most likely return.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Food here is decent but not much more than that..at least from what I had. 

The banchan here is the skimpiest I've had at a korean spot (food same price as most other korean restaurants too)..but to be fair this place is pretty small if that makes a difference. The fish cake was decent, still my favorite but not as flavorful as everywhere else I've had it. Kimchi was good and everything else tasted as it normally did.

My dad got the bulgogi and I got the dol sot bibimbap. I enjoyed my bibimbap, could use a liiiiitle more meat but I still really enjoyed it and felt satisfied. The bulgogi was good but nothing to rave about.

A lot of people got the soft tofu soup, maybe that was my mistake and would definitely give it a try next time along with their seafood pancake.

Okay spot if in the area and wanting korean but if really craving it I'd suggest elsewhere...need more banchan!!!
author: Melissa C.

description: Classic go-to Korean restaurant in the Inner Sunset neighborhood. My friend and I split a bulgogi (which was delicious and came with a decent heaping of onions), soondubu (hot tofu soup), and a seafood pancake. Highlight was probably the seafood pancake (pajeon) because it was huge and filled with shrimp, clams, squid, and octopus. It's perfectly crispy on the outside but there's just the perfect amount of batter that it's a little soft and chewy as well. Of course, expect for the pancake to be oily, haha.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Given this place had such great ratings and it's closer to the city than most of the Korean places out in Inner Richmond/Outer Sunset, I had to try this place out!

Because the store is super small, there's usually a wait. I showed up around 12:30 on a Saturday for 2 people and had to wait around 20 minutes? But there's always shops/bakeries around the area to explore if you want.

As for the food, I got the Daeji Bulgogi (Spicy Pork), which seemed to be on every single table in the restaurant actually. It was good, what I expect from Spicy pork Korean bbq, but nothing out of this world either. But for the price, definitely would get it again. From the other reviews, I've noticed the pancakes are popular, so definitely want to try those next time.

I'd say the only downside is that they don't give too many side dishes compared to other Korean places I've been to. They only gave small portions of broccoli, Kimchi, fish cakes, and bean sprouts.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
All I remember was my major food coma that lasted the entire day, just the side dishes alone could satisfy you! 

The location was like a safe little haven in the crazy city of San Francisco. My friend ordered the sizzling stone pot of tofu soup and I ordered my favorite: SPICY RICE CAKES. It was bomb, definitely get spicy rice cakes! We ordered some random dishes aside from the main plates but it must have been mediocre since I can't recall.

The total came out to be around $30, and I have to say it's not too bad considering the service and short waiting period. 

I recommend everyone to try it at least once ^_^
author: Emily T.

description:
We've been here a couple times now, and I really like this place! Everything we ordered has been incredibly delicious.

It's not a very big restaurant, and there can be a bit of a wait, but definitely well worth it!

So far, we've tried bul kogi (BBQ beef), dae ji bul kogi (spicy pork), kanpoongki (sweet and spicy chicken wings), dol-sot bibimbap (beef with fried egg over rice in a sizzling stone bowl), and the raspberry wine. I'm really looking forward to coming back so I can try their beef jabchae!

If you're looking for some really yummy Korean food, definitely check out this spot!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here at the later end of dinnertime, maybe 830pm, and the place was busy but starting to clear out. We were immediately served hot tea, and after ordering, a standard selection of ban chan. My roommate went crazy and ordered half the menu (exaggeration) so they moved us to a bigger table. Cute.

seafood soon dobu -- good flavor, not as spicy as I'd like at medium, smaller size than I'm used to seeing, no egg!
bibimbap -- generous portion, kinda soggy, but still pretty decent
seafood pancake -- huge and lots of seafood, again doughy and soggy even when it first came out of the kitchen
dukbokki -- kinda small and mediocre.. I'd get it with meat next time (the royal)

So food was okay, not great, but the service was wonderful and I get the feeling it's a family-run restaurant.. it just felt homey and warm.
author: Vivian H.

description: Love this small Korean spot.  I've been here a bunch of times, and it always hits the spot.  The kimchi pancake and seafood pancake are both so great to share with a group, and the dol-sot bibimbap (in the hot stone bowl) is my absolute favorite.  The fried potstickers are also great, and the soft tofu soup will burn the crap out of your mouth if you're not patient but you'll still be happy.  LOVE the banchan (little snack dishes) - I could live off of those little fish cakes.  Also try the kimchi fried rice.  There's usually a wait (shocker) but it's worth it.
author: Liz B.

description: Authentic Korean food with reasonable price. Friendly service. Kalbi was delicious! Soft tofu soup was also great. Go there for lunch! Good prices on the lunch menu.
author: Yingna L.

description:
Yummy Korean food in a convenient spot but long wait and small space.

I have read that the restaurant was small, but I no idea that all you saw was all you were gonna get. I can see why the wait is so long, even for a small group. I definitely don't recommend this place for a larger group. The service was pretty good. The man who was in charge of seating the waiting guests was considerate to ask our party of three if we would want to sit at a table for two or wait for a larger table. 

I ordered their seafood pancake, dukbokki, and kimchi fried rice. The seafood pancake was delicious. I feel like places really can't do this wrong. The only thing I didn't like about it was that some slices of the pancake were completely bare. The seafood and other goodies weren't distributed well. The dipping sauce was also not a particular favorite of mine. I'm used to having sauce that is slightly tangy and savory, and I think Manna uses just soy sauce with some sesame oil. It was really salty. There dukbokki was so good! I love this dish for its chewy rice cakes and sweet & spicy sauce. I thought the flavors were spot on and texture was perfect. I really like their addition of zucchini; I feel like it adds freshness and a crispness to the dish. I didn't get a picture of the fried rice, but I only thought it was okay. I had a few bites and didn't return to that plate. It tasted sort of bland. I like some fermented soy bean sauce in my kimchi fried rice, but I didn't taste any of that flavor. If you like eating the kimchi, as in the fermented cabbage, then I'm sure you'll like this rice. 

I posted a photo of the bibimbap, but I didn't eat any of it so I can't give any opinion on it. 

I suggest you come here before you're actually hungry and just catch up with friends while waiting for your seats. It was delicious and I'll probably find myself back here again!
author: Tina Y.

description: I come here all the time whenever I am craving Korean food because it's not too far from where I live. Their service is always pretty fast and as soon as you put in your order the food comes out in a timely manner, even though they are busy. You should be prepared to wait for a table because the restaurant is very small, but you are generally seated pretty quickly if there are one or two parties ahead of you in line. One thing is that it is usually hard to get a waiter's attention after they have delivered the order to your table. So be prepared to be patient.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Manna is the jam. Small (and popular) place so be prepared to wait on weekends, but it's well worth it. The bibimbap is excellent; I actually liked the seafood more than the beef version. Be sure to drizzle with sauce and pair bites with any of the numerous free sides they serve when you sit down. 

My absolutely favorite has to be the cold buckwheat noodles. If you're a hungry white girl like me, the waitress might ask, "Are you sure you want to order that?" Tell her yes. They might be cold (not sure if that's why she thought I didn't know what I was getting into) but they are silky, slurpable, sweet and topped with cucumber and a perfect hardboiled egg. 

The bui kogi was flavorful, but a little tough/hard to eat. The duk bok ki (sauteed rice and fish cake in spicy sauce) and kimchee fried rice are also delicious. 

Service is always prompt and no BS. Get your food and enjoy it.
author: Elena K.

description:
A Korean place that's pretty cheap & gets the job done. 

The food wasn't too pricey compared to other Korean restaurants, but there also wasn't much variety to pick from. It's mainly bibimbap and tofu soup. The food is alright. If you're looking for quick, non expensive Korean food, here's the place for you. 

Service is pretty okay, but they did mess up on my receipt & almost paid for something I did not order. Other than that, it's an okay place to eat at.
author: Vernice T.

description: A cheap Korean food with great quantity and pretty decent quality! Between 3 people, we ordered 5 dishes which is a bit too much food but pretty cheap for only $60 after tips! The staffs are friendly and attentive :)
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Good place to eat Korean food for fair price. Got the tofu soup, bibim noodles, and spicy pork bulgogi.

Not the best, but definitely not bad. Overall: 7/10
author: Edward K.

description: I've been here on multiple occasions. The food here is just okay. It's not amazing and it's not the best Korean food but it will do to fix a Korean food craving. The food looks better than it tastes.
author: Amanda T.

description: Ordered the Bibimbap - sizzling hot in a stone bowl.  The food came quickly, which was really nice after waiting for half an hour for a table.  Food is tasty enough and the price is reasonable.    However, I'm not sure it's worth the wait.
author: Judy H.

description:
With all the great reviews, I couldn't wait to try Manna. My impressions: Well, first of all, the wait was horrendous. It took over an hour and since the restaurant was so small, there was no indoor waiting area so we had to wait outside. Luckily, it was a warm night. 

The seating area of the restaurant was probably about 600-700 square feet, mainly made up of tables for two. If you have a party of more than 4, don't even bother. I was with a party of 3 and it took really long because we had to wait for two tables for two that were side-to-side to be vacant before we could be seated. Oh well, it is what it is and I should've did my research before I went.

Now for the food. Like all Korean restaurants, it started with the banchan, 5 different dishes in this case. I can't say they were the best I've had. The bean sprouts dish, for example, were blanched but still had the raw taste to them. Since every Korean restaurant does their banchan their own way, I guess I can't really complain.

As for the main dishes, I got the staples: seafood pancake, seafood sundubu, dosot bibimbap and pork bulgogi. The standout of the four was the seafood pancake. Super crispy and big! The dosot bibimbap was disappointing. Usually when I order this at other places, I would let it sit for a while so the rice would crisp up and develop a char on the bottom. Unfortunately, the stone pot was not hot enough. The vegetables in the dish also didn't seem fresh and were soggy. I recommend you pass on this one.  As for the pork bulgogi, it was good and not overly spicy. The sundubu was good as well, packed with quite a surprising amount of seafood in it.

Overall, I like Manna. Are there better Korean restaurants that I rather go to in the City? Yes, plenty. But Manna does offer a unexplainable charm. Maybe it's because it's small and you're elbow to elbow with your neighbors. Maybe it's because the tables are so small, you're worried there's not enough room to hold all the dishes you ordered. Whatever it is, I'll definitely go back. 

My tips: 1) Only go here if you have a party of two, otherwise prepare for a long wait, 2) Consider takeout. There were tons of people ordering things to go and 3) Don't be angry at the semi-rude owner, who's just trying to get everyone seated and eating as fast as he can. He's doing the best given the circumstances. He was actually very accommodating to our party.

Price-wise, it's very reasonable. They don't offer any leaves and garlic for your bulgogi or red bean rice in a dosot like other places do. But not every restaurant has the room for that.
author: Albert L.

description:
Go for the lunch time special!!!! 

Owner and workers are nice. I do think, however, their service has slowed down a bit since I've first came here.
 
Their FISH CAKE side dish is the best!! Yummmm. I mainly order their bibimbap in the stone pot because it keeps the dish hot. FYI don't mix it too fast so the rice can burn at the bottom! Burnt rice is delicious!

I tried ordering the regular bibimbap this time and I think I'd pay an extra buck or two for the stone pot (keeps the food very hot).
author: Anna H.

description: Best and most authentic Korean food in San Francisco! Service is fast and the servers are friendly and helpful. The food comes fast and it's always poppin'! There's usually a line during dinner time and especially on the weekends cause it's very delicious. One of my favorite spots in the city! 10/10!
author: Grace C.

description:
Randomly walking down the street, I stumbled upon Manna and thought "hey I should give this place a shot" Their staff is super friendly and the owner takes pride in making sure our food is up to par. What I like most about this place is that you can ask for as much sides and rice as you want. They give about 6 different sides, which includes bean sprout, kimchee, sweet beans, broccoli, fish cake, and pickled radish. I know there are other Korean restaurants that serve 10+ sides but most of the time I only eat half of them. At Manna, I go to town on every single one! 

I ordered their Hot Stone Bimbimbap and there were many ingredients. which included a fried egg, beef bulgogi, diced carrot, rice, and other delectable ingredients that fits the whole meal together. The cool thing being in a sizzling hot stone is your food will never get cold. Actually it's piping hot until the end of your meal. This place treats their customers right and they never fail to bring great service and food.
author: Moses D.

description:
3.5 stars
I enjoyed the fact that Manna actually has some authentic dishes on their menu, including what I ordered (yukgaejang) and other stews and soups. The employees were very nice and attentive, unlike many other Korean restaurants with young servers.

I read in other reviews that there weren't any Korean patrons--and they're right! I don't know what it is, but I was the only Korean person here, other than the employees. That said, I was very kindly greeted by the owner/manager who chatted with me a little in Korean and asked how I enjoyed my food (I presume they don't get many requests for stews, but rather bibimbap or bulgogi or kalbi since those are the more common dishes in America).

As for the meal itself, you are given some boricha (hot barley tea) but can request ice water. You're also given about 6 small Banchan dishes (The kimchi is not shin kimchi. Sad face.). The Banchan dishes were hit or miss--some of them were good while others were a bit bland. The yukgaejang was pretty good and tasted as I expected. I wish they had gosari (bracken fern) in it, but even without it it was a solid yukgaejang.

Overall, not bad Korean, but I do want to try a couple of other Korean places before making the trek out here again.
author: Julia N.

description:
The bf and I had a craving for Korean and we both had manna bookmarked on yelp for the longest time. For the price that you pay, it's pretty decent Korean food. And it's the cheapest I've seen anywhere for dinner. 

He had the galbi and he loved it. Though he's use to having the galbi that has smaller bones and a bit less meat , he was surprised by how big the portion was. It was cooked perfectly, he finished all of it an was satisfied. 

I got the soft tofu soup and it was pretty good. I know a lot of people have said its really watery, but mine was not. It had a good amount of tofu, beef, veggies etc. though the tofu was broken up into smaller pieces than what I usually like. It wasn't bad, but it still doesn't compare to my tofu house or mugobaka. 

I will definitely come back here again. Service is friendly and if we want more in the ban chan we just have to let the servers know and they will bring more.
author: Stella J.

description: I looooooove Manna. The chicken wings, bulgogi, japchae, and of course the veggies that you get to start are the best.
author: Emily S.

description: My new Korean go-to place when I'm craving KBBQ but not enough to eat all-you-can-eat. It's a lot cheaper and I'm proud to say I finished the kalbi dish all by myself. I stared at one of the waiters as they delivered a kimchi fried pancake to the table beside us. It looked realllyy good. Definitely ordering that next time :)
author: Kim L.

description:
After a long day of moving things into the new apartment, my roomie and I came to this little corner shop. We were greeted immediately upon entering, and were seated in a super cramped place. We were served tea in clear glasses, and the menus are on the tables (under the glass). 

I notice that there is a slight lack of soon du bu (there are 2 choices, regular or seafood). I also notice there are a bunch of other choices, especially bi bim baps. At the bottom, it does say, if you ask for extra rice or side dishes, you will not be charged. That's how real korean restaurants work. I've been to places that extra rice is a dollar... or some places that give attitude when you ask for more ban chan. Not this place though! 

When a larger table opened up, and no customers in line, we were moved to a larger table to avoid being cramped. That's was nice of them, unnecessary, but I'm definitely grateful for it.

Hungry and tired, I decided I wanted to end this night well with a lot of food.

Seafood pancake - lots of fresh seafood, pancake was a good size. Not as crispy as some places I've been to.

Duk bok ki - this is my favourite dish, and it was done very well here. the plate was a bit small, but definitely flavourful and yummy. 

Dol sot bi bim bap - Pretty good, but the rice didn't crust as much as I like. Maybe I shouldn't have touched it as much.

Soon du bu - Very flavourful and delicious. My only complaint here is that no egg was provided. 

Finally the service was outstanding. We were checked on a few times. Tea refilled without asking. Lots of smiles to bring good vibes.

I'm not sure if I was just hungry, but the food was pretty yummy, despite a few little things. The little things add up to about a star, as they were pretty insignificant. I'll definitely be back!
author: Kaje Y.

description:
This place is overall pretty good.

Sidedishes: they are okay. 

Some items on the "Lunch Special" Menu are the same as the Regular Menu...probably should have just not listed under lunch special. Below are the listed items that are same price with numbers matching per menu item.4

Lunch Special Menu vs Regular Menu (Same price items):
Kanpoongki, Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings 
#5 lunch to #5 regular 

Soy Sauced Chicken Wings, 
#6 lunch to #6 regular

Ramen, 
#15 lunch to #31 regular

Fried Dumpling,
 #16 lunch to #33 regular

Duk Bok Ki, Sauteed Rice Cake & Fish Cake with Special Sauce (Not Spicy), 
#20 lunch to #34 regular

Price differences between lunch and regular range from $0.49 to $4.00. Well I guess I should technically say $0 to $4 difference if we including the items listed above. 

Food amount is pretty decent. I do not really eat a lot so I had enough for dinner as leftovers. 

People change out about 30 minutes to 1 hour eating wait can take awhile depending when you arrive. Food arrival to table is awhile. Pretty quick about cleaning up a table to seat more customers.
author: Corie L.

description:
On Wednesday: My bff and I trekked all the way to Sunset to find that San Tung was closed (blasphemy!), so we came to Manna as a substitute. Not a bad substitute!

It was perfect for a chilly SF evening. Everything is really affordable ... my favorite dish was the bi bim bap - flavors were on point and portions were generous! Service isn't exactly the best, as it was hard to grab their attention. But when you do, they gladly refilled our banchans and tea.

The chicken wings were pretty good, but even after the bi bim bap I was pretty full... I only managed to eat two wings. They were delicious, but not as yummy as San Tung...

It gets pretty packed in here, so come early! There's also only one bathroom, so don't overeat... :P
author: Janet H.

description: This is a small restaurant, but the food was so delicious. We ordered 3 dishes: dol sot bibimbap, beef fried rice and dae Jim bul kogi , we finished all.  Will come back to try other dishes.
author: Lily L.

description: The line is long but the wait is worth it, as the food is very good, the prices fair, and the service excellent.
author: jason j.

description:
To start off, this place is SMALL. Most tables are meant to sit two, so if you have a party bigger, cross your fingers for tables to finish up close together. We waited about 30 minutes on an early Saturday (6pm)

Breakdown of our dishes:
1. Kanpoongki - Sweet/Spicy chicken wings. They were more sweet than anything else. Not spicy at all. And they were comparatively small compared to other places. Not even close to San Tung standard.

2. Dol Sot Bimbimbap - Served sizzling hot, this dish was pretty good, but the ratio of vegetables to beef was absurd. We only had a little sliver hiding under the egg. :( That said though, the flavor was pretty spot on and I do like the crispy rice pieces from the bottom.

3. Kimchee Pancake - This was probably my favorite of the night....and probably also the cause of my suffering later. I have a feeling it wasn't cooked thoroughly.

4. Spicy Seafood Stew - I didn't actually try this, but it was impressive. Instead of stuffing it with assorted pieces of small shellfish, they managed to get an entire blue crab (the legs and most of the body) in here. Good to know its fresh even though the crab itself didn't have much meat.

5. Japchae - The noodles were nice and chewy, But we were surprised that the actual serving was so much smaller than the sample picture.

My impressions of Manna were actually pretty good...that is, until I got food poisoning. I'm not sure how recent that 78/100 health score is, but it'll make me think twice before coming back.

They take everything but Amex.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Great quality Korean food at very reasonable prices. Even more so if you come for lunch between Tuesday and Friday. I got the kalbi, which was served on a hot plate with plenty of meat. 

Banchan selection is fairly limited but they have all my favorites: bean sprouts, fish cakes, and radish kimchi. The portions are pretty generous and they refill the banchan with a smile. Tea comes with the meal. The meal here won't be life changing, but it is consistently delicious, fairly cheap, and certainly worth coming again for.

It's a small restaurant, so probably not the best place if you have a large group of people.
author: William H.

description: Hot stone Bibimbap, Kalbi and fried chicken are all good. Banchans are decent too with good selection. Price is reasonable, great place for lunch.
author: Ingrid C.

description: Been here several times before and it never disappoints. Love their dukbokki and seafood pancake! The dukbokki has the perfect amount of spicyness which is good for those who wants a bit of a kick in their food but doesn't want to drink a gallon of water with it. The fish cakes are a nice touch, giving it a bit of a seafood flavor in it. The seafood pancake is the best out of all the korean restaurant in SF. Along with the soy sauce, it is soft and they don't skimp on the squid, clams, or shrimp. Although there was some shell bits in it. Love the bibimbap also. It's very basic with not much unique additions but I think bibimbap is best when it's simplistic. Would come here again if I'm craving for Korean food :).
author: Annie V.

description: For the price and the food that you get this place was pretty amazing for Korean food. Look it's not the best Korean food ever, but it's a great deal in the City. We had a large group and shared multiple dishes and only paid $14 a person including tip. If there isn't much of a wait I'd definitely come back again.
author: Guisela L.

description:
THIS PLACE IS WORTH THE WAIT!!!

I wanted to dine here the other Saturday night with my friend who was visiting from NYC, and the wait was insane. Literally, at least 20 people waiting OUTSIDE in the cold! Because we were in a rush, we decided to go elsewhere but 2 days ago, I came here with my mom and luckily, grabbed the last table. Literally, just seconds after we sat down, there were already people lined up outside. Mind you, this was a Tuesday night. So... What makes this place so amazing?!

The food is excellent! I has the veggie tofu soup and my mom had the beef short ribs (see pictures). We both finished every bite and sip! Both of our dishes were full of amazing flavor and cooked to perfection. I loved the little appetizers that they give. My favorite were the black beans. Also, ask for their house spicy sauce. It's amazing! Sweet and spicy---yummmm! 

The service is excellent! The two girls and the man at the front (I believe he is the owner) are all very sweet and attentive. Every time a new dish came out to another table, my mom had to ask what it was! Usually, waiters would get annoyed by that, but these guys were so sweet and told my mom what each and every dish was!

I'm not sure if they take reservations, but if they do, I highly suggest to call in for a table! 

If you want amazing Korean food at a great price, come here!!!
author: Anastasia N.

description:
A welcome warm and cozy nook in San Francisco's Thundra (i.e. the Sunset), Manna offers homely Korean cooking to warm you right up. 

It was a wet, foggy, and gloomy wednesday when we stumbled upon Manna after an unsuccessful trip to San Tung's. Just walking in from the cold and smelling the food in the air was warming enough. It's a small space so seats were hard to come buy but we were seated fairly quickly. They have lunch specials and the banchan selection is pretty decent. I ordered the jap chae and it was really flavorful. I did find it odd that it was served with an order of rice like all the other lunch specials - carb overload. Still the noodles struck a nice balance of sweet and savory. 

The folks that work here are just lovely. This is totally a family operation and it shows when you're at Manna so come on in out of the cold already.
author: Jon L.

description:
3.5 STARS

CHEAP KOREAN FOOD? YES! 
FRIENDLY SERVICE? YES! 
GOOD KOREAN FOOD? UMMMM...

WHY is Korean food SO expensive? My SoCal elitist friend, Justin Y. tells me it's because Korean food sucks in SF. As Neon Hitch says, please take (not get) your (whacked) ass back home. I'm kidding, ok...maybe not. :/

Taking over Little Bangkok (Thai) last June, Manna serves up Korean cuisine at affordable prices. For lunch, nothing is over $9.99 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=2dGc21IsA7mT5cYRdco-bg) and nothing over $12.99 for dinner (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=0HVVBelFxAx1YdTHB8z6pQ). A great welcome change as I usually pay $26 for a plate of kalbi at Korean restaurants in The Richmond. With the lower prices, you will notice that the portions are smaller though. 

My friend and I came to Manna last night for dinner after one of us had a whole bottle of wine to himself at happy hour; keyword: "himself" so I wasn't the drunkie this time. Everything we had was mediocre and flavors/textures were "off" BUT service was super friendly and lightning fast hence the extra .5 stars which has no bearing anyhow. 

*BANCHAN
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=6qYltvMEUAGF7riBzlZEKg
The best of the six was the myulchi bokum, the anchovies were nice and crunchy. The kimchee was the most disappointing as it lacked heat. 

*SEAFOOD PAJEON ($9.99) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=4Nn1s9cJjnNXOQi0qNecQw
The pancake was too thick and doughy. It was also undercooked as the center was merely raw dough. 

*KANPOONGKI: Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings ($8.99) - 3 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=UhRX8Yk073HFiXEK3v0GeA
Everyone knows how much I LOVE my wings which is why I initially bookmarked Manna when they first opened. These wings were disappointing. Although there were cooked to a delicious crisp, the sauce didn't coat all the wings. The sauce was bland lacking both sweetness and spice; not finger-licking worthy.

*KALBI ($12.99) - 3 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=1qnYALIc6fxleqrD_qmkgw
Where's the sizzle yo? The kalbi oddly arrived in less than 5 minutes with no steam permeating from the iron plate and into the air. It seems they precooked the kalbi before throwing it on the iron plate for presentation purposes. The kalbi was tender but lacking the quintessential smoky flavor from the non-existent char marks and the marinade was reminiscent to Chinese hoisin sauce--way TOO sweet!

Manna is a PRIME example of how service can make a difference. The super friendly owner and waitress made up for the lackluster and not very well executed food. 

For solid Korean grub, I'll be taking my ass back to The Richmond...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Here in SF, we're pretty hard-pressed for good Korean restaurants. Manna is one of the few good ones and it appears everyone knows this. And that is the reason why this restaurant sat dormant in my bookmarks for so long because, well the wait here is terrible. And it doesn't help that the restaurant itself is teeny tiny. 

The above I'm sure has everything to do with why we were slightly rushed (as in the check arrived a lot sooner than we'd expected) but I get it - it's hard to ignore the queue forming outside. Every so often, a wistful face from the outside peers in watching everyone enjoying their hot, steaming food and their glass of Hite. 

Food tastes very much like home cooking. They have a bit of everything on their menu that you'd expect to see on a Korean restaurant; bibimbap, nengmyun, ddukbokki, galbi, seafood pancakes, kimchi fried rice, chicken etc. Portions are pretty hefty, I thought. 

We'll definitely go back. However, we've since decided we'll be taking the "to-go" route with Manna going forward.
author: Esther A.

description: I love their rice cake!!!! Very Q and taste so good, little sweet and spicy!!!! And bibimbap also! So colorful!
author: Anna L.

description:
Soft tofu soup is the best in my experience. If you want an egg, make sure to let the waitress know (otherwise you won't have it). 
Kim chi fried rice is pretty good too. 
Subtract one star because side dishes are so so.
author: Anna L.

description:
I came to this place because most teens would say this is the best cheap korean place to eat at. In my opinion, I think its cheap only on weekends.

Their lunch special only works on weekdays. 

My friend & I waited about 20-25 mins to get our seats. I thought this place was really small since we were seated pretty close to the tables around us. This place was pretty hot, especially when our food got to us.

I got the kimchi fried rice and my friend got the bibimbap on stoned pot. If youre planning to share, I suggest you get a
Soup and rice dish. My kimchi fried rice was really good if youre a spicy kind of person. My friend said his dish was pretty good and flavorful especially with the sauce they give us to mix in with the bibimbap.

The staff are super nice and The price was fine, but honesty if you want it to be worth it, go on weekdays. 

Id come here if I was in the sunset and craving for korean food. Other wise, Id go to Han kwan ii instead.
author: Josie D.

description:
I am from the LA area and was recommended this place by my SF friend. Tried it and loved it. From the satisfying sizzle to the perfect combination of deliciousness in my mouth, the dolsotbibimbap was the unquestionably the best one I have ever eaten. The side dishes were also surprisingly much better than a lot of the ones that Korean restaurants provide. Met the owners, and they are the kindest, sweetest people ever. There's a reason why there is a wait because it is a must-try, but it is a really short one. I heard that the crispy chicken is better than that of San Tung's as well.

Thanks Manna for your beyond amazing food and service. Definitely recommending this place to anyone who lives in and wants to visit SF.
author: Rachel K.

description: cute neighborhood korean place. the food is great, the staff are friendly and willing to offer suggestions, and the prices are fairly reasonable (especially lunch specials). I usually get the dol sot bibimbap (with beef) and it's delicious and plenty of food. I've also had the ramen and beef bulgogi, also delicious. Even though it is popular and small, I usually don't have a long wait.
author: Lynne C.

description:
Great dol sot bi bim bap (sizzling pot rice). Beef, mixed veggie, rice and a fried egg. Add the hot sauce, mix it all up and let the bottom get crispy while you eat your way down. I've never ordered anything else.

Side dishes are solid. Fish cake, broccoli, bean sprouts, radish and the usual Napa cabbage.

$13 for lunch with tip. Not a huge portion but tasty and satisfying. One warning...expect to smell like a sizzling plate of Korean food for the rest of the day.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Delicious Food, friendly staff, and good prices. I eat here quite a bit. The line gets pretty long because the place is pretty small, so I'd avoid this place if you are too hungry to wait.

I recommend the tofu soup and the Bibimbap, but everything I've had is good.
author: Mark K.

description:
Ventured out for lunch in this area and my normal ramen joint was closed, so stopped here as soon as I saw ramen on their menu.

Now, I won't say 100% that it was but upon receiving my ramen, it sure looked a lot like top ramen dressed up in a bowl. I'm no ramen expert but it looked and tasted like top ramen, the broth was extremely spicy and I couldn't finish the bowl.

It was cheap for lunch and I like the little bowls of appetizers they bring to the tables, but don't try the ramen if you've had real ramen.
author: Christine E.

description:
Food is good, Service is terrible! 
I wouldn't recommend this if you wanna get ignored
author: Kaika K.

description:
I went to Manna last Saturday with my husband and we loved it.

Why? The food was delicious, the service was quick, the place is super small and clean, which makes it charming, comfortable. 

The Banchan dishes were terrific and I ordered the Dolsot Bibimbap, which I have to say is the best I've ever had. I will definitely go back here.
author: Sue R.

description:
A. Location

- parking such difficult :(
- many close to N muni line
- such small, go early, avoid crowd
- so close on munday

2. Food

- only know how 2 compar 2 san diego not la
- banchan (sidedish): fish cake such tender, grate bean sprout, missing spinach :(
- seafud pancake: many squid, very leek, on par
- tofu stew: such good, not 2 salty, flavorful, no raw egg :(

III. Overalls

- quality much gud, best tofu in sunset
- much missing: spinach banchan, egg in tofu stew
- barley tea 4 free, make shibe happy on cold day
author: Doge S.

description:
Seafood pancake-packed with flavor, cooked well, seafood portion is ok but cooked well 
Tofu Soup-a good balance of heat and savoriness 
Bimbap in stone bowl-vibrant, fresh, abundant, good balance of textures
Side dishes are good and readily replaced as requested

Seating is cramp so be ready to get friendly with your neighbors, overall restaurant is small so I can imagine wait times being a little absurd. Food does come out quickly so keep that in mind with the limited table space you have 

Overall Thoughts

I would come back again if I needed a korean fix!
author: Eddie W.

description: Great food, great price and quick service. Been here multiple times now and will continue to visit. Lunch menu is fabulous and the seafood pancake is amazing. The seafood tofu soup is spicy, tasty and lava hot!
author: Shek T.

description:
I think the food here is mediocre.

Everything is kind of bland compared other Korean places. I feel like the dishes here represent Korean cuisine in a more mild way. The execution of the rice cakes I ordered were alright. The sauce was really light in color and the cakes texture was not soft and chewy like they should be. The friend rice my friend ordered was also really light in color and not very flavorful.

The staff is nice, kind of slow but I'll let that slide since it was a weekday lunch on Irving. It's very bright with all the windows, also looks and feels very clean.

This review is based solely on the food though.
author: Melanie L.

description:
Pros:
- short ribs (tender, flavorful, and a bit oily)
- ramen
- soon dubu (soft tofu soup)
- quick service

Cons:
- tiny restaurant, so expect a long wait!
- difficult to find street parking

Bottom line: solid Korean food. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area.
author: Jiann M.

description:
I've been here on multiple occasions and it doesn't disappoint!
I love their fish cake banchan and their Boneless BBQ chicken. I took my parents here and my dad loved the sizzling rice bowl. 
Definitely a great spot for an affordable and tasty dinner. There is usually a line but the most I have waited is about 20 minutes.
author: Angela D.

description:
Recommendation: Sweet and spicy chicken wings were so delicious. Eat right away when they deliver them to your table. Garlicky, sweet, crispy. Yumyum.

Bulgogi in dol-sot bibimbap was somewhat disappointing.Tofu soups were more spicy than expected according to my friends. Also had to ask for an egg, they did not automatically bring one, which is a negative since places usually just bring it.

Difficult area to park. You've been warned.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Dolsot Bibimbap.  It sounds like an entree named by Dr. Seuss.  And not only is it fun to say, but eating it is an adventurous and satiating endeavor.  It's chock-full of delicious and warmly satisfying ingredients, topped with an egg cooked to your specs, and ends with a reward of golden, buttery, crunchy rice that you scrape from the hot stone bowl.  To me, this dish is pretty near to perfect.  

When last I encountered Dolsot Bibimbap it was at a Korean joint in Berkeley and, though good, it was filled with too many healthy tasting options for my palate.  Manna's version is filled with a plethora of wonderful ingredients but it just tastes satisfying and delicious, not like I'm eating health food.  This is a compliment to Manna.  If I lived nearby I'd be eating Manna's DB here on a weekly basis.  

An order of Soft Tofu Seafood Soup was equally satisfying.  When ordering, the waitress questioned the desired level of spice and, when she noticed wavering, settled on "medium spicy with a side of additional spice".  The soup emerged boiling to a degree that I thought it might contain something live (it did not) and accompanied by a healthy dollop of added spice bomb to be used as desired.  

Meals included an ample array of tasty banchan, refilled upon request.  

Including a small Korean beer, pre-tip dinner for two was under $25.  I've not been so satisfied at such a reasonable price in a long time.  

Manna has large picture windows looking out onto Irving and has a warmer feeling than most Korean joints I've been to.  At these price points and with this nice ambience I'd likely choose Manna again over the numerous restaurants in the surrounding area.  If it were a cold night with fog rolling in it'd be a slam dunk.  Manna's food is truly belly warming.
author: Tracey A.

description:
My go-to Korean restaurant in Sunset. You can't beat the lunch specials here! The portions are the same as dinner, but with slashed prices. The restaurant is pretty small, so be prepared to wait or come at odd hours. You can place your order while still waiting in line so your food will be ready by the time you're seated :) 

My favorites here are the Dolsot Bibimbop and Galbitang. The beef in the Galbitang is SO tender. The broth is perfect- not too salty but very flavorful. The dish also came with egg (!!) and lots of veggies. 

Also, the kimchi banchan is the BEST. Crisp, fresh, and spicy.
author: Samantha C.

description:
I had a craving for Korean food so I decided to come back here again. I absolutely love this place! The service is amazing and the staff is incredibly friendly. My sister and I love the fish cakes, kim chi and bean sprouts and the waitress kept bringing it out for us without us even having to ask for more. 

We decided to order the BBQ Chicken Bulgogi, Kim Chi Pancakes and some kind of kimchi soup my sister likes. What I love about this place is that they give you unlimited rice. When I eat asian food, I love to drench my rice with sauce and I end up eating 2 or 3 bowls. I hate it when restaurants charge you extra for another small scoop of rice. Moreover, the guy at the counter saw that i was running low and he asked me if I wanted more. You know a restaurant has excellent service when they ask you if you need anything rather than you having to ask for it. 

Overall, excellent food and excellent service. Also their hot sauce is really good like always.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Sun Tung's Chicken line was way too long for me, so my guest and I decided to chekc out this Korean Spot a few blocks away! And I'm glad we did!

PARK: is a a big butt, just circle the block 8 times and you'll find free parking eventually!

SERVICE: love them Korean peeps! Super friend server and great recommendations, even though I order the same thing all the time.

FOOD:
(1) Seafood Bibimbap, 3 stars, not liking the eggs.
(2) Soft Tofu Soup: 5 stars! Very good! A must get.
(3) Juicy chicken wings...dude if Sun tung fails.. come here.. they got awesome-as chicken wings, 5 stars.

**OVERALL, soft tofu soup and chicken wings! If you want to try what's awesome here!
author: Mindy Y.

description: A great hidden mom and pop traditional Korean restaurant located in the middle of inner sunset. Food is really great. There is a bit of wait since the place is so small. Their soups are as good as their hot pot bi bim bap. Really great to have found out a nice traditional Korean restaurant around the area.
author: Chul L.

description:
My friends constantly raved about this place and told me how good their food is, but always warned me that it's a small place and that I'd probably have to wait a while for a seat and even circle a few times to find parking.

Luckily, I came during lunch time with my friend to catch up and there was no line (and we also managed to snag a parking spot too!)

I got a dol sut bibimbap, and my friend got their chap chae. My friend loves the chapchae here so much that she claims that she has yet to try a place that comes on par. 

Their dol su bibimbap is pretty good, but it's like any other place (that's because you really can't mess this dish up. If you do, you shouldn't open a restaurant). They give you quite a lot of meat which is pretty good. 

Sidedishes are great as well and prices are reasonable. If you go during lunch, their lunch special is mostly a dollar off some of the dishes. 

Overall not a bad place, but I'd opt for another location if I had to wait
author: Harriet W.

description: It's a cute small quaint restaurant with great Korean food of different variety. The staff were very friendly and extremely attentive, and the location is great also.
author: Chassidy M.

description:
Love this place!!!
We ordered the short ribs, bulgogi, kimchi fried rice, and the chicken wings. EVERYTHING was soo delicious and the portions were generous! Service was good too regardless of how busy it was!! Come in during lunch prices are cheaper :)
author: Alyssa C.

description: My literal favorite place. Great customer service, reasonably priced high quality Korean food, what more can you ask? I recommend the spicy beef tofu soup or bibimbap!
author: michelle y.

description:
I went on a tues around 12:30 and there was no wait. It's self seating and they bring you some hot barley tea after you sit down. The place was clean and staff provided decent service.

Food

Seafood soft tofu soup, 3 stars: the broth wasn't thick how I normally like it and it wasnt too flavorful. They also didn't give me an egg to crack over the soup. At first glance I didnt see any seafood, normally they throw in some mussels or clams at the top, nada. Once you dig in you see the baby octopus and clams!

Bulgolgi, 3 stars: good amount for the price ($8.99, lunch). The plate wasn't hot so the onions didn't caramelize the way I like it. The flavor was okay, nothing to brag about. 

Sweet and spicy wings, 3.5 stars: good amount for the price (8.99), got about a dozen med size wings. It was more sweet than spicy, had an orange chicken kind of flavor. It was nice and crispy though! 

Side dishes,  4 stars: I liked the kimchi and fish cakes. A lot of places around don't give fish cake so that earned them the 4th star.

I would come back, I want to try the dolsot bibimbap, the table next to me ordered it and it looked good. I also want to try the kimchi fried rice and kimchi pancake to see how they compare to others.
author: Thuy N.

description:
My friend took me on a date. Seriously, a date! Great. I was not in the mood for a date. Restaurant was crowded on a Sunday evening just before the holidays. I had the worst day ever. Completely exhausted and a bit bitchy. How could I enjoy food when I felt so irritated? Came here for its famous dol-sot bibimbap and bulgogi. The service was quite pleasant. The owner kept on asking my friend to see if I was Korean. No I'm not. Why is everyone asking me if I was? I needed to be left alone that day, and me in a foul mood finally rubbed off on my friend because he was becoming irritated as well. Who could blame him? I was simply in a "why am I eating with you tonight" mood.  Thankfully no one noticed it. 

So we ordered dol-sot bibimbap  - one for each, and then some bulbogi for extra protein. DsB was the hit at this Korean place, even when you were irritated. Now, if that's not comfort food, what is?
