Fast forward a few weeks. Am no longer a bitch. Decided to write a review for this cool little Inner Sunset restaurant. Inner sunset is where you probably have been seeing me hovering lately. I've been so bored of the Mission and was looking for something hip and cool, Instead of going somewhere new I returned to Inner Sunset where I spent a lot of my youth hanging out with my friends from back east.  Fun fact, I'm still hanging out with friends from back east. Just newer immigrants than my original crew. 

And I wanted to tell my friend that back when I was young, Inner sunset had just Ibisu as the only Asia restaurant stand-out, and I've wasted a lot of mornings drinking margarita and Bloody Mary in this popular brunch place nearby. But now you can get the best bibiimbap here without having to go to Korea or L.A. So yes I would like to return soon to this corner diner style restaurant. And I promise that I'll behave like a mature adult and not some pouty brat.
author: Victoria E.

description: This place never disappoints! For sure my go-to Korean spot in the city! The workers are super friendly and attentive. Unlike a lot of other Korean restaurants in the city, the prices are reasonable for the portions they give. If you're eating with a few friends, I highly recommend the seafood pancake and the chicken wings for sharing!
author: Jenny C.

description:
I've stopped by again for another yummy dinner here, but my experience was a little bit different.

Waited a little over an hour for a table for 4 here.. I called it a game of Diner Dash gone wrong.
We had waited 30 minutes for a table for 4 to clear up and we were next on the list, BUT, the group that was before us that was a no show, came back from the bar across the street. The owner is a really nice guy though and he put them back up on the list. We ended up staying because we figured a table would open up soon. Unfortunately, every other table started opening up so we couldn't get two tables for two that were next to each other for the longest time. Two tables for two kind of near by each other opened up and he asked us if we would like to take a seat and we gladly accepted, because waiting in flats and waiting in heels are two different things. Another table for two finally opened up and he managed to swing some tables together as if they were magnets! 

The moment we sat, we were given utensils and our ban chan (YUM!)
Ordered the same stuff + a dol sot bibimbap and kalbi. Tbh I'm there for the wings and the kimchi fried rice. Manna does those two things waaaaaay better than Toyose, no competition there.

Towards the end of the meal, we were offered an order of the fried dumplings on the house. It was the greatest gesture, really! And boy were those things good. I like to call them Ling Ling 2.0.

Really love the food here, definitely worth the wait. I might skip on dinner if it was four of us again though. Still think this place is a little bit too cozy though.. Let's be real, this place only seats like 10 people and the food comes out super hot so no one can really eat for 10 minutes anyways LOL

Also wanted to give a big finger to all you people who head to the bar across the street and enjoy yourselves while the rest of us wait patiently and still manage to get seated after you because the owner is so nice. Hope something happens to you while you cross the street to check on your already called name  :~)
author: Emberly N.

description:
Have tried the other restaurant at Larkin called Jin Mi which is only so so compares to Manna which the food is better tasting and the banchan is better.
I've also have the seafood pan cake which is kind of crunchy on the top and slightly chewy inside, yummy.   The food is never blend so I always crave Korean when I am just tired of eating Vietnamese or salads.  I trust this place, I like the owner and staff.  I've never been over charge or get sick eating the food.  You feel me?
author: Mar H.

description: I love this place, their Korean food is legit. The food and service here are great. I always get either the soft tofu soup or the galbitang, and their sweet and spicy chicken wings. One thing people always come to Inner Sunset for is the chicken wings at San Tung, but the wings here at Manna is just as great and you don't have to wait 50 minutes for them. There are sometimes lines here at dinner time, but if you get here early or don't mind waiting 10-20 minutes, it's usually not a big deal. The servers here are always prompt and friendly, even when it's a very busy night.
author: Julia P.

description: Right after I sat down, the lady served me with the warm barley water :) Really love the drink. I ordered the normal bibimbap. The side dishes & bibimbap were served within few minutes. The portion is big, the taste is authentic!
author: Jennifer Z.

description: Although the food was great, service was friendly but a bit slow. Was not a life changing experience but very enjoyable.
author: Max Y.

description:
New local korean restaurant in the Sunset! It's a cozy place that sits just at the corner of the street.  All the 5 star reviews on yelp are pretty on point. The service is friendly and i'm happy with my quick complimentary refills of fish cake.

We started off with a short rib and broth soup that immediately warmed us up! It was full of flavor and enough to share between 4-5 small bowls. Simple and reminded me of something my grandma would make.  The bulgogi was generously piled on a semi sizzling platter. It's served with a bowl of rice but i couldn't finish the whole dish regardless of avoiding the rice bowl. All my friends ordered bibimbap and it looks nothing short of amazing.

Can't wait to eat here again!
author: Samantha L.

description:
A friend invited me out to grab dinner. They wanted Korean food so I was pretty stoked. I've been curious about this place for a while since I pass by it fairly often. 

The place was pretty busy when I got there but I got there late so my friends saved a spot for me already. I didn't have to worry about the wait. 

Everyone ordered bibimbap (2 regular, 1 veggie) and I got the nakji bokum (spicy octopus in sauce and veggies). Another friend ordered some other dish that had rice cakes and fish cakes. 

Service is attentive. I never really had an empty cup of tea throughout the meal. They're also pretty fast about getting food out. Getting the check was slower but they probably thought we were still eating. 

Kimchi and rice/fish cake dish came out first. Rice/fish cake dish was not bad, just peculiar textures. 

Nakji bokum came next. They ran out of octopus so they gave me pieces of squid instead. It was pretty good. Great with rice which was free by the cupful. 

I didn't get to taste the bibimbaps but they looked really good. 

Not a bad place.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Yums! Came here twice last week, and both times it was great. Their chicken wings are AWESOME. Sort of like the ones from Kuk-je, but HOT and FRESH.
They were always happy to refill our sides, which I really REALLY appreciate. Gotta have my brocolli. :D

Tried the Chicken Wings, Tofu Soup, Kimchi Fried Rice, Seafood Pancake, Chap-jae(sp), and Kal-bi short ribs. EVERYTHING was delicious!

I'm almost tempted to write a bad review instead cause this place is starting to get real busy!! Just kidding. I would never do that.............................
author: Athena L.

description: So happy there is good Korean food in the Sunset! The soondoobu was legit. Big portion, lots of tofu, decently spicy, big pieces of meat. For $8.99, it's a steal! Will definitely come back and try their other items. I wish they had an appetizer menu though.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Hello authentic Korean food, welcome to the inner sunset! 

This place is great. The food is simple, tastes like what I used to get in k-town, selection is great and it's very affordable. 

Tried the seafood bibimbap with fellow yelper Natasha H. and we both loved our dishes. For only $8.99, i enjoyed myself a big ol bowl of carbs and seafood. Oohhh yeeahhh. The couple that owns the place is also very nice. 

I can't wait to go back and try some of their other dishes!
author: Gloria C.

description: Don't go here. It's not worth your time. Coming from a bonafide Korean, this place was not good. They're banchan(side dishes) are alright but their main dishes are horrendous. I ordered the ddukgook and was beyond disappointed. The soup was watery, and tasted like they dumped a beef ramen packet in for flavor. I've been here a couple times trying to give them a chance but each time, I've been underwhelmed. If you want fake, overly sweet Korean food, then ur welcome to try it out.
author: Abigail C.

description: Claim that they were open today. Drove all the way to sunset and realized that they were closed. Disappointed.
author: Kris C.

description:
Manna has replaced Little Bangkok. The interior looks the same, but a little more modern, brighter, and cleaner.

Bf and I came an opening day (Tuesday 6/28/11) for an early dinner around 4:30PM. The place was empty but people started coming in slowly after we were seated.

The service is very friendly and attentive. The waitress constantly refilled our tea and our FREE banchan before our main dishes came out. The banchan was very limited -- only five dishes and a complimentary sweet & spicy chicken wings dish (because it was opening day). I had the dol-sot bibimbap, which came with very moist rice that doesn't stick to the pot, but the meat was limited. I sampled some of bf's kimchi jaeyuk bokum (pork and kimchi w/ spicy sauce), which was very good as well. The amount of spiciness wasn't overbearing, however, there was very little pork and a lot more tofu. We were offered some hot soup, but we were too full to eat anymore.

Prices are extremely reasonable. All dishes are ~$10 or under, and dinner dishes are only $1-2 more than lunch dishes. The menus are tucked under a flat glass on the table, so you can look through it while you enjoy your food (and it saves the waitstaff the hassle of collecting them from every customer). I will be back.
author: Priscilla W.

description: This is my favorite my go-to neighborhood spot. I get a #10 every time-- veggie bibimbab with an egg in a hot stone bowl. Drench it in the mystery red sauce and it's the most delicious, perfectly portioned meal, that's healthy enough and fills me up for the long time. The staff is quick and friendly. I hope they never change
author: Holly L.

description: This place is pretty small so you can probably expect a wait. I've only came here once, from looking at all the good reviews on yelp, but I'm not sure if I would come again. I got the bibimbap and the rice and everything was pretty soggy, I expected the rice to be more crunchy:/ my friends and I also shared their wings and it only tasted OK to me. I've had better bibimbap and wings so I don't think I would make the trip to come back here again :/
author: Bailey L.

description: Parking can be hard to find here sometimes. Really depends if you're lucky or not. We arrived at 12:30 and waited 20 mins to get seated. The place itself is very small located at the corner of the street. We ordered the spicy sweet chicken wings, bulgogi, and soft tofu soup. We were satisfied with all of them and I will come back soon. The bill came out to 31$ and customer service was average.
author: Tina C.

description:
This Korean restaurant never goes wrong. Their food is amazing with such decent price that compare to others will keep you jaw dropped and just want to keep coming here. The only downsides is that this restaurant is pretty small like a size of a small café so when you go hopefully you get lucky and not enter when it's crowded. I only been to this restaurant once when it was crowded but our wait was only 5 minutes or less, we were surprised of that but very happy. 

The food I ordered were soft tofu soup, duk bok ki (rice cake and fish cake in spicy sauce), and dae ji bol koji (spicy pork in spicy sauce). As you can tell these food are all spicy but their spicy level is just the right amount so if you are a mild person, I'm sure you'll be able to handle these dishes. The dishes you order come with banchan (side dishes) and rice, you can request for more when you run out without extra charge. For the soft tofu soup they ask the spicy level you want and whatever level you get is fine because the broth goes well with the rice and you'll be satisfied. 

I would most definitely recommend this place to try because its in everyone's budget and its delicious, also I've told my friends and family members to try this place and they enjoyed it too.
author: Victoria G.

description: Small place but great food quality! If the line is too long just order to go and eat it elsewhere. Spicy pork, tofu soup, and dolsot bibimbap are my favorites. The sweet and spicy wings are out of this world! Been going back here for quick lunch and dinners when i cant decide what to eat, never wrong. [:
author: Grace W.

description:
Whao, I pass by this ALL the time when I go to Perilla but never got the chance to try it out until earlier this afternoon. Came around 11am on a Wednesday... sooo no long wait BOOYAH!

It was a tiny restaurant with less than 8 seats I would say. Their restroom is creepy as hell, because there was the heating system in there. I totally thought I walked in the wrong thing....  They have a LUNCH SPECIAL! Yay for cheap Korean food! 

THANK GOD THEIR MENU HAD DESCRIPTIONS, because I had no idea what half those names were.... (i may butcher their names, but im trying my best to remember it as I list):

#1 Kalbi $9.99: 3 stars. I've had better beef than this, and the portions were quite small. The meat consisted of mostly fat and bones. HOWEVER, it was 9.99 so I wasnt too whiny about it. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?userid=sd4E5iKUZotDEeiF3cC81Q#0pLHSc38AVZFuiC0S3a_kA
#3 Daeji Bugolgi (spicy pork) $8.99: 3 stars. I dont like spicy.... but it was not too bad. the meat was a little dry but oh wells. Good thing was it didnt have bones, so it was all sliced and easy to eat.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?userid=sd4E5iKUZotDEeiF3cC81Q#umb8Ehp-tYYZF_hAqSQoxg
#31 Dumpling: My friend got this one, and he said it was nothing special and not SUPER good or anything
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/manna-san-francisco?userid=sd4E5iKUZotDEeiF3cC81Q#O_YWQmJwWnrfJ86dSOQNNQ

The servers were friendly! Parking will suck if you dont come at the right time. Meters are free after 6pm I believe. 

Not the BEST korean place, but if you want cheap lunch special stuff, this isnt bad.
author: Chena N.

description: i loooove pork soondubu it's like my go-to for when i'm sad, cold, hungry, when it's raining, when i'm celebrating, etc. i was devastated when my fav spot in queens closed down, but the one replacing it became my next favorite. THIS place would be my go-to for pork soondubu if i lived in san fran. i wasn't expecting much but was sooo happy when the first bite hit my tongue.
author: Joanne M.

description:
Small, well-lit corner spot in the Inner Sunset. Lunch specials range from $6.99 (kimchi bokkum bap) to $9.99 (kalbi) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=SzGCuaojkMSYdjysNvVdPQ).

Six basic banchan (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=oFA1TfuQqpRT9rej6OQD0w) are provided. Overall OK except the sprouts which were starting to brown a bit.

The kalbi is LA cut (think Hawaiian BBQ) and you get 6 pieces with lunch (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tr15WgMHIC_W2gqBpuk3-A?select=NwHuyYxB66SZqeClS4JQFw). The meat was very tender and most pieces had a good meat / fat ratio, but a couple pieces were mostly fat (see right-most piece in the picture). 

I asked about getting some lettuce to eat with the kalbi and was told they don't do that here.

From other tables, it looked like you get more meat with the beef or pork bulgogi vs. the kalbi.

I think Han Il Kwan, reasonably close on the other side of the park, is a better lunch value giving a side of tofu soup and some bin dae duk in the banchan for around the same price as Manna, but if you're in the Inner Sunset looking for Korean food, this is one of the only games in town.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Meh. Seriously.

In all honesty, I would've rated this place 3 stars, but I had to take one star for their service.  It was appalling, really. 

We order kalbi, bibim naeng myun, and jap chae.  The meat and naeng myun were okay, though the only vegetable they gave me was sliced cucumbers. Seriously. You usually have an array of veggies with your naeng myun...not just 20 thin strips of cucumbers... but the real kicker was the jap chae.

We got our jap chae and it was, I kid you not, a noodle soup. Now, I know jap chae has some sauce - but this was DROWNING in soup. We looked over at the table next to us who ordered it as well and theirs was perfectly served. We politely asked the server why ours was so soupy and their answer was laughable. 

They looked over and pointed at the table and said that it came from the same batch and they just split it so that's why we got so much sauce.  uh. WHAT? So essentially...you're telling me, you're going to literally just dump whatever's left over from a batch you made and serve it to us...looking like A TOTALLY DIFFERENT dish?  Especially when the table NEXT TO US ordered the same thing?  We were speechless...we had no comeback for this. 

We ended up asking them to re-do it and the guy from the front came over and looked at us and RUDELY told us it's supposed to be like that. Now, I know I might not look Korean, but I'm half and have had my share of authentic korean food. I know my Korean food - as does anyone who's eaten jap chae. We knew that this was NOT how jap chae is served, at all.  He ended up taking it back and served us a new plate.  Still soupy, but much less. We think they did it on purpose.  But really. We weren't even mean about it!  we were as polite as possible, but when you pay for food and you don't get what you paid for... you have a right to politely ask for changes. That's it. 

I wouldn't come back here unless I really had to. I'll find another Korean place.  Mediocre food, rude service, and overpriced for the quality :(
author: Steph S.

description:
4 stars for the yook gae jang! I've had slightly better yook gae jang at Tofu House in South Bay, but it's only better because their noodle/topping portion sizes are much larger. The broth at Manna is on point and I drank every last drop of it. 

3 stars for the ban chan. The side dishes could have been more generous and lacked variety, but when I called them over for a refill, they were happy to oblige. I hate that they have chap chae but you have to pay for it!

2 stars for the service. Typically, I don't mind Korean service because while it's not friendly (sorry, I do not speak Korean), it is usually quick because they want to rotate in new customers. I had to bring the check up, request water several times (I never got my final refill), and wait 10 minutes for gochujang. I really hate having to spend large portions of my meal craning my neck to get the waitresses attention. In all fairness, the owner is very nice and friendly, it's more about having his team (e.g. wife?) more attentive overall.

1 star for the kalbi. there were like 5 pieces and it was like $12?! Flavor was ok but sheesh, I could easily eat 3 of those plates myself for lunch...
author: Jess C.

description: The restaurant is hella small so we had to wait for at least 20 minutes for a seat. I've only tried their bulgogi and it was pretty good. I think it isn't worth the wait especially when trying to find parking around the area and the prices are reasonable.
author: Josh D.

description:
Peanut and Peanut Butter M&M banchan. Yes, I said it. Yes, we had it here. Show me another Bay Area Korean restaurant that serves this, and I'll show you an imitator-never-duplicator of Manna.

I want to give this place 4 stars. The staff's friendly and all, but the menu and dishes we had just didn't whisper those sweet 4-star nothings in my ear... that is to say, in my stomach. My doenjang jjigae and my friend's dolsot bibimbap were good consumable warmth after our Jamba Juice around the block after our boxing class up the street after our Golden Gate Park visit across the way after my museum tour across town. Yet, as I said, the overall food + drink + service + ambiance experience didn't hit that home run for me.

As this was but our first visit, I'll have to see where my thoughts land after some additional meals here.
author: Dan B.

description: pricey but the food is incredibly good and definitely worth it. the kimichi fried rice was REALLY GOOD
author: Vivian C.

description: Walking down an SF Sunset street on a late, foggy Sunday, it's easy to feel teleported to the scene of Edward Hopper's 'Nighthawks'. Likewise, a dimly lit sign peeks through the fog delivering promises of boiling hot tofu soup and sizzling bibimbap. Intimate by design and delicious by choice, Manna gives us all reasons to Never Stop Exploring.
author: Ben H.

description: I live nearby and I come here pretty often. It's really affordable for korean food in the city. I'm always conflicted with writing a review because all I can say is everything tastes good - which makes this essentially an unhelpful review. If you're sharing, my go-to selections are the seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice, spicy pork, and japchae. If you're eating a single entree, always go for the wholesome bibimbap. Wait time and parking can be deterring so I usually come here during the weekday off-hours.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Small portions but friendly service from this mom and pop shop. I had the Dolsot Bibimbap (with bulgogi) and hubby had the Kalbi and Jap Chae. On our visit, the ban chan dishes were: kimchi, fish cake, sprouts, steamed broccoli, pickled daikon, and black beans. As far as flavor, everything was decent- but the portions were remarkably smaller than usual places. 

Cheap, has weekday lunch specials, and accepts credit cards. Nice.
author: Pearl V.

description:
Man, this place is so great. 
It has wonderful Korean food that is very well-priced. Their dishes are delicious and you get great portions, and the kimchi in their banchan is just phenomenal. I have had kimchi in many other places and they just can't hold a candle to this place. They do only give 6 options for banchan, but it doesn't overwhelm you and make you full before you eat your entree. 
The prices are great. My husband and I each got a meal, split a large Cass beer, and it was $25. That's such a great deal, and the staff is very friendly as well. Our server was friendly and had great conversations with us, as well as the owner. 

A+ place!
author: Erica L.

description: The owner was taking names down outside and adamant that we wait 5 minutes while a "John" comes back. To me, this showed that he cares more about his customers than seating people to order and eat. The kimchi and pork dish I ordered didn't have a lot of pork.. so I asked the waitress and she gladly took it to the back where they added more and I was much more satisfied. They took a while getting the food out, but the spicy chicken wings definitely delivered. The small dishes also was yummy. There was a dish of some kind of sweet beans and we had at least 5 refills on that! If you're looking for a cute place to take someone while being on a budget, this is the place to go! Our total bill was only $20!
author: Anna C.

description:
Good Korean food. Good banchan. Great prices.

Even as take out they provide a good amount of ban chan. 

Wasn't a fan of the kimchi fried rice. And considering that they charged $7 for kimchi to be fried with rice together, and then an egg placed on top....hmmm no.. I could do all that and only cost me $1 if not less. 

It's a small spot and is full often. So either do take out or be prepared to wait.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I like this place. Clean, good food, good service. On the smaller side, not ideal for 6+ groups.

Dishes I've had and liked here: 

- BBQ pork 
- yam noodles (new find! very tasty)
- seafood pancake
- dukbokki

Had the beef bibimbap in the sizzling stone pot - realized I'm just not a fan of bibimbap.
author: An Y.

description: Best bibimbop in the city!  I come here often and it's always consistent! My favorite Korean in the city!
author: Gregarious B.

description:
Great place for Korean Food. Parking is definitely hard to find and there can be a long wait if you come during dinner hours. 

This place has great food, and even greater management. If there is something wrong with your food they will take care if it. One time my friend was eating a Bibimbap and he broke his tooth after biting a rock (from the stone pot) that got mixed in the food. Well he didn't really break a tooth but he did bite it kinda hard. My friend was just going to leave it because to him it's an honest mistake, right when we were paying I mentioned it to the manager and he offer to remove it from the bill, we politely declined but he insisted.

Over all this location has great food at not so high prices and great management. From the times I've been here the servers are genuinely glad to serve you, which is a big plus.
author: Oriel F.

description:
Their food is pretty okay.  Bimbap was pretty good and I liked my friend's Kimchi fried rice but not sure for the price, and I liked also the Kimchi jaeyuk bokum a lot it comes with a bowl of rice.  :)   Their turn over rate is pretty fast.. it was pretty filled for a Wednesday, but weekends I'm not sure how it's gonna be.  

I wouldn't say this restaurant is 1 $ it's more like $$ because everyone's meal is over 10 bucks so don't feel like your meal is 5 bucks or something.
author: Juila L.

description: Excellent food!! Small neighborhood family business. Plain, Nov fancy location, but the food is a delightful tasty treat. Ordered the glass noodles with beef comma and pork with tofu and vegetables both dishes were amazing. Also served with four or five small appetizer plates. Enjoyable meal highly recommend when looking for Korean food.
author: Sharine d.

description: Get the spicy bulgogi (it's basically spicy pork) + bibimbab! So good together, and very affordable. I live in South Bay and this place is so much cheaper than Korean restaurants in the Santa Clara/Sunnyvale area.
author: Ji Su L.

description:
Having moved out of the hood almost a decade ago, I thought Manna was newer than I realized. I've only been going for the past year and all instances were good, but in retrospect, there are some issues. 

Off the top of my head, the seafood pancake is excellent, the wings are hit-and-miss, the bulgogi is great, and the fried dumplings were fantastic. Portions are always surprisingly substantial. The octopus is one of the worst seafood dishes I've ever eaten in my entire life. It was like trying to eat spicy racket-balls, in that some parts were so over-cooked that I literally could not chew through them, and the sauce was dull.

Service is friendly, but it's hard to get a glass of water or a timely refill on tea, and I've been unintentionally skipped on the wait list because they couldn't figure out which side of the sheet they were using.

Pleasant staff, good food, reasonable prices, and ample portions, but not a great dining experience overall.
author: Quinn S.

description: Delicious tofu soup but they don't give you an egg to crack into it like other places do. Decently priced too. Bibimbap is pretty good though I like Hahn's Hibachi's better. Small little shop but with a good atmosphere.
author: Liv T.

description: Small place. Maybe 30 seats. Looks to be a family-run operation. Seems to be very popular in this neighborhood. Ate the seafood soft tofu soup. Very good. Very efficient service and very reasonable prices.
author: Rosemarie C.

description:
My all-time favorite: spicy tofu soup!! (with beef or chicken, depending on what else I'm having)

Their spicy tofu is always something I get every time I come here. It is just right and not too expensive! I always ask for mild; maybe next time I'll try medium spice. It tastes so good with their rice, yum. Not too oily either. And it's perfectly suited for the foggy and cold weather in San Francisco.

Their bulgolgi can sometimes be dry, but I usually throw it in with my spicy tofu soup and rice combined kinda dish. If it was more juicier, I would probably like it more. Otherwise, I'm not complaining. It is still good, but I've had better bulgogi elsewhere.

I've tried their Dolsot bibimbap, and from what I remember it was really filling that I could barely eat anything else.

They offer a small variety of banchan, usually consisting of mini broccoli, bean sprouts, this tofu cake-like dish, kimchee, and this potato thing that my sister really likes.

Parking can be hard in this area since it's near so many other businesses and a popular area for dining, so maybe if you come during off-hours for lunch and dinner, you'll be lucky.

Why I keep coming back is because their prices aren't as expensive as other Korean restaurants I've been to, and it's close to home. Everything is decently priced, and the quality isn't bad, but it could be better. They have lunch specials which are usually dishes a dollar or two cheaper than what's on the dinner menu.
author: Kathleen S.

description: Cheap and good place to get korean food. If you come at the right time, you can easily get a table but usually around dinner time there's always a wait. I always get the dol-sot bibimbap when I come and it's so filling and I usually have to take half of it in a to go box. The food is good but the service could be better. If you ask for a refill on the side dishes, it's like the waiters/waitresses don't want to get it for you and when they replace them they kinda just throw it on the table. But overall it's a good place to eat if you're in the mood for korean food.
author: Celine C.

description: Hands down the best Korean restaurant in San Francisco! The sweet and spicy chicken wings and the kimchi fried rice are my favorite. The bulgogi, short ribs and all the side dishes are delicious. My family and I go here frequently. Plus, they've always provided great service.
author: Genevieve G.

description:
When I crave for Korean food I go to Manna. Its rather small and always full so best to come early when planning to eat here. I used to go to Kukje Supermarket where they have a Korean restaurant in the grocery but after trying the food at Manna I was impressed. 

All meals come with tea, rice and an assortment of banchan, including kimchi, bean sprouts, brocolli and my favorite are the fish cakes. Tried the bulgogi, the spicy pork, short-ribs and the sweet spicy chicken wings.  Everything I had was strong, spicy and flavorful. The best part about it is how cheap the menu items are.  If you want to get full on a dime with good food and friendly staff Manna is the place to go!
author: Maria M.

description: I never thought I would find a authentic Korean restaurant so close to where I live. I guess I found one! This place was small but the food is mine blowing prices are very fair I will definitely recommend and come back!
author: Ron H.

description:
Love this neighborhood Korean spot

Everything on the menu is good.

1.  Seafood pancake is delicious 
2.  Chicken wing are up to par 
3.  Spicy pork is tasty 
4.  Bibimbops great 

Must try this place.  Weekend dinner hours - about 1/2 HR wait.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
This is a small but cozy Korean restaurant.

I have been to a number of Korean restaurants and this one does not necessarily disappoint. That being said, I wish its side dish portion could have been bigger - although they are really yummy!

I ordered the signature dish bibimbap in a hot stone pot. I think it is tasty but the dish was extremely hot - even after 30 minutes or so. 

The place is really small. The servers are really nice and attentive and constantly bring out side dishes for me. It is rather inexpensive.
author: Maria G.

description:
If I had the option to not give this place a rating that would be it, but one star it is. We came and they put us on the wait list. Didn't tell us that they are closing  and had us wait.. End result kitchen closed sorry but not sorry. 
Food looks great service is bad. Find another place.
author: Justin A.

description:
I have now eaten dinner at Manna twice in the past 5 days.

On both occasions, I ordered the soft tofu soup and the dol-sot bibimbab.  The soup, which I ordered medium-spicy with vegetables, had great flavor and definitely hits the spot during this winter season. The bibimbab was also very tasty and was served in a sizzling hot bowl.  

The portions here are huge, especially for the prices. You can eat here for about $10/ person and you will probably still have leftovers! 

It's a small place, so during key times, there might be a wait. But overall, this is a good quick casual place for some delicious Korean cuisine! 

I can't wait to go back and try more items on the menu!
author: Juliana K.

description: Manna is the place I go to whenever I crave Korean food in the city. Their tofu soup is the best I've ever had. Forget about Tofu House, that place is bland compared to Manna. Bibimbap and chicken wings are also really good, not to mention the side dishes that just keeps on coming! I would skip on the bulgogi and the spicy pork though, those were nothing special. The food always comes out quick and the workers are always courteous. Also, they have lunch specials on weekdays, so try this place out if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Karmen T.

description:
Cheap and yummy Korean food, you can't go wrong.

Came to Manna for lunch with a couple of friends on Monday noon. Luckily it wasn't busy inside the small restaurant so we were able to get seats quickly.

We ordered the chicken wings, japchae and the kalbi to share. The chicken wings and japchae were delicious! The kalbi was a bit tough to chew but it was nice and juicy. The banchan was typical kimchi and pickled veggies.

Will definitely be back for more!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Whenever my friends and I want Korean food, we always head to Manna.

Great service with good food!

I came here today with about 5 other people. We arrived at a good time because it wasn't too busy, and they were able to seat us. However, about 10 minutes in, it became pack. This is a cozy little place.

So here are some of my to-go to for this location:

Bibimbap - there's a lot of vegetables in it and it's very flavorful and filling. I love how it's in a stone pot, so the bottom becomes crispy. Don't forget to mix it around so you can quickly cook your raw egg on top. If you don't like raw eggs, they'll be more than happy to make sure it's cooked!

Tofu soup - all the tofu soups are delicious. I love it. You'll receive a side of rice with it.

Japchae - I love these noodles - so good! 

Korean pancake - so fluffy and delicious. You can't go wrong.

Side dishes - Unlimited and delicious. They are very responsive in helping you refill them in a timely manner!

Overall, I can't imagine any of the dishes being terrible. It's so good! 

I think the customer service is so nice. The lady and guy are so thoughtful and helpful. Whenever we see them, they have such a warm smile in helping us. This place is amazing, check it out!
author: Margaret L.

description: My first ever time I ever had Korean food and it was absolutely great! We got seated right away. We ordered a spicy pork and a sizzling plate of beef which was very flavorful. Whenever I go by this place, this place is always packed which means the place is a good spot to eat. Parking can be quite difficult, but really worth looking for to come to this place.
author: Anriella D.

description: Aside from the wait time, this place was the best korean I've had in the city. The staff was friendly and helpful, and the bi bim bap was perfection all at a very reasonable price. Cannot wait to go here again.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I think we ordered slightly wrong this visit as a couple of the dishes were similar and we probably could have widened our selection.  But alas, this is how your learn!

Despite this slight hurdle, the food was yum.  Rice cakes with fish cakes and kim chee, kaldi, bbq chicken, another kim chee stew with tofu and pork and jap chae.  And of course all the yummy little sides.  We had a great meal and the service was spot on.  There was a line out the door and there was no pressure from staff for us to leave as we lingered and chatted.

Definitely would go  back!
author: Ada C.

description:
I came here for lunch. It was cheap, delicious, and portion sizes were pretty huge. Between me and my friend, we ordered the kalbi, kimchee pancake, and tofu soup. The kimchee pancake was HUGE and it was really really good. The kalbi was also good, i don't remember much about the tofu soup, it was pretty standard. I don't think they gave us an egg with it though.

Overall, I was really happy that I got so much delicious food for a really good price.
author: Christina L.

description:
I came here for lunch, and I was able to find a table easily. I tried the kimchee fried rice, and while it was good, I wish there was an option of adding meat to it. But I also tried the fried dumplings, and they were delicious!

The service was good, and they don't rush you out.
author: Rachel H.

description: I'm spoiled coming from Queens, NY, where Korean food is extremely authentic. My general suspicion here was that the banchan given here was standardized to "not be too exotic" to non-koreans, as it was a bit boring. I tried the soondubu, dolsot bibimbap, and dukbokki here before, the first two were pretty standard, definitely good enough, but the dukbokki was one of the worst I ever had (then again, I had that one on a very busy night so maybe they screwed up one time) but it tasted totally undercooked and not chewy like it should be. Eh, unfortunately I've yet to find a better Korean place in SF so far.
author: Crystal Y.

description: The sweet and spicy chicken wings are a must try! I come here often but the sweet and spicy wings are always sold out. So if they have it, get it. As for the other food, everything I have tried has been delicious !
author: Fiona Y.

description: The Resturants wait time is sucks . There have no line food is just whatever . Serious plz not to come !
author: Kiyto T.

description:
Really like the food they have here! The best part??? The food here is relatively cheaper than your typical Korean restaurant! I love coming here for lunch because it's fairly cheap, and for the quality of food you're getting, you definitely can't complain.

When I come here, I generally either get one of the tofu soups, a bibimbop, the seafood pancakes, or the jap chae. Regardless of what I get, there honestly hasn't been a time where I've had a bad experience with what I ordered. Not to mention, I love the side dishes that they give you too!

Only downside is that this place gets busy pretty quick, and being that the restaurant isn't too big to begin with, you're most likely going to have to wait. Not to mention, parking is absolutely horrendous out here in the Inner Sunset. Be prepared to be circling the blocks forever because spaces hardly open up...yay, so fun.
author: Aaron W.

description:
After a haircut down the street, and a quick stop at the nearby Arizmendi, actual hunger finally hit. Kevin's Noodle House was too far to trek to in the rain, so we settled for the next best thing on a cold, rainy day: sundubu!

Manna was pretty empty when we arrived around 430pm, and started to fill up a little after 5pm, so service was pretty prompt. We ended up ordering:

* Banchan - So these come with basically anything you order on the menu. At six types, they offer up a smaller selection than other places I've been to, but, considering how much tastier they were, I didn't particularly mind.

* Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings (Kanpoongki, $9) [ http://bit.ly/YCTboY ] - Crispy and flavorful, but I can't say I was a huge fan of their particular flavor combinations. Still enjoyable, but I definitely prefer the ones over at places like SO or Aria. And, worth noting is that our entire dish was mostly drumsticks, not wings - not that I'm complaining, because I much prefer these anyway!

* Soft Tofu Soup with Beef, Spicy (Sundubu, $9) [ http://bit.ly/U8XMaL ] - Flavor-wise, Manna's sundubu is probably among the better ones I've tried in the Bay Area. Great flavor, good spiciness, and all around heartwarming and filling. That said, there was a pittance of meat in the soup; and where was our egg?!

Tasty eats, albeit with a few minor qualms, lands Manna with a solid 3.5 stars.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The restaurant is a bit small, and the tables are arranged close enough together that, when busy, will probably require that people get out of their chairs to let those in wheelchairs pass by. Otherwise, no real impediments, and they even have a motorized, button-operated door!

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
My favorite Korean place in SF yet! 

The tofu stew and seafood bibimbap hits the spot, especially in a cold foggy day. Love that the dolsot bibimbap had the right amount of crunchy rice at the bottom. I definitely savored each bite. Banchans were of a decent amount if you're eating alone or with another person. 

The place is quite small so I wouldn't recommend it for big groups. Nothing to complain about the service and the price. Compared to other Korean places, it's quite surprising to see just one "$." You get your money's worth here.
author: Emily M.

description:
Loved this dinner place! We came early so there was no wait and they were VERY accomodating about gluten-free. They made it clear what sides are okay for me. And then even made me a separate gluten-free sauce to add.

Really great service and delicious, cheap food. Wish I could come back!!
author: Tanya S.

description:
One of the few spots for Korean in the near vicinity of UCSF, it is a popular spot frequented by UCSF staff/students and Inner Sunset residents alike.

Food: The menu includes staples like soft tofu soup, bibimbap, various barbecued meats, and noodles and stews. The food is tasty, if a little salty, and reasonably priced. Try their soft tofu soups and seafood pancake. There are lunch specials as well. 

Service: Service is quick and attentive. It may take a while to get seated though, so be prepared to wait at rush hours. 

Ambience: Pretty casual. The dining area is one room and pretty crowded, but cozy. The menus are underneath glass on the tables. Good for casual dinner or lunch with friends.
author: J L.

description:
Friendly Staff, Accommodating Kitchen, one of the best Korean restaurant's I've been to in the city. Prices are great as well.

As a vegetarian, dining in Korean restaurants can be tricky, but Manna is super accommodating and won't try to stick you with sub-par quality with sans meat as an excuse.

What to eat:
Tofu Stew
Stone bowl Bibimbap
Veggie Pancake (ask for a mix veggie option)
Bean paste Stew

Definitely a neighborhood go-to spot!
author: Crystal F.

description:
The dolsot bibimbap was delicious and hit the spot. The burnt rice on the bottom is especially good compared to what I have tried before. All the side dishes are fresh and flawless as well. I also hear their chicken wings are tastier than San Tung's so it will be worth a try next time.

Service is great and the food will definitely be worth waiting in line for. Best Korean restaurant in the area! Would definitely recommend to anyone craving some quality Korean food in SF.
author: Jean H.

description: Ugh this place is so good and so affordable!! The bibimbap bowls are exactly what you want to eat during a rainy week in San Francisco and the service is quick and friendly.
author: Eliza D.

description:
We originally wanted to eat at the chicken wing place, I forget the name.  It's some restaurant on Irving, but since that place was super packed and we were starving, we headed over to Manna.

Service was very friendly and we ordered a ton of different things:

Seafood Tofu Soup
Mul Naengmyeon
Vegetable Dolsot Bibimbop
Seafood Dolsot Bibimbop 
Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings

They had a good variety of tasty banchan.  My tofu soup was yummy, full of flavor and lots of seafood.  The Naengmyeon was really tasty too.  I prefer it with a bit of vinegar, but my sister enjoyed it as is and gobbled that up.  My two friends who ordered the bimbimbop both seemed to like that as well.

The chicken wings were kind of amazing.  I wasn't expecting much, but the spices in the wings totally surprised me.  It was SO finger-licking good.

Parking can be a bit difficult around peak hours, but we were able to find a metered spot on Irving after circling the area a couple of times.
author: Stephanie L.

description: The food here is terrific! I usually order the Bibimbap and substitute chicken for beef because I personally don't like beef. I enjoy eating my tasty Bibimbap and the side dishes that come complementary. It is more than enough food for me. I also really enjoy the barley tea that is good but typical of many Korean restaurants. Prices here reasonable considering what you get and the service is good and quick. The place is kind of small so don't be surprised to wait 20 minutes if you arrive during prime meal times. They have a lunch menu.
author: Joseph T.

description:
As a New Yorker recently moved to SF, it's been a very difficult transition away from ktown into the vast 7x7 jungle of food. Where is the Korean food here?! Luckily, I was near the Sunset district and my family was craving Korean, so this was the first thing that came up on Yelp.

I loved the generous portions and the mom-and-pop-ness of the shop (does that make sense?). Service was excellent and attentive and the servers were incredibly nice, especially with refilling our tea and sides. The Kalbi was a bit fatty but it was a humongous plate and the bibimbap was also giant. I ordered the kimchi jigae which was way bigger than the stone bowls in NYC in ktown. I didn't think it was particularly special, but it hit the spot and there was sooo much kimchi. Wish there was a little more pork :( A girl needs her protein.
author: Lulu P.

description: Food is great! Customer service was alright. I had to ask for water a couple of times until they gave me some. It wasn't even busy... Food gets three stars!
author: Jenny N.

description:
Lunch special! Surprised they had it but its awesome. I could get korean dishes for lunch without spending dinner prices. 

Staff is pleasant and food while slim portions is decent compared to a lot of other korean restaurants in the city. Parking is a PITA though.
author: Jude N.

description:
Not a bad spot for Korean food. This is a very small restaurant, so expect a wait to be seated during busy times. Parking in the area is usually a nightmare, but we lucked out and found something right out front.

The service was really attentive and friendly. I liked most of the food, but some was just okay. I would say that a couple of the banchans were not great, but most were very good. The bulgogi was decent, but (being Korean!), I've had better. The soon doobu stew was good, but spicier than expected. I was with a friend, and we asked for medium-spicy, but I would put the stew that we got at "very spicy," which was fine for me, but could've been way too spicy for my friend.

Overall this is definitely a decent spot for a Korean food craving if you're in the area.
author: J K.

description:
Took my traditional Korean parents here and they loved it!

Pros: Delicious food and great side dishes - we ordered the bibimbap and and stew that was flavorful and yummy (my dad liked it)

Cons: Gets really busy, you may have to wait, there isn't a ton of parkign either

The Yelp reviews aren't wrong - this is a great korean option (among many) in the area.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Had a late lunch here with some high school friends on the recommendation of another friend Diane C. because she was raving about this place. Iono what's up with her, but she played me. It wasn't even all that!

We had to put ourselves on the waiting list because the place was jam-packed like a can of sardines and waited for about 20 minutes to be seated. We all waited outside because there definitely wasn't enough space inside for our party of four to stand around.

We decided to divvy things up family-style and ordered the dol-sot bibimbap, kalbi, and kimchi bokum bap from the lunch specials menu. However, note that their lunch special runs from Monday-Friday. They must've misinterpreted what I said because they brought out the kimchi chigae (#19 from the regular menu) instead of our kimchi bokum bap (#19 from the lunch specials).

I felt bad for having sent it back to the kitchen, but the waiter seriously gave me hella shit. I told him about the problem and he brought it back to the front where he talked to what seemed like the owner and pulled up our tab. He came back and addressed the lunch specials vs. regular menus and had the nerve to roll his eyes at me. We came on a weekend and didn't read the menu thoroughly to realize that the lunch specials only apply on the weekdays, but we still ordered from the lunch specials and the waitress that took our orders didn't say shit. They were probably throwin' shade up front, but despite the confusion on both ends, were nice enough to correct our order. Good call because things were about to go down!!!

The food was decent, but had the potential to taste a lot better. The kimchi definitely wasn't up to par, the dol-sot bibimbap was bland and skimpy on the beef, the kalbi didn't have enough flavor, and the kimchi bokum bap was just greasy. This pretty much sums it up to "plain" in four different variations. The total came out to about $34, which seemed just right for what we had.

Maybe it was just the time of day, but I'm indifferent. I'm no Korean, but I definitely know enough to say that I've had better. You definitely get what you pay for here. This place is alright, but there are plenty of other better Korean BBQ places around Sunset that are worth trying.
author: Peter L.

description:
So SFGATE wrote an article about this spot and my heart fell. I knew that a few things were going to happen:

1. prices would go up
2. people will flock here.

dropped by last night before the dinner rush (thank goodness). As I ate, the line did get pretty long. good press will do that to ya.

This time I ordered galbi tang. Galbi tang is soup made from boiling beef short ribs w/ water, daikon, green onions , a handful of yam noodles and an egg is usually stirred in somewhere. This is one of my favorite comfort/hangover dishes. 

btw, galbi tang here is only $10 as opposed to $15 everywhere else in SF.

Manna definitely did not disappoint last night. I was full before I even got 1/4 of the way into my stew because of all the banchan I kept munching on. Beef in the galbi tang was super tender (as it should be) and the flavor was just awesome. 

Banchan quality has gone up a notch. They definitely are not stingy with it here either. They always ask if you want a refill of anything when they notice you are empty or low on it. 

The prices haven't gone up (yet) but they probably will later. Upon mid scoop of rice into my galbi tang, I looked over and noted that Chris Cosentino was eating here. 
I have an inkling that Manna will continue to do well ;)
author: Susy C.

description: Good restaurant but long wait for food as they focused on take outs.  Not even snacks for an half hour.
author: John L.

description: Although its the pricier side, the quality of the food is really great here! Always order the Mulnangmyeon, Japchae, Bulgogi and Kalbi. The barchan that comes on the side is really good too, especially the kimchi, I feel like they made it themselves or something cause it taste very homemade. Parking can be harder to find on weekends but its def easy on weekdays if you are planning to eat here!
author: Cavin T.

description: Delish!!! Ordered the hot stone Bibimbap and the Grilled Octopus.....so yummy and flavorful! Reminds me of awesome Korean food in LA! :)
author: Chase B.

description: This is the new spot not only were the people incredibly nice but the food was bomb.... I still dream pf the spicy cold noodles. Plus they include a variety of little appetizers like kimchi and broccoli and refill upon request! Next i need to try the kimchi pancake looks like heaven
author: Brigitte C.

description: Great little gem :) I was craving soft tofu soup and this place hit the spot! Service was nice and the place is well lit and clean. Perfect food and rich flavors ... Ideal for lazy weekend days when all you need is good comfort food :)
author: Mariana S.

description:
One of my favourite Korean restaurants in San Francisco. Tasty food for a decent price. They have a fair selection of items, though I usually go for one of their soups. Banchan are fresh and plentiful. Service is good

The restaurant is relatively small and there can be a wait at peak times, but no more than at many places in San Francisco. There are a lot of businesses around this part of Irving, so parking can be challenging - if you have a few people in your party and it's food prime-time, consider driving by and having someone put down your name on the list, then use the wait to park.

They have a lunch menu also, which I've yet to try - it's only a matter of time, though!
author: Seán O.

description: Tiny place with extremely limited seating. Expect a 45 min wait on a Saturday night for dinner if there are more than 3 people in your party. I will say that the wait was worth it. Kim Chi fried rice, seafood pancake, sweet and spicy chicken wings, spicy pork, and bulgogi were all delicious, I have no complaints.
author: Briget P.

description:
Just left here without waiting for a table one minute longer. Two couples were seated, we were third. Another couple who comes after us is waiting further away from the door. The guy who takes down names comes out and starts a convo with the other couple:

Owner: Hey man, how's it going?
Guy: good... hungry man... it's date night you know?

Owner takes down our name after... and this is after my husband has already been inside the restaurant to TRY to put his name down. The guy totally ignored him. Didn't put the other guy's name down at all either.

Mind this, there has been a table open for 5 minutes now. All of a sudden, the other couple gets to walk in and sit. 

Right. And off we go too. Never coming back to this place. B*tch, it was our date night too.
author: Liana L.

description:
Panchan: I liked all of it except the kimchi. The kimchi tasted like it has been fermenting a bit too long. It tasted sour and not spicy. I will pass on their kimchi. 

KimChi Jaeyuk Bokum $9.99: I like the taste of this kimchi bokum, it was on the sweet side, but it worked well with everything we ordered. Everyone I went to dinner with was very impressed with this dish. 
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Mv_hcaEIqKlz0yBgPX-SKQ/l.jpg

Soft Tofu Soup $8.99
I was disappointed for getting medium on the spice level.  I was afraid that if I got it spicier, no one at my table would be able to drink it. It was good and the price for it was reasonable. I would come back here again and get it at extra spicy!
http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/h7uvra3HC5SnvU47Z9PeQA/l.jpg


Kanpoongki $8.99
This was good, just the wings we got were on the smaller side. Love the crispiness to it. 
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XhowR4lplD5bE_icFaQrZQ/l.jpg

Dol-Sot Bibimbap $9.99
The stone pot wasn't hot enough to get the extra cooked layer of rice on the bottom, but it was still good.
http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bq9dJGnZLX-jJ2JgfqTPsg/l.jpg

Seafood Korean Pancake $9.99
The cheapest seafood pancake I have ever had. There was more batter than usual, but for the price, it is understandable. My friend, who has never been to many Korean restaurants liked this dish a lot. Sauce for the pancake was a bit on the salty side. 
http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bSmRrNkH78-8cophZzkGjA/l.jpg

Service was awesome, the lady refilled our tea cups often and they were very attentive with empty plates to make room for our other dishes. Panchan and rice refills are free!! Prices are really good and I would come here again! This place is way better than the place I went to in Daly City.
author: Erica T.

description: I love their seafood pancake as well as soy sauce wings. I'm not a huge fan of their bibimbap or hot tea.
author: Fernilla S.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE. If I don't need kbbq and want a Korean fix this is my go to place. This is one of the few places in NorCal where the Korean food is amazing and not going to make you broke!! I suggest the seafood stew and the Short ribs. DROOL! There could be more side dishes but I mean 6 isn't too bad. I've been to places that has given me 3. The service is always friendly but word of caution parking in the area is terrible and the restaurant is kinda small so there is usually a wait during the peak times. It is worth it though.
author: Maybo H.

description:
This is the first Korean restaurant in SF where I thought the food was solid (and trust me: I'm Korean). The banchan was fresh. Do they make their own? Who knows? But it was fresh, and the kimchi was exactly the way I like it: crunchy and spicy.

We ordered: fried dumplings, seafood pancake, seafood soon tofu, and kalbi. The fried stuff was standard. Note: I used to say that you can't mess up fried food... but I learned the hard way that people actually can. No problems here though. The tofu soup had a good kick and full of rich tofu. Wish it had a bit more seafood though. And the kalbi was a bit sweeter than my mom makes, but the meat was tender (maybe a bit more sear next time?).

The best part was I ordered all this and stuffed 3 people for about $60 total. I usually spend that much on one meal by myself!
author: J J.

description:
It's on the corner, and it's even though it's SF, it's what you think of when you think of hole-n-the-wall (note: I've been to actual hole-in-the-walls, this isn't one but it's what I imagine most people envision before hitting up their first hole-in-the-wall). 

For what actually matters: the food: the soft tofu soup seems like the way to go when eating here. I had a basic spicy pork dish (Dae Ji Bulgogi), and we also ordered the seafood pancake. The tofu soup was way better than my pork, not saying the pork wasn't good, it just paled in comparison with the tofu soup. The seafood pancake was a decent appetizer, it splits nicely between 2-3 people. 

Bottom line: go for the stews or soups, they're what really stands out, they're hot bowls of goodness in your mouth, just waiting to happen.
author: Liz P.

description: Well, I've eaten here three times. The first time was because I always saw lines. I thought the food was average. The second time I ordered the Kal bi beef. It was good. The third time I noticed the cook opening a package of instant noodles like the Top Ramen type. Now that was a real turn off for me. I'm sure they doctor it up but, come on man, packaged instant noodles!
author: H L.

description:
Best Korean food in the city!!! Been here
Many times and never Dissapointed! #9 bimabap is the best! And their sides are so good! 
I've been to a few other Korean places in the city, but nothing beats manna!
author: Tatyana S.

description: The owner here is a great guy. Food is delicious. I try to get takeout at least once a week here. Great service.
author: Mario A.

description:
I was able to get a great vegan gluten free meal here with no trouble at all.
The owner / manager knew exactly what I was talking about when I asked questions about soy sauce - he said "gluten free"!   The egg on the vegetarian bibimbop was easily changed to tofu, and the meal already had no onions in it.  The waitress was very nice and warned me about onions in the little things brought to the table without my even asking.  

The food itself was very good.  I only wish they offered brown rice here, in addition to white rice.  Otherwise, everything was fantastic.  The vegetables were properly cooked, the tofu was fresh, the rice was good.  It did take a while to eat the meal because it was so hot when it came out.  

If Manna offered brown rice, I would go out of my way to come here.  Since they only have white rice and I don't live in the neighborhood, I'm not sure when I'll be back, but if you are vegan and / or gluten free, or have an onion allergy, this is a great restaurant to visit.  

The hot tea served instead of water was also very good.
author: N T.

description: Best Korean food I have eaten so far in the states. Must visit when in San Francisco staff speaks good English for been korean.
author: Frederic S.

description: the last time i came here was a year ago, but the flavors of my particular dish have changed. the first time i came here, i ordered the japchae and it was absolutely delicious! during my second visit, i ordered the same dish but it was drenched in salt. i couldn't even finish it because the salt was too overpowering.
author: Mary ..

description: I'm currently on a strict diet (low iodine diet) for two weeks so I was hesitated to order anything off the menu. My plan was to enjoy a hot cup of tea while my friend gets to indulge. The owner came by and took our order. I told him my restrictions and gave him a list on what I needed to avoid. He was like that's doable and immediately pointed out the beef bibimbap. So of course I was excited that I can actually eat something. When the side dishes came out, without asking he came to the table and pointed out which one I can eat. Overall, my experience was amazing! I love the fact that he was knowledgeable on what he was serving and the food by far was worth the wait. I can't wait to come back when I'm off my diet and actually try other things on the menu without any restrictions.
author: Myle T.

description: It's such an authentic South Korean food the service is impeccable，I left good memory there, bibimbap and soup (I forget the name) is my love.
author: Gary C.

description: There was a 30 minute wait on a cold night, but the food was hot spicy goodness. Love this place.
author: Jesse C.

description: Pretty darn good food! Plate was licked clean. Place is a bit small and you sometimes have to wait awhile for a table but totally worth it.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
Every time I drive by this place, there is always a line out the door. I've eaten here on two occasions and for both occasions, I came right before the crowd and was seated promptly.

Manna is a very tiny restaurant with a large selection of Korean food. I especially like their bulgogi dish. Because the place is so small and many dishes are soups or come on a hot plate, there is the potential of the restaurant itself getting a bit warm and humid. 

Not the best for large parties, since it's a small place, but there's lots of Korean food to choose from. Best for smaller parties.
author: Nirel R.

description: This place is to die for! The seafood pancake is so amazing!
author: Jocelyn G.

description:
Manna

Came here on a thurs afternoon around 3 , and got seated right away.

My friend asked for the lunch menu even though  we were late, and they said yes:)

Mt friend ordered the Kalbi plate and it wAs good.
I ordered the chicken stew which was also prepared correctly.

They have a good chef here.

The waitress was cool too.

I would definetely come here again and bring my friends :)
author: DOM d.

description: This  place is so good. My family and I came here for an early lunch and everything is so yummy and fresh. The food comes out sizzling, the kimchi is delicious, it's all just so good. Plus the staff are wonderful and friendly. Definitely deserves 5 stars. Yum.
author: Brianna J.

description:
Food is average, 3 stars, but throw in a star for the very attentive and friendly service.  The staff is quick to refill everything.  The space is somewhat claustrophobic.  

The banchans are decent.  They're quick with the refills.  The seafood and tofu soup was rather salty.  i preferred it over the disappointing seafood pancake, which was too doughy and rubbery in consistency and did not have enough seafood.  

I'd probably hit the Richmond for better Korean food.
author: Kris H.

description:
What sets Manna apart from the hundreds of Korean restaurants in San Francisco is their ban chan. Manna gives 6 simple dishes of ban chan-- kimchi, anchovies, broccoli, sprouts, fish cake and picked radish-- nothing fancy but everything fresh and delicious. I couldn't believe how crunchy the anchovies were. I've always thought that they're supposed to taste semi-stale but that's because that's all I've ever known. 

For such an itty bitty spot, Manna has a pretty decent sized menu. My dinner date, Karleen, ordered the spicy seafood stew while I went with the seafood soft tofu soup and we split an order of the chicken wings. Both soups were hearty and flavorful. I can taste the sweetness of the clams in mine-- again, something I've never ever experienced in Korean tofu soup before. The chicken wings didn't top San Tung's chicken wings for me but it was still delicious and I couldn't have enough.

The owners were so friendly and accommodating. Even though it was my first time, I felt like I was treated like a regular. A regular, I have no doubt, I will become in no time!
author: Tiffany U.

description:
I love coming here, their portions are huge and moderately priced. Kim Chee is really good too, i like to add it to my bi bim bap. Speaking of which, dol-sot bi bim bap is amazing, toasted crunchy rice yummm. The korean bbq is really good also. 

On a cloudy sunset day this is a warm inviting spot to have a large lunch or dinner. Close to 9th & irving N line muni stop and academy of sciences/de young museum. Not to hurt Tortoise's feelings but I think Manna might be the best korean food in town.
author: Cortland T.

description: Dol sot bibimbap with whatever hot sauce sits in the red bottle on the table hits the spot every time. Great meal if you want something warm and comforting but are tired of the Sunset's many pho and ramen places. It does get busy, but I arrived around 5:30 on a rainy Friday night and there were several tables open. Also a bonus for the neighborhood - they take cards, not cash only.
author: Alaina B.

description:
The GF and I went here on a Friday night at about 7pm.  Luckily I found a parking spot across the street as someone was just leaving their spot.  When we arrived, there just happened to be one empty table in this extremely small, and cozy restaurant.  We were immediately seated and took a look at the menu.  There was a table next to us and some one was eating a burrito and snacking on chips.  No shame!  

We ordered the ramen, yam noodles with beef and vegetables, and soft tofu soup.  Food came out fairly quickly.  All orders come with rice and an assortment of  typical Korean side dishes.  The ramen tasted good.  If you like packaged ramen, get it!  They also top it off with an egg.  The yam noodles were really good.  They tasted fresh- a lot better than the ones in Korean supermarkets that are prepackaged.  As for the tofu soup, it was good too.  I got the medium spiciness and it wasn't too bad.  And I am usually a wimp when it comes to hot food.  Inside the pot are pieces of meat, cucumbers or zucchini, and tofu.  It was especially nice on such a cold evening.  Feel free to ask for more sides or rice if you want them.  I am sure they would give it to you.  

Superb service served alongside better than average Korean food is what you should expect here.
author: Victor L.

description: We went to Manna because we decided to quit waiting in the line for the Shan Dong restaurant next door. It was a good decision. This was a relatively small Korean restaurant, but was not crowded when we came in. We ordered bulgogi, tofu soup, bibimbap, and cold noodle. The side dishes came along with bulgogi. We liked all the dishes.
author: Sfo B.

description:
Solid Korean joint (3.5 stars) with prices that are significantly lower than comparable restaurants. We got the fried sauced chicken, the seafood pancake, and the pork bulgogi and the final bill was $31, so not a hit to the wallet when you're hungering for Korean. The seafood pancake was huge, though not as much seafood as you'd expect. Pork was pretty tasty and the portion size was perfect. 

Banchan were average, and nothing stood out (bean sprouts, kimchi, broccoli, fish cake, sweet beans, potato strands).

Tiny restaurant, so expect at least 20-30 minutes of waiting in the chilly Sunset.
author: Kevin L.

description: I didn't have high expectations when I first heard about this place...good Korean food in the Sunset? What are the odds? They have definitely won me over with their great food. Expect to wait if you come for dinner. I usually see a line every time I walk by in the evenings. About the food, the banchan is solid. I've tried the tofu soup, seafood pancake, kalbe, bibimbap...all of it is yum. Not a great place for groups.
author: Alice H.

description:
I was really impressed with the food and service at Manna! 

Seafood Pancake- YUMMY! Good crunchy bottom with tons of fresh seafood and fluffy batter. A must order. 

Spicy Tofu Soup *Soondubu* Spicy- Great flavor and again.. fresh ingredients! Spicy but not unbearable. Really hits the spot. 

Bibimbap (in the stone pot)- MMMM... YES, PLEASE and THANK YOU. I will be craving you soon. 

Manna is really clean, the food comes out looking amazing and you can actually taste the high quality ingredients and attention to detail in preparation and plating. And the owner seems like a really nice guy who cares about the food he serves and about making sure his customers are happy and satisfied. I don't want to get into too much detail or this review might end up being an essay, but I was really impressed with the service. That plus the delicious food... 5 Stars, no hesitation. One last thing... there are so many korean dishes to choose from you might have trouble deciding!
author: Christine L.

description:
Super authentic Korean restaurant makes you feel like you're (back) in the motherland.

I get out of sparring pretty late twice weekly, but lucky for me Manna is on the way home. It's the perfect post workout meal.

I've had their Beef Rib soup at least half a dozen times, and the quality is consistent. And a platter of the popular bbq beef or pork in the Korean style is enough for dinner plus a snack in the morning.

Like most popular outfits in the area, they don't take reservations but the line isn't obscene. And if it is, you're on Irving, where good food is always nearby.
author: Christophe C.

description:
I came here with my parents tonight for dinner, and my experience was solid like the my other past visits.  Excellent service, friendly owners, great side dishes, tasty dishes, and affordable prices.  What more can you ask for?  

My dad is usually picky and well, he isn't too big of a fan of Korean food.  But, I brought him to Manna, and he said liked everything, which was "very tasty."  Tonight, we ordered the yuk gae jang, dolsot bibimbap, kangpongi, and bulgogi -- all of which were tasty, fresh, piping hot, and absolutely mouthwatering.  My only 1 minor complaint is that the broccoli banchan was a little salty.  But other than that, this place is still GREAT!!

I was afraid that there wasn't going to be table for my parents and me, but when we got there, there was a table that fit us perfectly.  We were greeted with a warm welcome, and it made the experience even more enjoyable.  I always feel like family when I come here.  Manna is a keeper. :)
author: Matthew L.

description:
Ok so this is the spot I promised never to reveal but the owner who is a real deal sweetheart deserves the review. Go here for the real soup as my x-Korean girlfriend said she has never had better soup!
But it is all good & the pon-chon is the best!
Enjoy
author: Urs F.

description:
My to-go Korean restaurant! 

Since it's pretty near the N-train, I usually don't bother to drive here because parking is quite hard to find. 

Good food, good side dishes, good prices. I really like their tofu soups and bibimbaps. Have yet to try their dishes of just meat, but I will be back!

One con is that the restaurant is pretty small, so there might be a wait depending on the time you go. I would advise against going with large parties because their biggest table seats 4! 

If the wait is too long, no worries. You're on Irving so you can probably find another restaurant on Yelp.
author: Michelle D.

description: A nice Korean restaurant to go to for someone who wants to try Korean food for the first time. Came here for dinner and ordered the chicken wings, seafood stew, bibimbap, and the bulgogi. The chicken wings were pretty good and had similar flavoring to San tung chicken wings. The seafood stew was a slight disappointment. There wasn't much flavor and did not remind me of tofu soup, even though it looked like tofu soup. Their bibimbap and bulgogi were very delicious though! Flavors were on point and highlights the strong and bold flavors of Korean food. Overall I did enjoy the meal. I did wish they offer more tofu soups but aside from that I would come back again. Staff is very friendly and the banchans were also very good. Place is on the smaller side and it is located on Irving so do expect a wait and finding difficulties with parking if you do decide to come here at night.
author: Wendy Z.

description:
We got food to-go tonight, I'm not sure if I just ordered the wrong thing, but I just wasn't feelin' it. 

We ordered mild Mushroom Tofu Soup and mild Pork Tofu Soup. The pork was okay, but the mushroom was underwhelming. I considered the fact that maybe its just not as good taken out as it is sizzling hot out of the clay pot. 

The lady was really nice and gave me extra fish cakes, but they were a little on the spicy side. 

Next time I'll eat in and give it a try.
author: Ping N.

description:
Food was flavorful. Bul kogi was perfect and came out on a sizzling plate. The DolSot Bibimbap was yummy as well. I let it sit for a while so the rice gets crispy. Staff were very nice and came by to refill our water and tea.
Downsides...small restaurant and small selection.
author: Lisa N.

description: I wanted to love it. I liked it. In particular, the bulgogi was so-so. Meat was not fresh or flavorful. Banchan were limited but good.
author: Andrew K.

description:
It's a ma-and-pop's kind of Korean restaurant - cozy and the food feels homemade. Given that there aren't many good Korean restaurants in the city, I would say this is the one I will probably go to for Korean food cravings. :) 

Pros:
- I really do like their dishes: Tofu bowl, Kimchee pancake, Dukbokki, Dol Sot Bibimbap, and this sweet fried chicken (forgot the name).
- Fair prices
- Friendly service

Cons:
- Parking is very difficult in the area during weekends
- Long wait as it is a small restaurant

Tip:
- They do not take reservations, so I would try to line up early and quickly.
- No Korean BBQ self-grill
author: Frannie C.

description:
Bf keeps taking me to these other korean restaurants. Why did he not take me to Manna earlier in these past 2 years we've been dating?! 

So good. Happy friendly staff. 
Lots of choices on menu.

Bi bim bap was yummy.
Small tables. Small place. you may hear your next door table mates' conversations.
author: Veranna N.

description: Probably my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. Portion sizes are so good for the price you pay. Also, you get the side dishes too, which is pretty sweet. I hear lunch specials are good here too. I really enjoy the soft tofu soup on a cold evening, especially in the sunset. Ah, so good. so filling. Service is just alright here. They can be a bit forgetful sometimes I think when it's a bit later in the evening.
author: Julie L.

description:
So there is a small story going into this place.  

Once upon a time, I went to college in Davis and there was a Korean restaurant called Manna.  A friend suggested, "oooh! we should go there!" Another replied, "uhhhh no, it's not the same Manna as the one in SF."  Given that I'm from SF, I had no idea what this Manna place was, where it is, and how it compares.  Eventually some later time, I tried the one in Davis and it was disappointing .____.  Decided to take my little cousin out one time and since she's never had Korean, I went onto my trusty Yelp app and THIS Manna came up. Hazzzah! I finally tried it. -- End of lame story.

Whoever that friend was years ago that spoke of this Manna was correct, this Manna is so much better.  It's a very small place and had about 10 tables all together from what I recall.  Good thing we went on a week day and some random time in the afternoon, we didn't have to wait too long hehe.  Though, after being seated, it did take some time to get the attention of the waitress.  Of course, that could be my fault too because I sat on the side facing the window and my little cousins doesn't know what to do at restaurants because she's a hermit. :P  Anywho, got the orders in: Kimchi Fried Rice (typical), Seafood Pancake (also typical), Chicken Wings (Most obvious), and the Bibimbap (I never order this because I had it once somewhere before and I just didn't like it.  My cousin wanted to try it). 

FIRST OF ALL, that is way too much food for us.  I always overestimate how much I can eat.. But it's okay because we both had a full box of to-go ^____^  The chicken was crispy, just the way I like it! And hot too;  a lot of times I've been to place where the chicken is not as hot as it should be.  I like it when I burn my tongue..... lulz, jk. But you get the point.  Seafood pancake had a lot of stuff in it, less of the mix which it awesome because so many places, all I eat is the pancake mix.  The Kimchi Fried Rice, duhhhhhhh. Best I've had ever really.  I almost didn't want to share with my cousin because she said she liked that dish the most... But of course, being the kind and generous person I am (no, not really)  I shared ;)   And lastly, the bibimbap! To my surprise, I really liked it.  I especially liked the crisped rice at the bottom. Yummmms, don't tell my mama, she will go off about my health. 

So there ya have it! the only downfall was the service because it cleared up by the time our food came out and it was hard getting attention for water and such but eh! She was still super nice and all. 

I also got very lucky and found parking right in front in the corner, heheheh. 'Twas a good day, the day I finally tried SF's Manna.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I dream of dolsot bibimbap.

I never really tried Korean food before I came here because I had always been afraid to dive into this cultural flavor experience. However, I am so glad I finally experienced this. 

The food is beyond amazing. Complementary appetizers were good, although I wish I knew what they were. I ordered dolsot bibimbap--best decision ever. The meat was marinated perfectly. The ratio of ingredients was just right. It was a satisfying and life-changing meal. Korean food is one of my new favorites thanks to this restaurant.
