The place itself is tiny and warm. There can be kind of a long wait to get in depending on the day, but this restaurant is 100% worth the wait. The food is fairly inexpensive. Servers are patient, friendly, and helpful. Can't wait to come back here again.
author: Idk A.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant in the Sunset! Their food tastes great, staff is friendly, and prices are super cheap and even cheaper during lunch! I usually get the Dol Sot Bibimbap (bibimbap in a hot stone bowl), which is only $8.99 during lunch and $9.99 during dinner. They also have many other Korean dishes (bulgolgi, galbi, japchae, tofu soup, seafood pancake, etc.) to choose from and all at affordable prices. Their banchan is also always fresh. This place can get pretty crowded though especially during dinner time. It doesn't get too crazy, but I suggest coming early unless you don't mind waiting a bit!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Every time my friends and I decide to come here for dinner there seems to be a fair wait. We came here on a Saturday night and it took us around an hour to be seated for a party of four. Granted, this is a pretty small place and I don't think I'd recommend this place if you have more than 4 people unless you're willing to wait even longer for tables to empty. I imagine shorter waits for parties of two. And as other reviews have mentioned, be prepared to circle this area for parking.

That being said, the food came out relatively fast and it was pretty good! We ordered bulgogi, ddeokbokki, and a seafood pancake. It came with the usual banchan and two bowls of rice. We had no expectations for the seafood pancake but we ended up liking that the most because of the crispy outside and delightfully chewy inside with a pretty generous amount of seafood (I think scallop and squid?)! The bulgogi and ddeokbokki are what you would expect from any other Korean place so no surprises there!

As for service, wait staff were attentive when we needed refills on tea or banchan. Nothing extraordinary in terms of service, but they were nice!
author: Jessica Y.

description: awesome local business! good food at very affordable prices compared to other korean restaurants. the staff is very friendly and attentive. it's a small restaurant that frequently has a line, so if you live in the neighborhood i'd recommend ordering pick up -- they still pack a subset of banchan togo!
author: Jessica C.

description:
I am lucky enough to get in there without a need to write down name, I am just dining myself alone. Got a table. Selected Spicy Seafood stew. The seafood today is soft shell crab,Mussels 4 big one, and some calamari,  vegetable: cucumber, onion, garlic, tofu. Just this stew alone already fill me up and the price is inexpensive $12.99.
When the stew come to my table, a gentlemen next to my table ask the servers what number of my dish is, kind of envy of my dish,, Lucky me pick the right one.  The servi ce is great because the restaurant is kind of small. I definitely will go back if i come to sunset district.
author: Thomas L.

description: The owner works the floor so he makes sure the service is pretty good.  This is one of the better Korean places in SF.  The quality of the meat is good.  The place is super small so you can get in if you come at a lucky time.  The free small dishes are really tiny.  We ate through two rounds of free dishes and found out that they don't give 3rd rounds.  The bibimbab was decent enough.  Tofu soup comes with an egg but you have to ask for it.  Again place is really tiny so don't bring a huge party.
author: Byron L.

description:
I visited Manna on a Wednesday evening around 6:30 p.m. and the restaurant was about half full.  The restaurant space itself it quite small, with fewer than 10 small tables.  Luckily, there were a couple open tables next to each other, so my group of 5 could be seated immediately.  The menus are printed like placemats, located under the glass table top, and we were quickly given cups of hot tea.  Within minutes of ordering our meals, there were a variety of side dishes brought to our table (kim chi, bean sprouts, little dried fish, fish cakes, broccoli, potato).  Manna has written on their menus that side dishes are unlimited and they are good about refilling them when empty.  The side dishes were pretty standard tasting.

My boyfriend and I ordered (and shared, as usual):

-Sweet and Spicy Chicken Wings ($8.99): these come out fresh from the fryer- be careful- they are hot!  The sauce on top of these fried wings is very thick and very sweet with a little bit of spice.  The flavor is pretty good, but the sweetness can be overwhelming after a few wings.  The order comes with 9 wings- so it'd be good to have someone to share these with.

-Beef Bul Kogi ($10.99): A generous portion for the price.  The beef was soft and the flavor was good.  

The food came out hot and the service was very helpful.  We got refills of our water, tea, and side dishes many times.  However, my only complaint was that the food did not come out at the same time.  Two people, who ordered bibimbap got there dishes right away.  My beef came about 5 minutes after and the two orders of chicken wings came another 10 minutes or so after.  Since we were sharing our dishes, this didn't really affect us too much- but I could see that this would be slightly annoying otherwise.  I'd say this is about 3.5 stars, but I'll round up because the service was so friendly and there isn't any other place to get Korean food in the neighborhood.

Notes:
-Unlimited side dishes and rice refills.
-Free hot tea.
-Parking in the area may be difficult, depending on the time, but is usually manageable.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Manna was just OK.

After living in the Sunset for 6 months, I've always been meaning to try Manna and last night, I finally did. 

My friend & I ordered the seafood soon dubu (soft tofu soup) and the dolsot bi bim bap. My tofu soup was nothing special. It seemed like there wasn't that much tofu in it. My friend said her bi bim bap was just "okay". To me, the food here doesn't seem to be able to compete with what you can get in the Richmond District, including dishes at Muguboka, My Tofu House or Han Il Kwan. Not only are the food portions at Manna smaller, but it lacks flavor and substance.

The service was quite slow, and I had to ask for tea (went practically the whole meal on an empty glass) more than once. While our server was polite and thanked us for dining with them, I did not feel they were adequate enough to make me a repeat customer. Especially with SOOO many other options for Korean food here in the city.

One plus: the prices seem SLIGHTLY lower than most other Korean restaurants. Apx $1 - $3 lower.. but I'd rather pay the higher price for better quality!
author: Mari S.

description:
Oh man, this is it. This is my go to place for Korean food. Whenever I need some comfort food, I go here. Caught a cold? Then the spicy tofu soup is just what you need (well, okay it's just what I need). Craving some meat because you're a little t-rex? Then get the bulgogi. 

I've tried more dishes from the menu, and none of them have disappointed. This place is on the small side - you might get seated in the middle of the restaurant, where you're party might be rubbing elbows with nearby patrons, but no biggie. There are other corners on the side if you need more room because you talk with your hands or something and don't want to accidentally hurt the person next to you (does it sound like I'm talking from personal experience?) 

(cuz I am) 

Delicious food, decent service. I come here a little too often, but it's still never enough.
author: Mico G.

description: Visited Manna on a whim because Yummy yummy is closed on Tuesdays and San Tung had a waitlist for lunch.  Not to say my party didn't have a great meal.  Our meal was delicious!  The sides all blended well, not to mention--limitless!  The Bibimbap was pre-sauced up with tons of vegetables and a wet egg.  The BBQ Spicy Pork was sizzling, and those carmelized onions :*** mmmuah!  The tofu soup (regardless of having no egg) was perfect for my taste.  The seafood pancake as appetizer could be eaten without soy sauce.  Other than a tiny loo and limited tables, everything tasted right.
author: Janet T.

description:
I love Korean food. And it's hard to find good Korean food with good portions at a good price in SF (at least that's been my experience - and please message me if you have suggestions!!!).

Manna is close to my house so it's a satisfying walk especially on a cold Sunset night given you're about to eat some hot and spicy yums. The place is in fact small, so don't rule out having to wait a bit (seems to be about 30 minutes tops). They turn over tables quickly; however, I at no point felt rushed to complete my meal. A benefit to the small space if you're social like me, is that you get to interact with your neighbors, especially in the case that they're eating something that looks good and you're curious what it is.

The last time I was there, my husband ordered the beef bibimbap over rice. He loved it alongside his Cass beer. I ordered the kimchi chige (Kimchee-pork soup which is my Korean go-to). It was delicious. alongside a bottle of clean soju. It could  have been a bit more spicy but that aside, the flavors were excellent and a perfect portion. The banchan portions and quality were very good. Their kimchee is quite nice.

Come here for a casual dinner, heck, maybe even a 2nd or 3rd date dinner if you're feeling like getting off the grid a bit. Service is excellent. I can't wait to come back again and continue my journey through their menu.
author: Greg Z.

description: Inexpensive because we left paying around $50 for 4 people for dinner. We had 5 dishes - soup, duk bok ki, kalbi, bulgolgi, and their wings. The wings were dry, which is disappointing because it's usually so good here. The soup was delicious. I didn't try toe duk bok ki because my sister said it was too spicy for her so I stayed away from it - but they did like it. The kalbi was good, but had a lot more fat than meat this time around. The wait was extremely crazy on a Friday night. We waited over an hour til we finally got seated. The place is small but has a homey feel with good service. Parking is hard too, so I suggest you coming with someone that will write the name down while you hunt for parking. They also don't seat you until most of your party is there.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This is a great korean restaurant and I plan on coming back soon. Growing up in Southern California, I have always been surrounded by amazing Korean food. Relocating to the bay area had been quite a shock for me since the korean population is not as dense in the city. I hear there are more abundant choices in east bay and in Santa Clara, but both options are far. I came here during a weeknight with my boyfriend and parking was terrible (as usual when it comes to Irving Street).

The wait wasn't that bad, we only had 2 parties ahead of us. I dropped off my boyfriend so that he could sign us in and I was basically looking for parking during our wait time.

I ordered the yukgaejang which is spicy beef soup with clear glass noodles, bean sprouts, green onion, and slices of beef. I would have liked the more traditional ingredients in here in addition to what came out, but nonetheless the dish was wonderful. I asked for it to be cooked extra spicy and they delivered a complete 100%. My boyfriend ordered the galbi which also came out good, but honestly you can't really mess this dish up. 

I liked the staff. It's an authentic restaurant with a korean wait staff and from what I saw a korean cooking staff as well. The service was great, which threw me off because usually good korean restaurants have terrible service. Not complaining though :) 

I will definitely be back!
author: Heather R.

description:
I wouldn't say this is the best Korean food ever, BUT! It is probably one of the best Korean food in the immediate inner sunset area (there are a few good ones that are further in outer sunset and richmond, though). 

Small restaurant with about 7-10 tables, mostly 2-person tables. Don't try to go there with more than 4 people, it's unlikely you'll get a spot.

I pretty much just always get the dol sot bimbimbap. My husband likes the spicy stir fry small octupus. I have not tried other things there, but from what others ordered they look good too. 


Overall:
--- good convenient location in the inner sunset shop zone
--- decent typical Korean dishes at reasonable prices
--- decent all you can eat appetizer small dishes that come with every meal
--- mostly 2 person seating, has maybe three 4-person tables
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Not too exciting, it's an OK Korean place.  The side dishes are good.

The place is small and gets crowded probably more due to lack of competition.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I've been coming in here once in awhile for a couple of years now and it still is good korean dishes for a solid price.

All the tofu soups are really filling and delicious. All the meat dishes I suggest you split with a friend and get another dish because it gets tiring with just the meat. Spicy pork is my favorite.

As a note, the banchan, which my fellow Yelpers adore, isn't why I keep coming back here. But it is good and a great addition to your meal. 

Don't be afraid for ask for more banchan they are really nice about that as long as you ask! 

Overall, coming here on a budget or not, your stomach and wallet will thank you :)
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Korean food is one of my favorites. Coming from LA it's hard to find a good spot in SF that can compare. Although, I really wanted to love this place, everything was just mediocre. When I walked in everything smelled great. Ordered beef bibimbap, seafood tofu soup and chicken wings. Tofu soup was super watery. Not bad, but not super. Staff was nice though, so extra star for that! I would still say give it a try and see for yourself.
author: David D.

description: I think that this is the only Korean restaurant on 9th street.  The food is good and I would get the dol-sot bibimbab with an order of the sea food Korean pancake, its quite nice on a foggy day.
author: jon f.

description: Terrific food, lovely presentation, affordable lunch specials.  Go now.
author: Dean B.

description: Excellent bibimbop and kimchi fried rice.  Cool space, good prices.  Service was a little bit slow but we were enjoying a lazy dinner waiting for a show anyway, so maybe the staff picked up on it.  Everything smelled delicious right when we walked in - the space is really inviting and intimate, and the smells made my stomach rumble.  Great experience.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Been here twice. 

I love Manna! It's a small, cozy place. Great food, great service, decent price. Side dishes!
author: Christina G.

description:
Came here to get take out one, and the owner carried all my food and walked me to my car. He understood that parking in this area sucks, and that I was small and would probably drop all the food. The service, smiling faces, and great portions for the cost is what keeps my family and I coming back here every time we want Korean food. No, their taste might not be the best, but they oust every other competition with price and service. 

No extra charge for rice or side dishes! They don't try to rip you off. All I need is for nice thick slices of pork in the Kimchijjigae, and I'll be in love. I find ground meat always a no-no in any dish (unless specified).
author: Christal Y.

description: Awesome bibimbap. Amazing sweet and spicy wings. Huge seafood pancake. Standard service. This place did not disappoint.
author: Jo L.

description:
mmMMMMMManna! 

Going to school in San Diego where there are tons and tons of legit and authentic Korean food and then living in San Francisco; let's just say that I miss the former when it comes to this type of cuisine! Nonetheless, I am SO happy to have Manna. It's yummy, close to where I live, pretty cheap... and basically is great comfort food for SF weather.

FOOD
-#9 Dolsot Bimbimbap!!! This is my favorite Korean dish. Ever. It's $10 for a nice big bowl of this, including kbbq. (Some places you have to pay extra for the meat) It comes with everything - sliced carrots, bean sprouts, sliced zucchini, sea weed, and egg. Everything, including this comes out hot and fresh off the stove. This dish be my favorite for ever and ever and I approve of it here at Manna.
-#13 Seafood Soft Tofu Soup. Love. I get it at level spicy and it's pretty tolerable. Flavor-wise, this is bomb. Seafood-wise, it doesn't always have tons of it in it. The last time I had to make sure there was seafood in it - I was afraid they had mixed up my order. However, it is no additional cost to include seafood in this soup ~$9 so it didn't bother me much that it didn't have as many squids and clam as I would have liked. 
-#28 Seafood Pancake. I've never seen such a HUGE seafood pancake! Seriously, it's just so much! Lots of seafood (ha, I noticed there was more of it in here than my seafood tofu soup). Comes with dipping sauce. Totally worth the monies to get this.
-#4 Dak Bul Kogi. Get this if you like BBQ chicken and lots of it. Since it's the only thing in this dish, make sure to order something else to balance everything out.
-#26 Kimchee Jaeyuk Bokum. Sweet tofu, pork, kimchee and gochuchang. I really liked the tofu since it is sweet.

SIDE DISHES
-All orders come with side dishes (banchan) of broccoli, fishcake, bean sprouts, kimchi, sweet black bean, and potato strips. 
-Free hot barley tea + refills with all orders.

PROS
-Everything listed above! 
-Food comes out pretty fast :)
-Great service!
-Good for parties of 4, and 2s.

CONS
-Closed on Mondays :(
-Gets pretty crowded during dinner, so come early! 
-No proper ventilation... it gets pretty steamy, so, foggy windows from the outside.
-Don't wear a big jacket. Your clothes will smell like fooood.
author: Grace J.

description: This is a nice casual place to go eat Korean food.  It is very small, and quite busy, but the service was good and the food better than average.  I had the Hae Mul Tang    (seafood soup) lots of mussels, crab, and and it had a good level of spice.  Banchan was good, they have Boricha (barley tea) and the staff is pleasant.
author: Brian S.

description: Best Korean restaurant in the Inner Sunset. Love the Bi Bim Bap! Fantastic place for lunch. Not too many tables so be prepared to wait during peak dining times.
author: Anna N.

description:
I've been searching for cheap Korean eats in the city for some time now and am so happy to have found Manna! I came here a few nights ago for dinner and was pleasantly surprised by the quick seating, fast service, reasonable prices, and food in general. I was happy with the selection of six banchan which they were happy to refill - kimchi, bean sprouts, dried anchovies, broccoli, shredded potatoes, and braised tofu.

We ordered beef bibimbap in a hot stone bowl and soft tofu soup with beef, which both came out to be under $20. Amazing! The bibimbap was perfect - loved the crispy rice edges and the fried egg on top. The tofu soup was delicious too, especially with the raw egg mixed in. One thing to note though - the mild really is mild so if you're looking for a bit of a kick I'd suggest taking the risk and asking for spicy. We ordered the tofu soup mild and I wished it was a bit spicier. 

Definitely worth the trek out to the Sunset!
author: Tiffany F.

description:
When it comes to Korean food in SF, I'm usually a lil skeptical.  So when I saw that this place was rated 4 stars, I knew I had to try it out, and boy I was not disappointed.  

Ordered the spicy pork bulgogi and daengjang jigae, and it tasted like my mom's cooking back home.  Side Dishes were also very fresh!

So SF krns originally from SoCal, if ure ever missing ur mom's cooking, don't hesitate to try this place out!
author: Joshua P.

description:
With all the Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai, Japanese, and Indian establishments running amok along Irving, a solid Korean restaurant was the only thing missing. Finally, that hole has been filled!

In the mood for pioneering, we decided to dine at the freshly opened Manna for our July 4th dinner. While the banchan selection was a little weak (only four), the Dol Sot Bibimbap we each ordered was delicious. Beef, assorted veggies, fried egg, and rice all sizzling in pot. There may have been fireworks in the sky, but chowing down on this was like fireworks in my tummy.  And service was awesome to boot! Friendly and super attentive, one wouldn't have guessed they were juggling a full house, with even more patrons waiting outside. 

Barely a week under it's belt, yet Manna is laying it down like a seasoned champ. FOUR STARS!
author: Natasha H.

description:
You don't have to traverse GG Park and go to the Richmond for good Korean anymore. The Inner Sunset is now one step closer to being a Sim City microcosm. 

Stopped by Manna for a solo lunch after visiting a client in the area, happy to be away from Sixth Street for the afternoon. Korean food is often manna for my ailing body, but there were no sniffles that day, just a void that was eager to be filled by my favorite food.

After walking in, I was immediately plied with tea and tasked with choosing lunch from either their lunch menu or regular menu. They're offering nearly everything you'd want from a Korean restaurant: bibimbap, japchae, bbq, jiigae, hite beer :)  

Why did I have to choose? In the Bible manna appeared with the night's dew. I deliberated for awhile, but chose the seafood soft tofu soup. The banchan were tasty (kimchi, bean sprouts, broccoli, and a few more), and offered to be replenished by the nice waitress. The soup was a spicy stew of kimchi, oysters, shrimp, and squid, with rice on the side, and was wonderful, once it cooled down enough to be eaten.

Going to a Korean restaurant alone is always challenging, because I fill up on banchan before the meal comes, which is usually way too much for me. Manna's servings are perfect. They arranged their lunch menu (11am-3pm) with healthy but tempered appetites in mind. I still walked away with some leftovers, but not half of their kitchen nor enough to feed a Sim City. 

Sorry, simmites. You'll have to come to this bright, corner spot on your own, or join me for dinner. Judging by their menu, we have a beautiful future ahead of us.
author: Joanna M.

description:
JAL-MUG-UT-SEUM-NI-DA . I'm not korean, i just cut and paste from google!
(4 stars)

When Korean people are making the food and serving, you know your going to eat some authentic korean food! This place is underrated... where are my fellow yelpers? Fantastic place deserves reviews!!

- Food, delicious
- Prices, good
- Service, very well taken care of
- Ambiance, small cozy  and clean restaurant - nothing fancy

After a good abs & cardio workout an apetite is built for something tasty. Driving aimlessly around the city looking for something to hit my cravings, I turned to my bookmarked yelp restaurants for help and came here. From first walk-in to leaving the restaurant, great service. Very friendly and humble people that really engaged on a good level with their customers. 

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

BANCHAN (free) - served 6 different banchans. give me a bowl of rice, i can eat banchan on its own and call it a day! Oh, and their kimich is LEGIT!! that's the taste i love, not store bought or prepackaged, it was just homestyle kimchi.

DOL-SOT BIBIMBAP -without the beef ($9.99) - I was going to order the typical bibimbap but the nice server lady told me this dish was more popular. i can see why! I had asked for chicken instead since i'm currently no red meat/pork in my diet. The big sizzling bowl came out with my dol-sot bibimbap with an egg on top. mixed it all up and ate as much as i could. SO GOOD! I'm not much of a hotsauce person but i was mixing it up and even adding some kimichi in it. The chicken was bbq'd perfectly. The vegetables were very fresh. 

Will I be back? I already have my favorite korean restaurant picked out in the city. but this place is still a great place that I will come back to!

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
Close to a half-hour wait on a Saturday night after San Tung looked like it wasn't in the cards for us. Being outside in the cold made us feel even happier to score a coveted two-top and be offered strong and yummy tea.

Got the seafood bibimbap -- delicious. Adam got the sweet and spicy wings, which were good but could've used a little heat. His entree came long after mine, so we wound up sharing both. Topped off with soju, the bill ran to $31 and change. I'd come back.
author: Allison L.

description: Decided to stop by here on our way down for UCSF after seeing a packed restaurant with only a 7 minute waiting list. This is my second Korean restaurant, but not my 2nd time trying Korean food (my roommate is Korean). The kimchi pancake was very good, and very sizable. I also really liked the bibimbap was good. The spicy+sweet sauce went well with the beef. I also liked that it was served on a hot bowl and kept cooking the whole time. Lastly, we got the short ribs. They were sweet and good, I personally like beef to be cooked a little more, but I guess it was cooked in more of a Korean Style.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Awesome spicy wings! Galbi and bulgogi were tasty but a tad on the greasy side.

This is a great lil family joint. Wait times could be long on weekends (45mins) as they only have a hand full of tables. Prices are pretty good compared to other korean bbq places in San Francisco.
author: Jason C.

description:
I've never had a bad experience here! The food is always excellent and the service is always amazing. 

So far I've tried seafood bibimbap, soft tofu soup, chicken wings, bbq beef, ddeokbokki and the Korean pancake (made with seafood).

They're always consistent and they never disappoint!
author: Eka A.

description:
I've been to this spot like 3 times and last time I went, I was just disappointed. 

Tofu Soup -  I asked the waitress to make it SPICY....  was it? It was just barely spicy. I was super bummed. 
I also asked to refill 2 of the side dishes (bamboo shoot and kimchi), she came back with just the bamboo shoots,  not kimchi!  AHHH!  

And then the seafood pancake was so salty I didnt even bother dipping it in the sauce. 
The food was a meh, service was a meh. 
I used to like this spot, but now, I'm gonna have to find myself another korean tofu restaurant in that area. 

:|
author: Tipsy T.

description: Food was excellent! First time I've had Korean in many many years! Had kalbi and it was delicious! Also had the seafood pancake, it was a bit soft and not cooked all the way but still good seasoning!  Waitress was nice and got everything we needed. I'd definitely come back!
author: Sara S.

description:
Brand new spot here in the Sunset, thought I'd give it a try. 

Still a new place, but it was packed. It's TINY inside.

They had no issue with us waiting for a specific table (I'm a table snob and when you walk in to the right hand side is a little table for two tucked away all by itself.. yep THAT is a table worth waiting for ..away from the noise!).

Our server was so friendly and happily answered all our questions. Their were quite a few items they were out of, and also a few that were listed, that they hadn't been prepared to serve, I'm going to assume this is due to them being a new establishment. 

Grilled BBQ chicken was so-so. Soft flavor, a little chewy, big portion.

Shrimp Fried Rice w/ Egg on top was decent, a little plain in flavour. The description said w/ veggies, but all mine had was green onion. I wasn't very happy with my meal. Also a big portion.

I would give them a try again in a few months after some of the kinks are ironed out. It's always hard to judge a place shortly after they open.
author: Meghan L.

description: I've been here a few times.  My favorite dish is the soy chicken wings.  Good portion and delicious.   The free tea is also very good. It's a bare bones space. No reservations accepted.  I usually eat there around 3pm to avoid the long lines. I'm pretty sure they are open all day which is great.   Parking,  not so great. Worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood.  Definitely try the soy wings.
author: Eleanor L.

description:
Love, love, love this place. Korean food is legit; I should know, my mom is Korean. I've never had anything that wasn't super good. My favorites include the dol-bibimbap, of course. So good, not stingy with the components. I really like their seafood pancake too; there's seafood popping out of the pancakes everywhere. I also am a huge fan of the seafood tofu soup; you can tell them how spicy you want it. They're kalbi and bulgogi are yummy as well.

I wish this place was bigger though! There are only like 10 tables; so get there early if you have a big group. Oh and the PRICE IS SO REASONABLE. You get a lot of food for your monies. :)
author: Kayla F.

description:
Long wait? No problem! I'll just look for parking and get some boba while I "wait". Hehe. 
Food was just as yelpers yelped! Good, well worth it, and worth the wait!
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
Simply Amazing, try the deep fried dumplings, the short ribs, and the japchae....  
Deeeee-lish!!  

Only downside is the place is tiny but fortunately the food is worth the wait!!
author: Concerned C.

description:
BF wanted Korean and I wasn't willing to go to the Richmond. Plus, i was getting kind of broke because of stupid summer school. So after trusting fellow yelpers, we chose Manna.

The place is easy to spot. It's on the corner. We found parking easily at the meters, but i can see parking trouble later at night since it's near a busy area (Naan n Curry, Crepevine, Starbucks, ect.)

Came in and got seated right away. I'm slightly claustrophobic and the place felt a little suffocating. I feel like in order to get around I have to side step between tables because they're that close. Bathroom: REAL small. You open the door and the sink is right there. Then you have to walk past a water boiler I guess, to get to the toilet. I liked that they had mango soap though. =)

I want to say that there are maybe 12-16 tables.

Anyways, back to the main reason why you're probably reading this review! The food. Yum.

Banchan: Only 5 small dishes. We got kimchi, bean sprouts, these really hard peanuts, broccoli, and potato. I was disappointed that I didn't get any fishcakes. That's my favorite. And after looking at the photos, I'm even MORE disappointed because I could tell that previous yelpers got fishcake or a different variety of banchan. Maybe it's a weekly thing?

BF got bul kogi. Came on a sizzling platter and a bowl of rice. I want to say that it's just enough for one person, probably female. Male? I'm sure they'd want more meat, but at 8.50 for the lunch menu, it wasn't too bad. 

I ordered the dol-sot bibimbab. It was either that or just bibimbab. I kinda have a thing with food coming into stone pots and sizzling platters. I feel as if a hole in my stomach has been filled with yummy, sizzling, crunchy, food. 

Our bill came to $19 even. It should have been a little more with cents, but they were nice enough to just leave it off!

The female waitress was very attentive! She refilled our tea plenty of times and come over maybe three times to ask if we were doing alright. We got our bill without needing to asking and she came and took it no longer than a minute or two after we set it back down. There was also a couple next to us who ordered something but found it too chewy for their teeth. The waitress allowed them to make a different order and didn't seem bothered at all by it.

Overall:
+Lunch menu was decent. Right price depending on what you're getting 
+ Service was good

- Parking can be hard, especially at night.
- Place was very small
author: Jennifer Q.

description: I like the bbq there. Bt over all, too salty for me, and i wonder why there's no brown rice...
author: Tian H.

description:
definitely a place to go for a good homely korean dinner. 

I order their tofu dish and it is as good as the one @ seoul garden in NYC but seoul garden comes with an egg which top the dish off.

Price is reasonable according to my friends or cheaper than most places. We had 4 dishes and 2 app comes up to be around $60ish tipped. and the owner is really nice as well as everyone there i guess. People on the west coast are so much nicer

Place is really small. I think seat for around 20 people and the wait can last over 30 minutes. I highly suggest you come here if you here for a visit then head over to twin peaks for a good time.
author: Kevin Z.

description:
Great lunch deals here.
Ban Chan constantly refilled
author: Geordie E.

description:
We both love Korean food but haven't had it in a while since moving away from Berkeley where my apartment was 1 block away from 2 Korean restaurants.  We have been hesitant about coming here but our craving was just too much to hold back anymore.

The first time we went, I got a Bibimbop which was nicely cooked but it was nothing special.  The Other half got a Kimchi chigae which he though was OK with nice, silky tofu.

The second time around, I got a Jabchae which was super oily.  Moreover, the yam noodles soaked up the sauce as the dish sat so the whole thing got really goopy.  The Boyfriend got a Galbi tang which tasted delicious but the beef brisket was sort of dry.

Overall, this is a nice place for satisfying our occasional craving for Korean cuisine.  The only complain I have is how quickly the place fills up.
author: Karen S.

description:
I love this Korean restaurant. It's very popular but the place isn't big. So it's better to get there a bit earlier. Great location. I love their seafood pancake and of course Kim chi! 

Really great service and delicious, Moderate price. Good environment.
Highly recommended!
author: Betty O.

description: This Korean place has awesome good. Service so great. #1 kal bi, # 7 # 9 bibimbab taste so good. If you like spicy, it is cery good with the spicy sauce they provide you.
author: Victor C.

description:
Cheap, solid bibimbap in a small, family-owned environment.

I've been back a few times, and I think I was more impressed the first time. All the same, probably a go-to for me in west San Francisco. Actually, probably one of my favorite place in San Francisco. I've never had a long wait (i.e., 20+ minutes), but maybe I've just gone at late lunch/early dinner weekday times. I've only ever ordered the vegetable bibimbap (#20), and I don't anticipate getting adventurous in the future.
author: Dawn N.

description: It's a tiny place and is always full. Be there early or else no parking either. Good food bt u better take a LYFT or something
author: Ryoji T.

description:
Yay: the nice korean man made an exception and allowed me to get just half a portion of bibimbap and charged me half price.


Mehh: my half portion of bibimbap also came with about 3 pieces of beef bulgogi... thanks Manna for controlling my daily red meat intake for me.


In general, you can definitely get better tasting and bigger portions of Korean food elsewhere for the same price.  But if you're stuck in the Sunset like me, Tofu Village is a better alternative along Irving street AND they give you a choice of purple rice.  Or you can just get pho.
author: Tian Q.

description:
It's very good restaurant and the price is very cheap and reasonable, and the owner is very nice.
However, I don't like the cold noodles, doesn't taste anything. 
Btw, bibambap is always sooo good, that's why I give 4 stars to this place.
author: Kassidi L.

description:
I love this place, I do, I do, I seriously love it!

Beware: if you don't come here early, you will be stuck waiting, why? It is an extremely small restaurant, I believe that the restaurant only has 10-12 tables (or even less) so there is not much seating area. If you aren't able to come here early, be sure to dress for the San Francisco weather because you'll most likely have to wait outside because the restaurant is TINY. 

I am sure you won't go wrong with ordering anything off of their menu, everything I have tasted has been delicious and scrumptious. But if you do want some suggestions, I like: the japchae, the chicken wings, the bulgolgi, and the spicy tofu soup. Great for those cold San Francisco nights, when is it not cold in San Francisco!? 

p.s REFILLABLE BANCHAN - I love it, especially the fishcakes, brocolli, bean sprouts, kimchi, and white radish (i think I just named all of them, oh well). 

REMEMBER: it is a tiny restaurant so come here early or expect to wait outside, oh, and they do not take any reservations!
author: Mona L.

description:
My husband and I have been meaning to eat here ever since we moved to the Inner Sunset about 2 months ago, but whenever we're looking for a restaurant, it's always been too crowded (line out the door) and we ended up somewhere else. I finally got to go while my friend was visiting and we were going for a late lunch. That is the trick--you have to go way early or way late to avoid the lines and crowd!!

The food was delicious. My short ribs were good, but the cold noodle dish my friend had was amazing!! I think I will get that next time I go. I looked at what the people around us were eating and it all looked good. I hope to go back soon. 

The prices were very reasonable.
author: Jennie S.

description:
My favorite Korean restaurant! I come here all the time.

I always order the JabChae and maybe one of the meat dishes. I think the spare ribs are my favorite. 

The service is always great, parking is kind of eh, and the wait ... well, if you go at the right time and not during prime time, you'll be fine. 

What I love most is the quantity and price. Korean restaurants are always so expensive in NorCal! Manna is awesome ... great portions for a great price. :)
author: Chrisy Y.

description:
The service is really good at this establishment. We had two 3 year olds with us and they were very accomodating and nice to our little nephew and niece. My nephew was passed out so we had to bring him in on a stroller. The waiters made room for us to roll him and have him next to our table without bothering the other table around us. My neice LOVES broccoli so when she saw the side dish her eyes lit up and had a big smile on her face. The waitress was nice enough to bring us an extra dish knowing that she loved it so much. 

The food was delicious and enjoyable. The spicy tofu soup (medium) was a great way to wash down all the rice and meats. I ordered the seafood stone bowl, although the seafood was "baby seafood" size it was really enjoyable. Next time I'll stick to the big slices of meat in my stone bowl. 

Definitely a place to come back to and try something else on their menu without any disappointment.
author: Jona C.

description:
MSG? I think so. 

That aside, the owner is super nice, whether I go in with slightly drunk friends, with my sisters, with the manfriend - always kind, and open to making me La Boki (extra spicy) even though I'm not sure it's on the menu.

Yum, but not rushing over...
author: Maria A.

description: I caught the bus to inner sunset to get some San Tung's wings, only to find they are on vacation, boo! I went to Manna for some Kanpoongki, sweet and spicy chicken wings, instead. It is not Kyo-chon Korean fried chicken in Los Angeles, but pretty good! The lunch special was a big portion for a small price, can't really complain about that!
author: Cara H.

description:
I am SO happy that we finally have a quality Korean BBQ restaurant in the inner sunset!  after a long day of work/school sometimes you just want some hot comfort korean food and prior to Manna, we would always have to drive towards Richmond district or out of the city... problem solved!  Please keep in mind this isn't THE BEST korean food i've ever had but it really fills the cravings without having to go very far.  If you live int he area, GO TO MANNA!  

we usually order the japchae, kimchi fried rice, tofu soup and kalbi.  so yummy!  we're usually lucky and don't have to wait longer than 5-10 minutes but this restaurant is always FULL.  as of this review they have the perfect amount of clientele!!  this is a very small restaurant so if you want to have a group larger than 4 it gets a bit cramped.  they squish as many people in as possible!

the total cost for us is usually around $40 (2 people) but we leave happily full and usually have some leftovers for lunch the next day.  Perrrrrrrrrrrrrrfect.
author: Sandy L.

description: Dolsot Bimimbap, probably spelled wrong but you know what I'm talking about, is absolutely outstanding especially with the spicy pork. Tofu bowl soup is also fantastic but takes a while to cool down, I am talking 20 minutes at least, so be wary of burning your tongue literally. I really love the six little things that come out complementary at the beginning of the meal and the tea is also complementary is wonderful. Highly recommend!
author: Sai S.

description:
I love family owned restaurants and Manna definitely gets my sign of approval. They make comfort Korean food and this is definitel our new go to place for something quick (when you want something really yummy I suggest Han II Kwan).

The only painful thing is finding parking! Both times we ate here the wait was less than 5 minutes (this place is really small). Their prices are really reasonable. I recommend the grill meats and the bim bim bop. The seafood pancake was o.k. but a tad oily for my taste. They also give a decent variety of side dishes and the owner is really nice. Although the soon dobu is not as good as Tofu House, this place has more of a variety and prices are more reasonable for the meats.
author: Betty C.

description: Love this tiny open place for bibimbap or anything else your Korean taste buds desire. It is one if the busiest restaurants in the inner sunset, along with San tung and izakaya sozai so expect to put your name down and wait if coming at popular time. No fancy texts when table is ready!
author: B S.

description:
Holy cow! I have so much to say about this place, but I'll keep it short and simple. 

Deeeeelicious food, dishes come out quickly, simple and efficient menu, and awesome staff! My boyfriend and I come here a little too often, its becoming embarrassing. I wish they had delivery, I would eat here even more often than I already do!

Although I really adore this place, there's always a wait ( because its that good), and the space is a bit squishy. Which both aren't necessarily bad things, just not a 5 star rating for me, more like a 4.5 star. I guess I'm being a bit picky. Over all I've had only enjoyable experiences here!
author: Lia S.

description:
I was hangry (hungry plus angry) when I realized that underdogs was closed. My girl Maegan and I decided against pho, hole in wall noodle joints, driving across town and then I remembered manna.

We ordered:

Jap chae - slightly gummy yam noodles with a great sesame taste. One of my favorite Korean dishes

Kimichi jaeyokum dop bap - I would eat this at least once a week when I lived in Korea. It could use more pork pieces but otherwise a solid dish 

Kalbi - long and deeply marinaded pork sizzling on a plate - can't go wrong 

And a never ending stream of banchen!
author: Jade W.

description:
I've been to this place twice and the first time, my impression of it wasn't that great. Sure, it is a nice addition to the inner sunset grub but having tried many good korean restaurants like Han Il Kwan and Shin Toe Bul Yi, this place did leave a little to be desired. For one, the variety of ban chan was meager, though they do give refills when asked. Two, the restaurant is small, which means tables are small, leaving very little room for elbows and dishes..

On to the good stuff. Service was great..refills of ban chan and tea were readily given, food came fast, staff was really friendly. Food was pretty good and the standout was their kimchee pancake. So tasty and crispy and full of kimchee. Gal-bi is good for the price too. I also tried the mandu gook which sounds nasty but is really just dumplings in soup. This was just okay, tastes like frozen dumplings you can get at asian supermarkets.

All in all, a good treat when you're hungry but if you can drive to some other korean restaurant, better fare can be found.
author: Sarah L.

description:
It's just "Okay".

Manna is a very small Korean restaurant, possibly only big enough to fit 20-something people. We came here a few weeks back on a Saturday just a bit before 6pm. We were seated immediately, but as we pondered the menu, other diners started to pour in and the small Manna was quickly filled.

I ordered the Dok Bul Kogi with Rice. The chicken was very moist and delectable. However, the rest of my group were not as satisfied with their portions (they got variations of Bibimbap and Soft Tofu Soup). If you've got a small appetite, this place will be good for you. However, if you generally eat two bowls of rice and meat for a meal, Manna just may come up short for you.

The only good thing is they'll keep refilling your side dishes, only IF you remind them, especially when it gets busy. And if the whole restaurant is filled with customers and your party's already got their food, the automatic attention you get from the waitresses decreases rapidly. I only say this because it took simply forever just to get more tea and to get our check.

Also, it took forever to find parking, considering how Manna's located in the inner Sunset, of which street parking is almost inexistent during dinner hours. Expect to spend at least 10-15 minutes to find parking; better yet, take Muni to get around parking hassles.

The price is just so-so in relation to their portions, but it's still worth trying what Manna's got to offer.
author: Bonita K.

description: Love that this place is near my work. They offer lunch specials. The food is really good. It is a small restaurant so sometimes there is a wait. You just have to go at the right time. Their Jabchae inspired me to make my own at home and it was delicious.
author: Veronica F.

description: I couldn't stop eating even though I was so full. I love the tea and the side dishes that they serve you. You should definitely try the kimchi fried rice if you're visiting here for the first time! I liked how small the restaurant was, it gave it a family-run, home-cooked feeling that made me feel all warm and fuzzy inside :)
author: Amanda L.

description:
One of my new favorite go-to Korean restaurants in the city!! 

Service is good here! They are so attentive and totally hook you up with the side dishes! 

Prices are cheap!! 

Food tastes awesome! I love their kimchi fried rice, chap chae, wings, tofu soup, bulgogi, kalbi... there are so many I can't name!!! Overall, everything is TASTY!

This place is not big (biggest party is prob for 6), so definitely come early and get your name on the list before it fills up!
author: Sharon G.

description:
cute little corner spot on irving in the inner sunset... parking is a bit tough at times, so i recommend coming during lunch... also, you'd be able to take advantage of the lunch specials. 

service is quick and friendly and of course they bring out the ban chan as soon as you're done placing your order. the seafood pancake is super delish, yet it's not as greasy as toyose's. they also offer the tofu soup... which is perfect on a chilly day. i ordered mine mild with beef and it was perfect. even came with a bowl of white rice.

i'm excited to come back and try other dishes!
author: Ann T.

description: Today I was having a bad hangover needed some Korean soup desperately. It's kinda hard to fine a good Korean restaurant in SF especially if you are Korean and come from LA area. Place looked legit so decided to give a try. And oh man... That gal bi tang made me feel so much better! People are so nice too :) I would definitely come back again to try other dishes.
author: Maya S.

description: Delicious! I got the mandu gook and my SO and her mom got the bibimbap. All of the food was really fresh and tasty. The barley tea was great. Prices are fair, even on the weekends. Super clean. Not a big place, though.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Prepare to wait outside in the cold if you are coming here around dinner time.
To me, the wait is worth it.
The specialty in this restaurant is easily the dolsol bibambap (get the normal kind, I tried seafood bibambap too but it did not appeal to me). For an amazing experience, get dak bulgogi, add it to the bibambap and about 3 spoonfuls of the gochujang. My few experiences here were divine and would love to come back.
They are a bit racist though, I saw so many tables that ordered a stable Korean soup and were not given something that usually goes along with it (being vague on purpose)
Also, I have seen some people avoid putting the gochujang into their bibambap for some odd reason...maybe they aren't aware that they are suppose to. And there are other times that they don't even mix it to eat it...weird...
author: Brian L.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant. I have been going there since I was a sophomore in high school. This is the perfect place for meeting up with friends and having lunch. It is a small family run restaurant. The people who work there are super friendly and make sure you are satisfied with your food. The only downer is, during dinner time around 6:00/7:00 PM, there are long lines.
author: Kelly O.

description:
My haven around the corner. Its a solid choice. and judging by the daily lines every night, I'm not the only one who thinks so.

I favor the spicy pork, but they also have great chicken wings and spicy rice cakes.

The food is affordable, flavorful and service i fast and friendly. Its all i've ever asked for in a place to satiate my never ending hunger
author: Justin N.

description: Came here for a late dinner with the parents for the first time and was pleasantly surprised. Mom and I agreed that their chicken wings rivals and even surpasses San Tung's!! (Gasp)
author: Arthur N.

description: Review based solely on vegetable bibimbap and the store/service. It was fantastic, definitely a good amount of food compared to other places. Went for dinner and lunch too and it was 1$ cheaper for lunch but didn't appear any bit smaller or anything. Good stuff
author: Ryan O.

description: Solid but nothing to write home about. This little place is always packed, so we decided to give it a try. They only give you six pickled/app items and the entrees are pretty small. Five of us shared for entrees which is usually plenty at other Korean places. The ladies were full by the end, but my fiance was still very hungry. The dol-sot bibimbop was disappointing because the bowl didn't hold its heat long enough to crisp our rice.
author: Linda H.

description: A small and cheap Korean restaurant on the corner of 10th and Irving. This place can literally can only accommodate parties that are smaller than 4. The wait for a table is not too long since people tend to eat fast here. I usually get their Dot Sot Bibimbap which comes in a stone pot or their Kimchi Fried Rice. The Dot Sot Bibimbap came with an egg, beef, bean sprouts, carrots, and cucumbers. The Bibimbap is sometimes inconsistent as the pot is not hot enough for the rice to burn which gives the nice taste, but you drench it with gochujang to compensate for the taste. Their Kimchi Fried Rice was alright, but they do not have much meat. I can actually do a better job making Kimchi Fried Rice at home. They are very stingy when it comes to the amount of Banchan they give you since they only give you a sauce plate full with only one refill. Service here is very responsive as they come check up on all the tables fairly often and they refill your tea while they are at it. Overall not a bad place for Korean food if you have a small party and if you looking for a quick place to eat.
author: Peter C.

description: Love love this place..kalbi so so yummy worth the price !! Bad thing is for people like me love to order a lot to try.. Their tables aren't big enough for me n my friends..
author: Crisy G.

description:
I like. alot. I had the Bibim Naengmyon noodles.

It was a bit too spicy for me (I'm a semi-weak person when it comes to spicy foods) but I kept eating until I had no more because it was THAT GOOD. AND FLAVORFUL. So delicious. :3

Tip: Go early for dinner. The restaurant is on the small side so it gets packed quickly. A line forms and before you know it, they cover up the windows with blinds because people keep looking inside the restaurant to see if there's room or if anyone's done yet.
author: Ann V.

description:
Good but could be better. Based on my one visit, I would say that this is a so-so Korean food place. The food and prices are good but not amazing. The seating is very limited so be prepared to wait for a table at peak times if you'd like to dine in. I wonder if take-out would be a better option to avoid a wait or the cramped space. At least the surrounding Irving Street area is really cute so it is in a nice area.

The bathroom is small and while it does the job, it is a single bathroom that is by their hot water heater and isn't anything to write home about.

Parking could be challenging depending on the time and day.
author: Jane N.

description:
The restaurant is small, so be prepared to wait. For a table of two, we waited about almost half an hour, it might have been a Friday night too.

The food isn't bad, the price is reasonable for the portions. My friend and I shared chicken wings and short ribs. The chicken wings were alright. I like the sauce, but it's not  close to San Tung. The short ribs were good, I like it with the onions. The portion were smaller than other Korean restaurants, but the price was cheaper too, about $13. 

Service was good and attentive, they always offered refills on our water, rice, and side dishes.
author: Mandy D.

description:
We were lucky there was a table for us, this small place gets packed for lunch very quickly. 

Small and friendly place, excellent food - well spiced, well balanced, not too salty. Special "thank you" for jabchae -- I have not found many places in the US who would serve it. 

I'm actually looking forward to visiting Manna again on my next trip to SF
author: Jeanette M.

description:
Kimchi: amazing. Kimchi pancake: also amazing. Everything else: meh.

It's not that I mind a wait necessarily, but I do mind being told the wait is 30 minutes when it actually turns out to be over an hour for a party of two. 

I got the vegetable dol-sot bibimbap (rice with some veggies in a hot stone bowl), and it was super bland. The only flavor came from hot sauce in a bottle on the table.

Also, I accidentally brushed my hand against the hot stone bowl and got an actual, visible burn. My own fault for being clumsy, I guess, but I recommend not ordering the hot stone bowl. I don't know why I paid extra for the privilege of a minor injury and burnt rice. 

My boyfriend got the pollack stew, which he said was fine but nothing special. The peppers apparently drowned out the taste of the fish, and it was monotonous to just have the taste of the peppers and nothing else for every single bite.

In conclusion, the food was satisfactory, but, aside from the kimchi and the kimchi pancake, wasn't particularly notable. If the prices were a little cheaper and the wait were much shorter, I'd probably give it 4 stars, but I just don't see the point of spending an hour in line for this middling food.
author: Lauren O.

description: I was super excited to try it...sorry but it failed in every way...from the sides to the entrees...poor quality. I will not be back
author: Cyril D.

description: Really liked there kimchi fried rice. The sea food pancake was big and tasty. I would give them 5 stars but not too much of a fan of their ramen noodles. I will come back but just avoid dinner time rush.
author: Brenda M.

description: Surprisingly good Korean food that's a rare find in the area. I would venture to say even better than most places on the Richmond side of GG Park.
author: Yohdaddy M.

description:
I believe Manna is a super popular restaurant in the Richmond area. There is always a long wait. Unfortunately, I didn't get to try the favorites that everybody else recommended-- so I didn't have a super great experience.

I had the tofu soup and short ribs. And they were both very lackluster. I cannot recommend people to get these two items. The short ribs were slightly dry and the tofu soup did not have enough soup. The flavor for both items were also on the bland side. If you want great short ribs or tofu soup, I'd recommend going to Mugu Boka instead. Otherwise, it might be a good idea to try some other items.
author: Julie H.

description:
Ok so my uncle from Germany gave us money to go out to dinner so my sister and I went all out...

We ordered the Duk Bok Ki (rice cake in spicy sauce) it was delicious although not spicy enough for my preference. This dish had bunch of flavor though. As well, we ordered the Seafood Pancake. Yum! I can have that dish everyday of my life probably. Comes with a tangy sauce to pour over. I also ordered Kimchi rice, nothing extravagant but it packed in good heat and flavor. Lastly, we ordered the spicy pork. Served really hot and great to eat with rice.

They have huge portions! We ordered so much food that the owner of the restaurant was confused if we didn't like the food because it seemed like we didn't touch our food :P We had plenty of leftovers for two days. I'll definitely come back and try more of their menu out.
author: Gunter L.

description: A smallish menu, but perfect if you go for the basics. Good bibimbap and soft tofu soup! Tasty meat, good broth, and on a weekday, the wait is not too long. Not super spicy (though perhaps you could ask them to take it up a notch). Overall, left a happy camper.
author: Amy L.

description:
Came here for an early dinner before Academy of Sciences Night Life.  It's conveniently walking distance, and it's a great place to grab a soju + beer or three before heading to the Thursday night life event.

This place was very small and comfy.  You could tell it's a local neighborhood favorite.  They give you 6 appetizers which were decent.  I really like the long rice dish as an appetizer but they didn't have that.  Anyways, the reason why I'm giving this place 5 stars is because their entrees were all ~$10 and they were HUGE.

Between two people, we ate until we were about to explode and then had enough for 1 1/2 additional meals.  Unfortunately, we couldn't take any of it to go, but you definitely get the bang for your buck here.  The kimchee pancake was the size of an actual meal in itself!

Definitely will come back here again if I'm on that side of town.
author: Andrew H.

description:
It can be hard to find good Korean sometimes but we definitely found a winner here.

All the dishes we tried were uniquely tasty and well balanced.  The seafood bimbimbao (sp?) was perfect.  It was definitely worth the 30 min wait to get a table.

Can't wait to go back and try more.
author: William G.

description:
Korean food tends to be pricier than other Asian cuisines. Why? I don't know. But I roll my eyes when Korean restaurants try to charge $20 for a pancake that consists of egg, flour, water, and veggies. Their profit is probably something like $18. Makes me want to open a Korean restaurant. Anyway, vent over.

In comparison to many Korean restaurants in SF, Manna is quite cheap yet maintains good quality, which is why there is a long wait at this place. I've been here a few times. Every time the quality of the food is solid. The service is "mom and pop". 

The only downside is that tables and chairs tend to be crammed together. Many times I would be having a private conversation and, suddenly, find the next table of dudes obviously listening. Awkward.

You can find similar quality Korean food elsewhere in SF, but definitely not for the price.
author: Alice W.

description:
Fantastic in every way.

Went for lunch on a Sunday and got a table with no wait. The dining room is light and airy during the day and very pleasant. Two waitresses helped us; both were friendly and attentive. Water and tea glasses never sat empty and dishes were brought surprisingly fast given that they were nearly at capacity.

Everything we tried was delicious. The Kalbi, Seafood Pancake and Fried Dumplings as well as all of the side dishes were fresh and delicious with truly dynamic flavors and what seemed like just a bit more care given to their preparation than that of other Korean restaurants.

Definitely worth a visit!
author: Josh H.

description:
Boyfriend and I only came here because Yummy Yummy was closed due to vacation.  The food definitely was filling but it wasn't very satisfying.  The banchans had an off flavor.

Soon Tofu with Mandoo:  It was hot on a cold night.  There were little bits of seafood.  It had the right amount of kick.  It was pretty forgettable.

Dolsot Bibimbap:  It had a reasonable amount of meat on it.  The crust was perfect on it.  The vegetables, however all tasted the same.


PS. This is an okay spot if you are in the area and craving korean but I would rather go to Yummy yummy or San Tung.
author: Jessica P.

description:
We tried the bul kogi, bibimbop, kanpoongki (wings), and Kimchi Bokum Bab (pan-broiled kimchi & rice). We had tried to order the fried chicken (#7), but were told to "cross it off" our menu as they don't have that now? and the donkatsu (#18) but were advised against that and told they only had subpar pork to use in that dish at the moment. I appreciated the candor but was surprised and puzzled that it would even be offered.

I liked all the food and would get the dishes again (except maybe the kimchi bokum bab - it was a little bland) - I thought the bul kogi especially had an excellent flavor. The food definitely suffered from being take-out, though, which of course was our fault. The bibimbop would have been better in the hotpot and we would have been able to mix everything together better. I was happy that they included the banchan in the takeout and especially enjoyed the kimchi.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Make sure you guys save your receipts!
These guys gave themselves extra tip on my credit card.
It wasn't even a possible number that made it seem like a simple mistake.
They changed the tip from $1.88 to $3.12.
Glad my wife checked the receipts, and saw the difference.
author: Soohyun K.

description:
I have loved everything I've eaten here. Nothing is over done but still very tastey and very reasonably priced. From to-go orders to dining in, I've always been satisfied with Manna. I appreciate the side dishes being included in my to-go orders as well. 

It can get crowded around dinner time if you want to dine in, so be prepared to put your name down and wait outside. Otherwise pick-up orders are always ready within the time frame they give you. I'll definitely continue being a regular here.
author: Alice H.

description:
The Good
really good banchan, generally no need to ask for refills. will not force you to finish everything before refills
reasonably priced for SF
great service
I've had the tofu soup and kalbi, not the best I've had in my life, but worth a trip if you live close

The Bad
long lines, especially on Friday and Saturday nights. main reason why I don't come very often
small place, will make you wait outside if there are no tables. 
parking is difficult
author: Larry C.

description:
I have come here a few times now because not only is this Korean food a lot more affordable, but the workers are really friendly. The owner/manager is usually there and always checking to make sure you have enough side dishes and that you're enjoying your food.

Definitely try their Kanpoongki (sweet & spicy chicken wing). It was light and crispy with the yummy tangy sauce. All their meals come with rice, so it comes in handy when you want to add more rice to your bibimbap! The Kalbi was tender, flavorful, and not too difficult to eat. I don't like using my hands to eat, so I appreciate it when it's made to be eaten easily.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Ok place for Korean food. I've had better, but this place isn't bad. Most dishes are around $10 for lunch. And you get the little side dishes. The beef bulgogi could have been a bit more tender. And the chicken has some spiciness to it. It was reddish in color, but that wasn't specified on the menu. Short ribs were good and tofu soup was good. They don't do the bbq at your table so all food is cooked in the back.

All in all, ok place for Korean food.
author: Ali F.

description:
To be completely honest, Manna is 3.5 stars worthy, but since no such rating exists on Yelp, the customer service and friendly owner bumps it up to the nearest star. 

For the price, portion, and taste, Manna is pretty good compared to other Korean restaurants in the city. However, one should not expect it to be nearly as delicious as the Korean food in Korea town in LA. (I do sound a little snooty, don't I?) All the dishes are cooked in the kitchen so don't expect a fancy grill either. 

My personal favorites from here are the sizzling tofu soup (either seafood or vegetarian is good depending on personal preference), jap chae, seafood pancake, and the kalbi (marinated to perfection, served on a clay sizzling platter over ONIONS- complete icing on the cake). 

The most memorable experience I've had at Manna was when my boyfriend dropped an enormous piece of kalbi (short rib) on the carpet, shortly after the waitress brought it over. The owner who was standing behind the counter noticed and immediately walked over with a napkin to pick it up and toss it into a nearby trash bin. A few minutes later, he carries over a new sizzling short rib and hands it over to us to replace the one we lost. SUPERIOR CUSTOMER SERVICE? I say yes. 

Manna would be the place to go for a decent Korean meal without breaking your bank account. The wait can get pretty long on weekends, especially around dinner time, so do plan on going early or if you have a big party, send someone to do the dirty work so not everyone has to wait.
author: Ada C.

description:
This place is quite smaller than I expected it to be but the food is amazing nonetheless. Since it was just two people, we were seated right away. The menu is already at the table underneath the glass. They first come out with hot tea and come back a few minutes later to take your order. Once you make your order, that's when they bring out the side dishes. 

Compared to other Korean places, the side dishes here are a bit on the bland side but the kimchi is the best I have had so far. It is super flavorful and has that spicy kick. 
The food came out pretty quickly and it was pretty bomb. I definitely plan on coming back to try the kalbi and the kimchi pancake. 

They do not hassle you to finish your food quickly even when there are other people waiting. When there are no tables available, they have a sign in sheet at the very front for customers to write their names down and wait for them to be called once a table is available.
author: Crystal L.

description:
ordered kalbi short ribs it was ok but not that tasty 
kimchi chige, yummy tofu kimchi pork spicy soup
ramen,typical ramen 
shrimp bokum bab very tasty they put alot of small shrimps 
The place was a little bit small so tables are a bit close together.
 we got 6side dishes kimchi fish cake beans sprouts brocolli radish
like to come back to try other korean dish ;)
author: Enah N.

description:
Parking - can be tricky if you start driving during dinner rush hour. Highly recommend going earlier about 30 min. prior to wanting to eat.

Wait time - depending on the time you get here. Came here at 6:30 and waited about 5 minute. Everyone that came after waited about 15 min. It really depends on your group size as well. This is a very small place. Fits approx. 25 people give or take. 

Food - everything was decent. After waitress took order, food took about 15=20 minute to come out. which I find a bit longer than my usual wait time. (half star off)

ordered Japchae, bulgogi, seafood pancake and kimchi fried rice
- Japchae was great for me. nearly ate the whole plate myself. not oily and taste was just right
- bulgogi was fab too...onions were cooked perfectly, not too soft or too raw - it had just enough crunch and softness to it.  The meat was awesome! Won't take anything away nor add anything to it
- Seafood pancake; I'm usually not a big fan but i was shocked to find myself eating more than 2 slices
- kimchi fried rice; Not all places are the same and i can't vouch for this dish. Sorry Manna but you failed with this dish and that's why i take half a star away. The rice was over cooked and with the end blended and all the ingredients, the texture was very similar to porridge. Not so great.
- side dishes on the other hand were fantastic. Loved every dish. Got seconds too!

Overall, I would definitely come here again and is willing to give the kimchi fried rice a second chance. I won't knock something until i at least try it twice.
author: Julie B C.

description: This place has some good Korean food, great service and awesome lunch specials. I think it's worth it if you're in the area. Otherwise, 9 dollars is a lot for that much food. I liked the dol sot bibimbap. They also pack banchan if you get it to go. Definitely a delicious option that's just a little pricey. It's SF, though, so what do you expect? Quality's good, not great and relatively cheaper than most places.
author: Ruobin W.

description: Great local KBBQ. I ordered the dinner Kal Bi .  It was well marinated and grilled to perfection . The six side dishes were kimchi, thin spicy tofu, sweet Blk beans, shredder marinated potatoes, bean sprouts and broccoli . Soooooo delicious .  I washed it all down w/a QB beer. Excellent service with a smile . If you are on a budget, it's less 30% during lunch . Enjoy
author: Joe L.

description:
Korean cuisine does not mean tasty options only exist in KBBQ, and Manna is a testament to this statement. 

We ordered a bunch of different options from their menu, Kalbi, dol sot bi bimbap, jabchae, soft tofu soup in vegetable, and kimchee pancake. 

The banchan here is slightly disappointing, not too many options and their house kimchee is not flavorful. I disliked the bean sprouts too, and probably the only slightly redeeming one was the shredded potatoes. 
I also did not care for the kim chee pancake. It was oily, and just not tasty. 

However, the highlights of the meal was definitely the vegetable soft tofu soup and the dol sot bibimbap. MMM I can drink the entire soup by myself! I loved that we ordered the vegetable option because the meat can get rather rough when boiled in this type of soup, and the veggies were so delish, carrots, potatoes, cucumbers with soft as a baby's bottom tofu. Yum...

I also really liked the dol sot bibimbap which is very popular at Manna. They give you some sort of hotsauce in a bottle for you to mix in with all the veggies, so be careful adding too much unnecessary salty MSG! This dish was very hearty and one of the best dolsot bibimbap I've had. 

The Kalbi was so-so. for 8-10 pieces, it was $13.99. the prices aren't crazy here but the Kalbi wasn't as flavorful as I wished. It was tender though. 

This restaurant is good to go with your family, or even friends, because the prices aren't decent ($8.99-&13.99) and everything is equally delicious. It's also a small cramped place, so beware of rush hour dinner time. Literally the floor looked like it could only seat 12 tables (2 per table) all at once ... eek!
author: Sandra L.

description:
I was craving some cheap food in the sunset where my family discovered this place. During lunch, all the menu items are cheaper then $10. The bon chon came out quick and they kept serving us tea which was nice. The service was good however, my brother asked for water but it never came. 

We ordered the spicy and sweet fried chicken wings, seafood tofu soup, and the bulgogi. The food came out a little slow but was expected because we came during the lunch rush. The seafood tofu soup was super delicious and had a lot of clams and other seafood items.
author: Jason L.

description:
After spending hours wandering through Golden Gate Park, Manna hit the spot with some delicious Korean fare.

My boyfriend and I arrived around 7pm on a Sunday evening to a nearly full restaurant, and we were able to snag one of the last tables for two. The waitress promptly greeted us and served us some tea to start while we looked over the menu. We decided to share the Seafood Pancake and the Dae Ji Bul Kogi (marinated pork). After placing our order with the kitchen, our waitress returned with several different "sides" for us to munch on while we waited for our food. The sides are bottomless and range from lightly steamed broccoli to kimchi. None of the sides stood out to me as being absolutely fantastic, but they helped stave off some of the hunger for what ended up being about a thirty minute wait for the food after we had placed our order.

The seafood pancake came out first, and it was a little different than I had imagined. There was a plethora of seafood that tasted fresh, which I was very enthused to see. The only aspect of the dish that I didn't like was that it was very sloppily made, meaning that all the Chinese broccoli was on one side of the pancake, and most of the seafood was on the other, making for a very unevenly disbursed meal. That aside, the pancake is HUGE and we couldn't finish it on our own.

As for the pork dish, I was absolutely blown away. It was perfectly tender and flavorful, and the marinade was fantastic. I would 100% recommend this dish, and I can imagine it is indicative of the quality of all their other meat dishes as I was hungrily looking at the bowls of Bi Bim Bop and other meaty dishes that the other patrons had ordered around us.

I feel that Manna was fairly authentic considering the majority of the clientele was Korean and it was incredibly busy for a Sunday night. If you're ever in the area and craving a delicious and relatively cheap lunch or dinner, Manna will definitely hit the spot.
author: Megan K.

description:
I was craving for something soup-like and my boyfriend was craving for rice. After going back and forth, we finally concluded on Korean food. We hopped on yelp and received Manna's search results. Irving Street parking is not necessarily the best even for a chilly Sunday night. 
The restaurant is tiny, thus the table placement is quite cozy. I would say it would fit about 20 people maximum. Once we walked in, I was tiptoeing and dodging people that were spilling onto walkways to get to the cashier counter located in the back of the restaurant to put down my name. There is no waiting area in the restaurant, let alone standing room. Nonetheless, my boyfriend and I were not over joyed with the idea of standing out in the cold, so we tucked ourselves in the back of the restaurant next to the drink refrigerator for 20 minutes before we were seated. 

Once we were seated, they serve a tall glass of the sesame-like flavored tea and gave six dishes of banchan (the appetizers) including bean sprouts, broccoli, fish cakes, kim chi, something that resembles black beans, radish. The kim chi was flavorful in spices, but it needed to be fermented longer. 
 
We ordered the kim chi fried rice and seafood stew with tofu 
Seafood stew: delicious spicy broth with plenty of bold flavors. There were clams and shrimps and cubed medium tofu.  
 
Kim chi fried rice: From the choice in meat, we chose beef. Overall, the kim chi fried rice was a little bland as the usual salty spoonful was lacking. It would have been better if it was made with spam and if the kim chi was more fermented.  
 
Service was great, they constantly came back to check up on us. Dishes appeared to have ranged from 10-13 dollars.
author: Becky Q.

description: Their kimchi is out of this world. It was garlicky but not overpowering, and it was not too spicy. I could've eaten it all night. I got the seafood dolsot bibimbap and it was phenomenal. Hats off to them, it was a perfect Korean meal!
author: Erica K.

description: Friendly staff, good food. In my experience, some Asian restaurants have very yummy food, but not very friendly waiters/waitresses. Manna have both. I am pleasantly surprised that their waitresses smile and look happy when they wait tables. I had their bibimbap couple times and liked it very much.
author: S P.

description:
I'm not Korean, but I've had a lot of Korean food. And this place is goooood.

A small little restaurant encased in all glass in the inner sunset, there is something strangely cozy about this place. You can look outside and see the fog rolling in, but you're inside this glass case of a restaurant and you're comforted by some bubbling tofu stew, Dol-bibimbap, or sizzling bbq. Even though this is the furthest thing from being at grandma's, you feel like you're taken care of as long as you're inside Manna.

And the food is yums! The seafood tofu stew is seafoody but spicy - just how you'd want it. The bbq is not too sweet - a pet peeve I have with some Korean bbq places... but theirs is flavorful in the right way. Same with the Dol-bibimbap - their meats and sauce isn't just straight up sweet stuff, but actual flavor.

Their seafood pancake is some of the best ever - crispy and with lots of seafood. Thick and hearty. 

On top of that, this place is CHEAP. And it's great for small parties of 2. 

We want to eat everything when we come here so over-ordering is always on order. But it's okay because it tastes great the next day. 

Like others, came for San Tung, but ended up here. And now, we just come here. Can't wait to come back and try more stuff.. but so hard to pass up what we've already tried.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
The wait tonight was not bad at all. There were two in my party and we waited about 10mins. It was super cramped. We were seated right in front of the register between two large crowds. Service was on top of its game. My tea was refilled every single time without having to ask. 

- Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings w/ rice: it was very good...very garlicky. The rice I loved...I love asian rice. 
- BBB: egg a little too running to my friend's liking but luckily the clay pot bowl was hot enough to cook the yolk some more. 

Food was very good. Accepts cc/debit which is always a plus because who carries around cash anymore =)
author: Serena F.

description:
This place is one of those gem hole in the wall kind of place that most foodies quest to discover! Home cooked goodness that will leave you smiling and your tummy full! 

KALBI = most excellent! 4.5 stars!!

SOFT TOFU SOUP = another most excellent comfort item! 4.5 stars!

ENDLESS BANCHAN = 4.5 stars!!

What makes this place a jewel is great service, good food at great prices!!
author: Victor C.

description:
I hail from the land of mouth-watering Korean BBQ and addicting spicy kimchi AKA LA, so I know my Korean food pretty well. Plus I literally hang out with all Koreans whose moms know how to make everything bomb-diggity, so yes, my standards for Korean food are pretty darn high.

Unfortunately, SF doesn't have much Korean food, and sadly, Manna was just OK.
