FOOD:
1. Bulgogi - The beef was overcooked, because it was tough to chew, despite cut into tiny slices. It lacked that strong marinated flavor. The only thing that really added flavor to the beef was the fried onions that was laid underneath the bulgogi.

2. Spicy & sweet chicken wings - Got this because Yelp mentioned they were pretty bombass, and the reason why we came to Manna in the first place was San Tong's line was too long...so of course we had to get them chicken wings! I liked how the wings were not overly fried or greasy at all. Bonus points for not lathering sauce over the wings to make them all sticky and goo-ey like some Korean places. The meat was pretty tender. HOWEVER, the wings were not spicy at all, and was only a tad bit sweet. 

3. Japchae** - Got to save the best review for last because this japchae was AH-MAZING. I highly recommend this! I've never really had such delicious japchae -- you can definitely taste the sweetness of the sweet potato in the noodles, but it wasn't deathly sweet at all. I had my bottle of hot sauce on the side, but you definitely didn't need it for this dish! The noodles were fresh, chewy, and just SO full of flavor. I didn't even want to eat the shreds of beef or onions that came with it cus the noodles were THAT GOOD.

4. Banchan (side dishes) - Kimchi wasn't spicy, fish curd was hard to chew, and everything else was just meh.

SERVICE:
Mediocre. They were nice people but...very unattentive. I asked my server for water/tea 3 times before she finally came to refill it. She also forgot to give me my take-out box until I mentioned it for the second time..sigh.

WAIT TIME:
30 minutes on a Sunday night. Place is pretty small (maybe can fit 20 people MAX). 

TIP: Be prepared to wait OUTSIDE in the freezing cold, so bring a jacket OR get take out!

TIP #2: If you want things more spicy, ask for the spicy sauce! They bring you a bottle of spicy sauce to lather spiciness onto your food :)
author: Evelyn S.

description: We went here a few weeks back and I am sorry that it took me so long to write this review. We ordered the Kim chi Pizza. Now I know that sounds like a culinary atrocity but it was amazing. It was like nothing we have had ever.  Everything we ordered was amazing. This is a great low key place to go and try some truly unique food. The prices are extremely fair and its a great place if you just want a friendly establishment that has surprisingly sophisticated food.
author: Atom H.

description: Yasssssss! This place is great! It's small, but they can accomodate you.  The wait staff is very friendly and likes joking around. The seating is close together, but it still feels somewhat intimate.
author: Amanda N.

description: Awesome food. I enjoyed it more than expected. The chicken wings were great. Perfect sweet and sour combo and super crunchy coating. I loved my ramen soup with egg. Bulgogi and kalbi were fantastic too. It is a small place and we had to wait but it was worth it.  The ice was cooked perfectly. The prices a reasonable and the service pretty good (attentive). It's the best food we've had on the trip so far.
author: Deb G.

description:
Cheap Korean food. 3 dishes for less then $40 with tip and tax.

Service is good, but place is so tiny. They give good side dishes, but the food is ok.

Dumpling soup-added tofu. Big dumplings, but wish the soup had more flavor. I dumped some Kimchee in there and it tasted much better. 

The clear noodles were yummy, and not dry, but oily and lots of MSG.

The Kalbi was only a little bit and mostly fatty pieces. 

Gets packed fast, but I don't know if I would come back here, even if it's cheap.
author: Karen H.

description:
I definitely enjoyed it here!

I came here with my friend for lunch one day and we had the lunch specials.  I got the kalbi & she got the jap chae.  We shared though of course.  The beef was succulent and flavorful.  The jap chae was delicious as well.

They also had many sides dishes too!

The best part was that it cost about $20 for the two of us =)
author: Mimi P.

description:
Yummm. 

Love all the tiny plates of fermented foods they give you before your meal. The dolsot bimbimbop is so good (LOVE the crispy rice on the bottom) and the chicken wings are like heaven (sweet, a little spicy).

This is a great place for 2, it's pretty small inside. 

Bottom line: great food, good portions, good price, friendly staff!
author: Meg L.

description: Absolutely delicious bi bim bop. Good portions, delicious tea and appetizers. I would absolutely recommend this place for a fairly priced solid meal! On the downside the restaurant is very small and the wait staff are a little hands-off, so if you've got a big group or are very needy, just be aware of that!
author: Cecilia A.

description:
New favorite! The word at Manna is FRESH!  Went near closing on a Thursday night, short wait. Other customers were so friendly they shared their cucumber shoju with us while we waited!

The banchan are tops.  Great range of flavors and textures and FRESH!  The home made kimchi - wow, could have eaten a plate of that alone.  No MSG if you care.  I think  staying off the MSG allows more subtle flavors to shine. 

All the dishes we tried were excellent - kalbe was tender and flavorful, chicken wings were perfectly crispy with a nice glaze.  The kimchi pancake is a treat  - not oily at all, great texture and flavors.  Bebimbap came to table sizzling and the egg on top was perfect.  

This is a very unpretentious place.  The owner is both friendly and clearly passionate about fresh great food and it shows in every item.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Bob K.

description: Manna is really, really, REALLY great! Comparative prices paired along with well seasoned side dishes and main courses means you get the most out of your night out. The lines are pretty much a constant, but waiting for a seat is definitely worth it. I've tried the Seafood Pancake, Royal Court Dok Bok Ki, Dolsot Bibimbap, Kimchi Jjigae, Seafood Tofu soup, and dakdoritang... All frickin' delicious. The service is also amazing, as they are so accomadating and attentative regarding side dish and drink refills. Check this place out!
author: Teresa C.

description:
This is a worthwhile place as a go-to for laid-back Korean food.

NOT DIY BBQ (no, I'm not yelling). Good banchan, tasty dishes, decent prices, and friendly service. There is usually a small dinner wait, and there's little/no standing room. My favorites are the pancakes and bulgogi.
author: Diane N.

description: My boyfriend and I had a great lunch here the other day. He got the mandu jigae, I got kimchi jigae, and we shared an order of kalbi. If you go before 3pm on weekdays there are lunch entrees that are less expensive than dinner. Complimentary tea and side dishes (though, not my favorite. You can tell the kimchi they use was the kind you can buy at any store).
author: Megan M.

description: Went here Saturday night with my SO for some dinner.  Took a while to find parking on the street and we where lucky to get into the restaurant before it closed.  Very tight getting around the restaurant almost like a take out only place.  The Korean appetizers were taste.  I had the spicy octopus which was good but very very spicy, almost too much where you couldn't taste anything else.  My SO had the bbq chicken which was good.
author: Donald H.

description:
The best friend took me here last night for a belated birthday dinner.

Any fan of Korean food would know that quality Korean food in the city is very hard to come by. Understandably so, we have no K-town here. Koreans can't settle in J-town, that would be absurd. They can't settle in Chinatown either, that would be weird. So they randomly take the outskirts of certain neighborhoods with seemingly no appointed settlement--if I recall correctly, I believe parts of the Richmond and Sunset? The rest end up in SMELL.A.

A big highlight of this place is the affordable prices. Everything is around $9-13, which is very reasonable for Korean. We ordered the Bul Kogi, Seafood Pancake, Seafood Tofu Soup, and the Sweet & Spicy Chicken wings. We decided that everything except the Bul Kogi was delicious. It was a little dry and tasteless, or maybe we're just not fans of that type o' meat.

In conclusion, ordering 4 dishes for two people was way too much. An order each person would definitely be just enough for sharing.
author: Anita W.

description:
I expected to love this place from all the great things I've heard about it. 
The wait was a little long, but it was New Years Eve so I don't blame them! 
We ordered the Seafood tofu soup (spicy), bulgogi, and the Dol-Sot Bibimbap.  I love bibimbap and the one they have here was perfect. A great amount of vegetable and tastes great with the bulgogi beef. 
The prices are very reasonable around $10 for each dish. 
The bibimbap was very good and crispy and the seafood tofu soup had a great variety of seafood in it; mussels, clams, crab,  and squid. There was also a very large amount of seafood in it, I was rather surprised. The portions are big and quite filling. 
The bulgogi has a sweet garlic flavor, not too overwhelming. 
The service is great and you get served quickly. 

I definitely recommend coming here although I admit I do prefer going to My Tofu House even though their prices are a little higher. 

Also I received a new cup of tea that already lipstick stains around the rim and it wasn't my lipstick! YUCK.
author: Veronica L.

description:
CHEAP KOREAN FOOD, yay! the food is bland however.. they should not try being "safe" with their flavors..   

seafood pankcake:
- like a thick version of japanese okonomiyaki
- not as packed with seafood like at toyose
- bland, even with the soy sauce they provide

kalbi (short ribs):
- plain, tastes like it has not been marinated well enough

tofu soup:
- has a spicy kick, however it is lacking the seafood flavor, perhaps they did not use kelp or enough anchovy broth?

kimchi spicy pork:
- meager portions of pork hidden in a pile of warm kimchi
- tasted good/garlicky/spicy when it was hot
- tasted like ketchup when it cooled down

fried chicken:
- could have been crispier and more flavorful
- only comes in wing-form, no drumsticks/pieces of plain meat

service was very friendly and welcoming, however service was very sparse..  they are completely short-staffed and so service becomes slow.  

recommendation: if you are going to dine here, come in a small group of friends (4 or less) because this is a small restaurant, and order everything family style to share
author: Tina A.

description:
Good food, I had the #3 which was a spicy pork plate and it wasn't "make you want to cry" spicy. It was a Saturday night near closing(9 PM) and it was still packed but I was able to get a table quickly. The food was promptly delivered, the waitress wasn't nagging or stopping by the table every minute, but when refills/something was needed she was at arms length. 

Very authentic, very tasty, would recommend to anyone in the area.
author: Nicholas S.

description: We came here for lunch on a weekday, which was no wait. We ordered from the lunch menu: Kalbi beef with rice, sweet and spicy chicken wings and Seafood Tofu Soup along with the small dishes. The portion for the Kalbi was small, but maybe it's lunch time. The sweet and spicy chicken wasn't spicy at all, it was all sweet. So the taste was off, but we still finished it despite the tangy sweetness taste. The Seafood Tofu Soup was really bad, because it seemed like they used Kimchi packet to make it look red and spicy. It was indeed spicy for mild flavor, but it tasted like instant Kimchi soup. Overall, I wasn't too impressed with their food.
author: Elaine C.

description: Not the best service, but pretty good food was served. Their Bibimbaps are delicious, and their banchans were decent (the kimchi was a little too saucy in my opinion). The waiters were friendly, but only refilled our banchans once when we asked, same with tea/water. They even gave us the check I'm Korean.
author: Tal M.

description: I absolutely LOVE this place! I usually come here during lunch hours, because it's always packed at night. What's great is that I don't have to look for parking because it's only a few blocks away from my house. I always order their seafood tofu soup, but what sucks is that they don't give us an egg :( I love that this place kind of reminds me of home because of how small it is! Their tea is always nice on a cold day in SF. The prices here are okay, $10 for a bowl of tofu soup like any other Korean restaurant.
author: Debby L.

description:
Service was good. We had to wait (Thursday night with a 3 person party) for a table to clear as they mostly have seating for 2. But they were very nice and apologetic for the wait. 

Small dishes variety wasn't that great but the rice was amazingly on the spot. The kim chi isn't as sour (thank goodness for me), fish cake was yum, broccoli was good. After having eaten the complementary things, I had my appetizer: seafood pancake - which was very yummy. I would order this again. And THEN I ate my entree. By this time I was pretty full but had just wanted to try it out before I boxed it up and ended up eating more than I had wanted to because it was so good. My friend got the bibimbop and says its better than the korean place we usually go to because the seasoning of the meat was better, as well as the seasoning of the rest of the veggies, etc. 

Definitely coming back here again.
author: Vicki T.

description:
I don't quite understand the Manna craze. I came here for lunch after reading all the glowing reviews and passing by the crowd of people outside the restaurant almost every day. The meal began with some tea and an assortment of different kimchi, and my friends and I then ordered the fried chicken wings, the clay pot (dolsot) seafood bibimbap, the seafood pancake, and the beef short ribs. On the plus side, all the orders were quite inexpensive, with none of the lunch specials over $10 (even the bibimbap). But there are far too many minuses for this restaurant to warrant a higher rating.

- The food itself is about average, insofar as Korean food in the Bay Area goes. I was particularly disappointed with the seafood pancake because it turned out soggy and oily, and contained those weird mini pygmy shrimps, rather than some real quality shrimp.
- The service is really awful. I've eaten at my share of divey Asian places and I don't generally have high expectations for the service at restaurants like this, but the waitress took it to a new level. It's one thing for a waitress to fail to bring water, or a doggy bag container, or your check. It's another thing for a waitress to acknowledge that she will do those things and then forget to do them. It was extremely frustrating.
author: Sidney L.

description:
Best Korean food in SF - and every dish is in a $8.99-$11.99 range!!!! 

The japchae hit just the right spot - rice noodles with sweet sauce, onions, and slices of beef! 

The short ribs (#1) we're in a similar barbque sauce as the japchae and it came on an iron plate, which means DELICIOUS GRILLED ONIONS YESSSSS
So amazing.

The small dishes were pretty good. I usually eat more of those since the main course isn't as good but this time I didn't even want to eat it cause the main dishes were sooo good! 

Oh and the staff!! This place seems to be a family run business. All the servers immediately tended to my every need (more water, box, check, etc) in great speed - thank you!! The food came SO fast, even tho I went at dinner time on a Friday!! I only had to wait 5 min to be seated. Their turnover is incredible!

Absolute perfection (except for finding parking in that area... So many other restaurants nearby!). Can't wait to come here again!!!
author: Connie Y.

description: Manna's is pretty cheap for Korean food for lunch and dinner ! You can ask them to refill the Banchan as many times as you would like(but there isn't really a good assortment), my party of four ordered the seafood tofu soup, japchae,the seafood hot stone pot and the spicy pork. The food was alright but one thing that threw me off was the japchae..... It was soooo watery, it tasted like some kind of noodle soup. It wasn't good but it wasn't bad. I just thought it was odd when the japchae was watery. The portions are kind of small also...maybe that's why it is so cheap.. I am used to having a lot of left overs
author: Janet Z.

description:
There aren't that many Korean joints in the city and most of them aren't that great.  Now I'm comparing them to LA Korean food and you can't compete with that.  So my stars are merely based on their food and service.  

First of all, it's Korean owned so that's a star.  At least I know I'm not eating Chinese Korean food.  

Second star goes to their side dishes.  Always delicious and it just keeps on coming!  It's like a bottomless pit of kimchee dicons and cabbage, salty bean sprouts, Korean marinated dried fish, and steamed broccoli.  All very good!  

Third star goes to their food consistency.  Their tofu soup is better than tofu house on geary!  Their grilled meats are good too.  Their bi bim bap in a stone bowl is good most of the time.  Some times their rice is too wet so you don't get that nice crusty rice a the end!  My wife loves their chap jae also.  

Fourth star goes to their service.  The owners are very attentive and always refilling tea and they are good at moving the line.  It's an efficient restaurant.  The waits are usually never more than 15 minutes despite the number of people waiting.  

It's our usual go to Korean joint since it's so close to where we live.
author: Michael T.

description:
I came here on a Friday night, and my party of 2 waited approximately 15mins to be seated. The wait staff was super nice and attentive to my needs. But I usually get this kind of service at Korean restaurants, especially in Los Angeles. Maybe it's a Korean thing, in which they think I am of them, especially since I tend to say "" in a submissive manner.

As I was seated, I was promptly served my brown rice barley tea and 6 small dishes of banchans. And my banchans got refilled automatically. 

My date and I ordered the kimchi fried rice and bulgogi. My favorite was the kimchi fried rice. This place uses shrimp paste kimchi, so the kimchi was not inferiorly sour! As I mixed the egg in the fried rice, the rice was had a good crunchy and gooey texture. The rice was gooey, not because the rice was soggy and not fried properly, but because my egg was runny! Additionally, the rice was slightly spicy. The fried rice was the perfect comfort food for a cold misty fried night as it warmed my body. Loved it! 

This place might just be my new favorite Korean restaurant; it is at least in the Inner Sunset. I am definitely coming back when I get my next craving for kimchi fried rice.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Came here on a rainy sunday evening after alice's summerthing. Our original plan was to go san tung, but the wait was super long, so we made our way back up to try to go to perilla, but i'm from the east bay, so i didn't want to pay to eat some mediocre pho. We stood there and pondered where to eat. As we stood there, the pungent smell of sesame oil from manna filled our nostrils and called us over.

The place is small and super packed, but we were seated for a party of four rather quickly. Service was mediocre as it was really busy and waitresses forgot to refill our tea, water, and side dishes when we asked. We ordered the chicken wings and soft tofu soup. Chicken was good and the soup was fulfilling, flavorful, and aromatic. Some places put too much tofu in, so there's never enough broth, but this place got it right. It definitely hit the spot on a rainy day like this.
author: Wendy K.

description:
I can see why this place is well rated. The food is delicious and the service is great. The prices are very reasonable to.

They provide complimentary boli cha. I love boli cha, so I was happy they had it and that it was complimentary.

The ban chan was delicious. Sometimes the fun of trying a new Korean restaurant is seeing what the ban chan will be. There are so many different options and combinations. I wasn't disappointed. The classic kimchi was an option and it was delectable.

I opted for the bibimbap on this taste excursion. I went the route of dol sot so I could get the stone bowl and egg. It was scrumptious! Flavorful and delicious. A satisfied belly for me! The bowl was large and pack with goodness.

The whole meal was under $10. Not bad!

The service was great, and the food was great. Yup, that's pretty much as good as it gets!
author: Zoe D.

description:
Trying to eat gluten and msg-free is a challenge when it comes to Korean cuisine.  Luckily, a friend who also deals with the same dietary issues took me to Manna without any mishaps.

Had the Seafood Dolsot Bibimbop ($8.99 before tax) .  It's a sizzling rice dish cooked in a hot stone bowl with an assortment of seafood and fried egg with gochujang chili/soy bean sauce that seemed to be free of barley.

It also comes with the Banchan sides (6 dishes - broccoli; pickled daikon radish and carrots; kimchee cabbage; namul bean sprouts; sliced fish cake; and mini-anchovies marinated in chili sauce).  The Banchan is refilled at no extra charge upon request. Korean style tea also comes with every meal.

What a find!  I heart Manna.
author: Bodhi D.

description: I recently fell in love with Korean cuisine and if your try it, you will too. Manna is a really good and cheap tiny Korean restaurant. Ot offers all the good traditional Korean dishes like my all time favorite the spicy pork. The pancake and pork were extremely good, but the rice bowl was average.
author: Tamara S.

description: I love this place, I wish they delivered. They would make so much money if they did. Enough about my daydreaming...I normally get the bbq beef for dinner. That's enough for me. I have gotten the seafood soup before and that is very tasty. I want to dine in sometime soon to try their pancakes!
author: Amy L.

description: Got us in quick, served food quick. Kal bi ribs so ono
author: Brandon K.

description:
Kim Chee Fried Rice + Bul Go Gi + Spicy Pork
Delicious. Fresh. Plentiful. 

Place is a small and gets a little tight but it was bomb.
author: Gunther C.

description:
My brother and I have been going here ever since they opened over a year ago, and we absolutely love it. Having eaten at many Korean restaurants in SF, I must say that this is our favorite. The food's good, the price is right and we are always pleased with the staff and service. 

The only complain I have is that the 2-seater table is not big enough to accommodate our appetites. It's also nice to see them doing well, whether weekdays or weekends, there is usually a wait line outside the restaurant.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Came here with my daughter,  who has been here a few times already.   We both ordered the beef and vegetable bibimbap in a stone pot.  Nice presentation and served piping hot.   Good flavor and textures.   Service was prompt when taking the orders and serving it.   However,  there was no real follow up and we kept having to ask for things. Business was steady and they didn't seem like they were short staffed.   Will go back and try other things on the menu.  

It's a small restaurant,  so either come early or after the lunch or dinner rush.
author: Florlina A.

description: Manna's probably the only Korean restaurant that's really good and is decent priced. Not too expensive like all the other Korean restaurants I know of. I am a huge fan of their Japchae (sorry if I'm spelling it incorrectly). Their tofu soup is also good and I really like their pork as well. I'm a fan and I'd come here again if I'm ever craving for Korean food during the daytime!
author: cadence p.

description:
Went with my bestie here for dinner and the dinner was great! 

Had:
 #2: Bul Kogi (Tender BBQ Ribeye) $9.99
#22: Kimchi Fried Rice over Egg $8.99

Totally recommend both these dishes! also, comes with 6 small side dishes (fish paste, kimchi, etc.)

Both dishes got us filled, portions are fair enough.
author: Kim C.

description:
This review is based on my order of Nakji Bokkeum/ (stir-fired spicy octopus), doenjang-jjigae/ (bean paste stew), and Shrimp Frid Rice/ (shrimp fried rice with two fried eggs sunny-side up on top). 

Pros: Good price for SF, good taste, good service(lots of free side dish), good choices. Almost all most popular Korean dishes were there. Worth the wait.
 
Cons: nearly impossible to find a parking(Sunday evening during Memorial Day weekend), and long line (waited 40 min.).

It was my first time trying to find a Korean restaurant in SF. (from Orange County, was there for the holiday weekend)
author: Joe C.

description: I picked up some take out recently and paid with a card. I noticed in my bank statement that they wrote over my receipt and gave themselves a tip that was a few dollars more than what I wrote. Very shady.
author: Anthony C.

description:
This place is legit. I've been passing by for the last million years thinking 'I have to try that place' but didn't get around to it until this weekend. Super small and unassuming (likely) family owned corner shop - Be prepared to wait if you're eating during normal meal times.

Manna can really only handle a max group of 4 so don't be the jerk patrons who take up 1/7 tables for hours while discussing which place has the best artisan toast.

Ordered:

Japchae ... Of courrrseeee!
Spicy Pork
Soy sauce chicken wings - OMG.

Everything was really good but the chicken wings were on another level. I mean, San Tung watch out! Different style - Much lighter batter and not super drenched in thick gooey sauce but absolutely packed with flavor. Wings were better than the Korean wing houses in SJ by a long shot.

Service is what it is - Little sweet Korean ladies who remind me of an aunt/grandma to be. Leave the snobbery at the door and you'll love this little hidden gem amongst yupville ;)

Can't wait to go back!!! Oh, and the prices are VERY reasonable for Korean food.
author: Con L.

description: It's great place to eat, expect a wait and for them to busy. I'm satisfied because they were able to be nice about my "demand" on refills or anything I requested.
author: Wilson T.

description: My first Korean food in the city was here last night, and I wasn't disappointed.  We had the dukbokki or tteokbokki, and it was pretty excellent.  I pretty much always have yukgaejang, it's my fave Korean dish, and it was good here.  The mul naeng myun was really yummy.  My girl asked for sesame oil to put in it, but it was so busy there the server forgot.  She later came back and apologized for forgetting but it didn't really matter because it was so tasty anyways.   We had the sweet & spicy chicken wings too, which were more Chinese flavored Korean-style chicken wings, but were really good nonetheless.  The banchan was good, but most importantly about that was that the kimchi was really good, a crucial sign of a good Korean restaurant.  If a Korean restaurant doesn't care about it's banchan and kimchi, then the food will be more often than not suspect too.
author: Frank K.

description:
My friends and I tried to eat here. We waited almost an hour and a half. We were told twice that we were next and yet they continued to call other parties with the same or more people. We ended up leaving and going elsewhere that was busier and got in much sooner. Needless to say we were disappointed with the experience, especially after reading so many wonderful reviews.

I hope that the food is much better than the service and that is why so many people have rated it highly.
author: Myra G.

description:
Manna's quality food and service and super reasonable prices (think $2-3 less than the average Korean restaurant) makes for a 4 star venue!  I'm a fan, and I'll likely go again...and soon!

My dining companion, a Korean cuisine (and K-pop and K dramas) aficionado arrive at Manna on a Sunday evening (past 8:00pm) and were seated within 10 minutes; just enough time to figure out what we were going to order. Staff is friendly and attentive.  Food arrived fairly quickly (and thankfully there was a nice array of banchans as we were famished), and devoured just as quick.  Here's what we ordered:

Spicy pork arrived on a sizzling plate and was still sizzling, just the way I like it.  (Strange to me when grilled meats aren't sizzling on a sizzling plate.)  Pieces of pork were cut not too thin and not too thick and were seasoned very nicely.  Wish it was spicier though.  Love the white and green onions that arrive below and atop, respectively.

Kimchi jigae was flavorful, spicy and had beef and tofu!  The tofu was more a firm tofu rather than a silken tofu, which was fine by me because if I wanted silken I would have ordered tofu jigae.  

Tteokbokki was somehow flavorful and hearty yet light at the same time.  Ingredients were fresh with plenty of rice sticks, fish cakes, mushrooms, green and white onions, kimchi and zucchini.  The sauce was just the right amount of spicy.

A fair amount of people around us were having dol sot bibimbap, and is also one of my favorite dishes.  Must go back and try especially because it's less than $10...unheard of!!
author: Marie B.

description: I like the short beef rib. It is very very soft and tasty! The rice along with the rib is also very yummy!  The seafood pancake is my second favorite food here! You have all kinds of seafood inside. The size of the pancake is big enough to be shared!! The tofu soup is just ok, compared to other tofu house!
author: Yan W.

description:
This place is def just 3 star, and that is frankly generous after the 1 hour wait we endured to eat here. Unlike other places where the wait is worthwhile because there is actually something special to wait for, I wanted to kick myself after waiting that long to eat the kind of Korean food that I could get... well... anywhere! Is the food bad? No. Is the food worth a 10 minute wait? Ehh... maybe... if everything else was at a 30 minute wait. I just don't get it... are there no other Korean food joints around? We were waiting because we wanted to be polite to our friends who invited us to join them and because we didn't know any better... we thought we were waiting for really good Korean food. Alas, Yelp... this was a letdown. 

I don't mean to knock them down, the owners were nice, service was good, the food was OK... and frankly, if there isn't a wait, sure, I'll eat here again. But NEVER will I ever go back and wait another hour for a table at this joint. No thanks. Get take out if you really want Korean food from here.
author: Alice W.

description:
This place is tiny and at times the wait is a little long, however, the guy there is nice enough to take down your phone number and call you when your table is ready. That way you can mosey on over to the bar across the street and grab a drink.

The portions are good and the look I usually get from the waitress tells me that I am about one seafood pancake away from lapsing into a permanent food coma.

Chicken wings rival that of San Tung's [ i know....blasphemy right?]
Bulgogi is tender and flavorful
Kimchi Fried Rice has just the right amount of kick

I'm sure I've tried other things but those are the ones that have stood out in my memory.

TL;DR: Highly recommended gem in the inner sunset. Get there early unless you want to wait.
author: Jaime W.

description:
All start with this! Great Korean food! 

Came in around 1:20ish. Plenty of seating! But still crowded enough to know that this was one of the places to be at!

Staff: owners are quite attentive to tea an your general well being. One of my friends had a bug bite our his arm. And the nice lady was like "did you get that from here" (with genuine concern in her voice)

Food: Excellent. We order the Seafood pancake, spicy pork and kimchi fried rice. 
I'm only going to comment on the seafood pancake! This was amazing. Loaded with squid and octopus tentacles crawling out of the pancake.

Ban chan(?) it was limited but the kimchi tasted quite fresh! (and it was sour like ultra fermented kimchi) so definitely a plus in my book. 

Service: Friendly mom and pop type restaurant as stated by others. Free rice and tea. And they were attentive on both. 

I have to come back and try the chicken wangs! I was eyeing that on the menu!

P.S. I also had no problems with parking. Better yet, I found a spot with an out of order meter. (which means limit 2 hours for free) :)
author: Christopher S.

description:
Came here today because another korean restaurant was closed up the street. Never seen or heard of it before, but when we walked in the restaurant was full and it smelled amazing so it HAD to be pretty good, right?

We ordered the Vegetable Stone Pot Bibimbap, and an order of Dukbokee. The side dishes they give you at the beginning of your meal were good. The Bibimbap was as good as any other place, nothing quite special but it was good. It could have used more vegetables though, because I kind of felt like i was eating a lot of rice. It came with spinach, bean sprouts, carrots, a few more varieties of vegetables, and a fried egg on top with the red sauce on the side. I really liked the Dukbokee. The texture was a little on the chewy side, but that's how I like it, and the sauce was the perfect amount of spicy. (I can't take spicy very well, so I guess it wasn't SUPER spicy if that's what you like). It also game with a lot of fish cakes and vegetables. They kept our water and hot tea filled, and great service overall.

Though we didn't order much, I noticed many other tables around us also ordered Bibimbap, bulgogi, the seafood pancake, and something that looked like noodle soup. Maybe it was tofu soup, but those items seemed to be popular there. 

I'd say for the price, and the decency of the food I'd definitely come here again. They also have lunch specials M-F until 3pm where some items on the menu are a dollar off. Most items on the menu are under 10 dollars which is pretty good for a korean restaurant, if you ask me!
author: Jaime H.

description: Some of the best Korean BBQ food I've had in the Bay Area, and the service was great. Try the Galbi and the Hot Pot Tofu Soup.
author: Nhan N.

description:
I remember when this location used to be a Thai Restaurant! Which just goes to show you how long I haven't been around the area.

Manna is great! Friendly service and reasonable prices for some good Korean food!

I came here on a weekday. I believe it was a Wednesday night and the place was packed! My friend and I were lucky to be seated at the last table in the joint! I would come early for dinner service because this is a small place!

I got the dol-sot bibimbap (mixed rice with bean sprouts, spinach, bulgogi[marinaded beef], carrots, and a sunny-side up egg) on a sizzling stone bowl. YUM! It was everything I wanted that remedied a long and eventful week. Tasty and flavorful! Did I mention rice and mini side dishes were included in the meal without any additional charges? Yes! WIN! To wash down all that delicious food we ordered a a liter of "Hite" beer to be shared between us. The beer had a light body and we could have easily ordered another!

Great place! Great prices! Check it out!
author: Amy C.

description: Their food is ok. Their food is not that much delicious. If you wanna have have something inexpensive is a good chose otherwise I don't recommend to go there.
author: Keivan L.

description:
The owner and staff are always so nice!  You're greeted well and even though there may be a wait, it's well worth it.  I guess I'm just delighted that they are so genuinely friendly.  I've worked in a couple food establishments and it's so easy for workers to get jaded and not care.  It's refreshing to feel *actually* welcome in restaurant! The food is tasty and well priced.  I always get the jabchae and some sort of rice cake dish.  If I could eat these every day, I would.  

Manna is my go-to place for Korean!
author: Amanda W.

description:
I'm always baffled by how expensive Korean food is in SF, but Manna has cheap prices for excellent food and large portions.

We ordered the seafood pancake and spicy pork.  Each came with rice and banchan and cost less than $10.

The only downside of coming here is difficult street parking and it's far from me.  However, another Korean restaurant called Jin Mi just opened up in the TL and it looks like it has the exact same menu as Manna.
author: S L.

description: Good homestyle Korean food for a reasonable price. Ordered the sweet fried chicken, chige, and bi bim bap. Chicken and bi bim bap was awesome! However, would pass on the chige (as frankly it didn't have as the depth in flavor as some other places) and opt for jab chae or a meat dish instead. With the standard side staples Korean restaurants give you, the three dishes filled us up. Would come back again.
author: Seira M.

description:
Let's get one thing straight, this isn't the BEST korean restauran in SF. It's passable, edible and sometimes hits the spot when you're craving a Korean dish.

Everything is a bit ummm shall we say overspiced? I've had the following:

llabboki-- 3/5 stars
tofu soup-- 3/5 stars
Korean pancake-- 3/5 stars
banchan(side dishes)-- 3/5

What I do appreciate is that they don't charge extra for extra banchan or rice, now that's authenticity!

All in all, everything is just slightly over mediocre. Seeing as better restaurants are all the way in canyoubeanyfartherRichmond, I'd come back to Manna. Their dishes have a clean taste, though I always find myself asking after a bite, "Why is it so salty?"

Parking: Parking on Irving isn't as much of a problem as it is parking downtown, but it still ain't easy. You'll probably have to drive around a few times to find a spot esp. during the weekends.
author: Rosa L.

description:
Korean food? SURE!

My girlfriend took me here for my birthday lunch on Sunday afternoon. Parking was a PAIN! However, after about 4-5 circles, I finally found a parking spot and proceeded to the restaurant. When we got here, this place was pretty packed with just 1 table left for me and my girlfriend. 

After about 5 minutes, we decided on what we wanted and when we got ready to order, the waiter noticed that we ordered like 4 things and suggested us the bigger table after the other customers left. 

As soon as the sides came, I quickly chowed down. It was about 2 in the afternoon and I had been up since 10, so I was STARVING. We ordered bulgogi, kalbi, clear noodles with beef, and kimchi fried rice. I have to say, everything was pretty damn good. The rice was full of flavor, the bulgogi was delicious as was the kalbi, and sides were plentiful. Definitely recommend coming here if you're craving korean food. Left here extremely full with some leftovers for lunch tomorrow. 

Service here was superb. Waiter/waitresses were efficient and nice. 

Total came up to about 40 bucks, which is considerably cheap for a FAT meal for 2 AND some. 

***Parking***: EXTREMELY hard to find especially on Sunday. I suggest you sit at a corner or at a parking spot and wait for people to get in their cars. 

Cash or Credit accepted!
author: Johnny G.

description: Love their side dishes! Small place, most of the tables hold 2-4 people. I've had a variety of dishes and all we're great. Just thinking about Manna makes me hungry...mmm...manna...
author: Wendy L.

description:
I don't care what people say, but this is best Korean I can get without having to cross the park from Sunset. The place is small and takes over a Thai place that never attracted enough customers. Maybe it was haunted. But Manna has scared the ghouls away. Even when there's a line, it's not before long before we're seated. I think it's owned by Korean couple with the husband serving as the main waiter.

-Kal Bi/BulKogi/Dok Bul Kogi are all the bbq standard fare. portions are kinda small but tastes are pretty point on. sometimes a bit weet.
-Japchae comes in a good portion size for an appetizer to share
-Dol-sot bibimbop is the one in a stone pot. it's good for a single dinner option and you can smother on as much of the red sauce as you like to change the flavor profile a bit.
-Soft Tofu Soup is DELISH and hits the spot whenever craving something small but filling. Maybe it's not as traditional as other Korean places, but for someone with Americanized Korean taste bud cravings, it works.
-Kimchi Bokum Bab is kimchi fried rice. Favorite way to combine something that will fill you up with a Korean kick

The side dishes are endless and service is really great here. Only trouble is battling other drivers at night for parking.
author: Dennis L.

description: This place is inexpensive and good. Good service and large portions. Food is very hot coming out so be careful. Seafood pancake was good. Short ribs excellent. Banchan. Plentiful.  Only small criticism is small variety of drinks available. I go here a few times a month.
author: Lambchop B.

description:
Party of 2

What we ordered:
#1 Kalbi Beef $12.99
#25 Nakji Bokum $11.99 (sauteed small octopus & veggie with spicy sauce)
+ beer

#1 was fantastic
#25 - do not order.  sauce was good but that was about it.  the octopus was so chewy & tough that I spent 5 minutes chewing each piece.  It was either not cooked well or they really need to cut it into smaller pieces.

6 free side dishes.  Not a great selection when comparing to Brother's, but will do.  Favorite was fish cake.  That's what helped me with the rice when #25 was didn't pull through

Service - excellent.  They kept offering to re-fill.

I will definitely come back and try their signature bibimbap.

Btw - during busy hours when others are waiting, they will try to "hurry" you out.  So basically this is no place to chat it up for a few hours.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Great Korean food and great service.  

Love the unlimited rice and of course their Banchan

My husband and 15 month old have eaten here 2 times.  Our main dishes Spicy Pork Dae Ji Bulgogi, Beef Bulgogi, and short rin Kalbi.

Excellent pricing as well. My daughter loves the Beef Bulgogi because of it's sweet and peppery flavor.

We will be back again!

Kamsahamnida
author: Sheila S.

description: Very good Korean food, albeit a little on the tame side. We both enjoyed the seafood pancakes! Service was excellent!
author: Michael S.

description:
I love Manna. The first time I went, I went after school with my friend. If you go on a sunny day during the afternoon, you will love the atmosphere because the sunlight that seeps through the windows just illuminates the whole restaurant. Although the restaurant may be small, its nice, quiet and cozy. So if you are looking for a quiet lunch or a cozy dinner, this is the place to go.

I may not be the expert of Korean food, but I know good Korean food when I eat it :D
They have really good BBQ chicken and royal court dokbokki. When I finished my meal, I just wanted to eat more dokbokki. It wasn't my first time eating it, but ever since I ate Mann's dokbokki, I started to have this addiction for it. 

I highly highly recommend the dol-sot bibimbap. It may be super hot when you get it, but it's still a pretty good dish to get if it's your first time at Manna. And if you are starving with your friends, sharing a plate of their ddeokbokki is recommended as well. 

I will be going back and bringing my friends there. I will definitely order to go if I am in the neighborhood.

If you are wondering about service, they are friendly people. There's some stereotype going around that if you are Korean, then they will treat you better. WRONG! They will treat you kindly no matter what!

I LOVE THIS PLACE
author: Cynthia D.

description:
We arrived around 12:30pm and the place was packed... Well, there are only about 20 seats in the place. We waited about 30 minutes for an open table for 5. We were welcomed with some cold water and hot barley tea - very traditional and tasty. We ordered bulgogi, kimchi chigae, and some pot stickers. The bulgogi was average, the chigae was delicious, and the potstickers were gobbled up by the kids. The side dishes were above average with the kimchi on the spicier side. The service was great!

When visiting SF again, we'll surely stop back by.
author: Todd C.

description:
This great little Korean restaurant is one of my favorites in the city.

Really friendly staff--not sure if it's a mom-and-pop kinda place or not, but it feels that way sometimes. I've had the pancakes, bulgogi, tofu soup, bibimbap, and several other dishes. All quite good.

Would definitely return.
author: Thuan N.

description:
This is my new fave Korean restaurant.  I have been here twice for dinner, and have tried the Dol Sot Bibimbap, Spicy Chicken Wings, Kimchi Pancake, and Bulgolgi.  Everything was a decent portion size, tasty, and super affordable compared with ohter Korean restaurants.

The service is top notch - they are constantly refilling my tea without me having to ask.  I also don't feel rushed out of the restaurant.  Everyone that I have encountered there is sweet and pleasant.  I've gone on weeknights, so I've never had to wait. 

I can't wait to try their lunch specials, as they have mostly the same items, but at an even more affordable price!  I'm all about a good deal. ;)
author: Genie S.

description: I was really disappointed in this place after having dinner with my friend here. The high marks on Yelp did not reflect in the quality of food we ordered last night. The seafood pancake was disgusting and burnt and the bbq pork ribs lacked flavor. Service was good but quality of the food was not so hot. It was a busy night for them but that doesn't excuse them of providing bad tasting food. Would I come back? Nope. No way.
author: Matthew L.

description: Definitely had much better Korean food elsewhere..and our friend got really sick after eating here ...
author: Tracy D.

description: Solid banchan, tofu soup, bulgogi, and bimimbap. Extra star for reasonable prices. Not too many dining spots and there can be a line in the evening.
author: Pearl L.

description:
WOOHOO! AS GOOD AS IT GETS!

What a relief, until Manna opened here recently I was quite sad about the lack of good korean food in this area. As i have been living in LA for the past several years I have been very spoiled by LA K Town Korean food. So you should believe me when I say this is great korean food. 

5 stars for the portions - Very filling. need i say more? 

5 stars for the variety - stew? check. meat? check. spicy tofu soup? check. noodles? check. duk bok gi???? check. fried rice? check If you are looking for "home-cooked" hearty korean food - you have to try this restaurant out! There are a variety of flavors from mild to spicy from cold dishes to hot - it all depends on what you are feeling! I personally like to come with a couple of my friends (2-3) so we can each order a different dish and share! :) 

5 stars for the service - some of the friendliest korean restaurant servers i have ever met. actually, probably some of the nicest restaurant peeps ever. hands down. the owners are so nice! you can tell they really care about your experience and the quality of food :) 

5 stars for the restaurant - although on the smaller side - it is always packed but they make their space work! plus it's always it's very clean :) extra points for me... :D 

and here are some of my favorite dishes 

1. sea food spicy tofu soup!
2. kalbi - it's a bargain for what you pay - you get loads! 
3. spicy chicken wings - perfect combination of sweet and savory w/ a little kick! 
4. bi bim bap - the perfect blend of rice, veggies, and meat - so filling --- and it comes w/ a fried egg on top! love it!!! and their spicy red chili sauce is a perfect addition 

and of course - unlimited ban chan  & rice ..  


Definitely try this place out - if you are looking to eat a flavorful meal and want a great meal for a great price - check out Manna! I'll definitely be frequenting by w/ friends or picking up some dinner to go :)
author: Jo C.

description: I don't understand why there's a line out the door. I did not like the greasy food; oil tasted old. Very salty and I love salt. Didn't finish my dish. It took awhile before they brought me my check when I asked; perhaps it was an off night. Wouldn't recommend it.
author: Dianne N.

description: Came here with the fiancée yesterday and ordered the Kal Bi and Bul Kogi ($30.43 w/o tip).  Food was good and the service was great.  The place, however, is too small.
author: Lyn B.

description:
we have been to a Korean BBQ place in Oakland that is amazing: only around 30 dollars, you get unlimited stuff for the charcoal bbq.  you get kimchi pancake tofu stew etc.. fresh appetizer good service...

this place doesnt have fresh appetizers at all. underflavored even for people like us who eat light.  rice cakes are under cooked.   fish cakes are disappointing.  babimbob is plain.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Monday night and I absolutely loved everything about it. 

We were quickly seated. 

The soft tofu soup and seafood bibimbap were my two favorite dishes. I usually get their kimchi fried rice, but I opted out of it to try something different. 

The service was great. Consistent refills of the yummy appetizers!!

Tip: the restaurant is very small probably about six or seven tables so it wouldn't carter to big groups
author: Lisa T.

description:
Good food but nothing amazing.  If you are in the area, hungry and you can get in I would think you would enjoy the meal. But I would not make an effort to go there or go back.
The problem is that there is no shortage of 4 stars, so being 3 stars is tough.
author: Nigel J.

description:
We went there for my birthday dinner, as recommended by friends who had been there many, many times.  The restaurant is relatively small, but could accommodate a group of 6-7 people. (I doubt if they would have space for more than 10.)  Most of the tables are for 2-4 people, and there aren't that many tables to begin with. They don't take reservations so it's first come first serve.  

The restaurant atmosphere feels like sitting in a friend's house for dinner. The service is fast, attentive, and very, very friendly. Apparently the owner knows my friend by name since she goes back there all the time.  

Their menu delivers quality homemade food, though on the smaller portion side. Our favorites are the kimchi fried rice, kimchi pancake, bibimbap and the cold noodle. Their fried dumplings are a bit too bland. They offer generous ban chan.  The tea they serve is the quality barley tea. The friendly owner even brought out and showed us the barley tea package they used!


The bill comes in surprisingly cheap for a group of people. One of the down sides is that the place is packed and there are always people waiting, so we felt like we had to leave soon after the meal. I would go back to try other items in the menu.
author: Elle W.

description: This place SUCKS!! Tried to come here for dinner... They didn't want to accommodate our party of thirteen. The servers asked if we can eat separately and even asked if we can eat at different times. WTF?!?!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
The food was decent, and the service was nice, but I've definitely had better for lunch at other Korean places in the city.

I came in for lunch and had the #4, which was the grilled chicken, and my cousin ordered the Kalbi which was he short ribs. Service was attentive they were very prompt with coming over and taking our orders. The side dishes they bring out were tasty, and I had no problems there.
The only i had was that the chicken tasted kind of... dry. I know chicken, especially grilled chicken, is dry and not something to be savored, but my lunch definitely did not have any taste or korean spice. I liken it to pulling out a chicken breast, adding salt, and cooking it on a george foreman.
Lastly, the rice was definitely undercooked when I went.
Pricing is fair, and I don't want to sound like a complainer, but given the other good Korean places there are in the city, especially in the Sunset and Richmond, it's not hard to find another alternative to Manna.
author: Derrick C.

description:
Unlimited rice and side dishes are a huge plus, especially for somewhere in San Francisco. It looks family owned and the family is so very nice! I asked them what kind of tea they used and they told me it was half corn, half barley. Impressive!

We ordered the bul kogi, which was a touch dry; wish it could have had some more sauce.
The seafood korean pancake was my favorite, it was really really delicious. The sesame sauce that came with it made it even better!
The sweet and spicy chicken wings are not as good as San Tung chicken wings but still enjoyable. Too bad I only had 1 because I was so full from everything!
author: Wilson T.

description:
My boyfriend had noticed this place one of the times driving and he has wanted to try it for a while, but since we were going to other places or eating at home, we never got around to it. Long story short, his parents were coming into the City and we decided on this place. We ordered quite a few dishes between the 4 of us and we were so full by the end of it. 

Food: 
Kalbi - so delicious. They gave us like 10+ pieces and I enjoyed all the pieces that I had eaten.
Bibimbop - We didn't let it sit as long as I would have liked, but it was delicious!
Jabchae - Really well made. I enjoyed it! 
Kimchi pancake - You know, I normally don't like Kimchi, but I really didn't mind it all that much in this pancake. It was pretty good.
Soft Tofu Soup - Delicious!

The service was really good too. Whenever a dish came out, it was placed on our table so all our food was nice and hot when we got it.  They're super nice too. 

ps. the people who come here are nice too. We were waiting for a table for 4 and they set a table up for two in the table for 4, but they gave it up for us because a table for 2 was opening up soon. Thanks stranger!
author: Nina Y.

description: The people here are very friendly. The bring the food on hot stone plates so you don't get to cook it in front of you but he food is fresh and sizzling when it comes. The workers are very nice and helpful and I would definitely come back here again. The price is decent too
author: Rob T.

description:
Dolsot bibimbap = LOVE!
That spicy sauce that it comes with is so delicious :) I had no idea what it was before, but they were kind enough to teach us how to eat it LOL..

Those chicken wings are super good toooo. I'm gonna say it, I don't know which I like better - theirs or san tungs! :o

We also got the bulgogi, but it was a bit bland. They don't have cucumbers as a side dish, which disappointed me dearly. I love cucumbers :(
author: Erica A.

description:
My friend and I made a decision to eat here for lunch one day. Based on the great reviews, I thought, "why not." It was a cute family run business and I really like kimchi (I know, lame excuse...)

Korean restaurants give you side dishes while you wait for your order. These are the equivalent to American appetizers with the only difference: they are free. I will say that these dishes met or exceeded expectations. 

My biggest disappointment was the dish that I had ordered, which, sadly, I forgot the name. It was a rice cake stir fry with meat (pieces of beef and tons of fish cake) and vegetables (aka too much green onion). The dish really wasn't that great. There was barely any beef and trust me, I overhauled the entire plate to find scraps of it. They compensated for the lack of beef with an overdose of fish cake. And as mentioned earlier, the dish's vegetable was pretty much all green onion. It wasn't worth it.

Order something else.
author: Lily Z.

description:
I've heard good things about Manna from a friend who lives in Inner Sunset. Their food is very authentic. Fast and friendly service from the Korean lady - the second set of banchan was brought to the table after  we devoured the first set.  We love their seafood pancakes and dolsot bibimbap. Sudoonboo (tofu soup) can be a little less salty, but overall it's a good, fast and simple meal. 

The prices are very friendly and affordable. It's definitely a great addition to the Inner Sunset restaurant scene. I will definitely come back here.
author: Saran R.

description: 2 stars for tasty, what seems to be authentic Korean cuisine. Attentive and kind staff too. The 69 out of 100 health score is horrifying, however. Buyer beware of how dirty a place must be to receive a score this low from the health inspector.
author: Chris A.

description: The food here is inexpensive and the service is on point . I first came here after walking around the farmers market nearby, the place is kinda small but that doesn't shy away from the food around it. Once I walked in, a delicious smell hit me ! The bathroom was very cramped and scary but that's not the case . The food is very good and it comes in with free rice and side dishes . Definitely going to become a regular
author: Dorothy W.

description: I went for the first time to Manna on the recommendation of a friend. The service was very nice. Barley tea is served complimentary in a glass. I had the bibimbop (beef) and kalbi. The rice was fresh and the ribs were tender. They give a mild korean spicy sauce on the side. Initially I thought that it would be filling but, after finishing the meal, I found that I could have easily eaten more. I think the servings are smaller than what I've experienced in San Jose. I would definately go back as the food tasted great.
author: Jeff K.

description:
While walking here my BBBFF informed me that she can now flex her pecs and make her boobs bounce. This in no way influenced my enjoyment of dinner! Serious...

The first thing you'll notice about this place is that it is small! If you are familiar with this neighborhood though, you'll know that square footage comes at a premium so many of the best places are shoehorned into tight confines.  Trust me though, if a wait is required it is worth the wait.

The japche is the best I've had and the primary reason for this review.  The sesame and beef flavors were deep and veggies fresh.  I'll be ordering this often.

KFC, we aren't talking Colonel Saunders...Korean Fried Chicken!  The breeding was unique.  It was more like a true breaded fried chicken as opposed to a battered and fried chicken, if that makes sense.  The sweet and spicy sauce was very well balanced, but that may not satisfy those looking for an inferno in their mouths when they have KFC.  Ask them to make it spicy if that is your thing and I'm sure they will accommodate.

The dol sot bibimbap had beautifully crunchy rice at the bottom of the stone bowl.  That always makes me happy!

I'll be taking the N Judah out here as much as I can just to come try more dishes!
author: Luis M.

description:
Manna used to be located in K-town down in Los Angeles. They recently closed their K-town and Culver City restaurants to move up to San Francisco? 

Manna's quality of food in SoCal wasn't that great except if it was your birthday, they'd douse 2 bottles of champagne all over you. I was expecting the same when I came here with a few friends. 

When we first walked in, the first things we noticed was there weren't any grills on any of the tables. Disappointing..

BiBimBap here SUCKS!!! Where's the friggn meat and gochujang?! My rice wasn't even sizzling..

Banchan here..eh hehehe..tasted like it came from a jar..

Service was friendly, but I can honestly say that I have had WAY better food than this..
author: Jason C. J.

description: There is a serious shortage of korean restaurants in the inner sunset so i'm sure a lot of people would appreciate this place. We ordered the seafood pancake, fried mandu and galbi which were all pretty good. The galbi was my fav, much better than others I've tried in the city. Service was quick. The parentals only live 10 blocks away so will def be back to try the other dishes.
author: Queena T.

description:
On a Sunday night it was packed with a few parties waiting outside. 
I always forget how horrible parking is in this neighborhood. Since I was getting take-out I parked illegally (shhhh...) and ran in.

Kampoongki (sweet & spicy chicken wings) - I didn't try any of these, chicken wings aren't my thing.
Bulkogi - so, so good! You must try this. 
Dae Ji Bulkogi - I liked this too but the pork was a little dry. Good flavors though!

Now Manna is my go-to Korean spot. If only I didn't have to drive halfway to Hawaii to get there.

I'll definitely be back to try more!
author: Sara P.

description: Been here many times before and the even though the food was great. The service was ehhh. It was like pulling teeth to get refills of water and banchan. But this time super versed all others. Came here this Sunday and there were 2 new servers there were accommodating and attentive eem the given the volume. I was for the first time able to enjoy enjoy my kal bi without yearning for water or fish cakes. Bravo!
author: Lizz M.

description:
Manna does not disappoint this girl. We waited for about 20 minutes on a Tuesday (mind you its a few days before Turkey day) outside in the light drizzle. The staff was apologetic and accommodating while we waited. Its a small place so it was expected. Hot tea upon being seated and our food came quick. 

Nothing beats the seafood tofu soup on a chilly rainy evening in the city. It was almost perfect... now if only I was home wrapped in a blanket with the soup in hand. I love all the side dishes ranging in different flavors. My significant other ordered the bibimbop in the sizzling bowl which he inhaled. 

The menu is fairly cheap compared to other Korean spots as most dishes are about 8-10$. We ordered two dishes and a large beer and the tab came out to approximately $25.
author: Wednesday M.

description: This place always seems busy, doing great business for a small shop. The easy to order menu is posted on the wall and under the table glass for convenience. The service is quick and friendly. You can get extra servings of pickles and plenty of tea. The dolsot bibbimbap in the stone bowl was quite tasty with a gorgeous presentation. A sunny side up, fried egg, colorful veggies, tasty Korean beef and luckily they serve the hot sauce on the side, so you can add at your own discretion. Good prices, good food, good service.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Manna offers affordable and delicious Korean food, which is rare in San Francisco.

The seafood bi bim bap was full of flavor, and the scorching hot stone bowls created wonderful rice crisps.  The sweet & spicy chicken wings were drenched in sauce but still crispy!

Manna also offers unlimited rice and side dishes - sure, white rice may increase the risk of diabetes, but it is a necessary complement to the strongly flavored food.

The service is attentive, and the owner seemed to genuinely appreciate our patronage.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I had better Korean BBQ.

I had better BiBinBup.

I had better Green Onion Pan Cake.

I had better.

Korean food has only 2 discerption.

Good and Mediocre

That's all.

There is a nice thing about Korean food is that there is nothing really bad.
It's just mediocre.
It doesn't have really bad food.
That's a good thing in Korean food.

The place is edible but mediocre.

Is this the 1st Korean restaurant on Irving?
author: Nobu K.

description: I really don't understand all the stars, Yelp! This is such mediocre Korean food. Its not worth going to even when I crave the taste and don't want to go far. Man I miss the Korean food Mecca of LA. On my last visit I had a stomach ache from the bibimbob :( two stars for a solid variety of banchan.
author: Aya W.

description: This place is relatively small and sometimes there is a wait.  Prices are very reasonable.  However the food is just so so.  I definitely had better.  Not really sure how this place gets high ratings.  Anyways, let's break it down.  The kal bi was small and the flavors were not there,  the spicy pork was meh, the chicken wings were a bit too fried and did not like the flavor to it, their tofu soup is passable; watered down, and last their kimchee fried rice was okay but really oily.  Wished they also had a option as to adding beef or pork to the fried rice.  The sides were okay, at least the kimchee was good...
author: Ann L.

description:
My fav. go to spot for korean food. The prices are more affordable than others around the area and food is very decent. They have a pretty extensive menu so there is something for everyone. We always get a bibimbap, jap chae, soft tofu seafood soup and the chicken wing. All that for $30 with left overs to take home as well. 
My only gripe is that they don't serve the mackeral as a side dish.
There can be a wait but usually no more than 45 mins I would say if you come during the prime dinner time. Ladies, walk a block or so up to Ambience to kill some time. They have extremely cute shoes & clothing.  
Oh and also factor in time for parking as you know street parking on upper Irving can be hard. 
I'll definitely be returning!
author: Bunnie L.

description:
Tasty. This place always has a line, so I decided that it was time to try it out.  

We ate: (sorry I can't remember the real names & can't find the menu online)
Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings
Yam Noodles 
Grilled Beef
Kimchi & Pork Soup

The Kimchi Soup is the only thing that I wouldn't get again.  It just tasted like kimchi, I was expecting something different.

The service was great! I will come back when I am in the mood for Korean.
author: Christy L.

description: This is my favorite Korean place in the city. Great friendly service, excellent food, very affordable prices. Try the Kimchi fried rice!
author: Keith W.

description:
Seriously my favorite Korean spot. 

Not only are the dishes super delicious but it's affordable as well. If I remember correctly, lunch specials are Monday thru Friday 12-3pm. 

My fav here is the tofu soup medium spicy. Just enough of a spicy kick to keep me warm and not sweating bullets. The seafood pancake is my second favorite. It's flavorful and they def don't skimp on the seafood. The banchan is also pretty good, nice variety. 

Service is usually on point. Owner stops by to ask if everything is ok and whatnot, water/tea is always filled, and they refill the banchan if you ask. Pluses in my book.
author: Jessica C.

description:
This is the best korean restaurant, with the best services. 

must try it!!!!!! and you will love it :)
author: Kel H.

description: Very nice. although there was very little meat in the yam noodles but great taste. And the  Bibimbap dishes that come sizzling out of the over are super-WOW this is the best. And the staff are super attentive. Crazy Korean fare is sure to keep you guessing and those little appetizers that they serve are so cool. Those Koreans do have a thing for those little squids and octopuses.
author: Lantz G.

description:
Manna has been on my radar ever since my coworker dropped off their menu on my desk. Stopped by Friday night with the bf...we waited a little bit for a table; the inside is cramped so we waited outside (make sure you bring a jacket on those cold SF nights)... we were finally seated and decided to try - kimchee chige, kal bi and dol sot bi bim bop. 

Our banchan and food arrived together...kim chige was delicious - not watery and had large pieces of meat in the soup. Kal Bi was good I prefer my meat to have a little char on it  but overall pretty tasty, and the dol sot was good as well.  Service was lacking a bit - had to constantly ask for water, tea, dishes were not bused around us only until they had diners come in.... but of course I'm sure they will work out their kinks since they are still brand new. 

 I would definitely come back as the price is cheaper than any place I've dined in the Richmond and I'm sure service will improve over time. Great addition to the inner Sunset - hope they are around for a long time!
author: Julie F.

description:
3/5 lunch specials

the food here is great, but i'm always partial to jong ga house in oakland. i had the kal bi, and my friend got the seafood bi bim bap. my meat was super tender and had good flavor. for a lunch specials, these were generous portions. i'd come back and try the pancakes that i was eyeing at tables next to ours.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Lunch specials less than $10. Dinner menu also inexpensive, tables close and crowded at night. Service friendly but slow when busy.
Very good Dol Sot Bi Bim Bop, with the crispy rice at the end of the goodies.
Ban chans OK, a couple items off taste and texture.
author: YearOf M.

description:
Unfortunately this might be the worse Korean restaurant in the city. Yikes! how can there be bad Korean food in the city? Came here with 3 friends around 6:30pm on a Saturday night. Already the restaurant was crowded and there were several groups outside. Put our name on the list and estimate wait time was going to be an hour. Ok, if the restaurant is full and there are so many people waiting outside, how bad can the food be?

Finally seated after a little over an hour. The establishment is tiny, which is probably why there was a long wait. There are probably 10 or so tables inside. Staff is friendly but not swift.  Seemed a little inexperience. Friends and I ordered some very basic Korean dishes. Kim Chee fried rice for me, Kal Bi Tang, Bi Bim Bap and another noodle soup I can't remember. My fried rice was pretty bland. It didn't have the tangy kim chee flavor at all. Plus the portion was pretty small. My friend's bi bim bap was awful. The whole dish was too sweet. Really strange. What's also strange is that the owner came by to tell us how to add the hot sauce to the bi bim bap. You think if we knew how to order bi bim bap, we would know what to do with the hot sauce. Not to mention my friend is half Korean.

Overall, the prices here are about $2 cheaper than most Korean restaurants. However, you really pay for what you get. Strange flavors and small portions. Looking around, we realize most of the patrons look like younger college-kiddos. No comment on the side dishes because I've already forgotten what they serve. Definitely was not worth the hour wait.
author: Terry D.

description: Came here with my boyfriend because we saw a friend come here a view days ago. Complimentary what tasted like hot rice green tea which was really good! But I didn't like that they gave it to us in a glass cup, because it got too hot to hold after awhile. Got there around noon & thankfully got seated right away because there was a wait RIGHT after me, phew! They gave us the sides, 6 little dishes of mostly veggies, to be honest they weren't the best sides but they sufficed aha. Got the fried dumplings for appetizer & I honestly really liked them & appreciate the fact that these were fresh! (I could tell by the wonton) because I've gone to so many places that serve the frozen ones. they were sooo goood. &they gave us a lot! 8 pieces. (considering it was an appetizer it was a lot, other places mostly give around 4 pieces) we also got the Bul Kogi which wasn't the best I've had. It had a weird texture to it like it was cooked differently than I've had before &i wasn't too fond of it. But we also got the Sweet & spicy chicken &although the pieces were pretty small the breading had a good soft crunch with a flavorful sauce. Not spicy (which is good for me since im not too fond of spicy) sweet, garlicy & just plain delish. I personally want to give 3 1/2, but I'm feeling generous & I'll give 4 d;
author: Moriah D.

description:
I tried Manna today with my lady. We both thought the place was good and the price was very reasonable.

We both had the sizzling hot bowls. They were delicious. The staff was friendly. If I could leave one suggestion it would be, for Manna to play light music in the background.
author: Chi T.

description: Tiny place with maybe 6-7 tables. Food ranks on par with other SF Korean places, but what puts this place over the top is their customer service. When I walked in I was immediately acknowledged and told to put my name on the wait list. On a Sunday night we waited about 15 minutes. We ordered the seafood pancake (on the thicker, doughier side), bi bim bap and bean paste soup. My bean paste soup was nice and spicy and piping hot. Our waitress was friendly and quick and our tea was always filled. The husband and I were not overly hungry, so we only ate half of our plates. When we asked for boxes and the check, the manager (I'm assuming) looked at our half full plates and legitimately looked concerned and asked if everything was alright. Too cute. Prices are reasonable enough as well. We'll be back :)
author: Lisa H.

description: Really solid. Went there for lunch. Bimbimbop was very tasty. Service was efficient, food was delivered quickly. Only real negative was green tea.
author: Khozema S.

description:
My girlfriend and I showed up and saw several groups waiting outside. We walked in and put our names on a list with about 4-5 names in front of us so we were prepared to wait a long time. Fortunately a bunch of people were finishing up as we got there so out wait ended up being around 15 minutes and we arrived at 8:15 on a Saturday evening. 

We were seated quickly and given two glasses of tea. I ordered the veggie dolsot bibimbap and she ordered the japchae. Our food came out fairly quickly considering the place was packed, and our service was appropriately attentive, friendly without being overbearingly cloying. We never had an empty glass for too long.

Overall:

Banchan is good (apparently you get free refills of banchan)
Food is delicious
Service is great
Price is incredibly reasonable (we ordered 2 dishes and a beer and with tax and tip it came out to just under $30)

I don't give 5 star reviews out that often but this place was the perfect amount of everything. Definitely recommended!
author: Eric L.

description:
FINALLY! A decent REAL Korean restaurant in the inner sunset. This is the newest restaurant in the 9th & Irving area, replacing that Thai restaurant  I never bothered to try haha.

The bf & I shared the dolsot bibimbap and tofu soup w/ beef. The bibimbap was ok - sorta on the soggy side, either because the rice was too wet and even the hot stone didn't dry it out or because of the egg yolk. The tofu soup definitely hit the spot. Sometimes even regular tofu soup has a slight seafoody taste to it, which I don't like, but this was free of contaminating flavors haha. 5 banchan dishes, which is minimal compared to other places, but they are more than happy to refill your dishes.

Besides the yummy food, the service was excellent and the place was definitely bumpin. There were a lot of people walking by randomly, but would do a double take to look at the menu and then they'd come in.

Small restaurant and most tables are set to seat 2, few for 4, so make sure to come early or plan wisely because I'm sure this place will become quite popular very soon!
author: Miss H.

description:
You show me another Korean Restaurant in SF that is as cheap and as good and has as much variety of Korean dishes, and I will rate it 4 STARS.

This place has the BEST PRICE, FOOD, and VARIETY  for a Korean restaurant you are going to get. Does this place have the BEST Korean food in SF? No. But is it pretty damn good, even better than some of the more famous Korean Restaurants that charge double sometimes triple the price? HELL YES! 

Bottom line, I love this place and there is no other place in SF that can compare to this place...Hanh's Hibachi does not even come close. 

$7-9 for LARGE portion of main dish, ALL the side dishes, and rice...I could only dream of a place that served Korean food this good for so cheap. 

MUCH LOVE TO YOU MANNA! Wish you the best.
author: Nick C.

description: I normally go to another Korean restaurant but it wasn't open.  So I went on yelp to look for another place and found Manna.  I ordered the kimchi tofu soup and it was very salty, hardly any tofu and meat.  The place was small so everyone was cramped in.  It was decent but not my go to place for tofu soup.  To be fair, the prices were good.  If I come back, I might try out the other items on the menu like the rice cakes or pancake.
author: J J.

description:
I've been telling (complaining) to my friends that all the Inner Sunset needs is a BBQ place and Korean  restaurant (Han's Hibachi does not count). I'm being a little generous with 4 stars because the service was a little slow (just opened so expected) and a couple dishes I wanted to try were not available. It's a block from my house though and I'll definitely go back.

We had the dol sot bi bim bap, a spicy beef soup and rice roll/fish cake. All were good. Manna will become a regular in the neighborhood rotation.
author: matt d.

description:
I've tried out this fairly new Korean restaurant since it opened a few months ago and I am very impressed.  It's pretty small, is starting to get crowded, and I'm afraid that it'll be hard to get a table once word gets out about this place.  The dishes here are very reasonably priced when it comes to Korean food!  Where else can you get a full serving of Kalbi in SF for only 12.99?  Their other bbq meats, like bulgogi, pork, and chicken, are even cheaper.  Such a great deal, and the food is so good too!  
I also like that they are very generous with their free side dishes.  It's true that you only get 6 side dishes, which isn't much compared to some other Korean places...but they refill those side dishes as you finish them!  They actually refilled our sides twice during our meal, and they were super nice to boot.  I am definitely going to be coming here more whenever I want Korean food.
author: Tyler C.

description:
I'm going to let the cat out of the bag and say the chicken wings they serve here are on the same level as those served just down the street at San Tung (AND without the sometimes excruciating wait). Of course it all depends on what flavors you lean towards, but if you like a little more tang and zip, you'll probably prefer the Manna wings. Don't believe me? Try them yourself.

Another awesome thing about this place is that, compared to other Korean restaurants, this place is a little bit cheaper. I often find myself struggling to get out of dinner for under $20 for myself (entree + apps, not including drinks) at most Korean places, but this place makes it really easy.

I can recommend their BBQ as well (they make it about as good as any place in the city).

For Sunset's best Korean food option, check this place out.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
I agree with some Yelpers that Manna fills the Korean food void in Inner Sunset.  Even beyond our neighborhood, if you want authentic Korean food that's cheap, I actually can't think of any decent places.  There are good Korean restaurants in Richmond, but you often have to pay over $20 for a dish - granted, it does gets you an abundant number of banchan along with other freebies and the meat portion is generous, but sometimes you just want a simple bibimbap without launching into a full feast.  

Manna gives you exactly that.  For less than $10, you get a nice bowl of bibimbap with delicious veggies and a little bit of tasty beef.  Yes, I think I got 5 pieces of beef altogether, but I don't mind that, given the cheap price. 

The couple that runs the place is beyond nice and accomodating.
