We overhear them patiently explaining to a couple next to us that every dish on the menu comes with banchan and you can get refill on banchan up to 10 times!  We didn't stay long enough to find out how many refills they ended up getting, but I was definitely curious!
author: Candice B.

description:
okay food, okay price, TEENY TINY PORTIONS!

I saw my friends veggie dishes and they look so plentiful when i got man, it was just sad looking. I was like was this it? With the rice I was also like, is this the portions for a small child??? Scoop me a real amount of rice! 

The i ordered the Bul Kogi and there was not much flavor to it. It was nothing too special. It's not something worth the extra trip to Richmond/Sunset for. 

What I have to say was good were the sides. The fish pancake thing was yummy but I wish their dikon was more pickled with tanginess than saltiness.
author: Jess G.

description: Small town feel, in a big city. Small, packed, waited, but worth it! Traditional & yummy-we'll be back Soon (not a fan of looking for new places & being disappointed)
author: Ryan I.

description:
Super good affordable korean food with excellent customer service. It doesn't get any better than that.

Driving down Irving, I was craving either japanese or korean food. I was brought here by all the great yelp reviews. It's a small restaurant with nice decor. When we arrived, it wasn't that busy but as soon as dinner time came around, the crowd started coming in.

The sizzling bibimbap was soooo good and had a good amount of meat and veggies. The sweet and spicy chicken wings were BOMB, The sauce was so addicting, I kept licking my fingers. Me and my sister devoured it. She ordered the kalbi and it came with a huge amount of meat and was marinated to perfection. 

The ban chan was good and came with 6 different little dishes such as broccoli, fish cake, kim chi, bean sprouts, etc...

I'd definitely come back here if  I'm in the area. I wish you guys had another restaurant in the South San Francisco/Daly City area.
author: Fran N.

description:
Four stars alone for the dolsot bibimbap!  Sizzling with a raw egg and chilled red sauce on the side, the mixing of this well composed dish reveals just the right balance of spices, raw popping heat, crisp textured sprouts and vegetables, and layered infusions of flavorful oysters, shrimp and calimari.  

The complimentary tea is comforting and the six banchan dishes were politely refilled throughout the meal.

The service was friendly and the redesign of the restaurant into a bright sunny space well done.  

A great first impression for us here in the Inner Sunset.
author: Jim W.

description: This is my favorite Korean spot in the city. Seafood soft tofu stew full of seafood with shelled mollusks, shrimp, and squid. The broth is savory and comforting, a must try. The seafood pancake was not bad, but could be a little crispier for my liking. The kimchi is really what makes the meal because it's the best I've had in town. But all of the food was a hit. If you're craving Korean and can pass on the in-table grill experience definitely make Manna your pick!
author: Jacqueline O.

description:
One day I noticed that a new Korean restaurant opened up while I was driving to and from work.  There's not many Korean restaurants in the area, let along in the upper inner sunset area. There's always parking on my way home, so I've made it a habit to drop in once every 1-2 weeks both for sit-down and take-out.  

 The 5 stars is for service, affordable prices and taste.  All of the dinner dishes range from $7.99-$11.99.  (The prices for lunch are even a few dollars less. ) 

-(*)Spicy Chicken Stew $9.99
-(*)Fried Chicken $7.99
-(*)Bean Paste Soup $8.99
-Bul Go Ki $9.99
-Kal Bi $11.99
-Gal Bi Tang $11.99
-Soft Tofu Soup $8.99
-Sulang Tang $9.99

(*) = Favorites
author: Stacey L.

description:
My husband and I came by this place one night when we tried to go to San Tung and found they were closed (it was a Wednesday). So we wandered around Irving and came across this place. We love Korean so we figured we'd give a new place a try. 
The place is run by a cute couple who are so nice! 

We both got the bi bim bap and decided to try also try the chicken wings. The bi bim bap was such a deal, it's hard to find one less than $12, but Manna's was! The egg was perfect.

The chicken wings were really good. Nice and saucy, which I like and it had a nice kick to it. 

What I love most about this place is that they are very attentive. My water cup was always full and they were really generous about refilling our banchan. Every time the kimchi was empty, they came and asked if we wanted more. LOVE IT! 
 
Will definitely go back for my next Korean fix!
author: Lang T.

description: Dined here the week that they opened and am happy to say we finally have a good korean joint in the InSet.  My kimchi jaeyuk bokum was great,  and if you don't trust my judgement, know that my korean girlfriend loved everything as well.  The only complaint would be that it took a very long time to get the check, but we'll blame that on opening week complications.
author: Joshua W.

description:
This place is probably one of the best Korean places in SF for what you pay for.  Been here several times and it's always consistent.  Most dishes are $10 or less ($1 cheaper during lunches), which is hard to find these days for Korean restaurants.  And you get just as much food as places that charge $15/dish.  The place is a little small, probably fits about 25-30 people, and there is a line during peak hours as a result.  I recommend going off-peak hours as they're pretty wide open.

Recommend:
Seafood Tofu Soup - Very good and lots of ingredients
Seafood Pankcake - It's very tasty and has lots of toppings. Many other places charge in the mid-teens for this.
Bulgogi - It's like most other places, but cheaper
Bibimbap - Pretty good, but given that it's almost the same price as the meat entrees, would recommend those instead.  It's rare that the meat entrees are similarly priced to Bibimbap, but quality is still good and consistent. 

They also give you unlimited banchan and rice.  Kudos as many Korean restaurants charge extra for more rice.

5* for being consistent, great value, great food, and having super nice servers.  It's pretty rare to find all of those attributes in one places these days.
author: Jon K.

description: Not particularly great but definitely worth trying. I got their kimchi jiigey along with the bulgogi and both of them are pretty darn good. However, I didn't necessarily believe this is the best spot for Korean food . Could've been a bit more authentic. Side dishes were money
author: Eric F.

description:
Finally a Korean restaurant in the Inner Sunset. No need to get my Korean food helpings from Art's Cafe (which also serves American breakfast) and Hahn's Hibachi (which I can't quite consider it as "Korean" due to being seen at numerous parts of SF).

Lunch-price was appropriate depending on what you order. My sister and brother ordered Kalbi with rice. And for $10, I don't think 6 small pieces of Kalbi did much justification with the price. I, however, ordered the seafood dol sot bibimbop and some spicy chicken drumsticks and though it cost less than the Kalbi, it was much better and tasted so good. Definitely bigger portions for me. The tea that was served to us was made with corn and barley and I thought it was refreshing to drink.

Will be back to check out other items on their menu.
author: Kim L.

description: Nice employees and delicious spicy rice cake! I wish the place was bigger but you can only ask for so much. I will definitely be back.
author: Karen J.

description:
I've been here with my family twice now, two weeks in a row. This place is my new favorite Korean restaurant in the city. I like it a lot better than other Korean restaurants in the Sunset/Richmond district area.

The first time I came here was a couple days after new year's day for dinner around 7:30. The restaurant was packed with people (it's a pretty small restaurant) with only one group waiting before us. We waited about 20 minutes for a table and by then my siblings and I were pretty hungry. We ordered the kimchi fried rice, sweet and spicy chicken (quite like San Tung's), bul kogi, and soft tofu soup. I wasn't sure if it was delicious because we were all hungry, but I guess the second time we came here confirmed that it really is deliciously AMAZING. The second time we came here we arrived at 6pm on a weeknight and there were some open tables.  Come early if you don't want to wait!

The great thing about this place are the unlimited sides, tea and rice! The service was great and the workers and owner are really nice! The prices are very reasonable too.

P.S. Parking sucks, but hey, what do you expect? It's Irving St. AND your clothes are going to smell of Korean food afterwards.
author: Andrea F.

description:
I came here because there was an impossibly long line at Yummy Yummy. Bananas, right? 

The food is okay. It's good enough to go down but it's not memorable.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Minna is small but this is a delicious korean place. The tofu soup and the BBQ are great. You get a nice selection of appetizers. I wish they had a spicy chicken dish but nope, just regular chicken. 

For appetizers you get Kimchi, Bean Sprouts, Fish Cakes, Pickled Radish and Cucumbers. At least that's what I got during lunch on a weekend. 

That's all you really need to know about this place.
author: Rohan D.

description:
What a delightful addition Manna is to the Inner Sunset!  This place has been in business for a little over a month, and it's packed almost every day.  

Manna definitely isn't a BBQ/grill your own meat kind of Korean restaurant which are more prevalent in Richmond, but it has all the staples of Korean cuisine.  The flavor and spices are spot on, and they even bring you barley tea instead of the usual ice water.    

Although the owners are still working on eliminating few of the items, the menu is quite extensive, and the majority of the items are also available as lunch special.  

The place is a bit small, typical of most of the mom & pop type of restaurants in this neighborhood, but there are enough tables to accommodate a large party as well as the lunch crowd.    

Most importantly, I can't say enough good things about the service!  The owners take care of the customers like their own family, and banchans (small side dishes) are refilled promptly before it's asked, and the excellent service really does make up for the little kinks yet to be worked out.
author: S. I.

description:
I went in for lunch and tried their Kimchi Fried Rice.
It was good but their was not any meat in there.( Wish there was)
The Service was good and my tea was refilled which is good because I love hot tea.
author: Vincent T.

description:
Finally found my default Korean spot in the city.  So my housemate Colleen and I really love Korean food and we've been talking about finding a restaurant to eat at.  She came across an article about Manna and how the food was delicious.  

So we set out on a Sunday gluttony tour and Manna was our first spot.  We ordered mandu, spicy friend chickey, bimbop and kalbi.  We had a feast!  The service was awesome and fast, the food was fresh and hot off the stove, the side dishes were really good (kimchi was awesome) and they kept it coming.  

The location has a real mom and pops feel.  They even have beer (i.e. Hite, etc) there as well.  This place is definitely worth the try.  Catch the 43 if you live in Pac Heights area!
author: Shad B.

description: Ahh I loved it here! The tofu soup is to die for and you can't beat their lunch price! They're so good I'm craving for it 4 days later still! I don't usually do spicy but medium was just right for me!
author: Jannet H.

description:
It's hard being Korean in the Sunset.  Korean food is mediocre.   Tofu Village - OK, but not very clean, Hahn's Hibachi - blah, and what's with the "Hibachi?"  

Manna was a pleasant surprise.  I went there for lunch last week with a buddy and we both enjoyed it.   Enough so that we brought our wives this past weekend for dinner out.  

Forgive my phonetic translation, I'm better writing this in Korean.  The Yoo-Kay-Jang (spicy shredded beef soup) is good.  The Soon-dubu-chigae (tofu stew) was also tasty.  However, though both these dishes are inherently spicy, I found them lacking the sufficient "meh-wuh" factor.   I had to ask the waitress to make it "Korean spicy."  I can only speculate that they made them less spicy for the general populace.  However leaving out the gochu-jang in the initial cooking process denied these dishes the inherent complexity of these standby Korean comfort foods.

The Gampoongi (Korean wings) were good.  For the best version of this dish, one must travel to Chicago, IL.  Great Seas Restaurant (Lawrence & Kedzie) is the center of the Korean wing universe.  

Skip the Korean beer, OB - it's the PBR of Asia, and falls in the same category as Tsing Tao, San Miguel, and Kirin.  Have the Soju instead.

Service was pretty good for a Korean Restaurant.  For those unfamiliar with Korean "service," being doted on by waitstaff is annoying to most Koreans, counter to American culture, which is why traditional Korean waitstaff can be perceived as aloof or even rude.  That said, the Manna staff are kind and attentive.

As soon as we get a warm day in the Avenues, I"m headed straight to Manna for some Mool Neng Myun!
author: Ike K.

description:
Well.......

My bf's childhood friends were in town and we were kickin' it at Blackthorn like usual for sunday's best $3 mimimimimoooosas. We were starving and some bug told us we needed to try something new.... This place just happens to be across the street from Blackthorn and heard many good reviews about this place. We ordered take out n ate it at Blackthorn with our draaaanks

+++What are those barbque wings called!?!!??!?! THEY ARE AMAZING
+ I had some sort of fishhead stew? It started with a P and I dont remember that it was called... but it was alright... wish there were a little more vegetables ratio
- The rice wasn't that good...... surprising...
- some of their pickled vegetables tasted really weird and foreign....

Conclusion: Maybe I would try this place again..... my first impression wasn't that excellent... but its not that bad either
author: Julia D.

description:
keep it short. 5 reasons why i gave this place 5 stars:

1. its cheap
2. free rice and unlimited ban chan (the  small dishes korean restaurants always give before your food comes out)
3. food tastes good 
4. employees are super nice and attentive
5. its cheap

mok-je! (i think that means eat in korean..)
author: Linh P.

description:
Amazing place.  Such friendly staff, and wonderful atmosphere.  We loved the food!  We tried kimchi jaeyuk bokum which was my favorite and Bibimbap which was my wife's favorite.  We also really liked their chicken wings.  And of course, the appetizers are simply superb!  Especially the dried anchovies :)

Their tea is also phenomenal.  I wish I knew it's name!
author: Irina P.

description:
Last Sunday night I had a fabulous dinner at Manna. I love Korean food and am veggie and ordered Manna's Veggie Dol-Sot Bibimbap. It wasn't the very best one I've had but it was one of the better ones I've had in the Bay Area. Additionally, many Korean restaurants do not even list veggie options on their menus and I believe Manna has 2-3 and I'm willing to bet they would make more of their dishes veggie-friendly if asked. If I lived closer, I'd be here more often. 

The place is on the small side and quite cozy. The service is excellent. The wait, even for a table for six and prime dinner hour wasn't too bad (20 min, I think). 

On a side note, the meat eaters were very pleased with their ribs, wings, and every other animal body part that was offered on the menu.
author: Valerie L.

description: We had the bibimbap, Kimchee Jun and soondubu. Everything tasted awesome and fresh. Nothing like the mediocre Korean places that plague this town, this place is legit!!!
author: Terry K.

description:
Would give 4 stars on service, 3 on food.  Food was fine but nothing special.  Would come back if in the area and had a huge craving for Korean, but otherwise would not go out of my way to come.

Pros:
- attentive service: the waitress and owner (?) checked in multiple times, and offered to not charge us when my friend didn't finish his food and they thought he didn't like it (he just has a condition that forces him to only eat small portions at a time)
- very bright and clean space
- prices seem slightly cheaper (~$2-3) than other Korean restaurants in SF

Cons:
- can get crowded quickly, pretty small place

A-OK:
- banchan: 6, decent, but nothing like the huge spreads you get at Muguboka or other places in the Richmond
- vegetable bibimbap: nothing noteworthy whatsoever
- vegetable soft tofu: tasty enough, again nothing about the ingredients, flavour, or anything else really worth nothing
author: Marco C.

description: Three and a half if I could. The kimchee fried rice was good but also really oily and made me feel a bit sick after eating it. Service isn't anything really special. You do get a lot of food but I guess I wasn't totally blown away. If you're in the area and craving Korean, I'd come here but I wouldn't make a special trip to try it.
author: Alli Q.

description: Love love love Manna! Their service is awesome and the food is even better. I had the japchae and it was fantastic. I love their unlimited appetizers too! The workers are so friendly and attentive. I accidentally dropped my spoon (& didn't even realize one of the workers noticed) and gave me another one within 10-15 seconds. My boyfriend and I got lucky enough to skip the line but it is pretty packed so be prepared to wait. Small restaurant but amazing service & good overall.
author: Cindy C.

description: Solid and consistently good Korean food! Bibimbap is amazing and everything is very reasonably priced. I've dined in and done take out before and each time, it's been delicious. The staff is super friendly and the wait is never long.
author: Laura M.

description: This is a pretty small restaurant so expect a wait during busy meal hours. what really is a plus is their friendly service and refilable appetizers! this place is a cheaper alternative to my tofu house on geary
author: Sara Y.

description:
When I first heard that the Thai place closed down I was sad because I would go and order Thai food before/after I go to work if I was hungry. But since they opened up a Korean restaurant, HAPPY!!! 

When I first walked in, I had recognize the waitress because she used to work at another Korean restaurant that I go to very often and surprisingly she remember me and what I had order at the other place. Come to find out, its her friend's restaurant and she's helping them. 

The first thing that I had ordered from here was their seafood soft tofu soup to compare how they make it vs Tofu Village. Although they were very similar in presentation, smell, texture. The taste was slightly different. 

The second time that I had came here I had order their DolSot BiBimBap. Now I had order this dish before at two-three other Korean restaurants before hand but I would have to say I do enjoy this dish more then their seafood soft tofu soup. 

Over all, I'm so coming back here if I need a late lunch/early dinner when I'm at work.
author: Maile W.

description:
This place is so little, I'm glad we happened upon it! it was crowded, but if you're only with one other person, it's easier to be seated quickly.  The kimchi was quite tastey, but I had a hard time making my stone rice bowl spicy enough (odd for Korean, yeah?)

Luckily for me, the chopsticks they give you are Japanese disposables- Korean metal chopsticks are impossible for me to use (but yes, I'm pro at Japanese chopsticks)
author: Emma F.

description: I was stationed in Seoul for almost 2 years and fell in love with South Korea. Most of all I loved the food.  Manna took me back to Seoul with their delicious food.  The staff was extremely polite and had Korean hospitality. I had the kimchi chigae and it was perfect. I recommend this place and will be going back soon.
author: Sam G.

description:
The food is pretty good (hence 3 stars). On the other hand, the traditional servings of small appetizers are sparse, service is slow...at least for some customers.... Seem new to the business, though, so I did not subtract any points. 
Whoever said the decorations were great must have been looking at the server. It is simple and sparse; the money is going to the food!
Since there are still few Korean places in this heaven of cuisine, it is great they are here, and am sure they can improve on how they work with customers.
They have take out which may help avoid the service problem....
author: Chou K.

description:
Since my first visit, I've tried a bunch of their dishes and have loved every one of them. The dol-sot bibimbap was huge and well-seasoned, and the Korean seafood pancake was extremely fluffy, super tasty (even without the dipping sauce) and was large enough to feed two people. 

This place also has a large number of delicious ban-chan, which they will happily offer to refill for you, whereas other places look at you like you tracked in poo on your shoes when you want more ban-chan. 

Manna is also seriously on top of their game when it comes to customer service. They constantly refill your teacups, check in on you in a way that is not overbearing, and the food comes out quickly. All that for an incredibly good price! This place very quickly became one of my favorite Korean places in SF.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Excellent service, as many of the little plates of pickled things as you can eat, and good authentic Korean food.  Bi Bim Bop and yam noodles highly recommended.  And cheap!

Warning, though: not a good restaurant for vegetarians; you have like 2 options.  Fishatarians like me can do well though.
author: Josh B.

description:
Rice sticks, fish cakes, some cabbage, some chili sauce, and there you have it: dduk bok ki. I love the stuff, but apparently some of my higher-minded Korean friends say it's only a reserved for late-night or hangover dining. Like something I'd eat after getting off a shift at the local Hyundai plant. Screw it, I'll order it anyways. Manna serves dduk bok ki, so that's one reason to go. But there are quite a few others: 

- Their mandoo (dumpling) soup is really good, and the dumplings are particularly good. 
- The fried chicken wings are decent, although for my money, I still prefer the San Tung version around the corner. 
- They have dol sot bibimbap, which is not something you can find at every korean restaurant.
- The bulgogi was just ok. Not very flavorful, but they give you a lot
- The service is outstanding, they were extremely nice here. 
- The place is super clean

Good choice for Korean in the Sunset.
author: Saunders C.

description: There was not a single flaw of this place! From the friendly service, to the extremely low prices, to the outrageously great food. If I lived near this place I would be there weekly.
author: Betsy H.

description: Unsure why this place has such a high review. We had their kalbi during lunch and it was inedible. The meat was way too chewy. The tofu soup and side dishes were fine, but what really pissed  me off was the fact that the waitress visited our table more than 5 times and never did she offer to refill our side dishes. The very same waitress offered to refill the side dishes of the next table when they ordered the same number of items as us. There are better Korean restaurants out there.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
I had Bibimbab for late lunch and absolutely loved it. 
I was also very surprised with very reasonable prices for Korean food. 
I just wish they are nearby my home area.
I can't wait to try other dishes in near future.  :-)
author: Annie K.

description: Thanks guys!  Great service tonight, walked in 10 min to closing on Sunday and treated no differently.  Bubbling hot tofu seafood soup came out with no delay, after 6 plates of yummy fresh veggies.
author: Cherry F.

description: Love the authentic Korean food + great service! Good value as well, highly recommended.
author: Robecta M.

description:
The family affair that is Manna provides good Korean fare at a fair price.  We enjoyed a recent luncheon, starting with the five varieties of panchan, including the standard kim chi, bean sprouts and - to my delight - the tiny dried fish that are so good.  Eating a bit compulsively, we were served another round of panchan after only a couple of minutes - that is the Korean way to deal with diners that are just a bit gauche (I have to admit this here).

I really  liked the clear yam noodle dish with beef (Jabchae) and also enjoyed the seafood Bibimbab - although I like it a bit spicier than this version.

I ordered the Korean rice wine (an entire bottle) and found it refreshing and good.

Small mistakes by the friendly service are easy to overlook because of the kind and friendly attitude exuded by everyone in the restaurant.
author: Thor T.

description: I always order too much food when I come here because it's so good and the yummy smells always make me think I'm hungrier than I am. And what's the best part of ordering too much Korean food? Leftovers!
author: Angelina C.

description: The (weekday) lunch specials are great! The daeji bulkogi (spicy pork) is really tasty, as are the side dishes. Mine were broccoli, bean sprouts, fishcake, and kimchee, which I felt was a good variety. The overall portion was generous too. Can't speak to service since I just get takeout, but the food has been ready quickly and the person at the counter has been friendly. I assume dinner is pretty much the same, just a bit pricier and with more selection.
author: Rachel C.

description: Love this place!! The best kimchi ever! The kimchi fried rice is one of my favorites on the menu. The service is always prompt and courteous. I come to the Inner Sunset just for Manna!
author: Sarah F.

description: Have only been here once, but it was REALLY GOOD!!! Portions were great, flavors were diverse and the price was reasonable. The only downfall, seems to be that everyone else thinks so as well, so there's usually a wait to get in!
author: Desmond G.

description: Small place but great food. We had to wait outside to be seated which was unfortunately since it was a bit chilly that night but there's literally no room in the restaurant. Once we were seated though the servers were quick and friendly. The food is probably some of the better Korean food in SF but it is a bit of a trek to get to the Sunset. Overall an understandable wait followed by a delicious meal at a low price.
author: Jason C.

description:
4 stars? I don't think so! The locals in the area must have been really desperate for a good Korean joint in the neighborhood to give this place 4 stars.

Although the food is decent, and the prices are $1-2 lower for the average dish (probably because the portions are smaller and the bahn chan is minimal), Shin Toe Bul Yi and Toyose totally kicks this place's butt.  3 stars because its a notch better than Pine bbq.
author: Audacity L.

description:
Manna is definitely the new place to hit up in the inner sunset.  This korean restaurant has a variety of different typical korean items.

Since this was my first time there, I can only rate the dishes that we ordered, all which were pretty tasty:

1.   The ddukppoki was very soft and moist as was the fish cake, indicating it was cooked properly.  It was a lot better than Toyose's version of the dish.

2.   The bibimbap in the clay pot was nice as well.  I've never actually had bibimbap in a clay pot, I usually have it cold with the veggies and whatnot, so it was a nice experience.  I wish the go ju jang sauce was a little bit spicier to add a little more kick to the bibimbap, but I think overall, the dish was pretty good.

3.   The spicy bbq pork dish was not bad, though I think I have had better in terms of flavoring, but it was tender and cooked properly, so I can't complain.

4.   The side dishes were pretty typical for a korean restaurant.  The only side dish I didn't particularly like were the salted anchovies because they were really hard when eating them compared to ones I have had before.

5.   They serve tea with rice grains boiled in it which is a familiar taste when I've been to many Korean restaurants in Southern California which has a nice, refreshing taste for my palate.

Thank goodness this restaurant replaced Little Bangkok because that place sucked (had the worst service and terrible food).  Manna had really good service and they kept refilling our tea and was attentive to our needs for the table which was excellent.  Overall, I think Manna is a great new restaurant as far as the dishes I have tried and I hope it lives up to my review in the future.
author: Lawrence E.

description: This is a small restaurant with about 10 small tables. We ordered seafood pancake, beef bbq, and Kim chi fried rice. They will give you different accompaniments, which were good. Pancake was well fried, and the rice was spicy enough. I love the beef. It was delicious. The waitress surprised me by taking order in Korean!
author: Angie N.

description: Every time I pass here, its always smells incredible and its always full of customers. I really like how inviting and warm it feels. The food isn't as good as I want it to be, but they do have some delicious items. I highly recommend the Kimchi Pancake, the Sweet and Spicy Chicken Wings and the Soft Tofu Soup. Those are the items I think Manna does best and are unique to them. As for the other items I love getting at Korean places like Bibimbop, BBQ chicken or spareribs, its not the best I've had, but still good. Overall nice staff too, very accommodating and kind.
author: Dexter H.

description:
Never really noticed this Korean restaurant located on the corner of Irving & 10th but came with a friend for dinner.

Small place but the large wall windows make it seem more airy.  Service was quite attentive and friendly.

Around 40 or so choices on the menu.  The dolsot bibimbap was pretty good, although the gochujang (red pepper paste) was more sweet than spicy.  On the other hand, the yugaejang soup came out a fiery red and was clearly pretty spicy (as evidenced by the beads of sweat forming on my friend's forehead).

I was disappointed with the kambongi (fried chicken), which was a little bland and somewhat fatty.

But what makes this place a hit is what others have already reported - large portions at very cheap prices (for Korean food).  $10 for entrees is pretty good.

It's a good place for a casual dinner ... but given how tight it is, it's probably better for a party of 2.
author: F. P.

description:
Manna is a tiny Korean restaurant located in a really busy area of town. Inner sunset is one of the most difficult places to find parking. What's worse is this place is small (around 20-30 people max) and it gets packed really quickly. This place isn't a cook it yourself type of place so they'll cook the food for you and bring it out. This isn't the place to go for people who like a little charcoal/burnt taste to their meat.

Bulgogi beef was really soft and tender. The marinade wasn't that good since it tasted like watery beef. Kalibi beef was chewy and had quite a bit of fat, but it was well marinated. The Korean wings were not what I expected... it tasted a bit more like orange chicken wings. The Korean fried rice tasted great and was well done in my opinion. There were some typical korean side dishes, but not as many as what some other places give. There was also a weird plain broccoli side dish given... I haven't seen that before.

Overall, I wouldn't say this place is worth a 15+ minute wait, but it's a pretty average place for KBBQ.
author: Steven B.

description: I went with friends to Manna because I heard it was good. We didn't reserve a table, so when we got there we waited for around an hour before they seated us. The place was pretty small so it couldn't seat a lot of people at a time. Despite the long wait, the food was extremely delicious, especially their seafood pancakes! It took a while before they served all of our orders, but hey, the banchans were delicious and they allowed free refills (we totally gobbled all the fishcakes, haha). The food was definitely worth the wait, and we were all extremely full after devouring all the banchans and food!
author: Annie H.

description:
I think a  lot of the great reviews come from the fact that SF is so lacking in anything resembling real Korean food. 

I came here and tried the soondubu. It was okay, good enough that I'd come back when I really need a fix. But it's not great. 

It has MSG in it. Korean food never has MSG, what's with that? Totally makes the flavor off. Also the broth was pretty bland.

The banchan were okay. Kimchi was too salty and a little underfermented, but that's a forgivable sin in a restaurant where you can't keep enough of the stuff in stock. The dried anchovies were too old. The rest was decent.

Actually, the soondubu they had for a while over at Pacific Catch was more authentic and tasted better. That tells you about the level at Manna.
author: Aaron G.

description:
Me and my husband love this place. We practically go there every week for dinner. It's non pretentious and the food is delicious! So far our favourite is the  Dol Sot Bim Bim Bap, their Spicy Soups, Stir fried Chicken with Spicy Sauce and their Sweet & Spicy Chicken Wings.   
It's a small place, I'd go there alone or with just one more person. Enjoy!
author: Tahirah R.

description: Good bargain for lunch. Most lunch entrees are $10 or under. We arrived before the lunch rush and got easily seated for 5 but within 30 mins there were people waiting outside. The bi bim bap is good and we also ordered and liked the soy sauce fried chicken, bul kogi and the gyoza.
author: Bud F.

description:
I've been wanting to try out this restaurant ever since I noticed it walking by a few months back. Finally cane for lunch on the off day after New Years. It is fairly small and they get quite many people coming in, but I was able to get a table without waiting.

I ordered the dol sat bibimbob (a rice item with mixed vegetable with beef and a fried egg in a sizzling stone bowl). It was definitely yummy, especially the rice that sticks to the side which then becomes very crunchy. It's been a long time since I ordered that so it's like a rediscovery. The order same with six small side dishes. That's a higher number than what I was anticipating for a place this size, though each plate was pretty small.

There are other items I see on the menu that I'd like to come back for. Especially the chicken wings, which many comment positively on (included reviews that compare it to nearby San Tung Restaurant which always has long wait), but I haven't tried it.
author: H K.

description: This place is one of my favorite spots in town! Best kal bi ever! I also enjoy their bibimbap, the bbq chicken dish, and the soy sauce wings(p.s. All of their dishes come with a side of rice, which is awesome). NOM NOM NOM!! We usually order take out because they get so busy and the space isn't that big, but during the week in the day would probably be the best time to go if you want to sit down. Otherwise, be prepared to wait at least twenty minutes to get a seat because this place is poppin!
author: dylan t.

description:
I love this place!  We try to stop in at least once a month (to stay in budget and support local!).  We always get the kimchee fried rice, chicken wings, bulgogi, bibi mi bop (sp?), and sometimes other things.  The one thing that disappointed us was the ramen.  I expected greatness (like everything else they served).  Instead, it was packaged ramen with spicy soup.  :-/  That said, we avoid that and order the stuff we know is good.  The place is small, and later in the day there is quite a wait.  We, luckily, live nearby, and walk over to beat the rush.  They are very attentive and constantly refill the tea cups, rice, and even the little side dishes!  

A friend of mine moved to SF and had never had Korean food before.  We brought him here, and he's now a fan.  San Tung is down the street and good and all, but for less the wait, you can get some banging Korean food!
author: ROB L.

description:
Seriously, I have yet to find a place with good korean food and reasonable prices in San Francisco. One of the few things I miss about LA is their all you can eat $10 korean bbq.  I don't think SF has that anywhere (and if I'm wrong, please tell me where I can find such a yummy deal). But my friend wanted to try this place so I  gave it a try. 

Their bibimbap was pretty good but it's the meat that determines if it's really good. My friend got the bulgogi and said it was kinda dry. No bueno. 

Service was not so great. The guy was nice but the woman was so rude! She put down a bottle of hot sauce with my bibimbap but before I even got a chance to use it, she grabbed it away from my table and handed to the next table without even asking if I'm done with it!! Rude!
author: Linda L.

description: I have yet to find a good Korean restaurant in SF.  I went for lunch and ordered the kimchee chigae which is not on their lunch special menu.   The banchan (side dishes) were decent but the kimchee chigae was just ok - it was not that spicy, lacked the tangy punch and didn't have some of the ingredients that I would normally get in other restaurants.  The prices though are very reasonable.  The waitress was nice but not the most efficient lady. There would be times when she would just arrange the order sheets and then stair off into space.  It's probably not the best place to go to eat out for lunch if you're in a hurry.
author: Kai C.

description:
Bibimbap, Chapchae, Kalbi were good
Panchan was OK
author: Scott F.

description: Food are delicious, one of my favorite Korean food place! And services are good and fast, no matter inside the restaurant or to go order. Love their flexible working pattern, make customer happy.
author: adrienne t.

description:
Friends wanted to grab dinner before they left the city, and they decided to settle with some Korean food among the choices I gave them. Turning to trusty yelp on a Saturday night, we decided to hit up Manna. The wait was about 30 minutes and we left our number to be called and decided to peruse inner sunset.

They have 6 different dishes for their Banchan (Kimchi, bean sprouts, dried fish, bean curd, broccoli, and shredded daikon/carrots) and corn tea, which help subdue our hunger and warmed us up on a cold San Francisco night. 

My friends ordered the Bibimbap and were satisfied with their food adding some gochujang (red sweet chili sauce). 

I ordered the Kimchi Jaeyuk Bokum (Sautéed Pork & Kimchi with Spicy Sauce) and loved it. Tofu and pork mixed in with some Kimchi was delicious. Adding rice with gochujang is my go to strategy of being full and happy. 

Customer service was amazing and prompt with refilling any Banchan, tea, rice or napkins. Food came quickly upon ordering. 

Parking may be difficult, so expect to walk some distance 

Decent food paired with excellent customer service warrants Manna 4 stars.
author: Casey L.

description: started out okay, because there was only one waitress who made sure of what we wanted. the other waitress and some old dude were pretty derpy. when our soft tofu soup with beef came, it came with one miniscule bowl of rice. did i mention it was a table for 2? i was astonished by their intelligence to only give one small ass bowl of rice to a table of two people. i didnt know a bowl of rice meant a lot of profit. when i asked for a second bowl of rice, you'd think they'd give me another bowl of rice. i didnt think my meal would get any worse... they gave me two empty bowls..... the food is pretty good, but bad customer service goes a long way for a good meal. be very assertive if you want to get what you need. i didnt want to continuously ask due to it being very busy, but it's up to the customer if they want to go or if their way. happy dining!
author: Jason C.

description: Solid Korean food in a cute neighborhood and pleasant clean location. I had the tofu soup with beef extra spicy and it was legit. The bibimbap is also good. We had an issue with our food but the manager took care of it right away. Great service.
author: Natasha F.

description: Best Korean food in the city so far.  This place beat the most of restaurant in K-town in LA even.
author: Miho Y.

description: Friendly! So much so patrons share their cucumber shoju with you while you wait. Which you will, the space is small but clean and well lit. We went on a thurs nite at 9pm and waited 10 short minutes, long enough to throw back a drink and decide what to order. Do: kimchee pancake, hot wings, bibimbap and kalbe. Banchan are prepared 2x each day, fresh and flavorful. Of all the korean i've tried in san francisco, this is my bestest choice.
author: Kelly K.

description: The tofu soup will grow hair on your chest but it's so good. The short ribs were alight...nothing out of the ordinary. They have a good amount of side dishes. Good place for affordable and good Korean food.
author: Eve C.

description: I was told to wait for 30-40 minutes but end up wasting almost two hours where many people after us got a  table already. We only have 3 people. What the hell! You need to have better time estimation and queue management.
author: Jason C.

description:
This (super long) review is for the poor customer service we received by the manager and staff on July 6, 2013. If you want the best experience of this place, I highly suggest not going when the male manager is there, especially when you're with a group of 5+ people. 

i am highly disappointed in you, Manna. I ate here before with my friends and i felt its food is quite delicious for a Korean restaurant in SF. My grandma was craving Korean food so I suggested Manna. I knew beforehand that the restaurant is small. Roughly 8-10 small tables that fit about 2-4 people each. 

We, a group of 7 decided to head over there around 5:00pm before the dinner rush. My aunt arrived earlier by herself separately and tried to get us a table or at least on the wait list. (They DO NOT take reservations.) My aunt told the manager that we have a group of 7 and the other 6 will be here 10-15 minutes. My aunt's car was parked right in front of the restaurant and decided to sit in her car to wait for us since it was cold. My aunt suggested the tables next to the main window. The manager agreed. 

During those 10-15 mins, apparently there was an unofficial rule of "first come first serve, as long as your entire party is here". There are three tables by the main window parallel to the front door, enough to fit our group if pushed together. The smallest of the three tables was empty. The second one was empty. At the third table the customers were almost finished with their meal. Apparently two more groups of people came during those 10-15 minutes and the manager seated them at those empty tables. At the bigger empty table, they ordered immediately and received their food. The smaller table's customers didn't even settle down yet. 

Within 15 minutes exactly at around 5:15pm, I and the rest of the family arrived, I wasn't aware of this problem and only assumed our table will be ready. Unfortunately that is a foolish thought. My aunt told me she witnessed the manager give away those tables that would've been ours. I went inside the restaurant with my aunt, hoping we'd have our tables but those customers were eating away. I recognized the manager from the previous time with my friends. He wasn't the friendliest guy but he didn't serve us at our table last time so I disregarded him when i was with my friends. But this time, I saw the manager's character. I noticed some tension between my aunt and the manager. My aunt reiterated many times that the other 6 will be here in 10-15 minutes but the manager said he had to sit the other customers who came later than my aunt first because they had everyone there. My aunt complained that the manager didn't even bother trying to tell her about this. But the manager backfired saying he walked around and outside a bunch of times but never saw my aunt. This kept going back and forth between the two. 

We were willing to wait for the two bigger tables to finish but my aunt and i noticed this. There was an empty table for two that the smallest table customers could move to on the right side of the restaurant since they haven't even started yet. We asked the manager if they could move so we can have that table but he refused to do so. Instead he suggested if we all can sit separately since there were other tables finishing up. Why? Why do we need to when he promised the window tables and failed to do so and then blaming it on us not being there? More of this bantering that would've been avoided if the manager was better at organizing table space but he refused to give in. I looked at the staff in the back. I could tell they were looking at us with a slight hope to help us but they never tried. 

It was 5:30pm when we all decided to walk away. There was no winning over this manager who clearly lacked customer service training. We eventually walked over to Marnee Thai on 9th & Irving who, despite being almost the same size restaurant, were more accommodating and welcoming to a group of 7.
author: Vickie C.

description: I was in the mood for Korean food and drove 20 minutes to get here. It's was totally worth the drive. This is a tiny place with about 10 small tables for 2 people. There was 4 in our party and luckily at 8pm just a few min wait. The food was delicious. We ordered 4 entrees to share and 1 appetizer with rice wine. Kimchee pancake was so flavorful. The service was wonderful and the server explained every item we inquired about.
author: kelly y.

description:
!!! 100 Review !!!

Gosh I have been waking up with a craving for Korean for like a month straight now ... its becoming a problem now ... fortunately its a delicious    addiction ...  

Manna has been bookmarked for some time now and it was finally time to try it out...  Very small dining area which seems to be all family owned.. my party of three arrived at about 8:45 on Saturday night and were seated immediately with hot tea waiting ...  

Ordered some ... Bulgogi ( different then what i am use to but delicious non the  less ) Pork Tofu and Kimchi ( lots of different flavors .. kinda new to me .. i enjoyed it ) Fried Sweet and Sour Wings ( Nom Nom Nom ) And some Hot Boiling Tofu Soup ( perfect for chilly night )

Side dishes are always a plus as well .... Bean Sprouts ... Daikon ... Fish Cakes ... Kimchi .... and my favorite the anchovies .. all complemented perfectly with fluffy white rice ... ( they also refilled are sides and tea within seconds of the plate being empty )

Now being a white boy who grew up in Jersey Korean food is a rare rare thing ... so everything amazing ... loads of flavors and textures I enjoyed the whole meal... 

Total for 3 of us ( each stuffed to the brink ) came out to about $44 ... 

Good food, friendly service, and nicely priced .. I can see myself coming back :)
author: Anthony S.

description:
Split a bunch of dishes with friends, including the Kanpoongki (sweet & spicy wings) that are a must! Can't remember exactly which Bibimbop we got but I'm sure they're all delicious. Warming & comforting soft tofu soup. Definitely everything that was ordered was amazing. Very affordable with large portions & a good selection of side dishes.

Way out in the Inner Sunset though (and street parking was a hassle even later in the night)
author: Anna R.

description: Very clean inside but not  too much space, about 24 chairs. Place gets busy, service is good however food takes awhile to get to your table. Servings are from small to medium. Nice mom & pop restaurant.
author: Cee B.

description: Korean food - not for vegetarians as it's a bit like the meat and potatoes of asian cooking, but nothing can be more satisfying on a cold, foggy, inner sunset day. Manna is an excellent example of good Korean food. I recommend the bulgogi, chapchae, and spicy seafood and tofu or spicy tofu soup. It's a lot of delicious food for cheap. And the servers are nice and attentive!
author: Teresa T.

description: I probably ordered the wrong dishes, but both tasted the same despite having vastly different listings on the menu.  Did dig the kimchi that came with the meal, however.  Would not say no to a return visit, but wouldn't go out of my way to make that happen.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I've been wanting to check out this place ever since it opened up a few months ago and I noticed their menu prices seemed to be lower than the average korean joint. Time to see if the quality matched up!

It's a pretty small restaurant and they don't take reservations, so try to go during non-peak hours. We arrived about 15 minutes before they closed and they very graciously ushered us in! Their menu offers a nice variety of dishes, with some I've never really seen before in other restaurants, so I'll be sure to try them next time. 

We ordered the basics: 
bulgogi ($10.99) - Cheap, but they didn't skimp on the amount! Or the quality, as it tasted pretty good - juicy and tender, with nice cuts of meat! (not just fat) Came on a sizzling platter atop some nicely cooked onions. Pretty great for the price!

dwinjang chige ($8.99) - bean paste soup with veggies and tofu. I was in a bland sort of mood and so I thought this would really hit the spot. Unfortunately I didn't know that jalapenos are added and I'm really bad at eating spicy so this kinda ruined it for me. The soup itself came with a great bunch of veggies and also some beef thrown in there (happy surprise!) but I just couldn't enjoy it too much with my mouth on fire. 

Each of our orders came with a bowl of rice and we also had a good spread of banchan: anchovies, kimchi, fish cake (!!), pickled daikon, and bean sprouts. They come unlimited and if you ask, the waitress will come by and bring you new dishes of them! The portion sizes of the entrees were pretty hefty and we had enough leftover for a lunch, but we're also small eaters. Service was friendly and attentive and we had our side dishes and tea re-filled frequently. Parking can be found a few blocks away... I'll be back!
author: Janey L.

description:
Went here with the friend to try it out for lunch.  This location was the old Bangkok Thai restaurant that didn't get much patronage.  I hope this place gets much more traffic than it's former tenants.

This place is small, but the service was very friendly.  They don't give you as much little plates of pickled accroutrements as some other places, but that's okay.  

We had the dol sat bibimbap.  It was delicious and warming for a cold SF day.

Will have to go back and try their other specialties.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: Hands down best seafood tofu soup! Tofu has creamy, super soft texture unlike other places. I recommend seafood tofu soup and kanpoongi!
author: Michelle K.

description: I love Manna! Most Korean food around here is very expensive, but at Manna the prices are right on point. For a group of 3, we has the dol sot bibimbap, soft tofu soup and a plate of japchae all for about 30 buck with tip. The food here was seasoned well, tasted authentic and over all just really yummy! The service is great, they give you free refills on sides, rice and tea. I just wish the restaurant was a little bigger! If you come during lunch or dinner time, don't be surprised if you are asked to wait outside for 15-20 mins!
author: Mina K.

description: Amazeballs. Had the Kimchi chige (spicy pork/kimchi soup). Service was prompt and friendly. Side dishes were fantastic, and they offered to refill them. My soup came with steamed rice, and I hope I didn't commit a Korean dining sin by putting the rice in my soup because the broth was so delicious.
author: Jennifer I.

description: Our favorite restaurant in the hood!  And with all the options in the Inner Sunset that's saying something! Every dish on the menu is stellar.  Our top favorites are the Jabchae, Spicy Pork and Kimchi Pancake.  The prices are super reasonable and the portions are large.  With the starting dishes they serve you don't need appetizers.  The owner and his staff are great and take pride in their business. There's usually a wait for dinner so put your name on the list and grab a drink at the Blackthorn across the street while you wait.
author: Casey B.

description: You must try the sweet and sour chicken wings. They are bomb diggity. I love that this place gives yummy complementary appetizers. Also, the tea has a unique hint of coffee to it. Come during happy hour and sad a dollar. The menu has a bajillion dishes on it and I can't wait to try other dishes.
author: Vivian L.

description: Amazing! Ordered the soft tofu, bibimbap, and spicy chicken. Absolutely incredible for a solid price, would definitely return. The sides were also pretty good quality, and it was all at a cheap price.
author: Clara H.

description:
I came here based on all the raves on Yelp.  I like the casual dinner Korean concept similar to the one I've experienced in numerous of places in LA so I gave it a try.  

I have to disagree with the majority of the other reviewers.  The portion is moderate.. not huge.  The price is looks attractive but I think that is because the portion are smaller.  In terms of the big test, the taste:  I was disappointed.  We ordered the Kal Bi, Bulgogi, Beef Bibimbap, and the chicken wings.  

The Kai Bi is much much smaller that I anticipated.  The price is attractive, $14 but its portion is small compare to if I go to a traditional Korean  BBQ.  The taste: Its cooked in the kitchen but it didn't have much distinctive BBQ flavor.  A bit bland if you ask me but my daughter who is 8, chowed down on it.  I think the traditional BBQ have the edge on this even though its pricier but its definitely have better value.  

The Bulgogi.. the biggest disappointment of all.  For the most part it was over cooked, and you know its over cooked when the slices of beef are seared crisped.  Since it was overcooked, it lacked the juice and favor.  Dumb downs on this. 

As for the Bibimbap, I ordered the stone kind so I get for the good stuff where the expectation is the rice is crispy and adds more flavor.  Its a mehh... For the most part, the rice in the bibimbap tastes like the pain ole rice.  

The only thing that got me going was the chicken wings.  The chicken wings was lightly battered so its not so heavy.  I admit, I was expecting the wings to be drenched in heave flavorful sauce but it wasn't.  It was nicely dressed and flavorful without all the sugar coating sauce.  If you come to this place, the wings is a must try.  

Considered that I came early and still waited for half an hour, this place is definitely not worth the wait.  I just have better.
author: Rama L.

description: Walked in spontaneously with my parents. We were kind of having a heated discussion when we first sat down so we didn't decide our orders right away and the woman working that night responded like we were doing her the greatest injustice by not being ready the first two times she stopped by. Once we finally settled that, the tea and sides came out quickly and the service was normal. I'd really recommend the Seafood Rice/Vegetables Stone Pot dish, it has a little bit of everything and was delicious. The Seafood Tofu Soup is on the salty side but enjoyable if paired with rice. The Thick Noodles w/ Homemade Spicy Sauce is served cold and none of us really enjoyed it. We took most of it home as leftovers and my sister said she liked it after heating it up.
author: Tina W.

description: Had a really tasty seafood tofu soup here today. It really hit the spot and I felt they nailed the spice level perfectly. Their ban chan was just ok, some were good and others were under seasoned. We also ordered the sweet and spicy chicken wings and those were nice and crispy with a great sauce that was definitely more sweet than spicy. Our waitress was super friendly and attentive. Would definitely come back again!
author: Lisa W.

description: I am Korean, and I have been to many excellent Korean restaurants, including the ones in Korea. Food from Manna is pretty up there in terms of the quality and taste. Service at Manna is unmatched by any restaurants. They are kind, generous, and genuine. Manna is definitely one of the top restaurants I will go regularly or take my friends to without any reservation.
author: Jane M.

description:
This is a very small place between 10th and 9th ave that probably seats no more than 25 people. They have decent lunch specials from 11-3pm that range ~$7. The menu is pretty standard  with portions being average. 

We ordered 5 dishes: the seafood pancake, the seafood tofu soup, the kimchi spicy pork, the beef short ribs, and the fried chicken. The fried chicken was quite bland and I recommend getting the sweet and spicy if you are craving some fried foods. The seafood pancake was average at best. A little bit soggy with not that much seafood. The beef short ribs were ok. Not over cooked and the dish was about 8 ribs total. The best dish was probably the kimchi spicy pork. The dish is good hot but when it started cooling down my good friend noticed that it tasted like ketchup which I also agree. There was also not that much pork (maybe 8 pieces total). The total came out to be $60 after tax and tip. 

Service was decent although I feel this place is understaffed  especially at max capacity. The food came out about 15 mins after we ordered and I feel this place can get busy at night since there isnt that much seating. 

Overall, a decent value for korean food especially for the lunch special. I think this place compares to Shin Toe Bul Yi on taraval. However, Ive definetly tasted better korean food but if I was in the neighborhood, I would give this place another shot.
author: Robert Y.

description: Generous with the banchan and the barley tea. Small and busy in the evenings, but worth a little waiting. Plenty of choices, including vegetarian options, all at a reasonable price. For soft tofu soup, I'd give the edge to My Tofu House in the Richmond, but this place is definitely worth a visit.
author: Jacob M.

description:
A busy city life, sometimes fast good food is all a city girl wants. 
I was craving Korean food and happened to be in the Sunset w a friend. 
I stepped into a restaurant on the corner of Irving. Busy and no tables were available so we decided to take the food to go. We were about to go somewhere else and eat but then we asked the cashier how long the wait would be and it was only 10 minutes! Not 15 not 25, but only 10 minutes. In city time, that is absolutely amazing. 
The servers, cashiers, and staff did not look rushed. The all looked so happy and calm. We went for a stroll and as promised 10 minutes later got our dinner. 
The Kalbi was juicy, just the way Korean BBQ should be. The side dishes were plentiful, and fresh. Healthy. The Bibimbob was good too but we were a little disappointed that it didn't have more meat or even equal enough meat as the vegetables. Still great food. Will definitely come back for the Kalbi again.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
I'll start by saying I am a white dude with no background in Korean food. Girlfriend and I have been meaning to check this place out for the past few weeks though, so we made our first visit last night.

Food and service were both pretty good. I got the sweet and spicy chicken wings, an order of dumplings, and she got the shrimp fried rice. 

The chicken wings were very good, but the dumplings were sorta meh. Would probably go back if I was feeling a little more experimental next time.
author: Brendan L.

description:
Yesterday my husband and I were visiting a friend in San Francisco. We decided to go to this restaurant near my friend's house for lunch after hiking from Lands End because we saw many people waiting outside and we thought it must be a very nice place to eat.  We also love Korean food.  But this proved to be a completely wrong decision.  I had the worst restaurant experience ever in my life.

The owner was extremely rude to us.  He ignored my request for hot water (I do not drink cold water because it causes pain to my belly), he was extremely rude and arrogant to us, he removed my husband's dish, and the most terrible thing is, he threw us out before we even began to eat.  And when I recalled, I realized that he intentionally skipped us when calling guests from the waiting list.  I cannot think of any reasons of his behavior.  The only reason I can come up with is he has some issues with us Chinese guests 

Let me tell the whole story so that you can judge if my suspicion is reasonable.

When we passed this restaurant, we saw many people waiting outside so we decided to give it a try.  My friend went inside, put her name on the waiting list, and asked the owner how long we had to wait.  The owner said about 20-30 minutes.  Because there was still a long time, we went to a bakery across the street and bought some cookies.  I was checking time frequently to make sure we did not get back late.  

When we came back 15 minutes later, my friend went to check with the owner but saw that her name was crossed out from the list -- we obviously missed when it's our turn.  So she put her name on the waiting list again.  This time we decided to wait right outside because we did not want to miss again.  My friend told us that thonly two groups of people were before us, one 2 people and the other 3 people. 

We waited for one whole hour outside, thirsty and hungry.  Then a waitress came out to call the names.  I went closely to listen just in case she called us.  She called the first name but the group were gone.  She called the other name and 3 people went inside.  I checked the name list and knew that we were next.  The waitress went inside.  After some time, the owner, a middle-aged Korean man, came out to call guests. He called "Hana" instead of my friend.  A group of 3 entered. I was surprised we were not called.  Then he called another name, not my friend again.  I went to him and asked to see the name list.  I saw that two names below my friend's were crossed out.  I was confused.  But before I could ask, he went inside rashly.  I told my friend. She went inside to check.  The owner said he called my friend's name already.  After the whole thing, I re-thought all the details and realized that he was LYING.  Two reasons: 1. Why didn't he cross my friend's name if he had called us? He did so the first time, and I saw the waitress crossed out names when no one answered.  2. I paid very close attention whenever they came out and was very certain they didn't call us.

But at the time, we did not think too much and went inside.  Because of my thirsty, I finished my tea and my husband's.  Then the first meal was served to my husband.  I was so thristy so I turned around to see who's available. The owner was bring a tea pot around.  After he came back to the counter where is close to our table, I requested, "Sir, could you please give me some hot water?" 

It seemed he did not hear me, so I repeated for at least three times.  He finally came, but with a cold water pot.  

I said, "I am sorry but I cannot drink cold water. Could you please give me some hot water?"

He did not look at me. Instead, he was looking up all the time. And he filled my glass like he did not hear what I was saying at all. I repeated my words several times.  But he did not look at me or respond at all.
 
So my husband asked, "Sir, did you hear my wife's words? She cannot drink cold water."

The owner suddenly became terribly angry and yelled at my husband, "Why are you mad at me? Why are you mad at me?"

We were extremely confused and did not know what to respond for this sudden and unexpected accusation.  Then what is even more bizard, the owner TOOK my husband's dish and PUT IT AWAY.  Then he asked my husband to go outside with him.  Both my friend and I were worried the owner might beat my husband so we followed. 

We followed the owner to the corner of the street. Then he said, "I REFUSE TO SERVE YOU."

My husband asked, "Why?"

He simply said, "Why are you mad at me?" and repeated, "I refuse to serve you."

Yelp does not allow me to write more than 5000 words. But anyway, we felt very humiliated and left.  I could not think of any reason why the owner performed so rudely and aggressively to us. I think the only reason is that he recognized we are Chinese from my friend's name, which arose his inexplicable aggression towards us from the beginning. I feel sad if he really is a racist.  I have a lot of Korean friends and respect Korean people.
author: Yueran Y.

description: This place is one of my favorite places on earth, best Korean food I've ever had. The service is great, really nice people and very accomodating. Fun for a date night or to go with friends. Food is cheap and always leave stuff because their side dishes are my absolute favorite!!
author: V L.

description: Love this place. Have been going since they opened their doors. But they've raised their prices quite a but since then. We don't go as regularly anymore because of that.
author: I Like Food, Food Taste Good ..

description: Really fresh ingredients, friendly service, with two clear stars from our meal: sweet and spicy chicken wings and kimchi pancake. The chicken wings aren't as good as San Tung but they were still tasty in their own right. The sauce could've been spicier, but overall it was good. The kimchi pancake had lots of kimchi in it and hit the spot. We also got the dol sot bibim bap and really enjoyed the crispy crust of slightly charred rice at the bottom. Love the texture and taste of it.
author: James C.

description: Manna never fails to disappoint me! Went here again with my cousin since she had never tried Korean food before and she loved it. We had the Kimchi pancake, Seafood Tofu soup, and the Dukbokki. Delicious! Best Tofu soup I've ever had. The Kimchi pancake was mediocre, but the Dukbokki was delicious as always. Came back the following weekend with my picky friend and he loved it as well! The Chicken Wings were crunchy and sweet. It's become my favorite Korean restaurant.
author: Annie L.

description: This is hardcore, mama-cooked-this-last-night Korean cooking. This is what you would eat if you were Korean American, lived in Los Angeles, and had a mother who worked in a dry cleaners then slaved over a stove for your privileged little backpacking wearing self every day. Atmosphere is a little chintzy and crowded, but not unbearable. I can't remember if we had a paper napkins but we might have. The food is ultra cheap so it's worth being a little flexible. This place is the real deal. The other very positive aspect is how nice the owners are. They aim to please.
author: p v.

description: I love, love, love this place.  The food is consistently good, they have interesting dishes (that are also consistently good), and the people who run it are tops.  I have not a single negative thing to say about this place.
author: Danielle G.

description: Excellent restaurant - definitely worth calling ahead to reserve a table.  Their marinated pork is addicting.
author: Mike L.

description:
bah, knocking one star off for their soft tofu soup!

soft tofu soup is my favorite korean food of all time. Manna doesn't have a lot of varieties of the soup, and their soup was a little watery and not that great. I was a little disappointed :( I need my soft tofu soup fix! How else am I supposed to get over a hangover?!
author: Jade R.

description: Korean food is not my favorite food but Manna is without a doubt my favorite Korean restaurant.  It has become a regular go to place in my neighborhood.  The dishes are very tasty.  Service is always good and friendly and prices are right.
author: Mr And Mrs Helene And Tyrone D.

description: Great food, especially the cow tongue.  Looking forward to the ice cream!
author: Dave B.

description:
Walked by about a month ago and wondered what the line was for. Saw a small, quaint Korean place and knew it had to be good if groups of people were willing to wait. Yelp reviews confirmed it (have I ever mentioned that I spend way too much time looking up restaurants on this site? haha)! Brought my parents here a couple weeks ago and came again with a friend last week. This review will focus on my first encounter, though my second was just as good!

Guesstimated eight small tables, no more than two to four at each, but groups can push a couple together if lucky enough to get empty ones next to each other. The place has a nice, family-owned, homey feel, and everyone was very friendly.

My picky parents' appetites were satiated, which rarely happens when I pick a place for us to eat. They're not huge fans of Korean food, but perhaps Manna converted them? Their conclusion was that it was okay, but I consider that pretty good, considering that they typically dislike all the restaurants I bring them to. The three of us shared the dol-sot bibimbap, bulgogi, and clear yam noodles. The bulgogi serving was a good amount and we could barely finish it with the other dishes. The meat came in medium bits and had nice flavor, without being too moist or dry, and was such a good lunch deal (almost all LD's are under $10, btw!). Though obviously not barbecued on a grill, the effort and style would've pushed the price up, and it was tasty. The seafood bibambap was equally good, though without much seafood. The crispy bits at the bottom got me though, and there were plenty of the beansprouts, veggies, etc. The yam noodles were alright, yummy but not better than what I've had at other places.
Service was kind and on point, refilling our tea cups several times throughout our meal. I love me some corn tea, so that was a definite plus! Free rice and banchan refills too... what?! Whispered the happy news loudly to my parents and took advantage of it.

The bill came to about $30, which was unheard of for such a satisfying, full meal! So happy to have discovered this place and am already planning on returning ASAP :) My college student budget declares thank you, food deities, for bestowing this gift of a yummy, well-priced Korean restaurant! 

Note: I haven't had a dinner experiences here though, so if I do eat here some night I will update my review on how it went!
author: Tina Y.

description: I've been to Manna many many times.  It's been consistently good.  Best Korean hot tofu soup I've ever had.  The one dish that I don't like is the seafood pancake-- barely any seafood.  This place got really popular over the years and the wait time can easily be 40-60 minutes.  Worth the wait?  Perhaps, considering it's the only good Korean restaurant in the hood.
author: Jessica F.

description: Super small restaurant but everything was great -- we got the dol-sot bibimbap which came out piping hot.  Also go the sweet and spicy chicken wings and kalbi -- both delicious and a good size portion.  Everything was delicious -- plus service was friendly and fast.  Had at wait 5-10 minutes on a Saturday around 2pm.  Even though it was late afternoon on a Saturday, people kept streaming into the restaurant.  Note that parking can be difficult in the area.
author: Imee C.

description: I love this place. I was wishing for a great friendly and inexpensive Korean restaurant to come up some place in the city. Low and behold this new restaurant shows up in my neighborhood. Super nice people and good good food. I go there for lunch and diner some days. Love it.
author: Keith W.

description: This place is alright. Let's start off with the good, the japchae is really flavorful. I think it's one of the best japchae I had.  The chicken wings were pretty good, but I've had better. I also had the kimchi pancake, it was favlorless and was too greasy. The service was not that great. They were a bit rude by commenting that we ordered too much food. They also rushed us out while we were trying to enjoy our meal.
author: Luna C.

description: Manna offers fast and reliably tasty Korean cuisine -- that won't dazzle you -- at reasonable prices.  The menu offers a selection of some of my favorite Korean dishes including chap chae, seafood pancakes, bibimbap, bulgolgi, and galbi.  The banchan is good, too, but with a rather modest variety of small dishes (half a dozen) compared to other places.  Service is friendly and the venue casual and inviting.
author: Chris T.

description: Manna is a great korean place in the inner sunset. The prices beat any other korean place in the city and the food tastes really good too. And comes out pretty quickly. The only downside is that its a pretty small place so lines form and then you just stand outside staring at the people eating inside. They are pretty good about keeping the wait time as short as possible though.
author: Henry W.

description: I may try this place again but I've had better Korean food.  It's good but I felt the flavors could be more complex, the taste seemed heavily focused on a fermented spicy seafood base from one dish to the next.  Granted we only tried about 5 not all.  Service was good.
author: Yumm Y.

description: Been to this place a few times and it's always good ... and packed to the gills. Probably because it's tiny. With no reservations taken, expect to wait a while to get in. Once in, you'll feel a little cramped. Not much space to be had. If you can concentrate on the person you're with and not be distracted by loud eaters, you'll find the food to be quite outstanding. I am particularly fond of the kimchi soup - a real treat on those cold, foggy Inner Sunset evenings. The staff is friendly (I'm guessing it's a family affair and in those tight quarters and would hope everyone gets along!). I would recommend either going early or running in late on the weekend.
author: Pete H.

description:
Manna is AWESOME !  The food is amazing - service is very good.

Prices are cheap compared to some other Korean places.

If you want smaller plates of food which cost more - go elsewhere. 

ps please don't order #5 Spicy Chicken Wings on days I'm going there, so they will have some for me. 

pps I'd seriously have to consider Manna for a last meal and I'm a Chicago Deep Dish Pizza lover - I'm glad I don't live over there w Manna on one side of street and Patxi's on the other ... I'd gain 100 pounds.
author: A D.

description: I've been to numerous Korean restaurants, but if you're in the inner sunset this one takes it hands down. Traditional Korean appetizers to begin with pickle vegetables, sprouts, Kim chee, etc. I got the Dol Sop Bi Bim Bap the first time which was really good. Highly recommended for first timers. My buddy got the korean bbq which was also very good. For those who really like Korean food, their bibim naeng myun is awesome.
author: Cody M.

description: My go to spot for Korean food in the sunset. Portions and price are just right. The food quality is the best Korean in the surrounding neighborhoods. I usually come here on down times, so I can't comment on the wait. It is definitely a smaller dining area, and it can get loud (especially when a couple of rowdy guys get drunk off soju). But the staff is always nice and attentive. Will definitely be back!
author: David T.

description: Small little place so don't come here with a large group, but good, authentic, affordable Korean food run as a family business.  Lots of side dishes to start.  Overall really good.
author: Lusi F.

description: Great Dolsot bimbimbap and the owners are super nice and friendly.
author: Jayme N.

description: Great food and attentive service. Just go early or be ready to wait a while for a table during dinner time. The owner is "Young".
author: D H.

description:
im confused as to y their reviews are so good. i wasnt that impressed with this place.

we got the kalbi and jap chae. 
i prob wont b back. =/

nothing bad in particular stood out. i just wasnt impressed and most definitely wont be going out of way to eat here.
author: Lisa N.

description: I loveeeee Manna. I have the same items on order rotation - seafood pancake, beef bulgogi, bibimbap, and sundubu. Each dish is delicious every time which says something about the consistency and authenticity in their cooking. The side dishes are awesome as well. The staff is super friendly. It's just a great meal overall. The restaurant is small so come early to avoid a long wait as it gets very crowded.
author: Brittany L.

description: Best Korean food I have ever had. The bibimbab is perfect. Also enjoyed the sweet and spicy chicken wings, seafood pancake, yam noodles (great dish), and pork bulgogi. Order your staples and try something new, the menu and quality seems infallible. 1 item per person is plenty for family style dining.
author: Moses A.

description: Incredible Korean food at a very reasonable price. Be prepared to wait, and because this place is in such high demand relative to its size, don't expect to linger.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
i came here today with my dad for lunch, i went hard last night and killed a bottle of jack d by myself so wake up with a fat hangover.

so my dad and i sit down and the whole time hes like "korean restaurants in san francisco suck! i dont understand why ppl eat here everytime i pass by." Then he looks at the menu and hes like "ohhhh thats why...."

its the price, the food here is relatively cheap compared to other korean restaurants in SF, i got Yook Gae Jang (spicy beef broth stew) and that was $10, and it was good, nothing special tho. But other korean places wouldve charged me around $15 for the same dish.

I recommend this place to you if you are craving korean food, but dont wanna spend too much, its alright overall.

3.5 stars
author: Michael K.

description: Waited ~20 minutes on Friday night.  Small restaurant but great food.  Ordered spicy beef soup, seafood bibimbap, kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, chap jae, kalbi & chicken wings.  All very good!  Free banchan & rice tea to complement.  Service was spot on very efficient and friendly. We can see mom cooking in the kitchen. We are BIG fans and will be back soon. Great find.
author: Mario S.

description: super affordable Korean food! Of course, I have to trek all the way out to Inner Sunset, but it doesn't get better than this! Satisfies one's craving for soondubu, would love to come back again
author: Shang S.

description: DELICIOUS kalbi short ribs, kimchi pancake, and jap chae noodles.  The bbq pork and chicken were not tasty.  There was a long wait of almost 1 hour on a Wednesday night - the restaurant is very small.
author: Cherry L.

description: Portions and service was great...left with a full stomach. Bul Gogi was well marinated and the seafood pancake was delicious. Too bad the restaurant was kinda small, but not deal breaker.
author: Dan P.

description: Pretty good korean spot in the sunset. They give you lots of of the ban chan. Galbi, seafood tofu soup,  chicken wings, and chap jae were all tasty! Small place, so you may have to wait on a weekend.
author: Caroline D.
